review_title: Solid company making changes and on the way up
pros:
Great & smart people (if you're on the right team)
Interesting, and surprisingly cutting-edge products (again, if you're on the right team)
Solid base pay
Good benefits
Telecommuting options / good work/life balance
Renovated offices (again, if you're on the right team)
cons:
Sometimes behaves like the "Federal Gov't" of the Tech industry... way too much bureaucracy and red tape / Politics of a large company
Run by lawyers (sometimes)
Fewer perks than most Tech companies (but more than most "regular" companies)
Some offices not renovated
Somewhat old-fashioned and lumbering sales teams (but they are slowly working to address that)
Older, more complacent culture (depending on the team)
No "guaranteed" bonus if you are outside of Sales
Not "data-driven" (depending on the team)

review_title: Consulting sales manager
pros: Product is everywhere, quotas are realistic, benefits are great. Company making profit. New cloud direction has great potentials. Ability to learn great skills and make great connections will enhance your career significantly. Everyday you career worth increases working at oracle. Whether that turns into success at oracle is another story.
cons: Product is matured and competition to sell services with partners is tough. Inter-company divisions compete with you, and the oracle consulting group is in general decline. It's the red headed step child of oracles sales business and it has a terrible reputation internally. To succeed you have to overcome too much adversity that should not even exist. Company is trying to change to a cloud business and is kinda in denial about how a successful that really is. The vibe is negative and management are not leaders. Morale and enthusiasm low.

review_title: What Got You Here, Won't Get You There
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
The colleagues are some of the brightest and friendliest I've known
Most of the teams are populated with competent visionaries who feel stuck
Oracle proper is a great company
Accelerators are in place if quotas are exceeded, so compensation is exceptional
cons:
All Sales teams are led by Product People
No Sales Strategy
Sales professionals with credentials and experience are expected to be relationship order takers.  
"Bro" Culture.  Most women feel as if we walked into a Frat house and never left
Leadership at the top is not respected
No one seems to care about Customer Experience or listening to any voice which did not come from a legacy /DLX employee

review_title: Take the good with the bad
job_title: Senior Inside Sales Representative in Austin, TX
pros: Oracle pays well and there are many people who are good at their jobs and want to help others. Depending on the team the culture can be very fun and make it not seem like the corporate sales job it is. It is also a great company to network within and there are plenty of areas to transition to.
cons: There is a lot of negativity given that it is a corporate environment with a lot of things our of your control. Management tends to not see turnover so at times they are ambivalent. Very often it is a territory or company that helps a rep make their number rather than the individual so it can feel like luck of the draw. Customers are starting to get frustrated with the approach of college kids constantly cold calling them.

review_title: A great company going off the rails
pros:
I've worked 20 years for Oracle and i've seen it moving from a great company with great products sliding to a company which is more occupied with wrenching the last dime out of customers than producing great products and services.
I am however grateful for the many opportunities
- to work international
- work from a home office which resulted an a great Work Life banlance
- to create my own career and move a lot from marketing, to sales, to product management
cons:
-Mark Hurd - he should go tomorrow
-Micromanagement
-Pay rises (NOT)
-Promotions (NOT)

review_title: Senior Solution Engineer -  Senior Sales Consultant
pros:
Employees get to work on the latest technologies and products.
Lot of opportunities to learn new tools. 
Workload is very less. Work life balance can be maintained. 
Lot of internal portals to pick up soft skills, managerial skills, access to information about various Oracle and competitor products. 
You can grow as an individual working here, if you are self-motivated.
cons:
The role being a presales role for North American Customers, there is no face to face interactions with customers. It is more of a back end office for the North American Pre Sales teams. 
On-the-job learning is pretty less. As you will only need to deliver presentations and demos that are mostly pre-built. Less room for creativity.
It is better to work for a presales team catering to India region, rather than working for presales team catering to North America.

review_title: Great place to grow your career
job_title: Senior Sales Executive in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Gym, Fantastic food, Free online courses, Cool atmosphere, and culture
cons:
Career progression or growth is next to impossible even as a top performer getting a promotion and to be paid the industry rates like  LinkedIn, Microsoft or Salesforce you need to wait a lot longer because management can only promote 1 rep a year. This means a small rise in basic salary if you get the promotion. If you are looking for a company that promotes internally for management look elsewhere. 

Not on the Luas line, Bus to the business park is always full in the mornings and sometimes you need to queue for it in the rain. Dart is also an option but the bus is also always packed in the mornings.

review_title: Blurred Vision
pros:
Oracle Brand Name and no clear competitors.
Domain knowledge is there for the takers.
Excellent On-site opportunities and client Interaction very early in Career. 
Place to stick around if BFSI is what you want.
cons:
Very Limited career options available for employees- hardly 2-3 goods ones in India and most employees join client companies midway. if you are ambitious, its a trap job.
Lot of shelf life- be ready to stick around for 5-6 yrs to make a mark on resume else midway, you find what you have learnt cant be translated in other banking firms.
onsite chances are a guise for being a body shop- thats all.
Political and favoritism culture. 
No resource recognition. 
Very Questionable Management Practices. 
As a consulting company, there is no emphasis on problem-solving ability, people skills and individual ambitions.

review_title: A nice place
pros:
Oracle offers a nice work-life balance, many employees are doing 9-5 schedule.
The job security is very strong, i haven't heard  of software developers layoffs in our building over last few  years. However job security does not apply to consultants - they are in a vulnerable area.
Depends on your manager you can telecommute part-time which is a nice perk.
Overall a good company for people who want to keep a secure job and trade off professional challenge and compensation for that, somewhat socialist model. Many folks staying here for 10+ years - somewhat unheard of in a tech company.
A lot of 50+ folks, means it is a good quiet firm to get to retirement age.
cons:
The work itself is not so challenging, you development skill can easily degrade over time.
A lot of politics, i guess it is not exception of other large companies.
No salary increases over multiple years, make sure you negotiate your initial compensation over an industry average.
Bonuses are given once a few years and top 3-4 %.

review_title: Surprisingly good!
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Great people to work with
Strategic focus
Flexibility
Work/Life balance
cons:
Lack of published bonus targets
Very slow to make hiring/job change decisions
Inside out focus

review_title: I'm proud to be at Oracle. Great diversity, very smart people, great leadership.  Love the gym, awesome restaurants.
pros: The office environment is very nice, lots of diversity, free gym with onsite classes 24/7.  Nice kitchen with free beverages.  My function is invested in, we are challenged to be the best we can be. So many training or learning opportunities, nothing is missed, if you want it, you'll find it.
cons: This is anywhere you have unhappy people, but it's a drag to work with people who complain about no increases or not being able to work from home all the time.  Oracle clearly communicates there aren't raises every year and they've been slowly transitioning certain groups back into the office - again giving ample time to adjust or look for work elsewhere if that's what you need to do.  Vacation policy, is a little dated.

review_title: Depends what you want
job_title: Senior Manager, Software Development in Bedford, MA
pros: It was a good quality of life job in terms of flexibility. They do have access to a lot of interesting products, and I really enjoyed the team I had. I got a good "big company" education in terms of processes, global business, etc...
cons: It was sometimes very hard to get things done, so a disproportionate amount of time is spent on process. Part of this is that they have a one-size fits all approach to many processes that work ok for their large teams, but tend to drown small acquired niche teams. There are a fair number of people punching the clock, so even though there were pockets of brilliance, there were also a lot of pretty mediocre people filling the ranks. You really have to be willing to play the long game and weather a lot of ups and downs to succeed at Oracle.

review_title: Solid Software Engineering Company
job_title: Consulting Member of Technical Staff in Redwood Shores, CA
pros:
The main advantage of working in Oracle is that there is an opportunity to practice very interesting computer science in a "normal" environment. By normal I mean that there is no pressure of releasing a new customer-facing product every week. Most of the products have a one or two year development cycle with a couple of minor releases in between.
My colleagues and managers were mostly very friendly and I enjoyed my stay.
cons:
There were a few architects though who tended to act extremely arrogantly. The more important their position the more rude and arrogant their behaviour. It is quite puzzling why they were tolerated.
The company tends to be very stingy about giving basic perks to their employees. Even getting necessary hardware resources can be quite a battle.

review_title: Bureaucratic, Inefficient
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Redwood Shores, CA
pros:
Benefits, facilities, and name recognition are great.
Smart people in some of the LOBs (Finance, Product Development, Consulting)
cons:
No sense of cohesion across the various departments of the company; finance, sales, product development, legal, HR, etc. all of the LOBs are very siloed.
Furthermore, groups within the same line of business (eg. sales) are motivated by only their self-interest, not Oracle's, let alone the customer; this results in a culture of internal competition and a dog-eat-dog environment. 
Career progression is very silo-ed, arbitrary, process-driven, and riddled in protocol.

review_title: Great for landing your next job...
job_title: Account Manager in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Great work/life balance, but probably due to the fact I was in inside sales. You'll enjoy your colleagues/immediate manager, the benefits, and flexibility to get your job done the way you choose without severance threats (as along as you complete the busy work) and the experience to work with some top notch clients.
cons:
Processes are archaic, which forces you to duplicate work and waste gobs of time. It's hard to think of a single sales internal system which updated in an accurate or timely fashion consistently. This is also a problem given the high turnover rate - every year account reps have to recreate the wheel on account intel, even if the previous rep is still at the company. 

The business development team doesn't have a reputation for developing any actionable pipeline, but you should be fine as long as you focus on developing relationships yourself, as an account manager should.

OTE was achievable for about 4 of my 50-person organization, and don't take their promises of pay increases seriously.

review_title: Balance Work/Life if great, but in terms of technology it could be some much better
pros: Work - Life Balance is great. You can work from home whenever you need to. Excellent health insurance, REER matching and university studies compensation.
cons:
Even tough it's a big company and it "owns" Java and several other technologies, they are still stuck with terrible frameworks such as ADF, and IDE JDev, it seems that some departments are strictly close to trying new things. 
Compensation could be better also, don't expect to get a raise if you don't fight for it.   
I believe that this is a project issue, but the planning is shady and it seems that its only in the mind of higher management.
Some teams don't use any software development methodology.

review_title: Just don't
pros: Healthcare, parking, good people - although less and less every day. Good work life balance paid for by terrible salary.
cons:
In pre-sales / sales consulting the management is going out of its way to ensure you are miserable, underpaid and are teaching the off-shore teams how to do your job. This isn't even in the 'digital' business but in the 'field' business too.

There are no annual pay increases to offset inflation. You are unlikely to get a pay rise in the first 5 years with the company. The only way to get a pay rise is to bring an offer from the competitor, at which point you might as well just go.

There is no career progress. Everything told to you during the interview process is a lie.

review_title: Just a number
pros:
A few great managers  - they can shelter you from the beast of oracle BS
Lots of remote positions
Some roles pay overtime - assuming they  don't cut it again (6 months last year)
Lots of travel - great if you love it. 
Great benefits - good value.
cons:
Some terrible managers - not leaders.
Acquisition company.  Not innovative. 
Lots of unnecessary process. 
Challenging stays quo is not appreciated.
Old school hierarchy. 
Reorg every June - loss of productivity 
High turnover - just laid off half my org and over 4000 others. Takes long time to resettle, lose a whole qtr of progress every year. 
Do not understand marketing. 
Products are average - not investment in r&d to build for future. Just buy others who are. Talk a lot about intergration but in reality not possible. 
Lots of video training 
Tons of effort required for interviews/hiring.  Huge investment. 
Very few promotions.

review_title: Oracle Support Services
pros: Good, hard working people working in the lower levels of services.
cons: They keep supporting very old hardware, so customers don't buy new hardware since their old systems are still supported (hurts sales).   But then when there are no more parts to fix the customer's very old systems, the customer is dissatisfied and won't buy new Oracle hardware because of the service let down.

review_title: Associate Sales Consultant II
job_title: Associate Technology Consultant II in Burlington, MA
pros: Work-life balance, generous pay, good benefits, friendly environment, solid upward mobility opportunities, training opportunities (though still room for improvement here), depending on your management the option to change locations within the company was there
cons:
Only 13 days PTO (then starting 2015 they decided to close the company for the last week every year and require employees to use 4 days of their own PTO), not much opportunity for lateral movement in the company - ex. in the Sales Org the jobs available are Sales Reps, Managers and Consultants - if you don't want one of these positions, there's not much else available for you

Often a disparity between sales and tech teams, work flow approvals and changes extremely slow, often unrealistic goals were set for sales teams which resulted in reps piping false opportunities or over-embellishing

review_title: Associate Sales Consultant II
job_title: Associate Technology Consultant II in Burlington, MA
pros: Work-life balance, generous pay, good benefits, friendly environment, solid upward mobility opportunities, training opportunities (though still room for improvement here), depending on your management the option to change locations within the company was there
cons:
Only 13 days PTO (then starting 2015 they decided to close the company for the last week every year and require employees to use 4 days of their own PTO), not much opportunity for lateral movement in the company - ex. in the Sales Org the jobs available are Sales Reps, Managers and Consultants - if you don't want one of these positions, there's not much else available for you

Often a disparity between sales and tech teams, work flow approvals and changes extremely slow, often unrealistic goals were set for sales teams which resulted in reps piping false opportunities or over-embellishing

review_title: No Hikes, Huge Layoffs, Very slow career growth
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros: Company culture is inspired from sloth's so you will get lot of free time for your self
cons:
-No learning
-Zero Hike for first two year and after that it will be in single digit particularity less than 5 %
-Promotions based on year of service not based on performance. Single promotion will take min 5 to 7 years on avg 
-Huge Huge Layoffs. When I was in company from my team itself 50 % people got laid off in single day. One guy who joined just 11 months back and he was star performer got laid off may be because he came with good background and may be his salary was high as compared to others
-HR's are not supportive. Actually They are most egoistic and rude people I ever met

review_title: Love it or leave it, it is what it is.
pros: Oracle consistently pushes to keep consultants trained in the latest technology, and provides opportunities to exercise those technologies.  Oracle allows consultants to take risks in order to succeed (or fail) based primarily on the individual's own performance.  Oracle has no problem booting poor performers out the door.  It keeps one pushing to stay on the edge.  Benefits and salaries are better than average for the region.  A good long-term assignment can make Oracle employment very rewarding.
cons: It's not warm and fuzzy, it's competitive.  It runs through cycles of collecting too many management layers looking for something to do (but cleans house by reorganizing annually to help shake them out).  There is pressure to travel frequently and there are limited alternatives to excessive travel.  It is often a place to learn Oracle technologies well, pay your dues, and depending on available assignments, just move on.

review_title: Aggressive, political, micro management, no work/life balance
pros: Typically other sales people are decent to work with. Clients are nice.
cons: Harder to work internally then externally. Red tape, clients complain oracle is hard to work with, management has no investment in people, accounts are assigned and it is really luck of the draw if you hit your number. Management has no guidance or any want for their employees to succeed. Work hours are set 8-530pm don't even think about leaving before or coming in any later - it is not tolerated. There are no women on the floor - I can't imagine a mother even working for this org. Some teams are really good to work for and some are beyond awful - do your homework. No such thing as raises or negotiated pay bumps for promotions. They expect you to do more work for no pay because you "want to be a leader" which is all nonsense. Morale is awful.

review_title: No personal growth in company
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros: Only good as a retirement company. Technical work is ok - not great, not bad but not all teams get good work. In certain teams work life balance is good but not everywhere. Biggest plus - Work From Home option.
cons:
Several Cons - 
Biggest minus point - no hikes year after year when it happens its like peanuts. So one will remain stagnant at same salary. They will hire resources from outside with good salaries but will not give any hike for years to people inside no matter how hard you work.

NO promotions - higher management acts like they have done some favor to you by giving promotion after years even though you don't get any monetary benefit out of it.

Higher management does not care about developers.

review_title: Not perfect, but great
pros: Personable, supportive managers are working here.  They've all done the work you're doing so are familiar with how things are for you getting your job done.  Plenty of good coaching and training is encouraged.  Good work-life balance and accommodations are made for health or family emergency situations.  Benefits cannot be beat.  The company sends out surveys to employees at least once, maybe twice a year to assess employee satisfaction and what areas need to be addressed.  Positive changes have been seen from these surveys.
cons: Little to nothing in the way of pay increases.  After ten years they are eliminating the work from home option for the support organization - money that could have been spent on payroll is instead going into facilities that strictly speaking aren't needed considering the work that's done and all the options for communicating with coworkers, who are often scattered across the hemisphere if not the world.  One star removed from overall rating because of this issue.

review_title: Lovely but also challenging
pros: Flexibility, constant knowledge, great development opportunity, sharing best practices, really great colleagues and manager. Great paycheck; A lot of work doing exactly what you're supposed to but also projects (they encourage you to have initiative and all ideas get a lot of support); Great succesoral program (for top talents as well as new talents); Passing forward the knowledge; Great buddy system
cons: Hard to get to the top; spend a lot of time on the lower hierarchical part; Paycheck doesn't increase (almost never and if it does it is with great efforts); working a lot of after hours (overtime due to closing fiscal quarters)

review_title: An embarassingly unethical company to work for
pros:
I was able to stay in Seattle, and then in Portland, Oregon. 
This was important to me because my wife left me due to my infidelity-  was the one cheating- so I wanted to stay close to my children 
Pay was about 40% lower than what I made in my next job
cons:
Constant pressure to shade things in a way that is not Professional 
Overselling to the customer of services and features they did not need- and do not need to still this Bad planning which was very destructive to personal work life balance

review_title: inside sales national team
pros: great atmosphere, young ambitious pool of colleagues, great culture and benefits
cons:
comission structure pits inside reps against matched field counterparts, as well as other internal salespeople who can sell the same products, to your same accounts, from within a different sales silo within Oracle. Big joke around the office is our biggest competitor is the person three cubes down from you.
Hours are long, 8:30-5:30, most people stay later and get there earlier. One hour for lunch. 
Oracle is so big if you need something and thepeople sitting around you don't know the answer, it could take a LONG time to find the answer. A teammate statred and her phone didn't work. It took three weeks for her to get a working phone in her cube, even though she worked constantly trying to figure out how to get the right contact in buildings/facilities/telecom/networking, etc.

review_title: Soulless borg representing all that's wrong with America
job_title: Sales Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros: Paychecks were deposited on time
cons:
Nobody cares, hodge podge of crappy products thrown together and sold to customers that aren't in need of them as they don't really solve their problems or do so in the rubest goldberg type fashion to the point of being laughable. (see ExaLogic, et al)

A microcosm of what unbridled capitalism turns into. Everyone here is apathetic and the serfs merely do their bidding and nobody knows why anything is done, while the folks at director level and above are nothing more than talking heads spewing out buzzwords that mean nothing to them because they're so disconnected from anything even approaching a real product it's sad. Most of these people have never actually built anything themselves and have been nothing but corporate leeches and sycophants their whole careers so it's no wonder the place is as big of a train wreck as its product lines.

review_title: Always wondered what it is like to work for a megacorp
pros: The health benefits are very good
cons: Pay is nowhere near the industry average, recurring furloughs at Christmas, a "write nothing down" culture of secrecy and nondisclosure, paltry salary adjustments with no ties to performance evals when salaries aren't frozen, recurring waves of layoffs, a hugely management-heavy organization that often has managers with only 2 reports, directors with one reporting manager, ranks when they are thinned never touch management but management's salary overhead cripples product line and division performance, can never backfill positions vacated by people quitting, company pursuing a strong and accelerating off-shoring employment model, problem managers are never accounted or dealt with, corporate acquisitions are a driver of corporate sales by which the acquired company must rebase all internal and product line systems to be "solid red" meaning All-Oracle even in areas Oracle is not competitive and all these oracle equipment and licenses must be purchased at industry rates, the most unequal and secretive profit and reward sharing company I have worked with in my 20 years in the industry.  I could go on but I've said enough.  If this all sounds good to you, hey get signed on today.

review_title: QA Engineer
pros: Pretty good benefits package. Relatively stable environment. Management is usually flexible and accommodating if employees need to work from home or modify their schedules due to family considerations.
cons: No value placed on employees. Layoff season every year between August and October. Decisions are based on product performance rather than employee contributions. If you have accepted an assignment with the wrong product, and the product they asked you to work on doesn't do well in the marketplace, they will get rid of the people they asked to work on that product rather than give them an opportunity to work somewhere else in the company. This happens on an annual basis.

review_title: Very limited growth in skills and salary
pros: Many paid leave and sick leave days. And chances to work from home for most of working days(but also depends on your department and manager).
cons:
-Low pay including 12 months base and little bonus/stock option, yet not guaranteed. Quite low wage increase, yes, not guaranteed again.
-Totally no target/goal setting and evaluation. Not everyone likes the KPI culture in internet industry but here things are exactly the opposite. 
-No promotion, at least in my small team. 
-Almost no training from company, only group sharing organized by engineers. You need to care about your own career.
-Job security depends on your department.

-For my group only: tough big boss. Boss Oriented Programming.

-Another annoying fact: there are more than 1 legal entities in Shanghai, 1 for sales and 1 for engineers and sales earn much more than engineers. Furthermore, IT/HR or someone else in charge even never bothered creating 2 separate email groups for each. So as engineers you will always receive benefit emails saying "Please ignore if you are engineer colleagues".

review_title: It's a big corporation
pros: Health insurance options are good as are other benefits.   When Oracle acquired my company, they honored the un-vested options that employees held.  That was nice as they could have decided not to and the employees would have had nothing to look forward to.
cons:
The corporate culture transition to Oracle systems was not easy.  Many choices were  "efficiency at the expense of effectiveness."  All legacy systems were shut down  in deference to  Oracle-approved servers, forums, etc.  A lot of old support and engineering defect and resolution data was lost to the field engineers; we were told "migration can't happen."  "What?  Didn't you guys cut your teeth on databases?  You've never moved data before? ..."     
Over time, Communication between former company members dwindled to nil across our business group as Oracle had silo-ed pre-sales support and post-sales professional services and TAC.   No one knew what anyone else was doing and sharing information was difficult.

review_title: A great career start, but very hard to explore other lines of business thereafter
job_title: Sales Development Representative in Austin, TX
pros:
-Good work life balance.
-Coworkers are very intelligent, often younger. Keeps the culture and feel of the office fun.
-Getting to be in the tech industry and see the frequent changes with such a large corporation is an incredible learning experience.
-Very intelligent sales people that you can learn multiple career/life skills from
-New office is incredible.
cons:
-No salary increases
-Extremely difficult to enter new lines of business
-Constant changes to comp plan
-Such a large company that other employees can contact your customers and tarnish your potential sales.
-Some situations are out of your control with the red tape and different management styles.

review_title: Great work environment, but no annual salary reviews
job_title: Software QA Test Engineer in Barcelona
pros: Talking  about the Oracle NetSuite Barcelona office, depending on the team, but in general, the colleagues are great people to work with and you feel great at work. You have different interesting perks like fruit, drinks, snacks and lunches depending on the event, health/life insurance, ticket restaurant etc.
cons: They promise you annual salary reviews, but these don't actually happen, so you better negotiate a good salary from the beginning because you'll be stuck with it. If any raises happen, they are pretty embarrassing.

review_title: Good Company to work for, BUT underneath the SHINY exterior, is a rotten one
job_title: Database Administrator in Redwood City, CA
pros: Good benefits, the ability to work from home at any time. The company is a major global workforce, and a majority of teams consist of members that live in different states in the US.  The cafeteria serves decent food, drinks are free and the health gym is excellent for blowing off steam
cons: Low Pay, if you get hired initially, negotiate a higher starting salary...a majority of people NEVER get pay raises for 2 or even 3 years, which is shameful for a company this size. They do have the money, and they do have the process, so I am not sure why they keep insisting on keeping their employees down.  Career opportunities are mediocre, you are able to move internally to any group, but promotions are hard to come by.

review_title: Great Company to work for...not!!!
job_title: Account Executive in Redwood City, CA
pros: This company will be around during the bad times. Their technology is in use at so many places a nuculear holocaust could hit and Oracle would still be around collecting their maintenance fees. Its also a resume builder to have Oracle on your job history.
cons: The pressure is constant and starts right away. Everyone is nasty to you and backstabs you constantly. The compensation for inside sales is a joke for the revenue you're bringing in. Like to share a hotel room with your co-workers on your 2 trips a year? Oracle is the place for you. Even the coffee is bad. Its the most political company i've ever worked. And the technology is terrible, its so old and outdated. They don't know where to take it. I couldn't wait to leave, and I actually did pretty well. I could have never seen staying there longer than the time I did.

review_title: good compensation and benefits but sad place to work
pros: like the flexibility/ work from home or office choice, campus in redwood shores is nice, specifically gym and good food in the cafeterias. that's about it
cons: the work environment doesn't promote initiative and creativity, too much process and bureaucracy, internal tools are slow, buggy and UI is terrible for most of them, but most people have  to use them a lot on daily basis - huge impact on overall productivity and even morale. No ability for employees to assess their management, overall management level is poor comparing to the other companies I've worked for. Fear or commanding management style is common. Most people on campus look sad or depressed, no positive vibe. Got here via acquisition and hope to get out asap, have few friends working here - everyone hates it and looking for an outside opportunity.

review_title: The Big BOOOOOOracle
pros:
Brand recognition ---good to say "I worked there"
Nice cafeteria's at HQ
cons: Too large --- too many people not contributing to their fullest potential. I came from a previous work environment where productivity was encouraged and rewarded (handsomely).  At Oracle it didn't matter if I tried or not --- no one noticed and if they did, there was no reward.   Innovation not encouraged ---- I had one Sr. Director tell me that my idea, thought it was correct and had merit, would be too hard to implement in a company like Oracle.   I proved him wrong by rolling up my sleeves and getting my hands dirty.  The result impacted every geography and was unprecedented for its time.  But I was one voice in a huge wind tunnel and in the end, I was bored out of my mind.

review_title: Do not think, just do as you are told
job_title: Product Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- As a very profitable company, there's no worry about whether the company will go out of business. 
- Work from home flexibility is allowed for most groups
- Lots of opportunities for business travel to all parts of the world
cons:
- Oracle is a company that makes its profits through lean operations (read: maximizing margins). That means, you as an employee get squeezed too
- Very little work/life balance
- You're not thought to think - you're merely supposed to do. 
- As a result of bureaucratic processes, you become more of a process manager instead of a product manager. Those of us from Sun that made it into Oracle, soon found that out the hard way

review_title: Challenging work that makes a difference: a great place to be an engineer
job_title: Consulting Member of Technical Staff in Burlington, MA
pros:
-Smart colleagues
-Challenging work
-Financial stability = job security
-Be #1 in your marketplace (Oracle plays to win, and it's great to see your products succeed).
- Very supportive of working at home and distributed teams

Oracle does things in a very rational way: it tries to help its customers. If you keep that in mind then you have a lot of freedom to innovate, and amazing resources to help you.

Oracle also does some of the most important, mission-critical business software on the planet. Your contributions will really make a difference.
cons:
- Some old-fashioned software development ideas
- Home-brewed dev tools are behind the curve

The official dev model is very waterfall-oriented. That being said, most product groups work at sneaking in better models.

Some of the tools needed by developers are internally developed, rather old, and can be quite frustrating to deal with.

review_title: Great, Good, Bad, Awful. Don't stay too long at Oracle or it will crush your mind, your soul, your spirits!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood City, CA
pros: A good company to learn Oracle-only technologies. But the longer you stay there the worst it will be...
cons:
- Promotions are based on "performance reviews" that mean nothing to your manager if you don't have a good relationship with him/her. You can have a 5 for several reviews and still go nowhere career wise.
- There are 7-9 levels of management above your position, which translates to a nightmare when anyone tries to do anything innovative or even beneficial to the company. It takes months to get anything approved, implemented, and tested, from IT to dev.

review_title: After working at Oracle for three years....
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood Shores, CA
pros:
Very flexible working in the company (work from home or office).
Work-life balance somewhat depends on the software cycles as expected.
Above average health plan, and about average 401k.

This is a great company for someone who wants to have a relaxed life, BUT (see bottom of Cons section for the rest).
cons:
Talent is not abundant here. 
Due to the above, career advancements pace is rather slow. 

(continuation of last sentence).... BUT I do not recommend it for any top school ambitious college graduate. If you have a mortgage, kids, and want a laid back job then this place is for you. Just keep in mind:
- career growth: almost non existent.
-compensation: almost non existent.
- Rewards for excellence: almost non existent.

review_title: Mixed Bag
pros: Oracle can be a fun, dynamic and very interesting place to work, with challenging assignments that foster growth and a real sense of accomplishment.  They also have gold plated benefits, which can easily become golden handcuffs
cons:
This can be a very depersonalizing place to work, with almost everything done under the umbrella of "self-service."  Oracle also gives off the impression that they really do not care about you beyond your ability to produce revenue, with even very short periods of bench time (2 weeks, or even less, depending on your boss) being questioned.  It is also the place where I heard a senior VP say, "You people need to get over the whole customer thing.  Customers are not the most important thing if it doesn't translate to revenue."

Also, when you apply, go for the best salary and benefit package you can negotiate, since you won't be getting either bonuses or raises, no matter how well the company does.

review_title: Great Benefits and People, use of latest Oracle tech, raises are difficult
job_title: Senior Database Administrator in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros: Benefits are good, free coffee, fruit, juice, vacation days, and discounts on several restaurants. You can take some of the Oracle courses for free (no charge to your org/division), and if you want to take any paid course usually management approve it. Flexibility to work from home when required. Also, at least for my department, we used to install/upgrade latest RDBMS versions which is very challenging and learn the new things faster
cons: Salary hikes are very difficult, you can spend 3-4 years with no hikes, so better to join the company with a very good salary if you want to be for a long time there. And if you get one it usually won’t be a substantial one. Heard of cases that is better to leave the company and a year later be rehired to get a better salary.

review_title: culture in Oracle India
pros: Good  brand  recoginition in market .  people  respect the  brand  value  and  customer  treats  you  with  respect.  only  Database  division is  working  good,  rest  all  are struggling.
cons: no salary  increase  in  last  2  years.  top  management making  lot  of money  but  bottom management  has  to slog .  there is internal  rivalry  between  various  Line of business.  Worst  HR. they  do  nothing  except  hire and  fire  on  command  from  top.

review_title: Excellent Work/Life, Great Benefits, Small Raise, Low Salary
pros: Work - Life Balance is great.  Working from home, not needing to sit in traffic.  Excellent health insurance, REER matching, vacation days increase after 7 years.  Oracle University training is great to learn new tools and go for onsite training/certification.
cons: Oracle has a salary range that they follow, but most salaries will be lower than the average.  Don't expect any raises as it is a rare occasion.  However company will continue to take away certain benefits like parking or internet fees.

review_title: Oracle Consulting - Can Be A Very Good Place To Work
pros: When the right leadership was in place, it was a terrific place to work!  Everyone knew what our sales & delivery goals were and all the senior managers pulled together and achieved success (solid book of business, good bonus payout, happy consultants).   Unfortunately, towards the end of my tenure there, the leadership changed and it changed, in my opinion, to a much less professional and well-run organization.  Even today, I hear mixed reviews on the consulting leadership team.
cons: Driven greatly by quarterly business cycles....the "close week" in each quarter can be a pain but it's also a part of Oracle's success.

review_title: Oracle is in constant reorganization. No clear direction or strategy. I do not recommend at all working for Oracle!!
pros: Oracle can provide some very good salary and compensation packages
cons:
Oracle is in constant reorganisation with no clear direction or strategy. Everyone is only defending their own territory and mix and match numbers with no real value to only making them look good.

Targets are not achievable at all. Astronomically high targets. A lot of Customers have made very bad experiences with the company in the past. Oracle has no interest to really do anything to improve customer satisfaction. Pressure from upper management will be only given further to its employees. 

The whole management has absolutely no idea what they are doing. I do not know how they got their jobs but there is something really wrong here how they hire managers.

Don't be fooled by the brand Oracle and the salary and compensation they might offer you. It was maybe a good company 20 years ago but definitely due to all this bad management and old company structures with no inspiring leaders nor innovative products has made this place not enjoyable to work for.

review_title: Oracle ain't horrible but it ain't great either
job_title: Product Marketing Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Oracle is a great company when it comes to being slow paced and not throwing a bunch of new hurdles at you. Some may find this comfort enjoyable but since there is new tech coming out daily and more millennial get bored easily, someone like me, a 25 year old, does not find oracle very much fun
cons: It's boring. You don't do much work, things are slow paced. The company is behind because of legal/security concerns, which I doubt. I just think people don't like to improve on things. The atmosphere is all party and no work. People make a lot of money to do absolutely nothing. OKRs are barely tracked, there's barely an employee review process, people don't really get raises till they get an offer elsewhere. I'm actually leaving soon.

review_title: Not a good place to work.
job_title: Software Development Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Oracle is a big company, if you have a god father to take care of you, your promotion and benefits will be reasonable.
cons: Oracle has some of the worst managers who can do anything they want. HR is mute,they never do anything for the employees unless there is chance of geting sued. A snr.Managers salary and benefits is equivalant to a  Application engineers salary in the industry. Bunus can be 3-5%, stock options at snr level can patheticaly low or nill. Oracle is not interested in taking care of their employees especialy in US. Not a single employee in Application is division is happy, that is why the code quality is poor. Turn over rate in Oracle's india development center is one of the highest in the industry..close to 20%

review_title: Oracle has matured as a company, yet still have some old-timers who are cranky.
pros:
Great benefits, time off, generous maternity leave, and flexible hours.
Stock options for some.
New management are a big improvement.
Nice lake and cafeteria.  
Larry is a charismatic leader!
Some of the most talented people in tech work at Oracle.
cons:
There are still a few people from the old days who are bitter and are very negative and stubborn  to new changes.  Spend most of their time playing office politics and causing havoc.

IT is not that great. Sorry. New people bought out by Oracle complain of not having anything to do.

review_title: Well balanced work family life
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros: The upper management has good vision and doesn't hesitate to adopt to the market trend. Work environment has good family. If you are willing your way up, there are plenty of places for you to grow.  Don't expect to do your job and get rewarded automatically. Make your work noticed by the management. I have cordial  relationship with my management and well respected by others in the team.
cons: Engineering process is not well adopted to agile principles. Still too tight with too many processes. Need to adopt flexible latest trends. It is ridiculous that you have to send it all the way up the food chain to purchases small and that too take  incredibly  long time.

review_title: it's OK, if your face fits
pros:
Products are mostly pretty good
Plenty of chance to work with new stuff
Brand has kudos
Variety of challenge
If you find your niche & your contribution is valued, it can be rewarding & satisfying
cons:
Short-term management focus on this quarter's numbers
Consulting division is not led well
Pay is not that great
Internal processes are over-complex & best ignored
Half-hearted approach to employee appraisal & development
Managers at all levels have their little favourites who can do no wrong - very political organisation
Some customers, and most SIs, hate us but can't escape
It's really no fun at all if you're locked into a long-term project with a disgruntled customer and a semi-competent manager who's struggling to deliver. But that would be true in most places, I guess.

review_title: Sales Director
job_title: Sales Director in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Large account opportunities and resources of a large company.  Good reputation with clients and the Technology Division.
cons: Very political in management hierarchy--self-interest only and had no interest in helping new employees or mentoring employees.   Blamed subordinates for management decisions so they were not held to account. To save face with a potential client who was unhappy with a lack of RFP response, blamed employee that was not at fault.  Management had decided not to provide resources to respond to the RFP and did not want to admit it to the potential client.  This type of behavior was highly unethical.  Managers were sexist and favored male counter--parts that were not better sales people with choice accounts.  Purposely sabotaged review process on 360 degree review...forced employee to change review of a technical counterpart because the manager had decided they didn't like this person.  Very political culture that cross divisions.  There was a great deal of animosity across divisions which was very counterproductive when strategizing on major opportunities that could use the products and services of many divisions of Oracle.

review_title: Would you like to be treated like an untouchable in India? Work for Oracle!
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Redwood City, CA
pros:
-Being able to come and go without anybody noticing or caring
-Putting in as little work as possible and still getting by
-Learning to work in an environment with no direction or purpose
-Job security: no matter how unproductive you are, you will not get fired
cons:
-Negative personal growth--being in the office stimulates cynicism 
-Insulting bonus structure
-Stock purchase plan has the inter-workings of a modern-day Ponzi scheme
-Office culture similar to that of Rwanda circa 1994

review_title: Manager
pros:
- great health benefits
- access to Oracle training
- stable
- continuous growth;  Oracle keeps buying companies and expanding its products and services
cons: For a company this big, they are very stingy when it comes to salary increases or bonuses.  I guess it depends on the business unit.  They reward top performers with bonuses or stock options but leave everyone else behind.  I have teammates who have not had an increase for 5 years now!  They are not the top 5% but they are good, solid employees who work hard and consistently produce and they are not flight risks.   It seems Oracle punishes them for being loyal.

review_title: Yet to make it to the 21st century
job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: A lot of very nice and competent people. Great for an early  career experience. Looks good on the CV with people that don't know the company. Great support from HR&admin. Great if you like to hide.
cons:
Internal competition. Sales have to prove their good faith before hoping to see the usual resistance to provide any support down. 

Very localized, travel restrictions may not meet your customer international profiles.

Many very old style managers that still think cold calling is the way to sell Enterprise solutions. Most managers transfer their pressure down without much creativity and often at the expense of their field team and their existing customers.

Some products are far from the competition. Most acquired solutions stop evolving with the market needs (for example from web to mobility). 

Field teams get overhauled on a yearly basis, plans&targets take time to be communicated, leaving your chance to reach your target to luck.

PreSales teams not always update on latest tech in their domain.

News from 2016 tell me that this hasn't changed. Hence the massive turn over

review_title: Associate Consultant
pros:
- It is a very flexible environment nowadays because of Cloud Softwares
- Normally your team are high-end professional in the field
- A very good work environment
- International Teams in most of your projects
- You learn about different Industries
cons:
- Some of the projects could be very time demanding bad Work-Life Balance
- There are a few benefits for the Consulting Team due to they are not normally in the building
- There is a very huge difference between salaries in Consulting vs Pre-Sales
- It could take more than 8 months to be officially promoted and receive your new salary
- Salaries are quite low compared with the competitors

review_title: Good for experience but very poor management
pros: Good benefits, very nice team colleagues, options for career progression, but they are only options...
cons: Even though you have options for career progression, unfortunately your management won't support you much. You have to drive everything on your own which can be tiring. For people who are motivated to get experience based on real customer exposure this isn't the right place to be. You won't be inspired by the company culture and management leadership. Also the company claims to be divers in their workforce, I can't see that at all and usually all the promotions go ti the Irish. So don't expect fairness or being treated the same way if you aren't having the right accent or appearance.

review_title: Good solutions; poor marketing.
pros: We're acquiring some of the best-in-breed software and are serious about tying them together to form best-in-class industry solutions.  It's the Cisco model applied to software, and thanks to SOA, it's working.  For people who have been acquired, the pace can seem slower, but if you can correctly leverage the huge sales force and pipeline, there is a huge customer base that you can sell to.
cons: Larry's hatred of Microsoft means we have to avoid their stuff wherever possible.  We don't use Exchange servers, and our email system is clumsy and painful.  We seem to rewrite even basic applications for internal use - why are we using "Oracle Chat" when there are at least ten good alternatives already out there?  Comp is on the low side, but they do give out options.

review_title: Decent benefits, no future.
pros:
- health benefits
- 401k matching, 50% of first 6% deferred (3% equivalent)
- "Oracle" is a nice word to have on your resume
cons:
- no raises
- no path for advancement
- very little recognition
- can't stress this enough, no raises
- CEO is 4th wealthiest man in the known universe, yet.... no raises.
- hourly paid employees have had hours cut back, and are not eligible for bonuses
- meanwhile upper management continues to receive bonuses, take credit for work of hourly paid employees

review_title: Not too bad
pros:
Ability to grow your skills in your acumen or others that are of interest to you 
Managers (at least mine) do not micro-manage and leave you to complete your duties in a time and manner that is beneficial to you, the team, Oracle and the clients
Oracle provides the ability to work at home in some positions which can be very beneficial
I've seen some people say better benefits, but compared to other companies I have worked for I feel the benefits are great... my dentist and my eye doctor have both told me the benefits are great as well.
cons:
There is the possibility that you will get pigeon-holed into the same position which can be frustrating if you are looking for a change.

Hiring seems to be going more away from the US and I don't like this.   I have lost a couple of opportunities for a position I really wanted because the manager could not hire within the US

review_title: Great Employee but don't expect a clear career path!
job_title: Solution Director, Engineered Systems in Solihull, England
pros:
- Great learning opportunities.
- Full range of Oracle technology (Applications to Disk) to get your teeth stuck into
- Good work/life balance.
- A wealth of internal resources with a heavy emphasis on knowledge sharing and networking
- Great Flexible Benefits systems for all employees
- Office location all over the UK, but in reality it Reading and the City office (Moorgate) that you need to be at.
cons:
- Promotions and salary increments are a very slow in coming.  (its been 7 years and I not had a single increase in wages).
- Oracle Struggles when its comes to career progression.  You got to make it happen yourself, don't expect Oracle to guide you.
- To many account manager trying to sell a solution to a single customer (Oracle Bus syndrome)
- Typical Sales organisation so some people are only out to help themselves.

review_title: The role was not what the recruiter described
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros: The induction training is fantastic and the benefits are decent
cons:
Where to start?! The Inside sales position is basically an admin role whereby you execute the processes required in the sales cycle for the field rep you are aligned to, who does the actual "selling".
The amount of red tape and processes to go through are extremely time consuming to say the least.
Management are promoted based on results, as opposed to relevant skills meaning those lucky enough to get a lucrative territory will prosper, even if they don't have the required skills. In my experience the result of this is some of the worst management I have ever experienced.

review_title: Customer Success
pros:
Benefits and salary are good. 
Being a large organization there are opportunities to move into other areas.
It's kind of like going to a big college; make what you want out of it.
cons: The size of the organization makes it difficult to get things done quickly. There is a lot of process in place and managing the process can be tireless. The processes do not have the customer and employee in mind. Getting a clear compensation plan for the year (and in a timely manner) is difficult. Which then makes it difficult to calculate and pay-out. Lots of time and energy in reviewing the calculations, showing what you were paid, and justifying the gap. For example, it took me a year and half to receive my bonus.

review_title: Challenging place to work in support.
pros: Training, hardware/software, flexible benefits.  Work/Life balance and Remote working where possible.
cons: Progression, salary increases, longevity in support.  Oracle has a habit of acquiring firms for gaps in their technology stack, and then absorbing the support teams and products from those acquisitions.  From experience, key product from acquisitions become main line products at Oracle.  Engineers with skills and experience in those main products have reasonable scope for growth and progression.  However, legacy products and teams are wound down until products become end of life and are no longer strategic.  This can make it challenging for an engineer brought into Oracle via an acquisition to move into other technical areas whilst  maintaining responsibility for the legacy product support.  Whilst training on main products and certifications are on offer, Oracle is now focusing on Cloud solutions and this changes the scope of roles available for existing support staff to transistion to.

review_title: Old school and starting to feel it's age.
job_title: Senior Principal Systems Administrator in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Fantastic health care and good 401k matching.   My boss allowed me the flexibility to push my goals and career development.
cons: Bad vacation policies.  Only 13 days of vacation in your first 3 years regardless of your seniority.   Oracle is really feeling it's age and is very behind the times as far as management and culture is.   Everything is extremely silo'd and as such there is a tremendous about of "non-work" being done and not a lot of actually progress.   This can be very frustrating at times for a creative developer.

review_title: Turning a 40 year old ship
pros:
Oracle has it all for solutions: DB, ExxaData, virtualization, apps, their own data centers. 
Recently moved to no restriction on PTO
Good benefits
cons:
Still have an on prem mindset in some groups. Hard to get folks to engage in the way true SaaS is delivered.  Also, embrace Agile methodology across the board. A springt of 6 months is not a sprint.
I believe they need to re-platform to bake everything together vs ICS for everything.  

Oracle has so much potential but they really must re-invent themselves from the ground up not just pay lip service.
Oracle is notoriously cheap so you must negotiate the best you can on the way in since you may not see a raise for a looooooong time.
Promotions are few and far between.

review_title: Not the Oracle it once was
pros: Great benefits; lots of opportunities; expansive product portfolio
cons: No appreciation for experience.  Executive management feels that recent grads with no experience can replace experienced talent.  I have no issues hiring younger employees...but it is hard to replace experienced solution engineers with recent grads when the experienced SEs go to competitors.  Sales territories are small and many reps aren't capable of selling.  Again, experienced sales reps have gone to the competition.  More of the sales job has been passed to the Solution Engineering team, which is also much less-experienced than in the past.  The application teams have also become too siloed, losing much of the benefit of a large product offering.  SE bonuses are very small compared to industry competitors and historical bonuses at Oracle.  It is all about increasing margins at Oracle, not increasing market share.

review_title: Not bad, Not great
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros:
The work is interesting.
Work life balance is good.
Technically competent colleagues. 
Beautiful lake on campus for daily walks.
cons:
Vacation policy is lousy.
Stagnation seems to be the norm rather than the exception. Oracle starts out with a competitive market salary but salaries stagnate very quickly and you will be well behind market pay after a couple of years.
Centralized organization with line managers having little to no powers and decisions made at the very top by people who don't know you.
Sponsorship of green cards was halted for a very long time. Immigration facilities in general could be improved.

review_title: No real career path available.
pros: Large company, well known software as well as hardware (Sun Microsystems acquisition). Vast array of technologies to play with.
cons: No real opportunity for advancement. Pay is below standard.  I interviewed for many open internal positions and got accepted only to be told that I could not get a pay raise or pay grade change. Example: Applied for Sys admin 4 position, aced the interview and was the number 1 pick out of the other interviewees; Was offered the position at a much lower pay grade. They would rather bring in someone from the outside and pay them more than promote someone from within. It's business that makes no sense.

review_title: Interesting....
job_title: Senior Principal Consultant in Reston, VA
pros: The experience of working for a world renowned corporation.
cons:
Unfortunately, I worked on a team that most of the team members (team leads and managerial level) came from the same former company and most of these folks lived in the same city. It was like the good ole' boy or 'inner circle' or 'in crowd' system. If you did not come from their former company, then you were never considered to be worthy and your input was disregarded. Also, some of the managers did not have the proper managerial skills to manager this particular project or the customer relations. As one of the managers told the customer...." I have bigger fish to fry". This was totally inappropriate to say to a customer!

I don't think this is indicative of the 'overall' Oracle experience. I think if I had worked in another BU of Oracle, I would have had a more rewarding experience.

review_title: Oracle is a Good Company -- they can do better marketing
job_title: Senior Principal Product Manager in Denver, CO
pros:
Good Salary, Great benefits, great people and opportunities. While people speak about leading corporate innovators. This is one of the truly great companies where you have the ability to working on technologies that matter. From:
-internet of thing
-to java
-cloud
-hardware engineering
-every other ERP,CRM, or other software application in between 
There is not another company on the planet that provides All of those opportunities.
cons: As with a lot of large companies work life balance, and feeling the startup culture are missing. Another thing that is missing is a culture of promoting good feelings (not in the sense of 'hippy happy feelings') but in the sense that the company cares that they are a very good world citizen. Individually, people are that way but as a corporation there is not a collective sense of caring

review_title: Great sales job for hard workers
pros: High salary, with an even higher commission potential upon successful sales. My life personally have a fun work environment, with plenty of time to prospect.  I hope to see more of the same as I continue to grow with the company.
cons:
There is a very slow startup time when your first hired, and although management sets the expectation that it takes a while to settle in, it seems like something that shouldn't be hard to address. 

Finding access to proper sales training and technical training is not easy.   Experienced sales reps will likely have to go through a training similar to what they've done with other companies already.

review_title: Sales - Regional Vice President for 8-years
pros: Compensation, sales process, brand awareness, career options
cons:
Mark Hurd is killing Oracle. Same as he did with HP. It's a shame.
Clients don't like Oracle but for now are stuck. The cloud is changing this, which is why Larry was extremely anti-cloud until a complete reverse 18-months ago because the cloud industry took off.
Negotiate a good entry package, because there are ZERO raises(as has been the case for 7+ years).

review_title: Account Manager
pros:
Work with some great people. Who you will learn to like them, because you will all share in the same pain.

It is possible to make a lot of money.

You will learn a lot.

After sometime there - recruiters will come calling.
cons:
It is possible to make zero money - and not because you can't sell. Territories change every few months. Customers cringe when they hear you say you're calling from Oracle. Especially when you're the 10th person that has called them that week.

Because all the products are so silo'ed - you compete with your own company on a solution to sell. Along with every other company out there.

Revolving door. 

Insane amount of call requirements - which have zero value.

College recruits are in for a shock.

review_title: Good company let down by poor management and culture.
job_title: Storage Systems Sales in Reading, England
pros: Like to invest in people. Good customer base using their database and apps.
cons:
Company works very much in silos - compete more with other parts of the company than you do with competitors.
Management incompetent - I worked in the storage business and the management team do not have a clue about what is required to grow a successful storage business in the U.K. 
Limited range of products with features out of touch with the rest of the industry. This applies to both their storage systems and their cloud offerings.
