review_title: Less Work-Less Benefits Company
pros:
Good work-life balance. Work is not so hectic (it may be dependent on the product development team you are in).
Flexible work timings (it may be dependent on your immediate manager).
Enough work-from-home options (it may also be dependent on your manager and team).
cons:
The compensation and monetary benefits are on the lower side, but for the amount of work you are expected to do, it can probably be justified!

HR department is more or less powerless. It makes the yearly reviews and appraisals totally dependent on the manager, and hence it lacks transparency to some extent.

It is an engineering driven company. Hence not the best for product managers. Growth in engineering track is any day better than Product management track. Good for engineers though!

Too much of flab in the mid-management level, that makes it difficult to climb up the ladder. There are many instances where mid-level employees leave the company, and come back to Oracle after 7-8 years at a much higher level, thus by-passing the bulky mid-level.

review_title: Outstanding company that innovates and provides the highest cloud speeds - Work with classy smart people
pros: Work for Larry one of the richest men in the world for a reason.  His database is the best in the enterprise category. The move to the next gen cloud is happening and 95% of enterprise customers are ready to move to the cloud in the next 5 years, this is a great time to join Oracle to help those customers move to the Oracle Clould.
cons: Oracle changes its direction at lightening speed.  I was caught up in a change of direction and laid off with a large team.  I would definitely return to the company.

review_title: Financial Analyst I
pros:
Starting salary for Rockin, Ca  Financial Analyst I is between 45-55k, negotiate before hire as you WILL NOT get a raise, this is also an hourly position. FA I is entry level 0-2yrs experience; FA II is 2-4yrs; FA III 4-8yrs depending on the job. 
 -Telecommuting is offered for some positions
-It is possible that your manager will be in a different office and therefore you have more freedom (watchout for some weasely coworkers trying to throw you under the bus)
-Once you understand your position it is fairly routine
cons: The Rocklin office is very mellow, and a lot of people are comfortable there. This office is good for those with families and need something consistent and predictable. Rocklin IS NOT a good place to grow your career unfortunately. Everyone has this complacent attitude and Bay Area managers do not put forth the effort in building up your skills or pushing for raises/promotions.

review_title: Experienced staff get paid less than new staff
pros:
- You can learn as much as you like
- Good hours
- Interesting and diverse work
cons:
- As you get better at your job your pay does not grow to recognize this.
- New employees that know less that existing employees are paid much better
- Little chance for career advancement
- No incentive to move into new positions. You can move to a new section but have to move at the same level and pay
- It is normal for staff to go 3-5 years without pay rises.

review_title: Good company to have a relaxed job and decent salary
pros:
Flexible timing is something can get you a lot of time for family by optimizing the work timings without hampering productivity 
High Initial Salary. Other service based companies offer very less with same years of experience
cons:
Not good for long term growth , 
No contribution from HR department , in fact not much of helpful.
Older employee do not get raise considering the fact management allocates a lot of budgets to freshers and new hires.

review_title: Prepare to have to fight for everything, even correct commission payout.
job_title: Inside Sales Account Manager in Málaga
pros: Oracle is a very mature company. Therefore basic things like onboarding, relocation etc. are well taken care of. Salary is industry average. You receive a lot of training for personal development
cons: The sales side of the company is set up in a way that everyone is fighting with everyone. For example, support renewal teams have contradictory goals to net new license sales. Also within teams and lines of businesses boundaries are intentionally vague, which means in your Oracle career you will have a lot of discussions and bad energy. Many of the best people leave after a short period of time. Also the company is very inflexible. New ideas are not embraced but turned down. Only the mediocre people stay and turn out to be managers. This means the mid-management of the company is of poor quality and lack innovation.

review_title: Sales and Business Development Representative
pros:
Benefits - especially for those just getting off of their parents insurance straight out of college
Break room - free coffee and drinks
Training - you get a nice free trip to California where they train you on the products that you will be consulting/selling. 
Working around 20 somethings - your peers
cons:
If you're not willing to cold-call all day long, this is not the job for you. 
It can take a while to become comfortable with the job, and a by a while I mean anywhere from 3-12 months. 
The compensation plan is reasonable, dependent upon whether or not you actually do well in the position. 
Metrics by which you're compensated - this was not explained prior to accepting offer
Most people here, although pretty friendly and professional, only come in to work for the paycheck .
They say that your territories / accounts for which you're responsible are evenly / fairly distributed, but that's not always the case - mostly based on luck

review_title: Client Success Manager
job_title: Client Success Manager in Reston, VA
pros: Working remotely and company supplied laptop.
cons: Too many clients to support effectively.  Oracle has deep pockets, but none goes to the employees in terms of salary increases, bonuses, etc.  Executives are way over paid and their contribution to growth of company is negligible.  The leadership does not care about employee satisfaction.  It is all about money and greed at a higher level.  No room for growth.  Oracle would rather hire outside the company at a lesser rate than invest in loyal employees.  Benefits become less year after year.  The customers overpay for support and they get very little in return for their contract renewals.

review_title: No career growth path, no raises/bonuses, skimpy vacation with a week stolen at year end.
job_title: Consulting Member of Technical Staff in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: I really can't think of any.  I guess I made some friends.
cons: Cut throat culture, very much sink or swim.  There's no opportunity for career growth.  After close to 25 years I only had 3 weeks of vacation, of which the company forced everyone to take a week of vacation at the end of the year.  I used to think I was making a difference and developing software that was important- finding 10's of thousands of bugs, but it didn't matter.  Frustration with the vacation policy, lack of raises/bonuses/stock options, and feeling unappreciated as a long time developer of the company's flagship along with watching money being wasted on building a high school all added up and caused me to walk away and retire.

review_title: Great to get your food in the door, that's it.
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Austin, TX
pros: Learned about Software Enterprise sales (coming from the Healthcare field) but also quickly learned that this organization is plagued and Larry has an institutional problem to solve if he wants to lift it.
cons:
-Poor Sales tech/enablement tools
-Poor equipment (old lenevo computers)
-Poor pay (compared to other small-mid size tech companies)
-EXTREMELY poor leadership
-Tons of people settling and staying because they're comfortable
-No sales process/sales methodologies (I was a lone wolf with my own process which is why I did so well)
-The college grads were refreshing at first, but then it turn into Greek life all over again, which has it's place, but I did graduate a few years back.

review_title: Director, Enterprise Suppprt
job_title: Director, Enterprise Support Management in Denver, CO
pros: Excellent direct management. Awesome teamwork between peers and direct reports.
cons: Acquisition senior management is poorly qualified to manage a very talented workforce.  Their narrow vision and personal agenda focus is toxic. This is true of CEO as well. I supported oracle products where he came from prior to his personal ‘incident ‘. His vision of cost control is admirable, but the absolute destruction of morale of those making less than 7 or 8 figure salaries has moved with him to oracle. The environment is now built on fear and forced feeding.  I lived 1 mile from a major oracle support center. Upon new senior management installation I was forced to commute 2 hrs each way to a different location. This after 19 years officing at the support center.

review_title: SDR Review
pros:
- The name
- Investment in your sales training
- Very clear path to promotion after a year
- Healthcare options
- Subsidized food prices in cafes
cons:
- Overall energy levels are pretty slacking
- Systems used by SDRs/reps are VERY inefficient and time consuming
- Market is saturated by Oracle sales people so lots of people have a bad taste in their mouths
- No free snacks/food available
- Overall layout of office is sad and not collaborative
- Huge discrepancy between SDR performance because of differing expectations of managers and reps

review_title: Slow moving, large corporation.
job_title: Project Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Being a large corporation, there's always the ability to transfer to an out-of-state location if needed.
cons: It has a huge beauracracy.  Things move at a snail's pace as compared to other companies I've been employed at.  Each small group assumes that their particular "process" is what is used throughout Oracle.  Yet, if you ask 25 different teams on what to do, you'll get 25 different answers.    Very centralized decision making.   Little, to no, power given to lower level management, hence everyone waits for one of the top few executives to decide on something, even on the most meaningless of changes or opportunities.  This results in very little "ownership" of one's job or work effort.

review_title: Be honest with yourself about what your goal is before working at Oracle
job_title: Manager Technical Support in Atlanta, GA
pros: Its a stable company, which in this economy is very important.  When the economy improves however, they will need to rely on other things to attract and retain their best and brightest. Its a great bunch of people trying to accomplish a great thing.  They all work very hard without much outside support.  If you are the independent type you will flourish in this environment.
cons: Very political environment, people seem to be afraid to say what they really think without finding a way to spin it. Management needs to support the work that is going on instead of creating roadblocks.  Management also needs to be more decisive and they need to be supportive of and recognize contributors of their teams

review_title: A lot of good, but there still are a few things to complain about!
pros:
1. The work culture is centered on openness and friendliness.
2. Voicing of opinions and consideration of such opinions is a given.
3. Employee engagement is given high importance.
4. Less bureaucratic as compared to the parent company (Oracle).
5. Recognition is promoted as being a way of life here.
cons:
1. All major decisions concerning compensation and promotion should be run by the Top Management honchos.
2. There are instances where there is definite siding with 'indispensable' resources even when they are out of line.
3. The Consulting/Implementation part of the organization does have the 'unofficial' concept of 'bench'.
4. The divide between the Development/Engineering part of the organization and the Consulting/Implementation part of the organization is quite pronounced.
5. The Support teams are at times very unresponsive, which impedes timelines for the resources in Development/Engineering and Consulting/Implementation.

review_title: soul-sucking misery
pros: Oracle is enormous; the name resonates and results in opening doors for those who have it on a resume.  The products are sound, so it's easy to get behind them. The benefits and salaries are competitive, and there are many perks (i.e. discounts for shopping and services) for employees.
cons: This is the worst corporate culture in the world.  Employees routinely experience only negative reinforcement; the formula is for managers to choose only 1 employee from the team as a "good example"-- the rest will never see a favorable review (and hence no bonus, raise or career advancement).  Managers are respected by their headcount and they are always affraid to lose it, meaning employees are rarely allowed to switch roles/departments.  There are no ethics to speak of as managers routinely lie and play "my word against yours"; and don't expect any help from HR who are only there to protect the company against litigation.

review_title: I have been fortunate to work for a great mentor who has helped me grow and take advantage of my time at Oracle.
pros:
Opportunity to learn software development and sales practices from a top software company.
Competitive (not the best but far from the worst) salaries and benefits.
In general, people are treated as professionals with a high level of personal autonomy.
cons:
Typical large corporation problems:  Lack of agility when seeking to make changes or introduce innovation (it can take a long time to get things done).
Different groups become silos, introducing competition or mistrust where cooperation should exist.
The compensation processes (raises, promotions, bonuses) are not very transparent, often creating doubt and uncertainty. Hard to fully understand why they are given, or if they'll be given.  This stems from a lack of access to upper management for many employees.
This, in turn, comes from the often distributed, home based work force.  We don't see each other, which slows team formation and prevents knowledge sharing.

review_title: You are just a number, there to make sure the few at top remain wealthy.
pros:
Some good benefits.
Good company to get training and then move on to where you will be appreciated and rewarded.
Great Software but Hardware side of Oracle is dying, big business is moving getting rid of their Sun estate 
and buying HP, Dell, IBM and running red hat as Oracle Hardware is far too expensive.
cons:
Poor senior management in the UK, no pay rises very little career progression. 
no interaction with people, everything is done via email, making you feel even more like a little cog in a big wheel. Made to keep doing courses that are a waste of time and add nothing to a persons skill set.
Lots of Rah Rah conference calls where managers pat themselves on the back for a job well done.
Very greedy company, everything is about the bottom line and selling as much as you can.
It's all about the money for the top one percent, very much like a wall street firm

review_title: It's a job - a stable, not terribly exciting job... but a job.
job_title: Systems Administrator in New York, NY
pros:
Very flexible schedule
Opportunities for internal training abound
Stable, the company isn't going anywhere
Good vacation and sick leave, and excellent benefits.
cons:
If you come in from an acquisition, the culture shock can be significant (and it's sink or swim)
In spite of internal training opportunities, raises and promotions are difficult to come by
'Working from home' or working remotely not as institutionalized as it should be, so some departments are hard to communicate with

review_title: Laid back, low drama environment with smart, engaged co-workers
pros: Pretty much everyone I work with is intelligent, hard-working, and just wants to do a good job. Most of my co-workers are very smart and have lots of experience under their belts, so I always feel like I'm challenged and learning. People are open to new ideas and always looking for ways to improve. Management seems to genuinely care about people and does what they can to work with you, your schedule, your career goals, etc. Corporate culture awards those who help themselves.
cons: Very self-guided, you are kind of left on your own to figure things out (sometimes to a fault). Limited opportunities for advancement if you want to stay in Oregon, no work from home options in WWOPS. Our org is pretty stingy with perks - no holiday parties, summer picnics, low increases. Increase/promotions are rare outside of yearly review cycles, and are reflective  of your current level/salary, not necessarily the market.

review_title: Horrible Corp Blame Culture
pros: Everyone thinks you work for a dynamic market leader (your NOT) but it helps on the resume.
cons:
Having worked at Oracle twice in last 20 years, I have seen some big changes since the acquisition program started in early 2000. There is now a 'Horrible Blame Culture' where no one takes responsibility for anything. 

The management team are not empowered below VP level and so just follow orders and delegate actions. Staff are overworked and are running scared of losing their jobs (Orcl call this Productivity) and this is why no one will take responsibility for anything other than their little world.

The only org rewarded are 'Sales' but they can't keep them either.  

Ask yourself would you have wanted to work for EDS or HP when Mark H. ran them ?
He's pulling all the strings at Orcl now

review_title: Principal Engineer
job_title: Principal Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Reasonable management.
Less work pressure
No onerous annual performance reviews
cons:
No salary increase at all over many years - never experience anything like this in entire career.
Top 10% of performers in a dept. get 1-2% salary increase - rest nothing !
No stock option grants
No annual discussion w. manager over salary or performance.
Management deceptive and elusive on salary expectations while the company and the execs rake in the profits and bonuses.
No opportunity to advance to management
Age discrimination
The only way to monetary or professional  advancement  is to leave the company.
Management very stingy on group cohesive events, if any are held at all.

review_title: Could be the best company to work for
pros: Oracle is a very big company and what is true in one department and team can't be in another. Generally speaking I think that is a good company to work for. In most case you can find a good work-life balance, You can find a loot of tools to develop your skills and help you to do your job. Great colleagues and corporate culture.
cons:
In good and bad it's a self service company, with a lot of internal processes. Personally I think it lacks a lot in the performance and talent development, poor support in coaching. Following all the business processes could bring you to depression.
Salary. It's really difficult to rise your salary even if you change role, the most you stay in the company the most your salary will be unaligned with the market.

review_title: Not good for long term employment
pros: Excellent place to get experience on many technologies. I have been working for Oracle for over 20 years.  Picked up great experience working with databases, SQL, PL/SQL, OBIEE modeling, etc.  It is an excellent place to work for 3 - 5 years, then take experience to another company.
cons: Oracle was great place to work up until 2000, then started cutting back on perks.  Stopped granting stock options to high performers (of which I am, one). No salary increases or bonuses for last 5 years (I have been rated top performer every one of those years). Forced use of 32 vacation hours for year-end company shutdown.  Company is breeding mediocrity - no incentive to work hard and excel.  All pay seems to be going to top Execs (45% CEO SALARY increase in 2015).

review_title: Cheap company
job_title: Consulting Technical Manager in Toronto, ON
pros:
- Good vacation benefits - 3 weeks, 4 weeks after 10 years, 5 weeks after 15 years
- Excellent access to training programs and online training
- Discount program for staff with Apple, Dell, and car manufacturers
- They will match 100%, up to 6% of pay invested in the group benefits program
cons:
- CHEAP on the benefits.  Vision $200 every two years?  Medications only partially covered.  A new start up has way better benefits.
- Stock purchase plan is cheap, the discount is pathetic.  Again, a new start up that goes IPO gives a much better discount to their staff.  
- For such  large company, you would expect the benefits to be better.  It's pretty pathetic.
- Raises are below what one would expect, and it's clear that they don't value keeping staff if this is the faste of things to come.

review_title: Poor communication, management, and training
job_title: Customer Support Representative in Orlando, FL
pros: Kind co-workers, very relaxed dress code, can do basically whatever you want as long as you take calls.
cons: No true knowledge base or training (beyond a couple of outdated videos), level 2 technicians/leads/managers will never answer your questions. Due to the lack of information available in the system, you have little to no way to solve issues and just end up sending people to sales. 85% of my day was spent with angry people screaming at me about how much they hated Oracle. It was considered an accomplishment to close even a handful of tickets a day, let alone under a half hour per call. Management cares more about the number of calls answered than actually solving problems.

job_title: Consulting Technical Manager in Toronto, ON
pros:
- Good vacation benefits - 3 weeks, 4 weeks after 10 years, 5 weeks after 15 years
- Excellent access to training programs and online training
- Discount program for staff with Apple, Dell, and car manufacturers
- They will match 100%, up to 6% of pay invested in the group benefits program

cons: No true knowledge base or training (beyond a couple of outdated videos), level 2 technicians/leads/managers will never answer your questions. review_title: Challenging work environment.
pros:
Oracle attracts great talent. They rely on their name an reputation to recruit.
Oracle has good products (also has some crappy ones).
cons: In my department there is no work-life balance, would like to transfer to the ones everyone says have good work-life balance. But internal transfer almost impossible. Everything is done via sheer force of will, escalation, and intimidation. You are expected to be available always. We are overloaded and they keep cutting people and benefits. Compensation is at least 20% below market. The longer you have been there the less you make compared to new hires. They rely on heroics but then don't reward the heroes.  Way too many middle managers building mini-empires that add nothing to company vision,  productivity, or profitability.

review_title: Application Sales Executive
pros: Depending on your manager, it can be a lax environment, flexible hours, and low expectations
cons: For your Sales' cycles, your biggest competition is Oracle itself. There are a lot of internal factors that will get your way to close deals here - antiquated and expensive products, painful process requesting sales engineers, price approvals, and getting SKUs on the contract right. Each account you have will contain duplicates, many of which are not in your name. So when you get an opportunity, be ready for someone to try and swoop in to steal it. Seriously, it's pathetic watching a rep claim the duplicate company is in their territory, therefore your opp is their's. Managers are worse with it. This is only scratching the surface when it comes to how bad it is here. Unless you're desperate, don't consider this place. Oh, and it takes approximately a full month + to get an offer.....a full month AFTER you're done with rounds of interviewing. Yes, their internal systems are that bad.

review_title: Not the company for a fresher to work at
pros:
( Based on work experience at Bengaluru - India)
- Amazing work life balance as a general rule ( experience may vary depending on manager)
- Flexibility to work from home
- Market Rate Salaries
cons:
- It has become a giant corporation with excessive number of people delivering below par work.
- Accountability for work delivery is less. It is OK to underperform and stay at the company. However this is often discouraging for people who actually want to work.
- It is ancompany for those looking to settle down. Not for hustlers, not for the ones looking for rapid growth, steep learning curve and challenges. Not a company for fresher.
- Frameworks in use here are either archaic or internally developed. The experience thus gathered does not help much outside.

review_title: Many good things but need to focus on improve family friendliness
job_title: Not Disclosed in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
The commitment by the company on some benefits. Here are the pros:

1. The lack of a dress code, a big plus. Just wear clothes.
2. Telecommuting - work at home, big plus as well
3. Employee gym
4. Employee cafeteria
5. Nice people and management
6. Their ethics program
cons: One big, big, big downside. The rigid schedule of 8:30 to 5:30 is very family unfriendly. At one time, they had flex time arrangements but took it away a few years back. Another is the lack of pay increases and bonuses.

review_title: If you like a challenge, Oracle might be the place for you.
pros: As a consultant, one of the best parts of working at Oracle is that you get a lot of hands-on experience very quickly. You can be 'thrown in the fire' and expected to produce quality results right-a-way. If you like the challenge then it is a great place to work. You typically are ask to focus on one technology or product at Oracle, but when at a client's site you may get pulled into other technologies or products. This keeps your job exciting and not so mundane. When the economy is doing well, Oracle is very supportive of training, including in-class training.
cons: Oracle is a big company so you can have the feeling of a small fish in a big pond. If you are looking for a lot of recognition from management this is not the place for you.

review_title: If you are not in the right group, you are doomed...
pros: Benefits are good, if your job requires traveling the company takes care of all the things very well. Vey supportive of telecommuting!
cons: Get in with a good salary if possible, there will be minimal or no raises for years to come. You would be lucky if you make 5% more than the starting salary after 8 years of working. The middle management consists of a lot of people from all the other companies that Oracle acquired. The are in a very confused state, most don't know what needs to be done, nor they know about the potential of employees who have worked for 5 or more years. They just spend time playing politics to hold on to their people.

review_title: It was good, I was happy
pros: Oracle has Excellent Benefits available to employees. Overal it was a great place to work for. If you are lucky enough to get hired at Oracle make the most of your time. They allow you to work from home.
cons: They love to centerlize positions that are not customer facing(positions that can be done from anywhere) to low cost countries, so if you were lucky enough to have gotten a Admin or non technical position in your local country chances are they can centerlize the function to a cheaper country at any given moment. Its a big company so you are just a number,  your direct manager can't really help you much as things need do need approval from GOD

review_title: Awesome internship, but a catch!
pros: Worked from home, managers went out of the way to include me in Oracle employee conferences, even though they didn't have to. Helped me learn more about the graduate world. Paid about 50% more than other companies did for internships. People were nice and very helpful. They even set me up to talk with senior high profile employees about my future. These people did not have to take hours out of their day to mentor me.
cons:
I graduated, asked for a reference and was told their policies wouldn't allow them, but would love to recommend me for internal jobs. Oracle mostly hires older and experienced people or have outsourced their programing development, thus no newgrad jobs. No reference hurt me. Even with the nice pay, a reference would have been much much better. Then again most interviewers seemed to understand about the policies.

I also didn't care for the majority work at home. I got stir crazy never leaving my house.

review_title: After working for well paying start ups, Oracle just can't compete in salary compensation to Bay Area start ups.
job_title: Senior Principal Technical Support Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Beautiful Santa Clara Campus, gym and cafe.
cons: No salary increases, have talked to people who have worked for Oracle for 12 years without any salary increases

review_title: good company with mature IT processes
pros: Work life balance is reasonable, very friendly coworkers, many opportunities for professional development (if you take advantage of them), excellent benefits, perks like large gym and exercise classes on site, casual dress code, occasional work from home if needed, and a great benefits package.  Senior management in my area are terrific.  This is a company very friendly to women - both in engineering and management. It's nice that the workforce is so culturally diverse.
cons: There are so many posts confirming that raises are few and far between that this appears to be an unfortunate but true fact.

review_title: Finance Analyst
job_title: Senior Finance Analyst in Redmond, WA
pros: Built a solid network while employed there for many years, lot to learn, easy to move around, solid processes
cons: Employee morale is low, non acquisition employees are very low paid, company wants you to do more / take on more with no raises or promotions, pay vs. market is not comparable at all, have a "either you like it or don't let the door hit you on the way out attitude," managers are very well versed and helpful but aren't able to help get employees what they need pay wise or promotion wise due to red tape, very political

review_title: Consulting Sales
pros:
Oracle is a juggernaut in the industry.

Very successfully transitioning to be the premier cloud provider.

Flex work allows people to work from their home office.
cons:
Customers don’t like us.  Terribly bureaucratic processes that make customers jump through hoops just to do business with them.

Focus is exclusively on revenue.  The customer’s best interest is always put second.

Oracle consulting services (OCS) has a terrible reputation with customers and software reps alike.

Most software reps flat out refuse to include OCS in their deals because they’ve been burned too many times in the past.

Most definitely make no distinction between leadership and management.  Being a manager makes you a leader by default at the lower ranks when their role is purely to manage forecast and kick news up the chain of command.

My manager has had 100% attrition on his team since he started in his ‘leadership’ role and the upper echelons refuse to acknowledge that he is the main reason that people are leaving.

Constant threats of loosing your job, people are totally expendable.  Condescending, arrogant and verbally abusive is a way of life at least in OCS.

review_title: Good company, could be better
pros:
Countless quality trainings. 
International feeling.
 Opportunities. 
Good working condition and work-life-balance. 
Good products, great brand on CV. 
Proactivity is encouraged. If you're self-starter you'll enjoy it.
Probably one of the best companies for a sales-oriented career.
Generous perks and great campus in Dublin.
cons:
Sales-oriented organisation locally, however technical learning is well supported. Targets/Career advancement is mainly linked with your sales/networking/political ability, much less on your tech skills. 
Poor marketing which makes it a hard sell if you're competing with AWS/Azure. 
The hiring-firing policy is hardly understandable (tendancy to hire too much people, but that is good for the local economy !)
Very hard if not impossible to get pay raise without changing role or leaving company.

review_title: A great company with great visions and encouraging culture
pros: I am proud to word for Oracle India Development Center. Unlike its parent company, Oracle Corporation, Oracle India is not huge. It is a bunch of smart people trying to create sensible and customer oriented products. Work is very demanding and challenging. Work culture is amazingly open and flexible. Management ladder is very much flat and not surprisingly, most of the managers rose to their position from being developers earlier in the same company. You are asked for deliverables and not for certain number of work hours. Innovation and communication with anybody in the organization is highly encouraged. If you enjoy writing quality software, this is the best place to be.
cons: Being a huge organization (or at least a part of one), processes are slower than they can be. But this is unavoidable in any big organization and Oracle deals with it in the most organized way possible.

review_title: Aggressive, action oriented and exciting company. Middle management sucks! Not much innovation here but great execution!
job_title: Senior Director Engineering in Redwood City, CA
pros: Good Pay. Stable Job. Aggressive and action oriented environment. Executive management is great.
cons: Middle management sucks! Too many VPs and too much title inflation in the company. Product development is not assimilating the acquisitions well, while the sales and other sides of the business are doing a much better job handing acquisitions.

review_title: Learn what you can and get out of there as fast as possible.
pros: Oracle can be a good training ground for people that has some or little sales experiences. It is a place that's very difficult for someone who's new. Most people are only there for themselves, especially, the managements. You think you could just do your honest work, sell some software, then get paid? No, you still have to battle others and people in finance to get your commission. Career path at Oracle? there isn't any.  That's why this is a place that you can pick up some skills, and then get out of it. It doesn't really matter to the company that they've lost some skilled workers, they can always hire someone from outside, in a week.
cons: They constantly make unnecessary changes that doesn't benefit the customer, employee, nor the business.

review_title: Oracle from ground level
pros:
Orace has great opportunities for carrer advancement.

The ability to work anywhere in the world is another advantage when working for a global organisation.

Oracle invests a lot of time and effort in training its employees, both from internal resources as well as externally, through sales training methodologies to management training.

Oracle do take their involvement with Corporate Social Responsibility fairly seriously and encourages staff to be involved as much as possible, this affords you the opportunity to help out in the community.
cons:
The inability of management to provide the tools required by the staff to to their jobs is a major hinderence when working at Oracle.

Due to the differring reporting lines and varying agendas of each business unit, it's very difficult to get a holistic pictur eof what Oracle are ever doing with respect to a specific client at any one point in time.

review_title: Big Company
job_title: Senior Sales Consultant in Redwood City, CA
pros: Access to the latest and greatest in technology. Ability to cross train in another area while working in current area.
cons: Never seems like sr management socializes ideas with staff when making decisions which well affect large groups of employees. Do not listen to the front line or ask for recommendations on changes that could help the organization. Too removed from day to day operations. Communications is horrible, so disjointed. Too many disjointed company websites making it impossible to find anything or be consistant in answering questions. Does not share the wealth. Sales makes more and more money each year (for the company) but personally am making less and less and less benefits and events. Taken away sales conference, fewer people going to sales club. Don't feel appreciated at all.

review_title: Sales
job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Burlington, MA
pros: Great place to learn about technology, with numerous opportunities for internal growth.  Lot's of job recognition and awards.  Great reputation among tech companies, and Oracle name carries prestige.  Quality people, and large, international, diverse workforce.
cons: Madenning environment to complete any sales cycle with cryptic applications, and excessive work process overload.  More time spent on mundane, clerical type activities such as various approvals, quote generation, opportunity tracking, contract adjustments, imaging, contract generation, forecasting, paperwork...so many mindless activities distract you from what is most pertinant to your job success, talking to customers and solving real business problems.  Long, frustrating learning curve to get up to speed with all the internal systems necessary to perform your job duties.

review_title: Good work-life balance, benefits, but very limited salary adjustments and promotions, especially in the US.
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Orlando, FL
pros: Good work-life balance, flexible working hours, laid-back management style, challenging work, good benefits, smart people to work with, flexible time-off policies
cons: Limited promotion, stagnant compensation, only higher ups benefit from stock buybacks since it pads their stock options, which most regular employees do not get. Capped vacation days at 18 days forever. Only 7 observed holidays. Quite a few employees are likely not reporting vacation days due to the low number given by the company.

review_title: Experience is oracle is good. Work culture is nice. But differs from team to team basis.
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Hyderābād
pros:
1. The work in application division(APPS) is okay but the server technology (ST) division is very strong as far as Java Technologies are considered.

2. Lots of experienced people in ST who have been working for quite sometime like above 10 years and very much expertise in their own areas.

3. Great place for java developers.

4. Inter team communication is very strong as there are integration between many different products.

5. Work from home facility and can maintain a very good work life balance.
cons:
1. Compensation for freshers is good but the hike and bonus cycles are inconsistent and depends on market. Some years you do not get hikes or bonuses

2. Big company and have to be an outstanding performer to be get noticed by management.

3. Getting stuck to a particular technology.

review_title: Big name, Big customers, small personal growth opportunities
job_title: Service Delivery Manager in Reading, England
pros: Oracle is and will be a big name.
cons:
No investment in employees at all! The base salary is attractive and perhaps one of the biggest reasons why people tend to apply for jobs at this company. However, once the job secured you do learn that the salary increases are close to non-existent. The performance reviews are set to ensure you never achieve the "Rating" to be eligible for it, and if you are...don't dream for much...

Learning, so everyone knows about the Oracle University. This is truly a great place, if you work outside Oracle. Management will always find an excuse not to put you forward for courses...

Job security: Well, to put it simple: It does not matter what you achieved, what you have built for Oracle or how your customers praise you. Once the word to "cut down" is being sent, management will always find an excuse to get rid of you easily. With a poor package of course as it is always about the money...

And don't forget, once you join forget humanity..you become a number...

review_title: Confusion Confusion Confusion
job_title: Software Development Engineer in Redwood Shores, CA
pros:
Nice locations, 
Good products that are orphaned
Some passionate employees (whoever is left)
Great work-life balance... Man, you can fly below the radar and cruise for years.. Just be sure you are pleasing your boss with a small win every 4-5 months...
cons:
Biggest shareholder Scam in in decades. The number of people leaving is not even funny. In some technologies pretty much everybody who knew anything about the product is gone. 
Everyday you go to work they are looking at you and wondering how much money they would save if someone in India or China or Romania was doing that job... 
Quality does not matter, people don't matter... I understand the money part, but its too short sighted in my opinion... Sure was glad to get out of that place..

review_title: No challenging work
pros:
Flexi timings, 
bonus(depends on the BU and the company's performance),
team outings,
Work from home
cons:
Everything is Self-service(you need to resolve any kind of issues by yourself),
You need to have extreme communication skills to pull others down and show off how good you are at your work. Your hard work may not be counted if you are not communicative.
You need to show case yourself.
You should know to how to butter your boss.
The appraisal process is very lengthy(ur appraisal would entirely depend on the company's performance, only if you can show cast your work even if it is small, it will be recognized. Moral of the story is, you need to boast of your work and yourself).
No challenging work, you may be doing the same work again and again and a very tedious process.

review_title: Review for sales
pros: Great pay and benefits. I also worked remote which was a wonderful perk. If you land in a good patch, you can make an absurd amount of commission with deals that land in your lap.
cons: I worked at Oracle for a little over two years now. It was great when I first joined due to my management, but the management chain went through some reshuffling and the quality of the job just degraded from there. New and obscure policies made it extremely difficult to fulfill your role, and I sincerely feel that the clients suffered because of it. Oracle has an incredibly difficult time retaining their talent (funny because they sell talent optimization software HA!) because they are more about the bottom line and pinching pennies than creating an enjoyable work culture.

review_title: Work life balance good. But not Salary and scope for technical improvement
pros:
1) Flexible work timings.
2) Immediate managers are good, very comfortable to work for.
3) Flexibility to learn anything and experiment with. Abundant resources available at developer's disposal to try on his own.
cons:
1) Salary is the biggest concern. Top management doesn't care about employee's salary.
If you are long timer, you will fall way behind the market. 
2) Increments won't even match with inflation rates. So you become poorer each year.
3) They literally treat Software product developers as another immovable asset like table, chair, office,etc and try to keep the cost to very bare minimum. But they forget employees are humans and they have to meet materialistic world expenses like School fees, Inflation, etc.

review_title: Transitioning giant in software with a wide portfolio, great long term vision with Enterprise Cloud
pros: Family friendly, smart people, provides path for career development, footprint in almost every industry vertical, bold in making long term bets, business in many countries, aggressively changing to cloud based services (a great time to join the team)
cons: Pays conservatively, takes time to build reputation in teams, many senior people with lots of knowledge - can get intimidating to new employees, many experimental projects, many development time zones (you will join late night or early morning meetings at times), many workers working remotely specially in few campuses, no free lunches

review_title: Education Account Manager
pros:
Good team environment in the office.
They let you run your territory like you would run your own business.  They understand your drive is in your commission earning potential, so they do not micro manage you.
cons: They expect that you will close everything that you commit to, even with their unreasonable timelines.  Expectation is that you will do whatever is needed the last day of the quarter to bring in your deals, even if signing authority is off sick, they expect you to track him down.  Once you commit to a deal closing, if it pushes for any reason outside of quarter, they fully expect you to replace the revenue with another net new deal.  Administration is a nightmare, with many sales requiring non standard PO terms from customers that are unreasonable, like issuing a PO with no taxes included.

review_title: big brand name and heavy politics game @ Oracle HCM
pros:
- Work- life balance or in sort no standard work and only life.
- pay master in Ahmedabad
- free certificates at initial fresher's level
- GIFT city location is advantage
- JD edwards department is good and few managers at HCM
- Many can take advantage of free lancing.
cons:
- heavy politics played especially under one manager's team
- manager is not technically sound and not ready to listen any sort of technical issues
- favorites are preferred and payed heavily and they get stocks options
- freshers are getting worst exposure and no real development
- its a Bug tracking support centre.
- HR department is dead inside 
- don't join if you want to have a good profile and don't spoil your career only for few more bucks.
- no onsites
-

review_title: Sales and Business Development Representative
pros: Through the ups and downs of sales, your team holds you together. I also had the best direct manager who supported you and challenged you. Great work life balance and flexibility.
cons: Pay was a bit average and the distribution of territories often created confusion and overlapping with other reps. Bonus structure was very much a "cloak and dagger" situation. Also, many folks come into sales but would like to venture into other departments to best utilize their abilities. The turnover rate is high because folks feel locked into a sales role and don't feel there's any other option but leaving.

review_title: Very Poor Culture and Bad Customer Approach
pros: Oracle is a rich company and some of the products are very good
cons:
Very poor culture inside the company from the top down.  5 layers of VP from CEO to the Major Act Mgr level.  Many product "pillars" (teams) competing  within the Org driving different product solutions and engagements with the same customers and contacts.    Constant internal conflict between teams within the company and confusing messaging to customers who are unable to find a trusted advisor.  Sales planning sessions are little more than beating sessions for management to fault those at lower levels.  Very uncompetitive base salary for an Org where sales opportunities can be killed overnight by competing sales interests within the company.  Some customers have experienced multiple large scale failures of core technology in production environments and are working hard to move away. 
 Oracle has some excellent people at the low levels of the Org working directly with customers and some excellent people at the top driving big initiatives.

review_title: Great company to work, management dependent
job_title: Data Center Technician in Frankfurt am Main
pros:
- Good Salary
- Good benefits (** in cons)
- Strong focus on education
cons:
- A lot of Issues in work life balance
- No Hike, No Bonus, Local Regional Politics.The German managers always trying to cut more from your benefits.
- Their culture is good in papers but not happening in real life
- Sometimes you feel isolated from the team. They do not offer office related benefits snacks etc like other companies.
- A lot of spread information and you need to perform everything by your self. No attention is given to you at all. 
- If you are a foreign colleague working for the German department is not good. Every information is coming in German and it is hard to understand.

review_title: Sales culture, leadership lacking, weak benefits
pros: Sales culture is good if your in sales, for most part. It does not always lend itself well to solving customer conflict.
cons: Oracle’s fertility benefits are a joke and actually very deceptive. I registered for the fertility solutions group within UHC, which supposedly covers 70% of meds and procedures under different deductibles. During IVF cycle 1, I quickly discovered that most meds and procedures are actually not covered. I was expecting 5k out of pocket which quickly became 15k in one IVF cycle. Luckily, I was interviewing with a company with a completely different mindset that seems to care about this topic - perfect time to bolt. I consider this area of Oracle’s benefits to not only be a con, by a CON JOB.

review_title: A great "name" company for which to work.  Resolve some administrative issues and be simply "great."
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: Great "name" company.  Very collegial atmosphere.  At ORCL you have the opportunity to work on challenging issues in large customer organizations.  Complex issues that require innovative solutions.
cons: Review / Promotion / Compensation reviews are essentially non-existent or glossed over.  Almost secretive in how and when decisions are made.  Feedback on performance is lacking.

review_title: Didn't drink the cool-aid
job_title: Former Brand Creative Contractor in Redwood City, CA
pros: The pay is reasonably good for the work. The name looks good on a resume. Good work quality produced and knowledgable group. Good peer level coworkers to work with.
cons:
People are not valued for their knowledge and-or experience. Things are done because it is the way it has always been done vs. finding better options or listening to better ideas. Hierarchical and stifling with a culture of fear of the managers above you. Everyone is always guessing what the head creative person wants, and good ideas are killed based on guesses vs. being presented and finding out.

Fight for a better idea against the opinion of a manager; you might be looking for a new job.

review_title: Interesting, Great Learning Environment, Lacks Social Aspects
job_title: Software Engineer Intern in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Great working and learning environment, real opportunity for personal development, if you want it, if you don't then nobody is going to shout at you for doing the bare minimum; it's up to you what you decide to spend your time doing.
cons: Within my team there was a distinct lack of social activities, more team building exercises and events would help. There is also a slow corporate process involved in doing anything, from hiring new staff to requesting a wrist-support mouse mat, it is a waste of time and usually results in staff being unhappy.

review_title: Oracle Sales - Fun, fast-paced place to work.  Very much a work-hard play-hard environment.
pros: Everyone in the sales org is on your side and is an advocate for you.  Management's goal is to get you promoted.  The opportunities as far as money and promotion are quite remarkable.  I have seen people move from inside sales to the field in their mid-twenties, where you can make 100s of thousands of dollars a year.
cons: Since Oracle has so many products to sell, I run into a lot of customers or prospects that are sick of getting calls from Oracle.  There's internal competition for deals and LoBs fighting each other for business.

review_title: I came over from a acquisition with Sun Microsystems - Oracle is company with tested and true integration processes
pros: Oracle has a complete portfolio  - engineered systems - h/w and s/w tuned to work together. If you are a sales pro, you have a complete story for your elevator pitch which can get you in the door to many fortune 100 - 200 companies
cons: Very large company which you are a number and you do not have much leverage to when a RIF comes your way. Not even the strongest internal network and keep your number from coming up. Oracle culture is straight forward, as a sales manager or sales rep you really do not have the ability to be entrepreneur like... business decisions are made in layers

review_title: Great technical talent, below average pay
pros: Some of the smartest database and enterprise information technology people in the world work here.  Still the 800 pound gorilla of enterprise tech.  Ellison has kept pace with the changing tech world and reinvented the company several times.  Interesting work with the world's biggest customers.
cons: Pay is way below average for the tech industry.  Have to leave and come back to get a raise, or just leave - lost a lot of talent due to this.  Sales management doesn't understand the missing pieces to make customers successful after the deal is done, or doesn't care.  Ellison is 70 years old - who will take over when he is gone?

review_title: Top down culture which knows how to win
pros: Oracle is a very well run company at the macro level, competes well in its core businesses and has a positive financial outlook. There are lots of people working here who care and are willing to do whatever it takes to make customers successful. There are opportunities for training and internal transfers and the environment at HQ is positive with great cafes, an onsite gym, a piano in on of the lobbies, and a number of other employee services.
cons: Culturally, Oracle tends to be managed in a top-down style and is also very geographically distributed in some lines of business, which makes it more difficult to feel connected, heard and integral in influencing business results. It also leads to some interesting work styles and work hours, and can be demanding in terms of needing to jump on things right away (even if they are not really emergencies) because you don't want to block progress in other timezones.

review_title: A place to continue your career
pros: Competitive salary and benefits. Real space for short / middle / long-term internal growth within realistic time-span.
cons: Not newcomer friendly - "self-service" policy in place delays settling in of newcomers by almost one month. Interdepartmental cooperation has a big room for improvement. Very hard corporate tradition regarding procedural steps that very often hinder productivity (too many hierarchical steps for most decisions). Typical "number oriented" corporate philosophy that very often disregards causes of under-performance and focuses on setting new higher sales targets (very often clearly unattainable) made to ensure higher management targets are attained. When compared to main competitors, not a big spender on what comes to investing on the ground and marketing the brand / services.

review_title: Strong vision, getting weaker on execution
pros: Oracle has a great portfolio of products and strong industry experience.  As an employee it never gets boring with all the recent acquisitions.  With Oracle's market share in either database or applications it is fairly easy to get an audience with almost any Fortune 1000 company.  The company has a good benefits package and they treat their employees fairly.  There is a good work/life balance and many first line managers are employee focused.
cons: Executive management likes to keep internal competition alive which creates confusion for customers (multiple products to solve the same problem) and internal fighting among the sales teams.  The company has too many middle managers who seem to create meaningless programs to justify their positions.  They rarely give out cost of living increases or raises, and transferring internally is very difficult.  They have lost a lot of great talent in the last couple of years that has not been replaced.

review_title: Sales
pros: They have good benefits and competitive wages.  Spend a ton of money on R & D for new products and solutions.  Solutions are getting better everyday
cons: It's a self service company, so when you are new you don't know where to get service.  You have to figure it out by yourself.  It's not awful, but not efficient.   Working with other pillars can be difficult.  In my experience, each pillar looks out for themselves first and not what is best for the client.  This causes Oracle to look bad in front of the client.   As for the solution - they are getting stronger everyday, but turnover in the support organization is rapid and they don't have enough customer success managers who know the products well enough to help the customers.

review_title: Good place to learn and gain reputation. Salary was low.
job_title: Staff Consultant in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: I was in Oracle CGBU based on Mexico City (area which is focused on communications industry) as entry level consultant. The best was the formation (training, expertise of co-workers, courses, product documentation, engineering support) that Oracle has to offer to you as a big school in contrast to other companies of consultancy. Being an Oracle employee you get access to all the benefits and infrastructure that company offers.
cons: Very low salary to consultants. You will earn only a third of the amount that you can earn in other small-medium company after a year. The performance appraisal is a waste of time since perhaps you get a good or excelent performance, your raises salary will be only 1%-2% each year!

review_title: An organization that is slowly losing its quality of work
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Hyderābād
pros:
Vast opportunities in terms of technical skill based development.
Exclusive ownership on a single component makes you a point of contact very soon and thus comes the visibility and recognition.
cons:
If you plan to spend a longer tenure in this org (I spent 5 years here until now), by the time you leave this org, your salary will be increased hardly anything from the offered salary when you joined. This is regardless of your productivity, working nature, punctuality.. etc.
The "work-life balance", Oracle once stood an example for, is almost gone now.
Are you vexed of waiting for a well deserved promotion or increment, just get another offer from outside Oracle and they will match that package just like that regardless of appraisal cycle consideration. Yes... that's the reason for the extreme level attrition today.

review_title: Moving goal posts
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Good benefits around pension and health care
cons:
Terrible internal systems
Finance is set up not to pay you on deals and wont inform you till you close the deal

review_title: Innovating at Oracle
job_title: Sales Manager in North East, PA
pros: Despite the large size of its organization, Oracle is still able to course correct relatively rapidly. This speaks to the ability to find new markets, refresh its product portfolio and retool/retrain its teams to continue being successful in the marketplace, Ultimately, it is about the people who choose to work at Oracle, who need to be able to adapt with the technology and not cling onto legacy platforms that might have made them successful in the past.
cons:
The pressures of EPS/Wall street can slow rate of change, (but compared to competition, Oracle has performed remarkably well in its transformation to the cloud for e.g.)
There is now no limits on how much vacation employees can take, this of course means, people are taking less vacation than they could be.

review_title: 10/10 Would Not Recommend
pros: Incredible flexibility, come here if you want to kick back and relax
cons:
No training, the only training they had was pretty useless soft skills stuff not so relevant to your role.
No Teamwork
No Excitement
No Challenge
Some pretty tough personalities to work with
I've worked for companies with vast amounts more talent than this and a fraction of the attitude

review_title: Mixed bag.
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Raleigh, NC
pros: The work is interesting and challenging.  The opportunity is there to work with cool, cutting edge technology.  I've found the pay to be on par with similar positions in the area, but no other company around here comes close to matching the benefits package.  I've had to decline new positions because I could not afford them after considering the difference in benefits.  Ellison is he first CEO I've had for whom I've had any respect.
cons: Stagnation.  No advancement opportunities.  No opportunities to change projects.  No one leaves, so the only way you'll have to do anything new will be to leave yourself.  Not Invented Here mindset means that you'll be using frustratingly poor tools when very good open source (i.e. FREE!) alternatives are available.  Combativeness across development teams.

review_title: Organized Chaos
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Its a great place to work if you are looking for a place to settle into a long-term role/ organization. On average, employees are older than at most Silicon Valley organizations. Lots of super smart folks around.
Hours are flexible enough and benefits are comparable to other companies
cons:
A lot of role overlap and project overlap; everyone seems to be doing everyone's job (or have an opinion they could do it better instead of focusing on their roles). It is not uncommon to have multiple organizations working on very similar solutions separately instead of streamlining and having the best folks deliver a joint product.
Alliances seem to be very important and who you know is as important as, if not more than, what you know.
There are so many people that it is sometimes a challenge to figure out the right contacts within the org

review_title: Just another acquisition
pros: I was part of an acquisition. Since I work from home, I have to say there's a good work/life balance. Benefits are probably as good or better than most high tech companies. My former company's organizational structure remained intact after the acquisition, so it's almost like still working for my old company, but under a new name.
cons:
The performance evaluations are a joke. Lots of hype, but little substance. Same goes for Development Plans. Because Acquired companies remain partially intact, if you didn't like your previous company, you won't necessarily be any happier once you become acquired by Oracle.

The IT Bureaucracy is the worst I've ever seen. Trying to get help for a PC issue is hopeless. You're forced to log a help ticket online, and you may never get a response. Forget about picking up the phone to call someone for help.

review_title: Ok place to start your career but not a good place to stay long term
pros: Very knowledgeable and supportive co-workers, access to technology and products firsthand so good opprotunity to learn and acquire new skills. Good benefits (healthcare, vacation etc). Oracle is also a good brand name to have on your resume when you move on to other companies in your career.
cons: Not much growth opportunities, you are basically stuck in the same position for years (despite posting very good numbers) and also the merit increases are dismal despite the company posting record profits year after year. The upper management conitnues to neglect the lower level employees and therefore the company has a high turnover rate, very little communication between you and your manager so you basically feel like you are working as an independent but are on a payroll.

review_title: Oracle has incredibly smart people, an aggressive and fast-paced culture with generally poor management.
pros: In most cases, you can work from the office or home. The people are overwhelmingly smart and skilled in their roles. The culture is competitive and individualistic which creates an environment where people are constantly trying to get more done and do it better. There is constant change and that keeps things interesting.
cons: Management at Oracle is generally poor and HR provides little oversight. In fact, HR provides no value for employees and little to no value for managers. It is an extremely process-heavy company that is fiercely risk resistant. This is only mitigated by the CEO's intelligence and risk-taking. Employee satisfaction is not a consideration around any executive office decision-making. Oracle, while reasonably ethical in business terms, is cold, mean and self-centered.

review_title: A career dead end that sets you up for failure
job_title: Hardware Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: This company pays much higher than you will ever see anywhere else at this level, and it has great benefits. There's also an on-campus gym and cafeteria
cons:
They do not innovate. They instead push you to finish your tasks to meet mismanaged deadlines all for the sake of making the company money. They do not provide the necessary resources to complete projects within the desired timeline, and instead just set you up for failure.

I was put in a position where I had to complete a (2-person) task that required heavy lifting, and was not given another resource to assist in that task. I pushed back to get the necessary resource, but was denied and instead sternly warned that this needed to be completed on time or there would be a business impact. Of course, as I attempted to complete it on my own, I injured myself and damaged the equipment, getting a reprimand on my record. I wanted to file a worker's comp claim, but was afraid to do so in fear of being fired.

review_title: Great people, great working environment, shame about the profit-first management style.
job_title: Principal Technical Support Engineer in Reading, England
pros: The people on the ground are fantastic, and the company does look after you in terms of flexibility, flexible benefits, training, etc. It's also a great name to have on your CV.
cons:
The management style takes its inspiration from Uncle Larry, and therefore everything it does is first and foremost for the financial benefit of the company and shareholders. I mean EVERYTHING - if something positive happens which appears to benefit an employee/employees, the decision would have been analysed on a spreadsheet, and if one cell is higher than another (ie. it benefits the corporate bottom line), then it's a yes. Otherwise no.

Kiss bye bye to pay rises, unless you leave. Which I did, and got a 50% increase.

I didn't realise how much I disliked working there until after I left.

review_title: Overall
pros: Strong GTM strategy and visionary CEO(s) committed to cloud.  Oracle likes to win, and they do, especially when there are specific competitors to set their sights on.  Map your career to Cloud at Oracle and you should have a good, long run.
cons: Raises and bonuses are rare, and when they do happen there is little correlation to performance - and more so based on catching people up who fall below a salary band. Therefore if you stay too long, you risk falling below 'market'.  Advice - when you take a job @ Oracle, negotiate the highest comp you can, as that will likely be what you earn for a while.

review_title: You're not getting a raise unless you're Safra Catz
job_title: Software Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Products are fairly easy to support.  Co-workers are friendly and super smart.  Solving issues and helping customers is the best part of the job.
cons: Costs in benefits go up, wages effectively go down (because there are no raises).  Vacation allowance is mediocre.   3 weeks max.  No work from home.  No flex time.  8-5 M-F in a cube.

review_title: Working at Oracle
pros: Every group/division can be different in how they treat their employees, but I'd say overall there is very good atmosphere of trust and fairness. There is a strong focus on education, and they reimburse for outside classes taken (Up to 5k/year I think). Benefits are good, and I'd say quite competitive in the market.
cons: They don't try to make the workplace anything special (maybe a pool table and arcade game are cliche or gimmicky?). In the 10 years I've worked there, they've given 2 measly %1 cost of living raises (this is the same with most everyone I've spoken to, some don't get any raises).

review_title: Good product, very poor practices in HR and Training
pros: Oracle has a great range of solutions both developed and acquired. It’s great to know that you have something market leading to offer to your customer. Flexible benefits mean you can tailor your salary and benefits to your own personal circumstances.
cons: Very poor HR policies in training and remuneration. Mandatory training in particular is ridiculous. Delivery teams and management know that’s the case but senior management totally unaware. Good real training is hard to come by. HR seem to think that it’s acceptable to never increase salaries .... ever. So don’t think of Oracle for long term, and only consider short term if you really want Oracle on your CV. There are better employers out there.

review_title: Japanese and International's pros and cons are mixed
pros:
Flexible work styles
Good work/life balance
Pretty good benefit plan
cons:
Cloud sales strategy does not work well
Sales quota is too high 
Slow to act

review_title: Oracle NETsuite Leadership is a joke
job_title: Senior Sales Manager in North Ryde
pros: Oracle Netsuite has a superb product. NETSuite is well run in the US. Lots of potential for internal advancement and promotion. Local office in North Ryde has a nice gym.
cons: The company is very poorly ran in APAC particularly in Australia. The current sales leader for ANZ is a joke. Cannot properly manage the sales team or build positive culture, spends more time surfing than forecasting. Oracle only hires incompetent people that wouldn't be able to get jobs at other good global tech companies.

review_title: Oracle is an exciting place to work.
job_title: Senior Director, Product Development in Redwood City, CA
pros: If you are interested in having a highly energetic, exciting and aggressive environment where you can learn your skills and grow, Oracle is the place to be. It has a  highly business-like, no-nonsense, competitive environment for go-getters.
cons: If you are expecting a "touchy feely" environment where your individual skills are respected and your value to the company is well recognized, you will be disappointed. Senior management especially is not very "people oriented". However, by being a very successful and profitable company, Oracle indeed "takes care" of its people more than adequately.

review_title: I made a lot of money and I learned a great deal.
pros: The money is fantastic and there are a lot of smart people working there.  The technology and software are best of breed, and there is a sense of pride in working with the caliber of professionals that you find yourself with.
cons: You are as good as your last accomplishment, and memories are short at Oracle.  There are no reviews, there are few raises, and you have to find satisfaction with yourself there - there will be no one to pat you on the back.

review_title: Ample opportunities to grow and succeed for those who are competent, smart, and hard working
pros:
1. Quality work
2. Opportunities to learn and work overseas
3. Flexible and relaxed work environment - work is the only thing that matters 
4. No/minimum politics
5. Cultural activities
cons:
1. Low appreciation/recognition for good work 
2. Low transparency regards to company strategy and business on-goings 
3. Sometimes people are promoted only because of the number of years they spent. For e.g. the client relationship manager in New York area couldn't manage relationship with the clients like rival firms. I worked there for 2 years, and I as a consultant was managing the relationship and doing her work. I saw her meet the client only when the project was awarded to a rival firm.

review_title: Like working for the union.
pros: Documentation department is very stable and most writers have been around for over ten years. The company has good benefits and is very professional in how it treats employees.
cons: Some organizations (like Consulting, and sometimes Sales) have high turnover. The company is a huge bureaucracy with tools and systems for every conceivable purpose, some of which are poorly designed and inefficient. Most middle managers are mediocre communicators who inherited their positions long ago when there were still opportunities to move up. Now things are static - only when companies are bought are new executives added. Some products barely work and are managed with amazing incompetence, yet no one seems to notice because the company is so big.

review_title: Ever changing workplace
job_title: Senior Principal Software Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
Good people, good managers. Good place to work if you do not expect much.
Education is paid for if you stay within the business.
cons:
Upper management does not understand the lower levels.  1st level Management has no authority.
Used to be very flexible work environment, but no more! No raises, bonuses or any type of incentive.

review_title: A dollar short and a day late.
pros: Internal mobility is fantastic.  Many products and opportunities for growth.  Solid stable company.  Yearly salary is not bad.  Management is getting better.
cons: Raises, bonuses and celebration of achievements non-existent which is hard to swallow for a company that is so successful.  No effort to retain talent.  Poor work-life balance. No time for training. Improvements to processes and organizations made way too late.

review_title: Senior Application Engineer
pros:
1. I joined with Good salary above market standards while joining the company.
2. Good environment to learn coding.
3. Brand name (But it is no way equal to Oracle standards)
cons:
1. Hectic targets and have to complete releases within very short period.
2. Very poor Top management and appraisal process is fully based on your relationship with manager.
3. Very long working hours and weekend office.
4. Lots of people have left the company during last year so it is very tough to laterals to understand the business and complete the work.
5. Don't join as a lateral now to avoid mental pressure.
6. Most of the guys who joined with me have left the company within 6 months period but I managed to survive to save my profile and to avoid short jump to another company.
7. I am personally affected a lot because of mental stress and definitely will change the company at the last moment I can hold.
