review_title: Through the eyes of a long term Oracle employee
pros: One gets ample resources for working, e.g. internet access, hardware, top end PCs, etc. only where applicable, employees get to experiment with various softwares, design approaches, etc. A great portfolio of enterprise products covering almost all business sectors.
cons:
Too hierarchical resulting into misrepresentation of high level goals and standards.
On an average the middle management come off as technically detached resulting in an inaccurate evaluation of the strengths and weaknesses of the technical staff (who does the actual software development).
Way too many so-called "software frameworks" used for integration resulting in longer and flawed integration iterations and distancing the software developer from actual software development.
One would grow old trying to plumb a handful of softwares into a functional module.
Follows a flawed appraisal system where the manager is like a "one man judge" who can make or break your career at will.
Non-competitive compensation packages.
No travel opportunities.

review_title: Great work-life balance, plenty of internal opportunities
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in San Jose, CA
pros:
Oracle culture promotes flexibility and a great work-life balance. There is decent stability - there are occasional minor layoffs within BUs, but not massive company-wide layoffs like other silicon-valley companies.
It is a big company with a variety of products, and internal transfers are encouraged. So there is the possibility of working on different products without having to switch jobs. In my 6 years at Oracle I have worked on two (entirely different) products already.
cons:
It is a big company with tedious and bureaucratic processes that can slow you down frequently. 
Open-source is not embraced, which imposes unnecessary restrictions on technology choices. One has to go through a painful third-party approval process in order to use open-source technologies.
Salaries are lower than silicon-valley standards, with little or no bonuses. This frequently causes attrition and makes hiring in the bay area harder.

review_title: Huge organization in a painfull transformation
job_title: OD Sales Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
- Benefits
- Salary
- Team spirit (Sales Reps)
- Working in an international environment with people from different countries
- A lot is possible IF you know the right people
cons:
- Silo behavior among departments
- You don't really know where the journey is heading
- Too many changes among teams / territories
- You have to be an entrepreneur inside the company 
- Without a good network you will have a hard time
- No clear marketing strategy for the DACH market

review_title: Oracle is a dinosaur of an employer
pros: Insurance, benefits, stability, networking, name
cons: Literally everything else. This business model is long outdated. Not a good place to work.

review_title: Huge, bureaucratic company, great at team level
pros:
I had a great time working with the former Sun Microsystems part that Oracle Corporation acquired in 2008. Specifically working on the Solaris kernel. This part I like--a lot. I worked with one of the best teams of people in terms of talent and being part of a cooperative, fun team.
Pay is good--or at least competitive.
Being a big company gives many opportunities to look around elsewhere if you don't like what you are doing now.
The top-management are competitive and have business smarts (if not always technical smarts).
cons:
Huge bureaucratic company with many processes to slow productive work down.
The corporate level seems hostile to cutting-edge technology and research.
Too many layoffs--they seem to perfer to layoff than reassign people.
My part of the company, former Sun Microsystems/Solaris/SPARC, is now gutted and doesn't really exist any longer except for a skeleton crew for sustaining support.

review_title: Account Manager
job_title: Sales Account Executive in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Oracle has a depth to their portfolio that is unrivaled. The company has the research and development funding to invest in continuous enhancement. They have been a stable, conservative choice for thousands of companies.
cons: The company tends to make decisions that are not in the best interests of their employees or their customers. Territory change and lack of consistency in the coverage model are rampant. The company has a vast amount of resources but it takes weeks to schedule client meetings.  Managers tend to be in CYA mode rather than coaching and trying to enrich the skills their team already has.

review_title: Great Company for taking care of employees
job_title: Senior Technical Support Engineer in Lehi, UT
pros: Stability.  I have had some health issues and I never once doubted that I had Oracle to rely on.  They are outstanding at making sure employee needs are covered.
cons: Upward mobility is rough.  Almost non-existent.

review_title: Cloud Sales are Non Existent
pros: Benefits aren't bad and you can make money if you're part of the right group (Tech, Eng Systems and SaaS Apps)
cons: Customers HATE Oracle so no one wants to talk with you.  Biggest drivers of revenue - audits and support cost increases&lock-in. Oracle Cloud is a complete bust. No innovation, zero strategy and complete lack of execution.  When you do sell something good luck getting paid. Commissions are always late, always smaller than you expect and always require a dispute inquiry by the seller.  However since only 1 out of 20 reps are hitting their numbers this isn't much of a problem.  Overall, it's a horrible time to be at Oracle and it's only going to get worse with Safra in charge. She's the financial engineering guru so expect more layoffs and department cuts to make numbers.

review_title: Oracle is a very nice company to work for.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros: Very flexible working hours and reasonable workload.  You will work with other talented ppl and everyone is helpful and will share his/her ideas with you.  You will be proud of your group. The time between your work and your family is well balanced.  Things are pretty well planned and you will feel very stable working for Oracle.  You will have enough time to stay with your family and/or enjoy your hobbies.  Oracle also provides a lot of internal trainings to the employees to develop various skills. Not to mention the nice onsite gym that every Oracle employee loves.  Someone likes the free lunch that is provided by some companies, but I'd rather have the time and flexibility to enjoy the lunch at home with the family.
cons: It's a big company, so sometimes things are slow, but be patient, everything will go through finally.

review_title: Good place to retire
job_title: Consulting Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: Oracle is a retirement home. The majority of its employees are completely checked out and are in semi retirement. A 11 - 3 workday is commonplace. For folks who want to get a paycheck without doing any work, this is the place to be. The gym is pretty good and six cafeterias at HQ means that you have plenty of choices for lunch. I recommend building 600.
cons: Oracle is extremely political, if you expect to be successful on the basis of the work you have done this is not the place.  If you have reached Oracle via acquisition, good luck! Expect your former product to die a slow painful death. From an engineering perspective, this means no new features, just integration hell. If you don't want to become a vegetable, get out as soon as you can.

review_title: Good Resume Builder
pros: Oracle is well-known throughout the software industry and builds enterprise software used by pretty much every major company you've ever heard of. As such, it's a great resume builder. Oracle is also multi-national and you get some great experience learning how a large software company works when so many people work somewhere else other than your building. The company is also good at promoting minorities and encouraging modern ideals.
cons: Oracle is still a good old boy network still run by database-centric people and many of them are poor managers. For all the companies they have acquired, there is not much new blood running the company. Acquired company management can abandon most hopes at Oracle unless you have connections. Also, no matter what your position, watch your back because someone is always looking to stab it.

review_title: Working at Oracle is Demoralizing
pros:
- the health benefits are comprehensive
- de minimis benefits helps support the employees financially (a little bit)
- they also provide free over the phone psych consultations to help you manage your stress and pressure at work
cons:
- you feel like a prostitute working here. All management can think of is the client's needs and you're left feeling like crap trying to fulfill it. You go through the stress and intense pressure, you do all-nighters and then what? You're not even rewarded for it. No pay raise, no bonuses not even a holiday Christmas party :((
- It's true, the managers don't really care/value you. They perceive you like a piece of replaceable raw material.
- they always make excuses about economic crisis and company acquisitions but in reality, pay increase at oracle is a myth

review_title: Product and Company was part of an acquistion by Oracle in 2006
pros: Oracle has great benefits, fair compensation, and many tools to help with career advancement.  Having Oracle on your resume is nice
cons: The Company I worked for was acquired by Oracle - and like many big companies that acquire small, innovative, fast moving companies, they allow them to slowly die as they pick out what they want from them.  In this case, a once market leading product has been left to stagnate and is now being cannablized by their competition.

review_title: organized chaos, highly matrixed, broad responsibilities
job_title: Director Industry Strategy and Marketing in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Broad set of responsibilities.  
Lots of activity.  
Exposure and Matrixed with many organizations.
Customer interactions and event speaking opportunities.
cons:
Often there isn't an alignment of priorities across the virtual team (matrix) for initiatives you are responsible to complete making it near impossible to succeed due to team  members not completing their pieces.

Poor BI / Analytics access / support to abundant internal data sales and product data due to SVP level eye-only governance policy.

Apps and Industry Marketing receive no budget to help them pay for their own initiatives and expectations.  This leads to significant amounts of time wasted having to look for funding in Corp Marketing, or groveling with Field Sales and Marketing.

Zero cost of living annual raises, and under-performing bonus program coming in well below expections.

No stock or RSU provided below upper management.

review_title: Lots of career opportunity
pros: Oracle is evolving into a modern, innovative company.  It has always been a large powerhouse in the enterprise software and technology space, and is now cutting edge with more opportunities than ever to stretch yourself in new areas and roles.  A healthy work-life balance is fostered by management.  Culture is always friendly and supportive.
cons: As is often the case, pros can simultaneously be cons.  Oracle is evolving rapidly - so much so that in a few orgs it is like a start-up.  However, it is still an extremely large company, so it is not nimble like a start-up and there are often political/bureaucratic challenges.

review_title: good for learning but you wont progress in your career
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
chocolate easter Egg
health care benefits
cheap food in the canteen 
free fruit
ability to buy additional holidays 
work life balance
cons:
draconian KPIs, threats for underperformance, unreasonable revenue targets and no strategy behind decision making.
incompetent managers and directors who do not know products, processes and markets  that their teams are dealing with. 
managers are focused on managing themselves (trying to survive and not loose their job for their underperformance) instead of  managing  and developing their people.
depressive atmosphere and no sales environment. 
lack of role models and success stories. 
lack of resources to enable you to close deals at the required volume
self service  everywhere including on-boarding and everything else.
no clear definition of territories and terrible data quality with slow CRM (feels like working for an IT company that is stuck in 1980s). be prepared working with excel a lot.
employees are always kept in the dark and there is no communication from the leaders

review_title: Very stable organization
job_title: Applications Developer II in Bala Cynwyd, PA
pros: Oracle is a highly stable, well-structured organization that will help you develop yourself into a better engineer.  It may not be the most exciting software you'll ever write, but you'll learn great development practices and will always feel safe and secure in your job.  There is always a clear path to advance your career, which is something that should never be taken for granted.
cons: Working at Oracle can sometimes feel like a snapshot of the movie "Office Space" at times.  It can be tedious, and the products are not particularly exciting.

review_title: wait a few years to join Oracle Digital in Ireland
pros: Career span as they are always hiring, job security, good products
cons: Territories are unworkable, impossible to get a salary increase once you are in. Performance is capped even when recruiters say it is not. No marketing so there is no leads, Cold calling is the only way to get a lead but you dont get even the customer names. Too much change too fast with no enough change management to understand the impacts. Most reps are unsuccessful and if you dont close a new deal in one quarter they put you in a performance improvement plan and you could be fired. They will get it right... in a few years

review_title: VP - Oracle Marketing Cloud
job_title: Vice President Marketing in San Francisco, CA
pros: A company that will work to help promote you within the industry.  Very strong international footprint and teamwork.
cons: Where to begin?  Came in via acquisition, and many things became readily apparent.  Oracle is first and foremost a database business.  Everything else is secondary.  Oracle Operations have been so fine tuned for very large database customers that any other business unit finds revenue shrinking and customers disappearing because of delayed contracts, delayed sales payments, delayed everything.  So quality, entrepreneurial, hungry staff pack their bags within 12-36 months.

review_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff
pros:
-Relaxed culture
-Work from home
- Average projects.
cons:
- Lots of politics, not good projects ,layoffs 
- You can find many experienced people doing nothing  except politics.  
- Managers have fixed mindset towards set of peoples ,he can humiliate a Senior Guy in front of other team mates in cubical itself.
- Demotivating environment 
- They can ask you to do anything / any random assignment.
- Employee disconnect ,no single 1-0-1 in 3 years careers with manager.
- They make you worthless and taken for granted too you stay longer with company.
- They present like they are competing with Microsoft and Amazon but work culture is worst.
- You will find in-competent people assigned important tasks only because of they flattery skills.
- Hike and promotion is at the discretion of manager ,so get ready for all torture.

review_title: Oracle Rocklin was a wonderful place to work.
pros: Great kitchen, yummy food, a nice, small gym and plenty of space to be outside and walk around and lay on the lawn.  So many kind people and a great diverse group spanning cultures and ages. Everyone I worked with was pretty great.  Turns out, I don't belong in the tech industry, and left as a result. But, it was a great experience.
cons: In my few years there, I didn't experience a lot of challenges, truly everyone was great.  I would say the lack of flexibility to work from home was an issue.

review_title: Stay here for a year (San Antonio)
job_title: Financial Analyst in San Antonio, TX
pros: Flexible schedule, possibly some overtime. That's pretty much it. Free la croix.
cons: No growth opportunities whatsoever. No bonuses, (even if it is stated in your contract.) If you want to grow, you must transfer to another team. At San Antonio, it is like playing musical chairs. Everyone transfers into each others previous role due to lack of growth. Don't be fooled, you will only get behind in your skill set and waste time. SA is a back-office satellite office and you will be doing reports ALL day. No analytical work.

review_title: OFSS Review - The Service Company Pretending Oracle Brand
pros:
Oracle Brand . Oracle is a Good Company - OFSS is not !  Actually OFSS is not Entirely an Oracle company. Read below - 

Although OFSS (Formely I-Flex) is acquired by Oracle. Still  OFSS is no where near Oracle . Oracle is a Product company. Whereas OFSS is a Service company enjoying the Oracle Brand.
cons:
> Note OFSS is an Indian Service company (I-Flex) who are Misleading the Clients with Oracle Brand Name. 
> New People are not Welcome. Extremely Bad. 
> You can not move from OFSS to Oracle. If you need to then you have to Resign fromm OFSS and Join Oracle - Exacty like how you join Another Different Compnay.
> You will lose all your Cutting Edge Skils - Big Data , Data Science etc. The Backward People in OFSS are living in their own tiny Bubble world. They know just about their day to day mundane work . And they think they are Doing something Great.

review_title: Review from Tech Perspective: Outdated Tech Stack, No Financial Growth but Good Work Life Balance and WFH Culture
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Hyderābād
pros: Good customers hence good domain knowledge or exposure to domain. Excellent professional culture, which helps in a chilled out work life so good work life balance. Most of the teams are flexible about timings and work from home as well.
cons: Biggest two cons are: Heavily, massively outdated tech stack and very rare hikes or financial growth. You have to be exceptional to get anywhere near a minimal hike in most of the orgs. Regarding tech stack, don't join oracle if you want to work on hot tech buzz. Oracle products are massively outdated in terms of UX and stuff. Even the tools like version control, ide etc are very specific to Oracle and not what industry uses.

review_title: Suck it all up and work for the name "Oracle"
job_title: Project Leader in Redwood City, CA
pros: "Oracle" on your resume would help you get your next job. There are some opportunities to shine and make your mark in the industry. If you are a budding/aspiring Managerial candidate, Oracle is a good place to work - A lot to learn here.
cons: Compensation & Employee Rewards/Raise suck big time! Majority of the annual revenues are diverted in stupid acquisition to increase stockholders value. Very little for employees. Political environment. Rigidity in knowledge sharing. Many a times it feels like they make very optimistic promises to their customer which burdens the engineers to put in extra hours to meet the deadlines. If not met, leaves a black spot on your performance.

review_title: Be sure of what you want before you sign on.
job_title: Senior Principal Consultant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Listing Oracle on your resume is one of the best reasons, as the company is recognized as leading software company. Compensation is good for my role. Work schedule is flexible, as is the choice of tools and methodologies (though there is a strong preference to Oracle owned technologies, even when they are not he best). Bonuses are sometimes good.
cons: Small salary increases is a large one. Bonuses seem to be dependent little on individual performance but rather on business unit performance. There is a strong preference to offshore development, even when it doesn't make sense due to great difficulty in finding experience, qualified candidates.

review_title: Flexible work environment, more grounded in chaos theory than orchestrated progress
pros:
Flexible work environment (but don't kid yourself... it is less expensive for Oracle)
Never boring
High degree of ability to change (in fact happens every FY start like clockwork)
Good compensation (but stalled over last few years)
cons:
Really... really big
Middle and upper management are "celebrity" like... you know they are there... but you only see them in pictures.
12-month horizon for any strategy change

review_title: Comments of an 11 year Sun vet
pros: Innovative tech environment, individual contributors can make major impacts to marketing campaigns, events, and technology evolution at their level (if self motivated), great salaries, shorts, jeans, barefeet, dogs, afternoon beer bashes, nice corporate campuses
cons: Incompetent executive and VP leadership (from 2004 on) that have failed to execute any kind of monitiztion strategy for the company.  Employees, mainly individual contributors, have kept this company going day by day (no stretch here).  Management heavy, key individual contributor contributions get little to no recognition (one has to just be proud of what they are doing knowing they will not get any credit), intern programs were dropped years ago leading to noticeable drop in the ability to cultivate and hire young talent.

review_title: A 'fair' starting point...
job_title: Senior Account Manager in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
- The people make all the difference. Some real talent and it has been a pleasure to work with them. I've made some good friends here.
- International replacement possible to almost any location Oracle has an office.
- Great place to learn.
cons:
- Too much training, that doesn't give real value in helping speak to prospects.
- Company believes that relationships don't matter, as they have the products.
- Management in general have little or no sales experience, making it hard to have a conversation about deals.
- Way too many deal reviews, with no real value to anyone.
- Most managers and sales support staff work harder on justifying their role than actually working.

review_title: Poor at rewarding top performers
job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: consistent employment, few layoffs - although constant job off-shoring leads to MANY group re-organizations and re-assignments.
cons: A massive company, that has a corporate-wide, long-standing habit (unofficial policy?) of almost never giving pay increases.  At first I though I was just overhearing the grumbling of a few "bad apples".  However, the quantity of complaints, my stagnant pay over the past years (combined with excellent reviews, and even advancing into a top tier support group) have all convinced me that I can no longer afford to lose financial ground to the 'standard cost of living' with Oracle.

review_title: It all depends where your at!
job_title: Program Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Work-life balance is great, no micro managing, and access to lots of senior people. But I'm in a unique position which allows that. I have a boss that give me autonomy, and support from senior leaders to act in the best interest of my program.
cons: The internal bureaucracy is horrible. Internal systems such as expense reporting, procurement, tech support, and any other system for employees is garbage. Employee apps are crap, and internal software is dated and not intuitive.   Compensation is slightly below average for tech companies, but not for other Fortune 500's

review_title: Poor Job Security
job_title: Technical Analyst II Support in Broomfield, CO
pros:
Starting pay and benefits were pretty good
Good shift differential for working weekends
Brilliant colleagues
Flexible working arrangements, was allowed to work from home
High quality vertical managers
cons:
Advancement was only considered annually and next-to impossible.  There was only a $0.25/hour raise with a large promotion.
Depressing lack of pay raises over a 5 year span
All in-house work was sent offshore for cheaper labor in a gradual process, so there was a constant fear of layoffs
Layoffs happened frequently, and cuts were deep, including entire departments
Layoffs did not account for job performance, as top performers of all levels and senior staff were dumped without warning.

review_title: Lay offs November 4th 2016
pros: I chose to join Oracle only because of their brand name & technology involved in spite of having 2 other company offers. I joined in Feb 2016 &on Nov 4th , I got the shock of my life saying I was laid off! I have no idea on what basis people are chosen to be laid off! The only plus in the company is WFH! Except this it has no process, the management thinks they're ahead of other folks/companies, but they just keep beating around the bush..
cons: Pathetic organisation. Please don't join this place..you never know when you would receive a meeting invite from one of the directors, & that's the end . You're given no explanation & told that business unit got closed . Just the previous night, my manager assigns tasks to be performed for the next 1month & this **** I  heard next day. All you will get to hear is this decision wasn't based on performance. Then what the hell it can be,god knows!! So don't waste your time & energy in this organisation.

review_title: No Guarantees with Oracle
pros:
Great work life balance. Worked from home for 6 years, and very flexible work schedule. Benefits are also quite nice. Lots of opportunities to learn new technologies. Oracle does pay well above the national average, but growth is somewhat stagnant. 

If you apply for another position within the company with more responsibility, you must remain at your existing pay grade, which isn't a great incentive to change jobs.
cons:
Although top executives continue to get richer, that wealth is not shared with the employee base. Cost of living & Performance pay increases have been few if any over my last 6 years at Oracle.

The whole Performance Management evaluation system is a sham. Employees are forced to write their own reviews, and managers just sign off to get it over with.

review_title: Outrageous Executive Compensation
pros: Oracle is largely a self-service company where employees are expected to figure things out as they go. This is great for self-starters. Benefits are good but not great in comparison to other Silicon Valley companies.
cons: Little effort to grow employees. Only a handpicked few and even then, promotions are few and far between. Appraisals are a joke and in no way tied to compensation. Oracle sells so many products that it's hard for the company to innovate and allow individual products to stand out. Everything is top down. Nobody is interested in information flowing up so don't expect your voice to be heard. Employees are just FTE's, there is no loyalty.

review_title: 2 Years in
job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Great company to start your digital selling experience. Whether we like it or not the digital selling model is here to stay - particularly when you are managing overseas accounts - The sales training in Oracle is pretty comprehensive and is amongst the best I've seen.
cons: The problems start when you land at your desk and you are handed your accounts - remember you will be handed a list of company names - not a geographic area - so you will be more Business Development rather than Account Manager (Or Cloud Specialist as Oracle call it). Its impossible to change the company list until the year end so you could start in June and by July know you won't be making any money until next year. That's very tough.

review_title: A Total Waste of 4 Years
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood City, CA
pros: Work remotely and somewhat of a work/life balance
cons: No recognition in any way of good work or accomplishments, no raises in 4 years, no career growth. I was offered one salary by a director initially, then it was cut back by $10K by the 'VP' saying I needed to 'grow into the job.' which I already had years of experience in. Pathetic way of saying, 'we're cheap' but we may employ you for a little while.

review_title: Director
pros: One company which gives you all the opportunities  to  explore the world and take assignments  / jobs  in anywhere in the world .  You see a open position  , apply for it .. if you clear the  interview process Oracle will take care of  everything ..  Work visas , relocation  .. housing .. For the  millennials its the best way to travel and explore the world  without spending a dime and  enriching themselves with experience no school can provide  .
cons: in the last decade or so  oracle grew inorganically and the focus shifted away from Innovation  which made it less nimble and flexible to outside factors  , was one of the last  tech companies to wake up to  Cloud  and now are playing the catch up game ..

review_title: Business development consultant
job_title: Business Development Representative in Burlington, MA
pros: There are no pros other than the signing, mid-year, and one year bonus. The cafeteria in building 8 is also a pro because the tater tots are to die for. So there are a total of two pros.
cons: Management above my direct manager was subpar. The trainings were classroom style and therefore unrealistic, theoretical, and ineffective to what we dealt with on a day to day basis. The company has a gym that is big enough for 30 people at a 3,000 person campus. The job is extremely monotonous but that was to be expected. The culture of the company is terrible. The only nice thing was being able to work with people my age. They align you with your product and org via lottery - which can turn out to make your time at oracle a cakewalk or make it impossible for you to hit your number unless you know how to finesse the duties of the job and get your sales reps to like you. Thank u, next.

review_title: No work life balance and no hike
pros: The team is technically good and manager is very supportive. Manager will allow you to explore new tech stack and come up with new ideas.
cons: Product owners will make you work like hell on new requirements when the project is about to go live! Open politics in the team. There are few dumb senior people also in the team with whom you have to work with. No hike even after working day and night. No work life balance at all during go-live. Useless work sometimes, support related. No architect in the team to manage the project well.

review_title: Not good for sr engineer's, management is a family business in Hyd.
pros:
Work life balance is ok.
Work pressure is not so high.
Job security WAS a pro point but it faded soon.
cons:
Old technology used unless product you work on was a fresh acquisition.
Reluctant to change to new technologies, nothing to explore. oracle people live in their own tech cocoon. The world around is way ahead.
Management is a family business there, too much partiality everywhere. People bring their spouse and let them grow while others are ignored. You can see this in almost all GBUs.
No respect for tech talent. Please your manager and you will grow(you know what I mean), else you are ignored or even made to leave the org. 
Freshers come and go for higher studies. 
No growth opportunities and hikes.

review_title: Comprehensive strategies, competitive culture
pros:
The benefits are amazing, incredibly comprehensive and inexpensive.  

From a product standpoint, the overall strategy is so comprehensive, between applications and infrastructure, that there is almost nothing you can't offer as a solution to customers.  Every customer seems to have some amount of Oracle installed, so there is always some Oracle relationship, whether or not it's positive, it's something to build off.
cons: Oracle's internal culture seems to remain one of competition, rather than cooperation.  This means multiple Oracle reps may compete for the same business in a single account, and some bad behavior results.  With the acquisitions, this is changing somewhat, and there are pockets of accounts teams that work as a team, but long time Oracle employees seem to have that competitiveness that emanates from Larry.

review_title: Oracle is a challenging and rewarding company to work for
job_title: Senior Account Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Established Leader in many market sectors and and lots of resources to help you win deals. There is an opportunity to make a lot of money if you have the right product responsibilities in the right territory.
cons: Legacy Product footprint has created a less nimble product story which has allowed companies with pure SAS stories to grab marketshare which should have been owned by Oracle. Ie SalesForce  Also with the acquisition strategy to grow the applications footprint, it brought confusion to the customer with shared sales responsibilities across Oracle products This also sets up competition across sales teams for customer info and management access.

review_title: Senior Hardware Engineer
job_title: Senior Hardware Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Laid back culture, good benefits, good quality work and great people, career growth wise you can climb the technical ladder easily than the management ladder
cons: 1. They are paying fresh college grads much more than senior members, that is disappointing. 2. Everything in very bureaucratic, slow and political. It's like working for govt. every thing is on a need to know basis. 3. There are a lot of old timers in the management and they need to adapt more recent project management strategies like agile/extreme even for hardware development. 4. Bonuses/rewards if any are very tiny and often come very late. 5. I don't think there's much remaining for bonuses after the VPs, directors and managers grab their Lions' share. So what ever remains is spread very thin amongst the peasants.

review_title: High Stress, Low Compensation
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: The work is interesting, the people are very smart.  Good health benefits.  I'm employed.
cons: Schedules are aggressive.  Engineering schedules shouldn't be driven by needing to announce something new at Oracle Open World every year.  Long time employees who know the most are not valued.  New hires make way more money with no experience, and leave after 2 years.   For a software company, they don't seem to realize that you need to retain people and what's in their heads.  No exaggeration, I was told by my VP that if I wanted a decent raise, or any raise, I would have to come in with a written offer from elsewhere.  Many people, conscientious workers and high performers, have gotten zilch for years - no raises, no bonuses, no stock options.  The greed at the top is obscene.

review_title: Oracle Sales Engineering
pros: Good place to work on a wide breadth of technologies.  Undergoing an exciting transformation to cloud, which is a bit rocky but opportunities will come out of it.  Stole some top talent out of AWS and Google to build cloud product so the future will be good despite current pain.  Little turnover until recently as previously market competitive salaries age, lots of very talented people remain.
cons: Oracle is moving to flat YoY revenue and is feeling pressure to deliver bottom line growth which is causing a lot of pressure on costs.  Lots of downward pressure on income.  Cutting OT (which is about 10-20% of income).  Cutting bonuses (about 20-40% of income).   Few raises if ever unless you are promoted.

review_title: My experience (IaaS org)
pros:
* My colleagues are all smart and I enjoy working with them.
* Flexible work hours
* Remoting allowed on a case by case basis.
* Decent technical challenges which are interesting and align with career development.
* The product/service I'm working on is important for Oracle, and has relevance in the market place.
cons:
* Oracle is pretty much a Java shop, and I don't like the Java platform. Luckily I have been able to use other languages due to my focus area.
* Weak standards around code quality and maintainability in some teams, which can be frustrating.
* Too much of a reliance on top-down, hierarchical decision-making. This cultural issue makes it hard for developers to show initiative and come up with solutions without the aid of management.

review_title: High infant mortality rate in sales in poor layers of 'the stack'
pros: Oracle provides decent training, even though much of it was 'on line' CBT based coursework mandated in first 90 days.  The effort to drive the cloud vision for the company and how each layer of the Red Stack tied in was thought out well and marketing message was on point.
cons: The fact that the "enterprise accounts" are covered by an average of 20 plus reps creates contention internally, confusion for the customer, and hinders the ability to collaborate with Oracle peers carrying different 'bags' in the field.  This is unfortunate as a strategic approach would include shared risk/reward for the team working together - not as separate P/L's within Oracle competing for share of the customer's wallet.

review_title: Great Diversity, not as great management
pros: Overall a continuing-to-develop-and-grow company that has  along history of being successful.  Oracle has produces products that scale very well and has continued to grow over time.  Oracle has had a history of hiring extremely talented SEs - this has had huge payouts over time.
cons: Typical large scale management - blanket pushes of changes across the organizations without any analysis of impact.  The upper management doesn't seem to know what is happening on the sales teams.  Sales teams quite often compete over the same client to sell competing products instead of the best solution.  Teams are forced to sell products they don't get compensation for.

review_title: IT Senior Analyst
job_title: IT Senior Analyst in Redwood City, CA
pros: You get access to powerful systems.  It's fairly easy to get approval to make purchases from vendors.  Vendors give you lots of attention.  Health plan is fairly good.  You can work from home in some departments.  Stable company.
cons: There is usually no money for raises.  Getting promoted does not come with a raise.  After you've been there a few years, your pay is terrible, no matter your performance.  The management of the  different IT organizations do not get along or cooperate well.  While training is encouraged, there isn't enough time for it.  There are often too many meetings.  Management, especially, is so buried in meetings that they have little time to work with their teams.  Ineffective use of project management tools (Spreadsheet and word processor documents in e-mail?  Really?)

review_title: Work a few years and move on
pros: I was happy with my comp when I started but raises are almost unheard of so if you want more money down the road you'll need to leave .  Good health insurance options.  Some groups allow you to work from home.
cons: Oracle values stock price and technology not customers or employees.  As a result you're not going to be working with people who are not excited to be at Oracle.  Mark Hurd is all about cutting costs and reducing employee count so their isn't a lot of opportunity to move up the ladder.  Because the company is so large employees are not part of any decisions that impact them.  Managers pass on the messages from senior management and employees are told this is the way it is and their is nothing we can do about.

review_title: Professional Services
pros:
-great work/life balance
-flexible hours and ability to work from home - what mostly matters is that you get the job done successfully and on time 
-no micro management - there’s a great level of trust 
-much less travel than other consulting firms, depending on your project 
-great opportunities, especially for newer hires, to take ownership of projects and be able to work with C-level execs on customer side
cons:
-SuiteSuccess methodology can make projects seem repetitive due to rigid scope and less creativity required from PS 
-transition from Sales to PS can improve as gaps often come up during delivery, but they’re working on this 
-with NetSuite being such an intricate and robust product, there should be better knowledge sharing resources, e.g. make slack available to the PS team!

review_title: Poor leaders and management. Has learning opportunities but not for long.
pros:
You can get experience in how a big enterprise work and how organized a company can be. 
There is opportunity to learn about highly scaling applications but technically the learning will be stopped in one or two years because no new technology come up.
Very good work life balance. Less stress if you like a relaxed work.
cons:
Leaders are crappy and are at the mercy of the director for deciding even the smallest things. Director is good at bringing work to trivandrum office but is not good at his approach to employees. Very judgemental and discouraging. Plays crappy games with  employees. 
HR is non functional and very confused. When some issue arises, they don't know how to solve it in a good way and always try to favour the management, even when the employee has a valid point. Unless escalated, HR never hustles for the employee.

review_title: Oracle's work culture problems - too many middle managers who do nothing
job_title: Senior Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Very large company and there are many opportunities to try different things.   for those starting out in technology or are early in their career, the opportunities are endless.  Great benefits, great training availability.
cons: Very poor management and leadership.  Promotions handed out more due to seniority than competency.  Poor work culture, too political.  Successful careers are identified with ability to expand and build your empire, which forces ambitious and motivated people to emulate those activities rather than build competencies to be truly successful in a new position.  No one ever gets fired or reprimanded for failure, which there is alot of at Oracle.  Dates are always missed, people are not held accountable.

review_title: Join us only if you have no other Option.
job_title: Senior Principal Consultant in Jacksonville, FL
pros:
You are working with a Product Company,  they make the product, the sell the product, they support the product. 
This gives you unlimited product exposure. There is no limit to the training Programs one can take.
cons:
Favourism, Favourism and Favourism
as long as u r good pal's with your manager's, you would go long way. 
No Ethics, Money Talks, the company would not want to loose a single penny on you.
The day you are on bench and the quarter is bad you are out of the company. Live's
in todays $$$$'s no long term investement on its employees. There are no standards followed 
when it comes to Promotions or Appraisals or Bonus time, it is the managers who decide. 
so if you are a good pal of your manager you grow.

review_title: Stable but Uninspiring for the Masses
job_title: Senior Director in Redwood City, CA
pros: Well managed company with a huge reach in its customer's IT organziations that offers a wide range of products and roles.   Offers its senior managers competitive comp and freedom and good work / life balance for many mid and junior level roles
cons: Don't come to Oracle expecting to drive innovation or rapid advancement.   For mid level and senior managers it's a highly political, surivial-of-the-fittest environment.   For individual contributors you need to rely on a good manager to look after you.  Raises and bonuses outisde of sales and engineering are rare so make sure you will be happy with your base salary .

review_title: Oracle Direct is a dynamic work environment where change happens overnight. Unfortunately your target is not exempt
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
- International work environment
- Reasonable working hours
- Training is there if you want it
- Some managers are very helpful and enthusiastic about helping you progress
- You can be creative in your work approach in general (although not without limits)
cons:
The organization is not clear on where it is heading, and focus is constantly shifting.
- Targets may change mid-quarter with no warning
- There are no incentives for xLoB cooperation and cross-product competition is abundant
- Some managers are completely disinterested in your personal progression
- Information about changes are generally spread through rumors up until the day the change occurs.

review_title: Don't plan on staying long
pros: Pay is decent, some benefits (for now). A lot of smart people to work with and good networking opportunities.
cons: Plan on staying at the same level and pay as when you are hired, because you will not get a promotion. Even with stellar appraisals from your management and their approval for promotion, it won't happen. There is a serious top down push to cut costs wherever possible and that means your chances of a promotion or raise are slim to none even if your management recommends you for one.  Hurd is bringing over a bunch of his buddies from HP who now run several major orgs and they are implementing the same cost-cutting strategies that brought HP down. Negotiate a good offer up front and don't plan on staying for more than a couple of years if you want to take your career somewhere.

review_title: Oracle Saint-Petersburg development center
job_title: IC3 Software Engineer in Saint Petersburg, Sankt-Peterburg
pros:
I worked for Oracle's department, which was a former Sun Microsystems.
+ Very good working environment (big office, convenient layout)
+ The best management I've ever seen (they could create a very rare type of working culture - they didn't make people work, many people worked 10-12 hours a day just because they really felt a work as a part of life).
+ Very skilled colleagues. Here one could learn many new things (not only about Java).
cons:
- After introducing sanctions against  Russia, Oracle had to start exiting from Russia. This is very bad piece of news for both Oracle and Russia.
- As a big company, it was very difficult to grow in Oracle, it was easier to quit and came to new position, than grow.

review_title: Programmer Analyst 2
job_title: Programmer Analyst II in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros: Good salary, one of the best environment to work, people is very welcoming, up to certain point being part of a self service company helps you a lot.
cons: Depends on the role you end. I am part of a HIGHLY visible team with extended rota and weekend support. It can be exhausting as we didnt get paid for the extra days, we did get comp-off days and expensed meals but the workload was just TOOmuch to handle. If you end up being part of the top performers of your team the  you can say goodbye to your free time, you will not get a life-work balance and moving to another team is almost impossible as management wont let you go. Might as well start at a new company.

review_title: Oracle Cloud
job_title: Senior Cloud Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros:
Nice buildings to work in
Downtown Seattle is fun and exciting
High salaries due to competition with Amazon for bodies - but it won't last much longer.
cons:
Staffing is overwhelmed and unprepared for what they are trying to do.
Way too much overhead in the form of corporate processes and policies
Run like a Bank versus a startup that needs to be dynamic
Way too many former Amazon people - its cut-throat environment cannot sustain itself for long and not have complete anarchy.
There are published "values" for employees - however, its obvious you are rewarded for doing the exact opposite and screwing over your co-workers is endorsed and appreciated at all costs. 
Cannibalism is a daily way of life

review_title: Company Review
pros: Very large company with lots of networking opportunities and professional development . Company is well known, and provides good individual growth and career training.  Great work life balance, and employee benefits. There is opportunity to work with great logos, and often your products sell well and have strong market presence.  Fantastic opportunity to develop and opens doors for your career.
cons: Experienced lots of changes in roles, account territories, teams, and management in a short period of time. Difficult to receive salary promotions due to bureaucracy.  Loss of confidence in senior leadership and lack of role stability. Management can easily make you dispensable, and your salary does not reflect the revenue contributions you make, or your market value. Your leadership collects your paycheck, and often new hires that you train make a lot more then you.

review_title: Oracle offers good work/life balance
job_title: Senior Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Oracle offers reasonable compensation and a great benefits package.  The culture is extremely supportive of flexible work situations and many people work a fair portion of their time remotely.  If you're looking for a good work/life balance and flexibility in your work situation, this may be a good place to look.   Also, with a large corporation such as Oracle, there are numerous opportunity to move around within the organization and gain experience in different areas.
cons: Oracle can be extremely political and competitive at higher levels of the organization.  In general, the focus is on managing up, rather than trying to develop and grow talent people.  Also, because it is a large organization, bureaucracy and slowness to act can be frustrating at times.

review_title: Oracle has been a great place to work.
job_title: Principal Technical Support Engineer in Orlando, FL
pros:
The best reason to work at oracle are the people.  There is a very good work dynamic here and the office politics really are at a minimum.
The benefits are very comparable to the industry in general.
cons:
Very rarely do you hear from the happy customers.  That is just the nature of the beast really, but it can drag on you after a time.
Once you've gotten to the 3 weeks of vacation time per year, that is it forever.  This really needs to be changed/updated.

review_title: "Oracle - Intense, fragmented and Brand-driven"
pros: i believe that Oracle is a good place to sharpen skills around pursuit, sales, quarterly target management, account planning, people sales.  Oracle provides ample networking opportunities at events like NAS, Open World events globally and through a myriad of industry events.   The Oracle brand is one that employees feel empowered to stand behind - the brand alone provides a sense of pride and strength in approaching most situations.
cons: Oracle is an intense working environment that puts the success of the company/unit and the individual at a "no-holds barred" situation.  It is sales at all (or nearly all costs) without regard to strategy, direction, future success.  Oracle has way too many dimensions that confuses partners, customers and to a certain degree Oracle's internal employees.  Back office operations are fragmented due to the sheer size and geographic spread of business that Oracle maintains.

review_title: Never put in less than a 50 hour week.

If they want you to transfer to another location they expect you to pay your own moving costs eventhough they are transferring you. review_title: Excellent Company to work with !!
pros: Freedom, flexibility, work-life balance, good corporate culture, friendly environment, mid-night snacks for night shift employees & breakfast for employees who work before 8 AM for free of cost, free cab facilities for night shift employees plus they provide the conveyance allowance & awesome brand to work for. Gained a lot of knowledge & wider scope is available for all the processes. I enjoyed working for Oracle and until the politics appeared I did not had an intention to quit but to retire in the company :)

review_title: It was great, until it wasn't
job_title: Customer Support Analyst in Columbia, MD

Managers consistently fell through on providing wisdom and knowledge about the products, as well as their own job descriptions. Employees are under-appreciated, unmotivated, and with their lack of support, unwelcome.

review_title: Growing too fast and hiring too young!
pros:
The growth brings opportunity. Best in class acquisitions. 
Great benefits.

.

review_title: Did you want your commission?
job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Redwood City, CA
pros: Great benefits and that's about it.
cons: Too many to list! How about they change your comp plan and pay you out and then change it back and illegally retro it back to the beginning of the year and have you pay it all back. Then management tells you to consider it an interest free loan.  The finance comp people say its not their problem and HR is useless. Who does that? Oh Oracle does and that's when you sell their outdated products.  And then they replace you with college hires for half that price and they leave after a year and they go after their signing bonus's. Shady place! All the quota earners were pushed out. Great sales management!

review_title: Life in the endless support lane
job_title: Principal Consultant in Bainbridge Island, WA
pros: You get to download all the Oracle products you could ever want and see the inside comments on everything from bugs to support tkts. If you're lucky you might work with top nonche talent. Some of the hotels they let you stay at are really nice.
cons: Lower pay, Not very transparent mgt, even when discovered they don't seem to commit to personal growth and resolving issues. Lots of dead weight not very tech current staffers that have zero customer focus (like saying get on the next flight out if customer wanted to look into something not covered service plan which selected by sales by mistake) doing the same thing for last x yrs and haven't sold anything during that time.

review_title: Sr. Regional Sales Manger
pros: As a market leader in their core database product line, Oracle offers an excellent opportunity for learning how to sell in a cross matrix organization to the highest level of executives at the largest organizations in the world.  The learning curve is fantastic.
cons: The internal culture is highly competitive and too much of your time is spent "internally networking" in order to assure that your externally facing sales / account management efforts are not undermined by your own colleagues calling on the same account.

review_title: Strategic Sales
job_title: Applications Sales Manager in New York, NY

review_title: Not bad. Really depends on your group and manager

review_title: Sadly, HR Canada is incented to downsize.

review_title: Cloud Account Manager
job_title: Cloud Account Manager in Burlington, MA

Transactional - Oracle truly does not care about their customers - "just close a deal". review_title: Oracle as a career  support analyst
pros:
With a wide range of product offerings and technical challenges of integrating within internal and acquired companies, Oracle has opportunities to experience and learn. 
Many times customers and consultants push the envelope of existing Oracle technology to address their business needs. As a result, the analyst is placed in very interesting political scenarios between the customer and development's ability to address that precise need. Often times workarounds become part of the product where some are not - thus an unsupported customization may be necessary.
cons: Huge queues, limited scope of analyst involvement in resolving the customer's real problem, sometimes very long resolution times due to lack of development staff or availability.

review_title: More improvements needed  in order to make a successful and productive hub in KL!
job_title: Business Development Associate in Kuala Lumpur
pros:
-Flexible working hour (depends on your team managers)
-Excellent coaching & training team within and from across the borders.
-Good benefits packages for employees.
-New & cozy working space that anyone able to enjoy your stressful workday.
cons:
-Leadership team's goal and objective is very vague.
-Fast hiring but was not really a qualified hiring I would assume as many struggled to stay in the position for even a year.
-Talent retention is NOT a key drive count for the management to sustain healthy and productive employee system. Simply, only result oriented.
-Commission/Bonus payout is very disappointing as payout was not according to what was promised. It has many hidden agenda to it which was totally undisclosed during hiring.

review_title: Not Employee-Friendly
pros: Oracle is a stable company.  Many refined processes that mostly work.  They are quick to pay expenses and the employees are great people.  Work-from-home is widely acceptable.  Benefits are good.  I enjoyed what I did and the people I worked with so I stayed until a reduction in force push me and many other experienced people out.  It happens.
cons: Oracle is not an employee-friendly company.  It is very clear that the company is in business for the major stockholders.  They have many rules and strict policies that employees most follow.  Creativity and outspokenness is not rewarded.  Bonuses were not paid for a few years (it may have changed), pay increases were minimal and far between.  Promotions were difficult to get approved.  Generally, the priorities are Oracle first, then customers, then employees.

review_title: Only for On campus recruitees & people above 35!!
pros:
good work/life balance
It is a good company to work for a couple of years if you are selected on campus
It is a good company to work if you have more than 35 years and looking for a company to retire
cons:
But I wont recommend it for experienced people. Once you are in you must be ready to live with the same salary and position. Work will be monotonous. You will be outdated with a technology that is not updated for 10 years. You might gain in depth product knowledge but nothing that is related with latest technologies.

It has been three years since we got hikes and promotions. Though attrition is increasing, management has no concerns about employee morale. Management is focusing only on acquiring other companies and investing cash into acquisition instead of existing employees.

There is no fixed cycle for promotion/hikes. Depends on the senior management which means we will never get it.

Salary is equal to other companies like TCS, CTS Accenture. But at least in these companies you will have onsite oppurtunities.

review_title: The beast continues to grow
pros:
oracle can be described as a stable company acquiring interesting technology and strategically placed in fortune 1000 companies.
There are individuals that consistently contribute to the company's success, but management as a whole does nothing to foster that spirit and there is a clear lack of "global message" combined with a strategy to move towards this message other than in sales. 
This makes sense because one of the corporate cultural traits is that it is $$$ driven and that aligns well with those in sales but is inconsistent when positioned against other espoused "corporate values" such as innovation, customer service, return-on-investment....
cons:
fractured identity depending where one is from (acquisition wise)
fractured ownership of customer (is it sales? consulting? support? other?)
middle management is not empowered to make strategic decisions
bureaucracy

review_title: Awesome place to work
job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Solid brand behind you which in sales is important.  The sales training is second to none.  Oracle does it right when it comes to training their sales team to be successful.  Perks and benefits are great which is what you should expect with a company of this size.  Sr. Management team is approachable and open to honest and constructive dialogue.
cons: Very process driven.  And by process... I mean process.... there are, at times meetings to discuss what we are going to cover in later meetings....  you'll become the managing director for all directors and managers in the department of redundancy department.  However, if you learn how to maneuver the processes.... cake walk...
