review_title: Great company in its day
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Menlo Park, CA
pros: If you love technology, Sun was a great place to work.  There was an engineering culture second to none, and you got the experience of working for a company that understood that when you make the market bigger, that benefits you.  It's seen as a failure now, but really was just playing a longer game than the market had tolerance for.
cons: Politics.  Insane politics.  The California side of the company - particularly the non-technical management - was more like kindergarteners bashing each other in the head with rocks.  Getting pulled into someone's office for them to try to enlist you in helping get their boss fired so they could take his job happened to me.  Just awful.

review_title: Acquired and Left to Flounder
pros:
- Enjoy working with my co-workers
- Flexible work/life balance
- Management within our office attempts to maintain morale and culture
cons:
- No promotions or raises through 2 cycles of reviews throughout our office (after being acquired)
- Furlough of our PTO to save money, then 41% raises for CEOs are announced
- Internal tools are dated, riddled with bugs, do not meet needs
- External tools are taken away for inadequate internal replacements
- "Self-service" tools and mentality leaves employees with no IT support or assistance
- Bureaucracy, internal process, and legal hoops make it impossible to accomplish anything in a timely manner

review_title: A company you will always miss if you leave it.
pros: No restrictions on employees of any kind, you can work from office or from home. You are never denied leaves. People at senior/architect level are some of the most talented in industry. Job Security. Good HR policies, Good managers.
cons:
Low salaries, no or low increments. Technology used in some projects (ADF n SOA) is not much popular outside, If you stuck in any of such project as developer you will find it hard to switch if you want to move on at some point of time. No on-site opportunity if you are a developer or QA, people in implementation teams may get onsite.
Hiring process is becoming lenient, Budget allocated to Application projects is low so salary offered to new hired employee is also low, Its also one of the reason of not much talent being hired on lateral hiring.

review_title: Run as fast as you can
job_title: Financial Analyst in San Antonio, TX
pros: The only pros about this place was the co-workers. Aside from them making the place bearable, the only perk was leaving at 4 since you had no work.
cons: Unfortunately, you get absolutely NOTHING to do. Imagine sitting in a cubicle for 8 hours a day starring at a wall and that's your job at oracle. They do not train you at all and really push learning everything on your own, which is not efficient. They also tell you (after hire) that you will not move up or increase your salary for the first three years. If you have absolutely no motivation to work or move up in your career then oracle is the place for you! During my time at Oracle 5 people out of 12 team members quit in under a year... that goes to show just how awful the place really is.

review_title: Cobblers' children have no shoes
pros: I work with a nice bunch of people, and if you live west of London the location is not bad.  Good canteen, good training possibilities and the benefits / pension package is quite good.  I've not been there long enough to know whether the career opportunities are any good.
cons: Coming from a contractor position, the money was a big cut.  But what irritates me more is the fact that Oracle is quite tight.  My team are all developers, but they won't buy us decent laptops, and they won't pay to send us business class when we fly to California for work.  Then there are the sclerotic business processes which slow everyone down - probably typical of large organisations.

review_title: Good place to hang out, not grow
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood City, CA
pros:
*Large stable company, infrequent layoffs.
*Good gym
*If you are comfortable pushing back and saying no, you can have pretty good work-life balance.
*Comprehensive (but expensive) health plan options including dental and vision.
*Very good 401k options. 
*Flexible hours and remote work available depending on manager
cons:
*Although benefits are decent, monetary compensation is laughable. Don't expect raises, bonuses, or stock unless you have an exceptional manager willing to fight for you or you want to work startup hours for half startup pay.
*Not many options for working with new technologies. Oracle innovates by acquiring.
*Experience can vary wildly depending on your manager.
*Limited lactation room options (HQ) with terrible scheduling system.

review_title: Good company with a few unethical practices
pros:
Worked here for three years.
1. Work life balance is good.
2. Co workers are good and knowledgeable.
3. Office politics are limited.
cons:
1. You may need to work more than eight hours based on offshore-onshore model.
2. Violates terms of labour market check for 457 and 482 visa in consultancy area. Though a lot of advertisements are given, but hardly anyone is hired from Australia in consulting field. I believe offshore workers are cheaper, which is the prime reason behind it and some other companies like TCS, CTS, Wipro etc does similar false job advertisements. While Australian workers in my experience are equally or better skilled, but cost is always a concern for Oracle.

review_title: No longer relevant
pros: Oracle is in almost every company and a known entity.  The DB and apps are standards for enterprises all over the world.  Best reps make extraordinary money.
cons: Oracle has a huge push into the cloud.  The SaaS apps reps can do well, but most of the customers have been punished by Oracle sales practices and will now select other vendors.  Reps are viewed as extremely replaceable and no one is valued by the company.  LE is putting everything into cloud, but the IaaS battle is over and Oracle is irrelevant.  DB and MW are getting viable alternatives and the Oracle apps for current enterprise is the only area of growth.

review_title: Place that could be GREAT!
pros:
The availability to work with great knowledgeable people and solutions.. 
People on the majority are nice to deal with. Technology is leading edge.
cons:
If you don't work in Sales or HQ you will have very little chance to climb the ladder.
There is a lot of separation among teams, if you have to work with an other team not associated with yours there is a lot of politics you have to go through.
The review process is a joke.. Oracle just does it to make themselves look good and there upper managers sleep well at night.
Even though Oracle posted great numbers there is no bonus, or raise.
Getting a promotion entails allot of politics and longevity.

review_title: Great place to work for free.. :)
pros:
Nice place to work
you build a good social network 
lots to learn on the technology front
some of the Sr Mgmt are very good
work life balance is good
cons:
Compensation & Bonus .. Horrible..    Bonus is like a drop in the ocean & Salary Hikes .. Dont ask..  New joinees are paid higher than existing employees. 

Sometimes, money is wasted on unnecessary trainings just because they dont know what to do with that budget. 

Job is secure as long as it is not automated.. .:p..  

Management is living a retired life with fat pay checks ( An early pension for them)

review_title: Very rewarding; however, exhaustive and high pressure
job_title: Applications Sales Manager in Chicago, IL
pros:
Top brand - Great products and market strategy, recognized as leader
Very talented staff and supporting cast
Limitless pillars of solutions provide endless options for expanding knowledge base and career paths
Good compensation and great benefits
Strong marketing engine and resources to support sales effort
Overall - great place you can be proud to work that adds strong market-ability / value to career
cons:
Lots of red tape - lengthy processes and approval chains
Very demanding upper management with mixed level of appreciation
Micro management of activities - lots of reporting and baby sitting
Often battle or have to sell internally more than with customer / prospect
Territories assignments constantly changing

review_title: Great Pay - High Demands
pros: As an organization, Oracle is a highly competitive and dynamic place to work.  From a sales perspective, Oracle compensates it's salespeople very well, with the opportunity to not only receive commissions on "net new" sales, but also on sales generated by the "inside sales" organization.
cons: Oracle is a very "process" oriented company, with little or no room for creativity in the sales cycle.  Managing the internal sales processes is extremely time consuming and cumbersome, often requiring as much time &/or work effort as managing the external sales process itself.  This cumbersome process can negatively affect the pace of the sales cycle and slow down the closing.

review_title: My experience has been very satisfying
pros:
quantum of work is what is humanely possible. If because of some reason it is not, you would be told so by the management that this particular project is estimated aggressively to eliminate competition etc. And when you are stretching to get the work done, leadership is aware of this.
That typical attitude of software companies where they push managers to make people stay longer is quite less.
cons: The people management during 2008 crisis was handled very badly. The company lost its human face and yet did not save substantially in terms of salaries.

review_title: Overpromise, Underdeliver, and blame the people at the bottom
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
- Rapaciously aggressive sales force that is pushed to promise anything to anyone for a buck keeps the pipeline full
- As an industry standard DB, it keeps everyone's technical abilities up to speed
- Good health insurance available (for now)
cons:
- no salary increases/bonuses for years
- very little commitment by management for operational delivery, issues of responsibility or delivery can be unaddressed forever.  Always time for "hair on fire" let's finally get some customer's issues addressed, absolutely no time to figure out why that always happens
- lots of responsibility pushed down the management chain with absolutely no way for those at the bottom to affect any change or deliver what the customer expects.  Which ends up with a lot of "it is some other team's fault" situations

review_title: If your in sales and you don't care about anyone except yourself then Oracle is for you.
pros: There's good training and you learn what not to do to motivate you employees.
cons:
All the usual , bureacratic, lone wolf environment, no one cares about each other. extremely negative sales atmosphere. incompetent management. Hire experienced  and intelligent highly motivated people and proceed to mismanage them by treating the like misbehaving children so they are unmotivated by the atmosphere of complete disinterest.
Lying about job aspects, sales cycle lengths and market potential made me quit very quickly.

review_title: Tough Place
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: It's a big company with a lot of opportunity, smart people, and enormous market penetration. Working at HQ is pretty deluxe, with a lovely campus, numerous and diverse cafes, a well-equipped fitness center including a pool, and now the 90' racing trimaran that won The America's Cup parked in our own pond. If you do you job quietly and thoroughly you can stay as long as you want.
cons: It's a fear-based, soul-sucking, cheapskate organization that squashes ambition, derides creative thinking, and encourages compliance. You spend much of your time managing upward. Quite frequently we are directed to follow through on ineffective or meaningless solutions because an executive mandated it. There is an unaccountable pattern of self-loathing within the company such that they're willing to support tepid ideas from outside (often through acquisition) rather than strong ideas from within. Worst of all, there are no raises or bonuses, and very little encouragement.

review_title: Great Experience, Political and Competitive
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Austin, TX
pros: Very good benefits, starting salary is hard to beat, and the opportunity to move up is competitive but possible if you are on track and constantly exceeding your quota. You gain a lot of experience talking with Executives all over the country.
cons: The culture is built to weed out anyone who isn't doing amazing. The leaders manage by fear and will try and make you quit rather than help you get better if you aren't doing well. if you don't know about something, there is no one to give you an answer. You have to research the answer which makes for a constant gray area.

review_title: Sales Rep Review
pros:
Good medical insurance
Good 401(k) - 6% match
Good base pay for an entry level
Young, fun people to work with (except mgmt)
cons:
Commission is very low
High execs are basically worshipped (i.e. Expected to work late when CEO came to town, and never even saw him. No overtime pay of course.)
Management breathing down the necks of employees
Cannot be flexible in time in the office (strict 8:30-5:30). You can't do (8-5)
Expected to work after-hours with no pay
Reps who have a few accounts are still expected to make the same number of dials as people who have 200+
Virtual team does not want to share information with you
Most customers hate Oracle, and don't want to talk to you. This makes it hard for you to hit your quota. 
Internal systems and approvals take too long and makes customer impatient. 

Neither pros or cons: 90% of the people I know are looking for another job.

review_title: Large company with many processes
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Large company with many great products and very smart people. The company is constantly growing both both internally and thru large acquisitions (Peoplesoft, Sun Microsystems, etc).
cons: Due to the size of the company and based on the controlling personality of the CEO, there are a lot of layers of management and approval processes to get even the simplest task completed. Nearly every decision needs to be reviewed and approved by the CEO office. Things that should be completed in hours or days sometimes takes weeks and months forcing customers to wait or leave but it did not seem to matter to executive management.

review_title: Consistently profitable, very uncomfortable for employees
pros: Consistent profitability, significant bonus potential for sales technical staff.
cons: Highly political, and no one who works here feels confident of staying employed.  If you (or your team) does not perform 100% then you're gone. Zero loyalty to even long-time employees. Internal procedures and infrastructure are horrendous  - confusing, poorly explained/documented and 100% company-focused.  Internal IT is hopelessly understaffed and is seldom helpful when employees need help.

review_title: Big name, big pain points
job_title: Email and Web Developer in Seattle, WA
pros: Wonderful team, huge brands to contribute to, great office location, awesome place to learn and be taught your craft, solid benefits, and the work life balance was good.
cons: Every pitfall that accompanies working for such a large corporation exits here, and is exacerbated due to Oracle's sheer size. It's very hard to get a raise, your role is very rigidly defined, the bottom line will always come before employee satisfaction, and getting anything through the bureaucracy takes way too much time and projects really suffer because of it. It's the same with interviews and employment offers, the process is unbelievably slow. It's ridiculous, and I'd had enough.

review_title: Good Company, but Pays/Hikes not competitive with the market, though it is Big MNC!!
pros:
1. Good Work-Life Balance
2. Typical Product focused company
3. A very big MNC having Offices in all over the world
4. Many employee engagement activities (Fun, sports/games, cultural events..etc)
5. WFH options for the many teams/BUs based on Manager's approvals
6. Many Training Programs conducted by internal and external people
7. Chance to work with Multi-Cultural/regional People
8. Free Gym
cons:
1. Pay is not competitive with Market.
2. Large difference / Inconsistencies in pay for the same experienced people for the same job profiles. Also, less pay when compared with newly joined people - even though they are less experienced for the same job profile.
2. Slow development, not much challenging work.
3. No Hike/Less Hike.
4. No Transport (Only MMTS Shuttles and Home drop cabs are only from 8pm)
5. No free lunch

review_title: Good company to work for, but a lot of bureaucracy
job_title: Implementation Consultant II in Columbia, MD
pros: Good pay, excellent benefits (the health insurance is great!), and a very conducive environment to learning. I also can work full-time remote rather than having to relocate to go to an office. I am also salary with overtime.
cons: Travel is a requirement, sometimes for long periods of time. The bureaucracy is a mess. Nothing ever moves quickly, and the overhead is tremendous. On-boarding took months after getting hired, and the hiring process itself took months. Although I have not yet qualified for a raise, I have heard through the grapevine they are far and few between (however, again, this has not been vetted by me personally).

review_title: Principal Consultant
job_title: Principal Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good benefits, 401k matching, decent pay, good perks for corporate employees.  Some opportunity for advancement if you are in the right place at the right time and you know the right people.  Good place to build a resume but few are truly satisfied with long term.
cons: No emphasis on work/life balance, forced to work nights and weekends with no compensation. Denied vacation. Only 3 weeks paid per year.  Denied  consulting bonus' due to poor management choices.  Any cool local perks are not available if you are a consultant.  Promotions are not tied to more pay, you get the title and more work but no additional pay.

review_title: The worst mistake one can ever commit by joining the Solution Engineering Team at Oracle
pros:
Good Pay
WFH only verbal
Cab Facilities
Broadband
Telephone Bills
cons:
Before joining the HR have mentioned about work from work policy, but believe me there is nothing like WFH after you have joined the Solution Engineering Team.
The job role "Solution Engineering " is a very nice way to warp up the Pre Sales Activity. If you come from a Development backgroud , I would request you never to join the Solution Engineering Team.  The management is really bad and does not care about employees.you just have to impress your management by doing some stupid work which does not even make sense.
Micro management is everywhere.Few people in senior managemnet are like leeches.
They will mention too high variable pay sometimes upto 35% , but belive me you will not even get 20% of what your variable in  CTC says. If you want good varaible be ready to lick your manager's ....

review_title: Oracle - The name says it all !
pros:
I am a full time employee of Oracle's Financial GBU i.e. OFSS.

1. Good company to join as Fresher for the brand tag.
2. Good learning opportunities in Financial Domain.
3. Exposure to both technical and functional side of a product (in my case Flexcube) as an Associate Consultant.  
4. Team members are ever helpful.
5. Onsite opportunities if you are in the right team at the right time (most opportunities in Middle East and Africa teams).
6. Lot of time to utilize to learn own subjects when not particularly engaged in work, without scrutiny.
cons:
I would like to list out some cons that I have observed.

1.  Very less hikes (expect single digit hike after working for >2years)
2. Very long appraisal cycle (it takes months to reflect the hike).
3. Management not to keen on frequent face-2-face interactions.
4. Employee benefits are less.

review_title: Worst Job Ive Ever Had
pros: Free drinks, and Starbucks available
cons: This is the worst job I've ever had. Lack of goals for sales, wage discrimination for women and black people. Management quitting left and right, micromanagers, frequent layoffs. They also want us to continue stalking customers even after they've said NO! The customers hate the products. Management tries to make your job seem more important than it is because they have managers they also report to.  I'm constantly talked down to even though I'm the smartest person on the team. All they do is hire rich college kids from top schools so they don't have to pay them a decent wage. High turnover with the college kids once they figure out the gimmick. Lack of communication within departments and if you report someone for racism, HR does NOTHING about it. This company is going downhill and wont be able to keep up with other tech companies. Also a complete lack of diversity.

review_title: NetSuite Professional Services
pros:
-Work life balance
-Co-workers are great and willing to help 
-Ability to work from wherever, flexible work hours 
-Benefits are pretty good, unlimited sick days 
-Development program for new grads is an excellent opportunity to learn and make an impact right away
cons:
-Lack of support from manager, as they have over 50 direct reports each on my team
-Not much collaboration on projects 
Strict utilization targets are difficult to attain considering vacation and zero control over project timeline
-Implementation gaps come up often and are not easy to handle 
-Many customers are not fit for the methodology that NetSuite sells, resulting in unhappy customers
-Many people are leaving the company, morale is low

review_title: Counter-Productive Internal culture
job_title: Outside Sales Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: You have the ability to make a lot of money here.  There are many potential career paths available similar to any large company.
cons: Sales reps are internally pitted against each other selling "jumpball" products.  This creates a culture where lone wolfs can thrive but team players are put at odds, along with the customer.  Internal processes are extremely slow and cumbersome.  In Oracle's defense, that may be typical of most organizations this size. I haven't worked at enough to be an accurate judge.

review_title: Good for those who believe in self learning.
pros:
- One gets fair amount of time for self learning and the work life balance is inclined more towards life. 
- People are supportive and always willing to help.
cons:
- The tech stack is pretty outdated and might not be helpful when you attempt to switch to another job. 
- Not too many (actual) challenging tasks you will be getting.

review_title: Be very clear what you expect from working with Oracle.
job_title: Senior Technical Writer in San Mateo, CA
pros: As a technical writer, you can learn how to do it right and get the benefits from working with a group a professionals. Because of Oracle's size, you get to do one thing--write, write and write! You write for international audiences using a strict set "doc rules" which include adhering to style guides and templates.  Once that discipline is "under your belt", you're good to work almost anywhere .
cons: Because of the large size of Oracle (do I dare say, you're just a number), in many ways you are more dependent on having a good relationship with your manager. If your manager has minimal skills or simply can't manage, then you're really screwed.

review_title: Oracle is a good large IT company if that's your cup of tea
job_title: Principal Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Large, stable company. Good benefits and culture. Leadership communicates well and often. Even in a downer economy, Oracle is still producing good numbers for the Street. The flexible culture allows good hours and work from home or telecommuting. There's good lateral movement opportunities, and given how many companies Oracle buys, you have a decent chance to switch compentencies or area of expertise if you choose to go after it as such. Co-workers vary with the group you are in but are generally effective and smart. The area of growth now is Asia, and there are plenty of good opportunities there.
cons: Can get lost in the size and employee pool. The management structure setup is highly complex and often I find groups of employees working on similar or relevant areas unaware. The knowledge share competency could be improved.

review_title: Part of the Sales organization.
pros: Great people working in sales but many are leaving.
cons:
Salary not competitive in my area, 
Oracle deciding at their discretion to NOT pay commissions on large transaction to sales people
To much time spent forecasting.  Twice a week.  Once on a spread sheet then on the CRM system.  
Not enough time to sell.  
Order system over engineered.

review_title: Good place to work, learn critical skills
pros:
Oracle offers many opportunities to create a diverse skill set, over time. Since job descriptions are very focused and narrow, it does take awhile to spread yourself around and learn. But they are there.
Your colleagues genuinely are some of the smartest you will encounter. This is a fine opportunity to develop a wide and diverse network of peers.
In general, the compensation packages are good and fair; with a number of obvious outliers thrown amongst.
In this environment, you are constantly asked to achieve higher goals, to stretch.
cons:
Because of the environment of heavy hitters, even the most accomplished will find it hard to stand out. Only the truly driven will thrive.
It's a big company, and while entrepreneurship is encouraged, it truly is at times maddeningly difficult to have your ideas break through the "big process" mentality.
There are a lot of people here who have fallen into the "I'm just a cog" mentality.

review_title: Heading in the Wrong Direction
pros:
Oracle still has a broad range of great technology.
There are many opportunities to do Interesting work.
The company still has lots of smart, hard working people, though fewer than there used to be.
cons: This is a company headed in the wrong direction. They missed the boat on cloud and are now playing catch up. The general attitude of executive management is that everyone can be replaced. This means that raises, corporate bonuses, promotions are nearly non-existent. It also means that fear-based management has taken hold and that sociopaths are rewarded. Cost cutting, beyond the point of diminishing returns, is the order of the day. Mark Hurd is doing to Oracle what he did to HP.

review_title: REALLY Depends on Group
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Sacramento, CA
pros: Good benefits, looks great on the resume
cons:
Management plays a major role in how much one enjoys one's time at Oracle. I've heard from other employees that moved into an entirely different group how much better and more enjoyable their time in the company is. However, my group is one that compels employees (but not managers) to be in the office, forcing them to move from HQ in some cases or lose their jobs. They will allow working remotely but it better be on a rare occasion. 
There is almost no internal promotion and they do not really provide one many skills to improve. The jobs pay decently and the benefits are good but they would rather have all the procedures automated if it were up to them and not bother with training. Everything's all about the process and not valuing individuals for their contributions.

review_title: Netsuite: Your success companion!
job_title: Accounting ERP Senior Technical Support Specialist in Makati City
pros: NetSuite is the best company to be engaged with. They do not hire people to be their mere employee but instead they hire with the view of investing and enriching their human resource. They'll equip you and invest on you from Day 1 of your employment. They offer the perfect work-life balance culture with both weekends off, a very competitive salary of which is totally unexpected, an impressive list of benefits from Meal, Medical, Dental, Optical, Retirement, Life Insurance and many more, a perfect work environment, it’s everyone’s dream company. If you are looking for a stable company to offer long-term partnership, you should work here! NetSuite is the company where you want to grow old with. This company provides you the competitive edge of advancing in your field of expertise while enjoying your job.
cons: As of the moment, undoubtedly none so far.

review_title: Applications Sales Manager
pros: Name recognition is a help at times   Pay can be good. But it's spotty
cons: Too big, gets in its own way. Management though is by far among the worst I have ever seen. Known harassment cases against women and oracle is not firing them all the good people who started oracle marketing cloud left. New management that came in are forecast jockeys. Could not put any of these people in front of a customer and have it be a help. Load and loads of unnecessary work. For example- if you wNt to book a plane ticket you need to go through three levels of approval before you are cleared to go. Second- Lots of resources ( like SCs) are overbooked and unreliable. Very difficult to get a deal done at oracle. Every rep I know is stressed beyond belief.

review_title: At Oracle, only money matters
pros: If you get a boost working for a place that's always making tons of money, Oracle is a great place to be.  If you don't really get a contact high from the numbers on SEC 10-K reports, then maybe not.  Oracle makes lots of money, but tends to not share it with the employees too much.
cons: Directives to management include things like "you may not give an employee a raise and a bonus in the same year".  Bonuses were always pretty slim anyway.  All compensation are predicated on new college hire staying less than 3 years and then they're out.  Mostly you don't need much experience to get to "principal" (level 4) and then it's really difficult to get to level 5.  It used to affect vacation, but Oracle now has "unlimited (with manager approval)" vacation, so better hope you have a decent manager.

review_title: Oracle Data Cloud
pros: The Oracle Data Cloud is collecting a lot of great technology companies that should be the back bone of online marketing. The compensation is generally good.
cons: The management is failing upward. They are constantly putting "leaders" in charge of products they don't understand. The ODC does not understand enterprise relationships so they seem to miss the mark on how to engage clients. The people in charge of strategy for core products don't actually know the product, the industry and how clients see it. It is embarrassing.  There is no formal review process so no one is evaluated on their performance. The people who move up do based on who they know and clearly not on what they know.

review_title: Stay away - Miserable & soul destroying
pros: Getting paid out when you leave.
cons: The company is absolutely miserable and soul destroying.  It is a huge bureaucracy ruled only by lawyers and bean counters.  The company treats employees like idiots.  The IT systems are so antiquated the 1960's would be a huge leap forward.  There are constant layoffs, off-shoring and down skilling.  One moment they have a love fest, the next moment massive layoffs.  Our customers absolutely hate us.  The products and services we provide are mediocre to poor.  The business model appears purely to buy something decent then run it into the ground.  Politics and favoritism are the basis of senior management decision making.  The company is struggling as the revenues dry up as customers move to other modern companies.

review_title: Provided me with flexibility I needed as a working mum with young kids
job_title: Solution Consulting Manager in London, England
pros: Enabled me to work from home when needed, I could buy extra holiday ever year, offered onsite nursery
cons: still run by "boys club" - senior management needs to change, too many that have a comfortable position. You feel like a number - not feeling of wanting to invest in employees. Commissions and variable pay were always being reduced - max exodus of employees and mid-level management during 6 years I worked there frustrated with how they were being treated - promotions should be on merit and the work you have done, not because you haven't been in a role for +2yrs

review_title: Don't stay long. Else you can't go out later.
pros:
Good work life balance.
In general people are friendly.
Most of the people would be working here since the beginning of their careers and they are experts in what they are doing.
cons:
Primitive technology stack especially in fusion families. 

If you want to explore latest open source technology stacks and keep up to date in the market, then stay a hundred miles away from Oracle (fusion teams especially). You get dragged down into ADF and Jdeveloper combo, which is a black hole and you spend days in debugging what this framework is doing internally.
They give a good hike when you join which makes the existing eligible employees depressed as they might not have seen a hike in 3-4 years and they can't move out as they are not prepared as per market standards.

review_title: a cog in the wheel of a fast moving tractor trailer
pros: Oracle is a stable profitable company with a good brand and reputation. The company offers excellent benefits package and fair compensation. Many office locations with a global presence and customers everywhere around the world provide ample opportunities to travel. A diverse set of product lines in many business units provide many opportunities to move to different areas of interest, although employees are required to stay with a job for at least a year.
cons: Promotions to leadership positions tend to be bestowed upon those with the best social networks and not necessarily to the most skilled individuals. Most employees do not receive bonuses, stock, or stock option compensation for good performance. Oracle's size and market capitalization leaves little room for out sized growth.

review_title: Great place to work, but you won't get rich here unless you are at the top.
job_title: Senior Principal Support Engineer in Orlando, FL
pros:
- Great work environment
- Dedicated and loyal employees
- Reasonably good benefits for hourly employees
- Work-from-home available to most employees
- Sharing ideas is encouraged
cons:
- Bonuses only paid to salaried employees.  Most employees are hourly
- Execs continue to receive excessive salaries and bonuses
- Compensation for hourly employees remains stagnant for long periods of time.
- Hourly pay often lags behind competitors
- Internal process changes occur so often it is difficult to learn one before moving to the next

review_title: Unbelievably bad
pros: Were it not for the Flexible hours, and the ability to work from home or pretty much anywhere there would be no Pros
cons: Hard to know where to start on this meaty topic.  Aside from the dysfunctional management, long hours, and total lack of information.  Lets add smelly office, brutal office politics and downright favoritism.  Although a small company, there are more 'Chiefs' than Indians since everyone claims a director title.  Combine this with a clueless management who thinks its ok to bully employees as well is demonstrate total lack of ability at every level of the organization.  Additionally, the most clueless are typically promoted upwards.  Here, the higher you go, the more clueless you get.

review_title: it is not bad.
pros: stability in work, very few groups effected by the acquisitions... and all parallel groups are being grown paralley.. Ranges from java developer in tools to application developer,  flexibility to work remotely, move to different groups
cons: too big company, too many procedures., too many templates to fill, can be inefficient. It can be overwelming for new hire.. there is people directory site, which may be of some help, but not completely helpful.. There are lot of inhouse tools, quite close to on market tools, but some differences, will take time to get used.

review_title: overall a good company.
pros: A good company on aspects like work life balance, employee care, global outlook. If you want to work on some cutting edge technologies, Oracle is the place to be. Also you get to work with people from almost all the nationalities in the world. Internal processes are the best.
cons: Not so good from the point of view of career growth. Oracle has grown too big and it works against you in getting proper visibility from the top. Further if you get stuck in a team which owns a not so profitable product, your life is going to be really hard. You will neither get  good hike nor any promotion.

review_title: Boiler Room Atmosphere with Heavy Nepotism and Cronyism
pros: Sales AE's are the center of the universe and the pay is very good if you get a good patch. You are also a leader in the industry and product is known brand. You also have a large bag to carry with a lot of products to sell.
cons: Unfortunately in my territory in California your patch was wholly dependent on who you know and if you are in the "IN" circle. This is regardless of your experience and talent. They hire junior inside slaes people and throw them out to big outside sales territories with no understanding of ERP. No surprise they cycle through a lot of reps - also likely your patch will change every year.

review_title: Stay away unless you have a particular project/group you're joining
job_title: Engineering Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: predictable, hours are flexible, pay is ok, some managers are considerate, good lunch choices (though not free), on-campus gym
cons: It's true that technologies that Oracle buys get no innovation unless it was already bringing in high margins.  There are too many incompetent people at Oracle, whether from cousins and friends being hired or just folks know they can get away with things.  Pay is not commiserate with experience or value to company, but then this is probably true in many companies, but here, PhD folks get hired who can't speak english, end up working on bugs and even then you wonder if they did things right.  Anyhow, if you want to work in a place and feel like you're already retired, this might be for you. If you're looking for energy and innovation.... well, keep looking.

review_title: Eight months at Oracle
job_title: IT Manager in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Like a lot of people I came to Oracle as part of an acquisition.  Folks in Product Engineering seemed happiest and liked their teams. Lots of interesting technology to play with. Company makes money. If you can find a good manager and team, it can be a good place to work.
cons: Very political and hierarchical, people look up your position and decide whether you are important enough to pay attention to. Things are done by firedrill, communication between teams not always good - you get little warning and expected to drop everything.

review_title: Overall a good company,  but needs to get out of the 80s with Management structure
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Good salary and benefits. Good mixture of experience on the floor. Great mixture of products,  but too reliant on auditing and quick to threaten customers when they don't play ball.
cons: Managers and Directors need to stop sucking  up to one another and grow a pair when dealing with UK management. Talking big and trying to out impress each other and then turning into a bunch of spineless Yes men when the UK office has a 'New' idea they want to implement.

review_title: Bittersweet
job_title: Associate Sales Consultant in Redwood City, CA
pros:
- You get to learn what it means to work for a large company
-  Good first job out of college
-  Learn a lot of different sales techniques
-  Exposure to IT technologies
-  Great resume builder
cons:
- Not an inviting environment
- Culture needs to be changed, still running in an 80's environment
- Lot of internal battles with various businesses
- Don't expect any sort of startup perks
- Not a whole guidance by management
- Don't do a great job of incentivizing people to stay
- Don't expect to get paid more if you work hard or any overtime.

review_title: Stable Job
pros:
- job stability
- good benefits, 401k matching
- flex program - you can split your time between working in the office and telecommuting.
- good corporate discounts
- great company matching on charitable donations 
- lots of virtual training opportunities
cons:
- can be frustrating at times adhering to corporate policy and dealing with internal resources.  
- technical policies can restrict which open source projects you can use
- internal software services can sometimes be a bit antiquated, not always up to par with external solutions 
- not really sure how much opportunity there is for career growth here. Haven't seen much promotion from within here.

review_title: Account sales rep 2
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great place to work! Flexible work life balance. Great money! Benefits kick butt!!! If you are put into a good patch you make awesome money. Selling is the easy part of your job. Getting A order document will give you 100 new gray hairs. Systems we use are so outdated and crappy.
cons: Its all about what territory you get on if you will make good money or not. Very much political BS.  I made over 100k my first year but it was all because i was give a awesome territory. It was taken away from me after two years and i was given a horrible territory and i will not be living off  my base.

review_title: Business Development (a mixed experience)
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Burlington, MA
pros:
-Excellent pay
-Great growth opportunities for sales
-Lively atmosphere
-Brand recognition
-Responsive and level-headed management
cons:
-Little  opportunity for movement into non-sales roles
-Massive internal bureaucracy. Can easily feel lost and siloed.
-Huge entry-level cohorts means you can slip through the cracks in terms of development
-Need to have good relationship with sales counterparts to succeed. Can get unlucky with uncooperative sales colleagues.
-Assigned product set can clash with realities of your territory (in my case, I had to sell high-cost SaaS services to small-midsize companies)
-Artificial sense of competition discourages working with team

review_title: Senior Consultant
pros: Work life balance is good as a consultant travelling in Europe - 3 or 4 days on and 1 or 2  days at home.  Bonuses are quarterly, and can be very rewarding - depending on sales performance. Flexible Benefit Point scheme is great to choose what you need that year (I.e. more cash, more holiday or child vouchers). Experienced work force - best of the best. Get to know everyone from the top of the chain to the bottom.
cons: Pay rises are small in comparison to anything else. Progression is good to start with but can become stagnant. Not always clear on how to get to next level or where to go in career direction. Can sometimes not be very social, depending on the project.

review_title: Oracle Commerce LOB
pros:
1. Initial package is good, CTC is fixed pay - no variable and bonus component in offer letter
2. Excellent work life balance, option to work from home, leaves as required
3. Good office infrastructure
4. Lots of refreshment options - badminton, cricket, fotball, table tennis, carrom, chess inside office premises
5. In house gym and yoga sessions
cons:
1. No hikes. Might work for the same pay even after 3-4 years, though you are a top performer, and from a premiere institute .
2. Promotions and increments are independent of each other. Even if you get promoted, there may not be any increment in salary, even in the next 2 cycles.
3. There is no transparency in the process of increments, and definitely performance is not the key metric
4. Not great food and beverage option at the office cafetaria.

review_title: Great company to have it on your resume, then you can move on to find a right/good job.
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: You get the industry wide acceptance that you are working for a great company. It is easy to move from one job to another with in the company easily as the company has lot openings internally.
cons: Other than getting the Oracle name on your resume, technical knowledge gaining opportunities are limited. I agree with the some of reviews about Oracle regarding "Quantity" Vs "Quality": Management is always expects more output than people can deliver, so in order to deliver members deliver buggy non-quality products. When you join oracle, one thing you can say good bye to is "work life balance". Management in the company assumes that Saturday/Sunday is also working days.

review_title: It's a Job, that's about it.
pros: Oracle is very clear about what it wants to sell, there's never a debate.  Benefits are outstanding, and as a sales rep, you're pretty much left alone to do what you need or want to do in managing your territory.
cons: The sales model allows for multiple competing sales folks to be calling on the same customer which is very confusing to the customer, but is a result of the sales plan.  Therefore there is minimal trust and cooperation among the sales folks.  Quota setting is based on the level of rep you are, not on what a territory can sustain.

review_title: A place to waste your life if you have no ambition or desire for meaningful work
pros: If you luck out with a good manager in a department reasonably protected from upper-level politics, you can enjoy a relatively stress-free work experience for a few years. Excellent benefits. Always acquiring new companies, so there is a near-constant inflow of fresh blood, and most of them are people who would never choose to come here by their own will, so in a way that's a good thing that keeps the community varied.
cons: The only innovation you are going to see is from buying other companies, which innovate up until they get bought and messed up. The politics at SVP level and above are ridiculous. As with most huge companies, there are constant reorganizations. Internal tools are antiquated and painful. There is very limited ability to use any external software - culture of choking on own dog food.

review_title: Stable job, lot of opportunities to learn
job_title: Principal Technical Support Engineer in Chicago, IL
pros: Good job security. Lot of learning opportunity - mainly through online (self-learning) tools.  Excellent, supportive people - especially in the Customer Support and Development organizations. Managers at lower and middle levels are generally quite respectful and considerate towards employees.  Not sure if the same can be said about other groups like Consulting, Sales etc.
cons: Not much opportunity for career growth, especially in the US. Pay does not grow much either. Being a huge organization with lots of acquisitions, they are probably trying to get rid of people than hire, especially in the Sales and other common administrative functions - which is understandable.

review_title: Not a bad place to work
pros: Oracle makes great products ad employs some brilliant people. I am in engineering so my comments speak to that organization.  The benefits are top notch and the resources are good I.e. the hardware we use etc.  No, we do not get our own Exadata full rack!
cons: It is a big company so there are waves of politics to wade through if you want to get ahead. You. Need to play the game because rest assured, others are.  If you really want to advance in engineering, you need to work in Redwood Shores.  Also, the bonuses and stock options have been WAY down in recent years at least for our group.

review_title: This company likes to make money.
pros: You definitely need to be able to work independently as most positions are in the field. Also you need to build a support team whom you can call on for direct answers because finding it via the intranet is laborious and at times futile.
cons:
Not much in the way of promotions. Get what you can in the beginning for salary and expect to be there for a long time. Also metrics are a big thing. Nothing is more demoralizing than to see expert resources laid-off because of arbitrary metrics.

You really have to know someone to find another position in the company to hire you. You have strict boundaries to work within and crossing lines of businesses is not rewarded.

review_title: Good work/life balance but invest in your employees
pros: Good work/life balance--no one ever stays late here.  Flexibility to work from other offices when necessary.  Pretty good benefits--they match 401K up to 3%.  Have a free gym onsite as well as several other restaurants (employees pay)
cons: The culture is not like other silicon valley companies in that they make their employees feel valuable.  Expect a lot of change within the workplace (manager turnover, will move a sales team to completely different product, will split up a team).  No shuttle to/from SF--commute is own car/CalTrain

Expect a lot of change within the workplace (manager turnover, will move a sales team to completely different product, will split up a team).  No shuttle to/from SF--commute is own car/CalTrain

review_title: A challenging place to work, but lots of opportunity and good pay
pros: Good benefits, good salary, lots of opportunity to move around to other areas.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy and needless administration rather than focusing on the big picture.  If you 'check the box' on doing meaningless projects and are ok with the status quo, you'll fit in just fine here.  For me personally the work/life balance and compensation is what keeps me here.  With any big corporation, you'll hear the same story.

review_title: Good company but don't expect a raise
job_title: Master Principal Sales Consultant in Sacramento, CA
pros: Great co-workers, endless opportunities for learning, broad portfolio of products and the best DB technology around
cons: I went through a promotion cycle last year at this time (about 40 hours of prepping a portfolio) and flying to Reston Viginia to interview with a panel of VP's (another 40 hours). I was confirmed for a promotion but never recieved a title change or salary bump. I've been with the company for 4 years but don't imagine staying around much longer. The employee investment is there for professional growth but there is no follow through.

review_title: Not a sure thing...
pros: The people are genuinely great; hard working and very team orientated.  There are many great resources and a decent amounts of training available.  Industry leaders in cloud marketing with amazing product and strategy offerings.
cons:
Such a huge company, it can be easy to get lost in the mix.  If you are not aligned in the right org or team, you will have very little opportunity and you will never see any benefits.
Poor utilization rate management can lead to stressful job environment/potential to be laid off
Self service model can be very frustrating trying to get internal technical support
I've had 5 managers in 4 years, which significantly limits career growth and opportunities

review_title: Great products but stressful place to work
job_title: Technology Sales Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
* Great products, some coming to the end of their plc
* Motivated and well educated employees
* Good salary and benefits
* Oracle 'brand'.
cons:
* Management running the business like a 'Financial Institution' and sweating the assets
* Lack of Innovation
* Top down command and control management style with little room for worker feedback apart from an annual survey
* Line managers pushing workers sometimes too much often leading to health issues and high stress levels especially in sales and consulting
* Best people leaving the business
* Snr Leadership lack vision on next phase of growth
* Lack of trust across many teams leading to many conflicts and 'battles' in the business
* Lack of direction on future growth strategy - there is only so far you can go with current strategy
* Customers don't often trust Oracle sale people

review_title: Big company in big transition
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Burlington, MA
pros: Oracle has great benefits. I've met a lot of good people at this company who will most likely stay in the tech circuit. My favorite "benefits" are things available you must take advantage of -- class reimbursement options, Toastmasters International fees, weekly yoga classes in corporate gym, etc...
cons: Oracle doesn't seem to have a mission statement. If sales and making money is your only motivation, this is not an issue. It seems to be a body with no soul -- it functions, but there's no one home. Promotions are made especially difficult, especially in the field where preference is for hiring from the outside. Partially building on that, there is nothing besides money or to incentivize top talent to stay. With forcing of cloud upon both customer and sales reps, it seems to be more of asking people to leave...

review_title: Recent changes have ruined the sales roles
pros: Will never be acquired and large gives you ability to change roles
cons: I have been at Oracle for over 5 years. The constant changes in field responsibilities and compensation plan has ruined the company.  The recents changes of putting entire sales rep teams on a pooled team quota has driven good people away.  You no longer get rewarded by individual sales performance.  The leadership is not concerned how field sales people are treated or compensated.  It went from the best compensation plan for sales people to the worst in the industry.

review_title: Was once a great place, bucking the downward trend. Now hampered by an exodus of talent and amateur middle management.
job_title: Technology Sales Representative in London, England
pros:
Oracle has a great strategy. One Red Stack makes sense.
Plentiful resource pool to pull from.
Foot soldiers are still leading the way.
cons:
Despite Oracle's strong strategic story, the fractional sales model means that there is no one communicating this message to customers.
Inflexible support model prevents new sales. No surprise that 50% of global revenues come from support renewals.
Amount of admin, spreadsheets and report creation is a huge time consumer.
Middle management offers no support and is mostly made up of recently promoted telesales managers.
Old boys network is strong and thriving.

review_title: Steady professional advancement, lucky opportunities
pros:
Reasonable company, pleasant working environment.
I always felt like I had the opportunity to make a case for a project or an idea or to bring an argument forward. Almost always listened.
A company where entrepreneurial spirit is welcome - what is not explicitly forbidden is allowed.
A great company to be in IT. Lots to learn, lots of intelligent people around.
cons:
Quite dissuasive of changing country.
Salary slowly evolving (regardless of the rampant inflation in emerging countries) created odd situations where a newer colleague had almost double the salary just because arrived more recently?
No true HR involvement in career development - actually not a very structured career development.
Cost reductions and cutting exercises increasingly frustrating.
Company evolving from an engineer's one to bean counters and from a visionary technology creator to a next blazing tech whiz buyout administrator.

review_title: Great benefits and work flexibility
pros: I work form home at least three days a weeks which is a huge advantage.  The benefits are excellent and the people I work with are generally very smart and pleasurable to work with.
cons:
We use all of our own products so it gets very difficult to produce a steady stream of quality work.  Once you get the system to work for you it gets upgraded (usually changed to a new application) and the process starts all over again.  

You can get promoted but they wont give you the salary for it.  But they will hire from the outside and give them market rate. I think that is a corporate practice but it doesn't make for good retention of top talent.

review_title: Great place to work and grow in Technical Sales
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Reston, VA
pros: Great benefits and training provided. Offers opportunity for career progression and unlimited salary potential. The Company adds to your resume a Fortune 500 Company which creates career opportunities both inside Oracle and in the industry. You are given autonomy in your territory which enables unlimited experience potential and ability to understand the process of running your own business.
cons: Some Sales territories have unreasonable quotas that are several times the historical revenue production. Limited contacts are given to new employees and account information is not immediately provided. Can take several months to accumulate contacts and identify deals.

review_title: Could have been great, but a let-down in the end.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood Shores, CA
pros:
It's a stamp on the resume.
Very established company. I was in sales so it was easy to get people listening since Oracle is a big name.
Pay and perks are pretty good.
cons:
It was so boring! The culture is very corporate and dull. It's not a fun environment.
You feel like a drone, and like your manager and most peers don't really care about you as an individual. You're a cog in the system. 
Everyone is obsessed with how much $$ they make and the latest car they bought. I'm motivated by money too, but bragging about it is low.

review_title: Sales Executive
pros: Big Company. Lots of resources. If you are working in enterprise-level sales, major accounts or key accounts, I am sure the system would work just fine!
cons: We were acquired so this is a huge culture shock... rather "lack of culture" shock. Since everything is 'self-service' you to not interact with a regular team on projects or to facilitate the sales process. Instead, your requests are sent to an aliased email and someone responds, but often with more questions than answers. Very cumbersome systems in place for on-boarding customers thereby limiting once's ability to be successful in street sales. Not impressed, but that is what sometimes happens in Murders & Assassinations.

review_title: The worst job I've ever had
job_title: Software Engineer/Software Developer IV in Cambridge, MA
pros: Pay was quite competitive. Health insurance options were also quite good.
cons:
Engineers are quite talented, but are ruled by the management. Managers also act as scrum masters, and some of them take the word 'master' quite literally. No raises or bonus payouts the entire time I was employed. Some managers play favorites, enabling some engineers and passive aggressively encouraging others to leave. General morale seems to be quite low, with people putting in just enough to get their paychecks.

They started a mandatory year-end vacation policy, but the vacation days come out of your vacation  quota. So if you'd already taken vacation before and running low on vacation balance, prepare to go into negative quota.

review_title: Applications Sales Manager HCM
pros: The company, people, and training are second to none.  For sales you learn the entire red stack and for HCM a deep working knowledge of all applications.
cons: The big challenge in enterprise HCM sales is competing with the market leader Workday.  The HCM suite has made significant strides but the market still favors Workday.  This can be a common challenge for many pillars as Oracle has so many products many times they are not the product most customers want.  Many times success at Oracle can depend on the territory as the successful reps tend to have current customers.  Other challenge is the many systems to learn but that is also getting better.

review_title: avoid if you can
pros:
salary average
some great product / technologies
cons:
One of these rare companies where software audit has been industrializing: bad reputation on the market
Too many employees: as a sales I have to do almost everything’s and get barely support from the company
Making a proposal with internal tools takes forever (more than 5 days sometimes with complication of licensing / hw model)
Organization is not helping sales: challenged each and every time for stupid metrics, management has no clue what a customer looks like and ask to spam them with our stupid Eloqua mass mailing system 
Worst organization on the planet:  each and every org is in charge only of its product: in the end for each customer you have 5 to 8 sales addressing different subjects -> customer are confused and lost 
Oracle is currently trying to follow the market with its new cloud model, but the organization remain the same : 50% of the people aren’t aligned with the business or are just there to slow own the selling process.

review_title: You learn the ropes here.
pros:
- B2B giant with commercial relationships with all the S&P 500
- Good place to learn how to work in a multi-national environment
- Personally speaking, I have progressed fast within the organization
- Remuneration good, when making your targets
- International transfers available and used by employees
- Oracle is self service, and self starting.. no one is going to hold your hand, but nobody is going to micro manage you either.
cons:
- Oracle is possibly more bureaucratic than the old Soviet Politburo...
- And at least as political...
- Too much reliance on offshore teams- seems to have sacked all the good people, and employed grads with no experience instead
- Process is king, queen, and court jester....

review_title: Oracle former employee
pros:
Possibility of working remotely
Few positive and nice colleagues
Access to the online trainings and course contents but no time for learning
cons:
In few words, I would describe my experience at Oracle as being a negative one, particularly for the last year; I would not recommend to anyone who cares about his/her mental health/ not recommendable more than 1 year
High work volumes without extra financial motivation
Lack of annual appraisal or at least a feedback
Lack of support for transfer to another department
It was a period with ups and down when I was expected to work even during holidays
High pressure on reporting and target
High pugnacity level 
High level of stress and focus on target; sabotaging and competition among employees is encouraged and nourished by upper management
Courses accessible only for the manager’s friends and favorites
Favoritism
Power abuse
Employees are threatened and constrained to resign
Bullying and discrimination is encouraged

review_title: Company Shipping Jobs Overseas
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: For junior employees, there are lots of opportunities for learning and growth.  Senior employees who fit the company's intense focus on delivering software using lowest common denominator designs and written by indifferently trained junior employees, the company is an outstanding place to work... once they make manager or the equivalent technical rank (Consulting MTS), they will finally have a role in the company's future and an ongoing position relatively safe from layoffs.
cons: If a senior employee is focused on programming, or on teaching others technical skills, he or she will be barely listened to, frequently thwarted, and, lately, vulnerable to layoff.  A major push to outsource jobs to Mexico, India and China has begun at corporate HQ and no one below the level of manager or consulting MTS is safe.

review_title: Manager driven
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Hyderābād
pros: Work life balance . If your manager does not bother you can really work from home
cons:
Now frequent layoffs.. After Thomas left,  oracle cloud has become captain less ship. 
It's a manager driven company.  You will get promotion  , hike or even conducive  work envieonment also by the mercy of manager. 
If you are unlucky and got stuck with a vision less manager,  you will experience the incompetency on its highest level. 
Mostly managers are 15 - 20 old in same team,  so the product is like their keep. They do not want to make any change from technology point of view because they will lose the hold. 
No yearly hike.. 1st year of joining,  they do not give a minute of their thought for you.

review_title: Oracle - a good place to work, with some room for improvement
job_title: Senior Director in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Benefits - one of the most comprehensive benefits package in the industry
Range of technologies - full spectrum of technologies is used at Oracle, including database, Java, web services, XML etc.
Smart people - some very intelligent people, especially at senior levels of the organization 
Processes and systems - true process and systems excellence for rapid turnaround of issues and automation of manual tasks
cons:
Too big at times - you have to deal with a number of different organizations to get your job done
Can be bureaucratic - Oracle can lack the entrepreneurial spirit at times and there is an emphasis on doing things "by the book"
Not the best paymaster - base pay is middle of the road, and equity at lower levels in the organization is non-existent.

review_title: Oracle provides outstanding benefits, a comortable work environment and rewards top performers.
job_title: Senior Principal Applications Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Great benefits.  It pays to work hard.  If you work hard enough to be in the top 10-20% of your group or organization it is almost always rewarded with a decent bonus, stock options or merit increase.  Oracle rarely has layoffs, unless of course your company was just purchased by them.  I have never feared for my job.
cons: Depending on the project, the extra hours can start to add up quickly. Some senior management only manage up and don't pay enough attention underneath them.  The company has grown so much it can sometimes be complicated to work with other organizations.

review_title: A large corporation presents challenges and rewards.
pros: Oracle is a large corporation with a good reputation in its field.  Experience with Oracle and its wide range of products is valued by many other companies making you a more valuable worker.    Unlike working with smaller companies, you will have the opportunity to interact with people from around the globe.  You will also have the opportunity to learn and create the software products that drive many of the world's largest companies.
cons: It can be daunting working for a large, impersonal corporation.  Your direct management, human resources representative and other coworkers may not even be co-located with you.  You need to have initiative and not be afraid to seek out other people in your job.

review_title: Good Place to work provided there are some sacrifices
pros:
1. iflex means onsite. Thatz where u learn the tricks of the trade. 
2. Customer interaction. Handling customers of different geographies, language, business styles. you get to see only here.
3. Knowledge in Banking will improve in a large way and also knowing the way things done in different countries is all an addon in your experience.
cons:
1. Very Long Workhours.
2. Balance between personal and professional life depends totally on the project you are put on.
3. Technical skills limited to use in making the product. Can lead to staleness in the long run.
4. Project Planning and execution of tasks is haphazardly and needs a long way to catch up to meet industry standards.

review_title: Would pay to work there for the learning!
pros: If there's one IT company left in 20 years, this is the closest there is. You will not find another company with the diversity of solutions now after all the acquisitions, bascially every thing you can think of that a company can use is on the price list. The only other vendor with that breadth is not a vendor, it's the GPL world, and that's not 1 vendor.
cons: It's like hotel California: you can check out any time you like but u can never leave. An urban myth goes that one guy got fed up with his manager so he left to a competitor, Oracle bought them and he found himself back under the same manager, then left again to another competitor, that one got bought out too, etc...

review_title: It takes 150% effort to get ahead.
pros: This is a well known and respected company.
cons: As a consultant the only time you are secure is when you are billing the client, if there is an upcoming holiday do not be surprised if they request you to work just a few extra hours. If you want to get ahead you will need to enhance your skills through training which you will need to do on your own time, taking time off to attend a class is silently frowned upon, they are glad to pay for training as long as you are still billing the client 40 hrs each week, minimum.

review_title: Good Work
pros:
1. Good Work
2. Good Technologies to work on
3. Work-life balance, but one has to draw the line himself to keep the distance between personal and office life.
cons:
1. Pay is very low compared to other Product Development companies
2. Flexible timings isn't really a plus it always means spending more time for work

review_title: Not a bad company to work for
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Denver, CO
pros: Oracle, especially in the past, has been a big proponent of working from home.  This is a perk in itself and helps with work/life balance.  Note, however, that certain organizations have stopped this and are now requiring people to be in the office full-time.  Vacation amounts are fair.  Business is fast-paced with new products and acquisitions.  Oracle is generally an industry leader which is good for job security.
cons: Raises and bonuses are rare - even when executives continue to make loads of money and the stock price rises.  Little focus on training or career development.  Seems to be little opportunity for promotion / career growth.

review_title: Not as expected.
pros: only for old aged or for them who really don't want challenging work environment.
cons:
1) very stagnant
2) All you hear is 'BUGS' nothing as development really. It gets 60% of revenue from support work only.
3) Manager driven so depends on your manager how good or bad he or she can be.
4) Allows work from home in name only, it becomes chaos if you really WFH.
5) No proper management of team meetings and calls. It may happen according to any timezone and YOU HAVE TO ATTEND IT.
6) Blame game is quite freequent to see here. Peoplekeep on passing work rather finishing it.
7) They just say relocation is no big deal, but you can try to turn upside down if manager denies it you won't get it.

review_title: Overall a good company
pros: The company is heavy on processes and procedures, which is a good thing in a large company. They manufacture their own hardware and software excepting the network stack. Lots of smart people to work with.  Good benefits. Your experience very much depends on what group you get hired into.
cons: Focus here is on operations groups. Raises don't track for longer term employees. Employee retention is not a focus. Company hires new staff at a higher salary than what they currently pay great, well-respected employees. Unless you have VP level sign-off, moving from one line of business to another means setting your career back because pay and titles are frozen at whatever level you were in the previous group.

review_title: Growing on the backs of its employees
job_title: Senior Sales Consultant in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: If you want to work for a company that has a vast array of products and is focused on its bottom line then Oracle is a great place to work.
cons: I joined Oracle believing that hard work and focus would pay off. I've since learned that there are virtually no pay raises amongst my group of employees (Sales Consultants) no matter what you do and promotion is just a distant pipe dream for most. Furthermore Oracle has baited and switched its employees on parts of their compensation so that we're making far less than we used to, for the same work. Very disappointing

review_title: Senior Sales Consulting Director
pros: Great products, solid install base, potential to be a significant player in the future of the IT industry.
cons: Lagging behind the cloud market, overly bureaucratic business processes, pay cuts, no raise or promotion policy.  All lead to a churning workforce.

review_title: Summarized in a word - Meh
pros:
One of the largest tech companies in the world, Nice to have on your CV. Oddly good about upgrading technology (my laptop was always new)
My department was fantastic, and my management team stellar - until you went higher up.
cons: General disdain for raises (seriously, what kind of company simply doesn't give raises for years in a row?) Failure to understand complexities of new business acquisitions. Not sure they actually want to be in all of the business they're in.

review_title: Living the dream...
pros:
We are the #1 Cloud Business Software... we're passionate, driven, and committed to the vision of our Executive Team. 

The people make the company... we work hard, we have fun - we've been firing on all cylinders for over 18 years. 

Career development is encouraged and supported... within existing departments, to other departments, to other countries, and more.

We hire the right people.
cons:
Work/Life balance can sometimes get lost but this is mainly due to our rapid rate of growth and need to hire more people to support that. There are pros and cons to both sides of this.

Along with that, while we all support our Executives because we know that they make the right decisions for us, the business, and our customers... we'd like to hear from them more internally. We also appreciate that they're 'running the company'.

review_title: Working for Oracle
job_title: Senior Account Executive in Makati City
pros:
Oracle has very good technology, especially on the information management side. Their renewed focus on cloud, while late in the game, assures their ongoing relevance in the industry.

The commission scheme is very attractive to salespeople, since its very simple to understand and overachievement is rewarded generously.
cons:
The organization is built for conflict and internal competition. It is not very collaborative. People are encouraged to compete with each other, and among teams. It does not inspire loyalty in its employees, so people come and go pretty quickly. 

I get the feeling the organization does not value the customer relationship in the long term, its priority is on how much it can monetize in the short term.
