review_title: NetSuite used to be great before Oracle
pros: NetSuite used to be great place to work, company culture, management accepted feedback from employees, company seemed to take case of employees, for location good pay, interesting work, good product, growing site so new career opportunities  e.g. new teams, positions, moving sideways or up.
cons: With Oracle buying NetSuite lots of things have changed, it's become increasingly corporate environment, more procedures and policies, management lost interest in their employees or maybe cannot do much without Oracle approvals. NetSuite culture is slowly fading away.

review_title: Only Constant is Change
job_title: Customer Success Manager in Austin, TX
pros:
Learning Opportunities
Young Workforce-- most people are young professionals, or straight out of college 
Large network of people willing to help you learn 
Good Benefits 
Decent Salary for right out of school kids
cons:
Unorganized-- managers don't know what is going on any higher than their team, and directors do not share anything with managers 
Slow to innovate-- oracle is a slow turtle, so any changes that do need to be made are slow to happen 
Territory arguments-- oftentimes instead of working with sales we are seen as working against sales and have to internally argue about who should speak with  a customer 
Customers don't always come first-- a lot of the time we cannot put our customers first because of odd company policies 
No Raises or promotion opportunities visible

review_title: Oracle SCC
pros:
- You get to know so many products from oracle offering. This is a good point only if you are interesting in learning oracle technology.
- Work life balance. Work from home as and when needed.
- Short working hours.
- Great interaction with people around the globe.
cons:
- No real project. All the times you would be working on use-cases which really do not need any great technical skill.
- If you are a developer and want to develop amazing things, please do yourself a favor and do not join this org.
- Salary hikes - FORGET it, do a lot of manipulation and project yourself what you not are (i.e. expert) and hike is on way
- Very less technical architecture, design interation.
- People are less technical in terms of oracle being a products company

review_title: Accounts Payable analyst
pros: The only pro you will find is the weightage that you are working on a oracle software which is used in many companies
cons:
Engineers working in AP - that's their standard  . This is only about AP TEAM - Too monotonous work , process is divided into bits and pieces where you cannot learn much about the process unless you boot lick your manager , promotions are given based on your years of experience in oracle and not your work , you cannot change ur team or work unless you know the other manger or his peers personally . 
No use of applying for internal job change.

review_title: You take the good you take the bad...
pros: While Oracle is typically not the first to market with emerging technologies, it is still a place where you can be exposed to all the latest technology trends.  There are several resources available to employees if when the trends do not directly relate to the products you are working on.
cons: There is no cohesive company wide strategy.  There are top priorities that get the most investment and attention, but incentives conflict across organizations that causes unintended consequences.  Meaning, products that continue to have demand in the market cause existing customers to go to competitors because sales alienates those that aren't interested in the products they are incented to sell the most.

review_title: Fear-Mongering culture: no place for individual decision making or leadership
pros:
- Strong health benefits
- Strong focus on bottom line profitability
cons:
- Complete management through fear, no decision making enabled at management or field level. All comes from SVP level and above.
- No internal accountability, individuals are not driven to succeed just to avoid perception of failure which will lead to firing.
- No risk / reward. "The nail that sticks up, gets hammered down"
- Extremely compartmentalized organizational approach (no end to end ownership)
- Very poor / non-existent internal communication, no focus on customer
- President through VP level very commonly swears incessantly and berates management and field resources in individual meetings (ala. Glengarry Glen Ross). Very disrespectful. 

- Not a company that rewards top performers and dynamic problem solvers, intentionally drive those individuals out of the organization, so they can pay less for wheel-turners.

review_title: Some very smart people but culture and comp are terrible
job_title: Senior Director in Redwood City, CA
pros:
-lots of career opportunities
-flexibility to work from home (depending on group you are in)
-best practices in its processes so you can learn a lot
-good insurance benefits
-cafes onsite if at HQ (though food isn't free and not discounted at all, but its good)
cons:
-mentality is "you're lucky to work here"
-comp is terrible with raises ranging from zero to 2%, bonuses just as low
-depending on the group you are in, work/life balance is terrible. groups tend to be understaffed. I've worked many holidays, vacations, weekends and all nighters
-"self service" cutlure can be hard to adjust to. it can be frustrating finding your way on your own with the bredth and depth of the size of the company
-communication isn't stellar. employees are usually last to know and many sometimes hear about org changes weeks and months later.

review_title: Inside Sales Manager
pros: Oracle gives Sales Professionals the Freedom & Flexibility to work with set defined deliverable. It is a paradise for High Achievers / Performers and treats them well. Oracle itself is so vast due to which working with the internal LOBs and other channels gives incremental growth to the sales professionals here.
cons: Well ... its a con which most of the other companies are also facing nowadays and i.e. the question regarding salary raise or increment.

review_title: Innovative company with broad depth of experience
job_title: Principal Solutions Architect in Reston, VA
pros: Oracle in itself is a self contained ecosphere of products and platforms, the work environment is top notch and pay is above what you'd make as a government contractor which is the predominant employer in this town.  Communication is abundant with plenty of backreach for problems you absolutely can't solve on your own.
cons: Sometimes there is a disconnect between the management layers, primarily caused by most upper level management resides at the San Francisco HQ.   Also training is limited in that Oracle compensates for training only within the Oracle ecosphere.  Raises are non existent unless you obtain a hard to get promotion.

review_title: Assimilated by the Borg
job_title: Technical Writer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: I loved the culture at Sun. Sure it was confusing, changing, and difficult to keep track of things, but we all pitched in and we all shared the benefits or pitfalls. A lot of that culture persists but it's fading.
cons: Sun had an egalitarian ethos. Oracle's culture is definitely authoritarian. The compensation scheme is manipulative in the extreme: in good years, one person per group gets a raise; we're all supposed to claw over each other to be the designated "hero".  Otherwise you get bupkis even if you're good. Compared to Google, Facebook, or even Salesforce, it's a trap. The morale of the Sun division's workers is eroding year by year.

review_title: OFSS review
pros: Good name on CV. Possibility of exposure to very interesting projects. Laptop.  Travelling. Group insurance plan.  Nice products to work with.
cons: Indian mentality.  People (resources) are treted as animals, numbers , by their supervisors.  Working conditions of the worst kind at customer site, no PM will help/protect.  No cooperation between colleagues individually, or departementally.  Oracle exists only as a brand and does not characterize, living or working conditions. No raises.  No hikes.  No acknowledgement of good work.  No career chances.  Nobody cares about anything.

review_title: Client Success Specialist
pros: Great mid-level management who have a strong focus on their teams. Benefits are great and there are some decent perks to the company (work from home, 401k, easy expense reimbursement system). There is a great culture with employees as the chaos of a large organization can create a "in the trenches" mentality where everyone helps each other out.
cons: Raises are practically non-existent in the organization. There isn't a focus on retention which drives a lot of folks out the door because they feel there is no investment in them. Again, mid-level management tries their best to fight this but it typically appears to be a losing battle.

review_title: Great place for learning but has a use and throw policy
pros: I've worked in Oracle Product development as well as Consulting. They allow internal transfers between business units. You get to learn a lot and Oracle has a lot of access to learning material. Work environment is very good.
cons: They have no value for technical folks, esp in Consulting. Once you are not billing, they try to create panic and literally force you to look outside. You maybe an employee who's received a lot of accolades and awards but all that doesn't matter when its firing time. Hikes are negligible. They have a lot of people in mid-management who really don't add any value.

review_title: Great company to work, learn and grow
job_title: Regional Sales Director in Bogotá, Bogota
pros: Oracle is one of the most important companies in the IT industry. Offering a huge portfolio of solutions developed with an industry flavor and trying to get easy the processes of the customers saving money, time and efforts that are out of the core business environment. Also, offering core products to modernize business technology and processes.
cons:
I don´t have any concern about Oracle, Is a great company and always gives you the opportunity to grow as a person and as a professional.
Tip: For people who do not like the self service model it is important that they make a change in their way of thinking and working.

review_title: Oracle
job_title: Business Intelligence Systems Analyst in Bangalore
pros:
1. You can Learn Multiple Skill and upgrade yourself.
2. Open and good environment to work.
3. Management do consider your views, ideas and suggestion.
cons: Oracle is not a good paymaster or less employee  oriented company, compared to similar organization in the business. Every quarter a new acquisition news will be there.  Company is more focus on expansion and less focus on human resource attrition  which actually is more needed in IT business to keep motivational level of employees high through out the year for long term growth of any company.

review_title: Worst Technology company for new college graduates
pros:
They have decent benifits.
Campus has a good gym.
There are some smart people to work with.
Good work life balance.
cons:
Human Resources is dysfunctional. No one cares about your career. They only care about hiring and layoffs.

They don't act like a single corporation but instead each group acts like a different company. Each group has its own culture and practices and little/no cooperation. Also there is heavy discrimination among perks across different groups. If you are not in a group where they are investing, your life could be miserable.

Top level management doesn't care about employees at all. Your hard work and loyalty is for nothing.

It's fairly a sad place to work.

Learning opportunities and pace is really slow.

Despite of all the fuss about their new cloud offerings their toxic culture is a recipe for disaster. 

Dysfunctional HR or self service culture means There are no advantages of working for a big company like working for different groups and broadening skills.

review_title: Sr. Account Manager
pros: I wish I could say job security, but Oracle is like a revolving door
cons: Decisions are fed to you from the top with no input on risk or impacts. Managers are like sheep and are afraid to make a decision about anything.  Be aware once your in the red machine there is no salary increases, so be sure when accepting an offer you go high. Heard directly from HR that Oracle recruiters are only comped for hiring outside of the company, which limits your advancement opportunities unless you know the hiring manager. Oracle only care how much money the execs can get and don't care about what their decisions do to those actually executing on the strategy or our customers

review_title: High turnover
pros: There is a possibility to make good money if you are a capable rep with commissions and you understand how Oracle works internally.
cons: Oracle has a very high turnover in the sales department for good reason. They have been reducing employee pay and are very stingy about raises, outings, any kind of expenses. Employees are the last consideration under Mark Hurd (Oracle is not exactly customer friendly either)

review_title: Not recommended
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Austin, TX
pros: It's a job.  The salary and benefits are decent.
cons: Upper management does not seem to care about lower level employees.   It takes FOREVER to fill an open position due to all the approvals needed all the way up the chain.   Management can't seem to stay on a course, changes their minds all the time as to what direction to take with projects and assignments.

review_title: Bugs bugs bugs, and fix fix fix: The main product of what we do.
pros: It is a savvy top management, placing the company in a dominant market position and making it a stable place to earn a living.
cons: Competence does not count, only nationality and office politics. You must be Indian to advance. or you are doomed to pickup broken glass in a never ending cycle of bug fixes, deception and ritual self over esteem of people causing the bugs. You might be facing meetings on regular base with not a single American in them, its that corrupted meanwhile.

review_title: A once great company.  Its acquisition was probably the best thing that could happen.
job_title: Technical Professional Level V in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Looks good on a resume.
Great rank and file with a very high intelligence level and a lot of drive.
Engineering staff at the contributor level is as good as it gets.
cons: Pay and promotion have nothing to do with your achievement and contribution and are based on ones loyalty and servitude to your / upper management, whose motivation is based solely on their own advancement and power.  Of course there is some level of that in "every" organization...at least at the location I was at for seven years, it is detrimental to the operations when the good ol' boys and girls network is the only way to advance.

review_title: Good but not so good..
pros: working with a variety of people is a bonus.  You can learn a lot if interested in pursuing technology.  Inter-departmental and inter-divisional opportunities are great.  There are process driven levels which can help network across continents if you are a sociable person and have good grasp of language. You can stick to the company for years together if you dont want change. because the company's name is big, getting travel visas is very easy (LOL)
cons: stagnancy is a major concern unless monotonous work schedule is your career. if you get stuck with a weak manager, appreciation/recognition is next to none. internal politics play a major role in career progress and you cannot change divisions if your manager wants you to get stuck or just leave. hikes, promotion and bonus are highly dependant on how much you like to kiss ass!!

review_title: Great company to work for if the compensation was appropriate
pros:
Best benefits around
Comparatively good vacation and time off
There is encouragement and reimbursement for classes and certifications
Work from home / remote flexibility is great
Management is starting to change to the positive, less complacent
cons:
Very poor compensation unless you're from an acquisition
IC and M levels are salary based rather than experience, meaning that you might not get the promotion because you're below the salary range 
Acquisition employees are moved over laterally, which in most cases results in their promotion because they fall outside the other certain salary range
Focals only happen once a year if at all
Company is lacking innovation and motivation to innovate

review_title: Good work place for professional growth but not rewarding
job_title: Senior Principal Sales Consultant in Milan
pros: Big company with good products and services. Oracle is a great place to develop your skills and learn how business works –  good training, nice people. Good possibility to balance working life with free time.
cons:
The vested interests in older database technologies dominate and stifle the opportunities to the newly acquired companies. Tend to be too focussed on technical products than business applications
Salary Raises are very low. Even when you do make a career jump into a more senior role, the pay will usually not all come with the increased responsibility or title. 
Bonus amounts - management does not ever share how they are calculated. I never have any idea what I will get. 
Do a good job of negotiating when you first become a part of Oracle

review_title: Diverse & exciting product portfolio with great Career progression!
pros: Good opportunity to work with new and exciting new Global solutions. Major investments made by HQ for Australian market (eg. Local Data centres in Australia for Cloud solutions) - helps differentiate our capability. Great personal growth oppty for hard workers with focus on the customer primarily supported by a sense of urgency & good attention to detail.  I moved from PreSales to Account Management to Sales Manager and General manager role over the last 10+ years.  Global Women's Leadership Forums with Global Conferences and Career Opportunities in Senior Management roles.  Great Compensation Accelerators to sell Cloud solutions.
cons: Large complex organisation divisions. This is now being addressed in more collaborative cross line of business engagement to improve go to market to focus on the customer.

review_title: Challenging work, great benefits and people, below average wage
pros: Lots of challenging work and opportunities to continue/advance your career.  Most of the people there are extremely professional and pleasant to work with.  The benefits are the best I've ever had.
cons: I received great reviews during my 4 years at Oracle.  However, not once did I receive a raise.  I was promoted 3 times - no raise.

review_title: Great coworkers but the creativity is stifled
job_title: Associate Consultant in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: This corporate powerhouse has been hiring a lot of recent college grads for their sales teams lately. A good mixture of experienced sales people and young people. Having a Fortune 100 name on your resume can work wonders in getting that next job. Pay isn't terrible although you get a lot more elsewhere for the same title.
cons: Very old school corporate policy. Creativity is stifled and it can take many levels of approval to get a single project or decision rolling. Growth opportunities seem to be hard to move up and other companies pay well above the salaries here for the same position. Poorly established career path for current employees so moving up the ladder is a guessing game at this point.

review_title: opposite of a startup. Great for intern or recent graduate new to corporate world.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: work/life balance, training, tolerance (age/ethnic/gender, seriously not just superficially). Benefits are excellent. location and food. Great for interns, because you get guidance and mentoring that you would not get a smaller company. Wide variety of people, so you can find friends here. It's a community unto itself.
cons: Hierarchical, restrictive rules for example you can't just download and use software even for investigation/research purposes. This can cause inefficiencies. Sometimes can feel like a cog in a big machine, so I can see why people leave.

review_title: What you'd expect at any giant tech corporation
pros: Product strategy is unified on all fronts towards the cloud....and although they're late to market, I think they'll win in the long-term. Good biz dev / sales foundation to establish right out of college. Competitive salary and OTE. Brilliant engineers and product managers to work with.
cons: Way too much bureaucracy and slow, archaic, moving parts and internal systems. Our CRM is god awful and is a joke compared to Salesforce. Upper management and upper-mid management is so far removed from the day-to-day of the foot soldiers that its not even funny. Find yourself in the right LOB selling into the right vertical and you'll be raking in cash. But there are countless other patches and products in which the reps make zero money.

review_title: Great Company
job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I have worked at Oracle in Sales for 6 years and over all its a great place to be. I have made great money and learned a lot. The culture and management is great. They have a work hard play hard attitude and I love being apart of it. I truly feel that you can go places with some Oracle experience.
cons: However, the red tape at a large corporation like Oracle is difficult to get a deal done. At times approvals and internal workings can be very frustrating.

review_title: Great benefits although they dont have a collaborative culture.
job_title: Staff Sales Consultant in Ciudad de Mexico
pros:
The salary is good, the benefits are really good aswell: medical care, 12 days of holidays the first year, restaurant and supermarket vouchers, etc. 
Its one of the most important technology companies and gives value to your resume. You have the opportunity to interact with really intelligent, innovative and special people.
cons:
They lack of a collaborative culture, they do not promote team work (at least not at the area were I worked), it is not easy to have a professional growth there, comissions exists only for special people and they do not have focus on the customers. 
It is hard to have a balance between professional and personal life (may be not in every area, but in a special one).

review_title: Application Sales Manager (Oracle Marketing Cloud)
job_title: Applications Sales Manager (Oracle Marketing Cloud) in Toronto, ON
pros:
- Great technology via acquisitions with brand awareness. 
- Flexible work environment
cons:
- Horrible management that use dictator style threats to manage sales teams.  
- Sales management treat their teams like children and micro-manage to a extremely painful level.  - Sales Territories are set with no business intelligence.  Randomly set and given a spreadsheet and phone to target your territory.  No additional modern sales tools or lead generation activities.  Basically back to 1997 sales culture.

review_title: Technology Sales
job_title: Technology Sales Manager in Toronto, ON
pros:
Good to very good products
Name recognition + Install base
Opportunity to make big money (though clearly less than 5 years ago)
Very good overall value proposition and technology vision
cons:
Very silo'd sales envioronment with many reps all trying to sell to the same accounts.  Leads to considerable in-fighting in most regions
Reps with install base accounts generally doing much better than those looking for new business - but beware of accounts who are very unhappy after Oracle license audits
Not all the new cloud products are mature relative to the competition.
Sales Management has a culture of driving sales, and sales only.  Coaching & personal devlopment is rare.  Get to know your prospective manager if this is important to you

review_title: A company that suck your blood till the last drop
pros: there is no pros i came to Oracle as part of an acquisition they multiplied the amount of work 8 times and made us work 5 to 6 hours more a day and the only thing you hear that it is part of your contract
cons:
There is so many cons see below the list:
1/working extra hours with no extra money
2/favoritism is rampant depend who you get on with
3/the salary you are hired with you will retire with
4/expectation are so high that new hire will start at 9 am and go for lunch and not comeback turnover is very high
5/they think they own you like they bought a slave
6/they tell you that you have sick pay up to a year well i had a long term illness they paid only for six days and they told me to go and see with social welfare to pay the rest and after a month being sick they asked me to comeback to work or resign so I did

review_title: Golden Handcuffs
pros:
- Work-life balance
- Company is well poised with a reboot that can make it truly great again
cons:
Culture, products/tech, management, execution, marketing, sales strategies, etc etc. I hate to be so negative but most people I work with can identify the problems and wants to make corrections but it seems there is just no spirit or passion or incentive to do so. Everyone seems short-sighted and only concerned with collecting a paycheck, not the greater good. 

To climb the proverbial ladder at this large corp, just put on your blinders and stay positive no matter what!

review_title: Wolf in Sheep’s Clothing
pros: Decent health benefits through UHC
cons:
No on-site management
Harassment by fellow coworkers
Coworkers behaving like high school kids
Hired under false pretenses, did not utilize my skill set or advance my career
Disorganized team with a lot of backstabbing
Favoritism played with employees who don’t actually show up to work or do their job (no on-site management issue)
Management cares very little for your personal life if you have a major life disruption
Work from home employees forced to work in-office shortly after I was hired, causing many to leave due to WFH being a perk earlier on
No chance for a raise, even if you outperform others, but you’ll be featured in an employee spotlight if you do well
Feels like a drain every day you go in to work

review_title: Good Experience
pros: Everyone is roughly the same age, having just graduated from college. Good experience if you're looking to get your foot in the door, have a career in tech!
cons: Not a lot of perks like other companies. It's difficult to assess what your bonus will be, as there are several factors that determine it, many of which are out out your hands completely, and influenced by your overall org/team. The culture in HQ in the sales side, is unprofessional, it feels like a "boys club" and there is always uncertainty about the security of your job. Compared to other SDR positions within the area, base pay could be higher, and the advertised bonus "guaranteed" from the recruiters is almost never attainable. Hardly anyone attains the $25k yearly bonus. Our metrics are constantly changing which is frustrating.

review_title: Changed from a WOW company to a SOS company
pros:
Flexi timings - log in any time, log out any time
Vacation and Leaves - no one asks you to fill if you missed
Work from home - some people I know haven't come to office in the last 6 years
High tech work - depends on your team and project, but it has been satisfactory so far
cons:
No career growth - no promotion in the last 7 years
No Salary growth - you don't get a hike ever year. If you do, it'd be in 3-5% range
No appreciation - management is busy trying to save their jobs and selling products
layoffs - almost 25000 ppl have been laid off in the last 5 years. Getting laid off is a always-on fear. Thankfully, old employees get a good remuneration when laid off
No tax-saving benefits

review_title: Oracle - neither here not there!
pros: Good Work Life Balance, salaries are good ( could be better)  Oracle provides training courses on its software to its non-IT employees and allows its employees to work remotely quite often.  It is possible that you and  your manager will not be in the same office or even the same city.  This takes some of the pressure of people who hate being micro-managed
cons: Not a lot of bonuses or and no real proft sharing....not a lot of raises so get your high salary up front...Oracle could do better in providing more or at least significant employee perks instead of the ones that we can't use.

review_title: Don't Join in Oracle Fusion Team
pros: Higher Management is kind and friendly
cons:
Even though they take you as Java professional, you wont be able to use it. 
Late night unnecessary works. 
In oracle,  fix the fix to the issue is 5 mins the process of getting approval and making that change will take almost a day. High unnecessary process
Hike and promotion is almost a joke, it is not rating. In few teams it is 80-20, only 80% of their team will get and rest 20% will not, and again it is not by rating, it is just picking randomly mainly the 20% will be newly joined people (If no one joined after you in oracle , you will be considered as new till 2 years in oracle, i know it is joke but that is how it happens here )
Management will not understand or try to understood the  true ability of a employee and it just ignores him passion and abilities and make him to do junk work

review_title: Great career launchpad for recent grads!
job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Burlington, MA
pros: There's a ton of training that immediately allows you to work amongst peers who have been in sales for many many years. There's the possibility to go into management or field sales within 5 years of your hire date, given you're meeting metrics and closing deals. Lenient when it comes to working from home or if you needed to leave early for an emergency or something. You start with vacation time. Pretty good pay for someone's first job out of college. Beautiful facilities, dining, exercise etc... Good communities, great people to work around.
cons: Traffic getting and leaving from work no matter where in MA you live. The internal processes can be very overwhelming for anyone, but especially recent grads. A TON of training that is helpful but also overwhelming.

review_title: Great for life balance, no clear career path
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Broomfield, CO
pros: Oracle is obviously doing better than the other giant IT companies. Most of the job are pretty stable and less challenge.   Maintaining a project is must easier than innovate a new one. Few managers are push but most of them will tell you the relationship among teams are more important.
cons:
But, but but but, innovating in Oracle is not appreciated as the formal acquired company - Sun.  
Lower salary for existing employees, slow promotion.

review_title: Great place to work
job_title: Technology Sales Representative in North Ryde
pros: Oracle has a great culture, excellent learning and development environment and a lot of good people around that are motivated and driven. Oracle looks after its employees very well and puts in the effort to help create connections between people in departments who don't normally cross paths day to day. This creates a good team atmosphere.
cons: Although not a downside for some others may find the high pressure to be a downside. Sometimes it can feel like all that matters is your forecast which in reality is all that matters as a sales person. At the end of quarter it can become very cold around the office. it can be a very dark place if you for what ever reason cannot commit a forecast that will put you on or over target.

review_title: Acquired by Oracle, false broken promises
job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Friendship with employees who are going through the same struggles with Oracle.
cons: They ruined the company we were before Oracle purchased us.  They came in with so many promises and none of them came true.  Employee turnover is extremely high, about 50% of the work force of our original company has left.  This is due to promises of wage increases that never ever occur even after years.  They refuse to hire employees to back-fill the position of those who left.  They promised us our friday lunches would continue and they did for about a month and then it was cut off.  The team morale is extremely low and everyone is looking for new jobs.  Forced use of vacation days.

review_title: All Talk
job_title: Principal Applications Engineer in Denver, CO
pros: Leading edge technology and good benefits
cons:
They do not seem to care about their customers or employees, only their stockholders.
No raises or bonuses in over 8 years.
They outsource jobs to foreign countries. Employees go through the effort of mentoring peers in foreign countries only to have their position eliminated.
They layoff older and experienced workers to hire college grads at lower pay or outsource to foreign countries.
Severance package is poor. Benefits end at midnight on the last day of employment. Maximum of 26 weeks of severance despite nearly 30 years of service.

review_title: Worldwide Operations - Supply Chain
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good work-life balance, having a powerhouse brand-name company on your resume, opportunities to work from home if you can justify it, lot of smart and friendly coworkers, decent health benefits, will pay for additional training/classes IF you can justify it
cons: Compensation / pay is lower than industry standard from a company of this calibre, pay raises only come in if you assert yourself, stingy with promotions, no yearly bonuses. Also a legit question, what kind of Fortune 100 company doesn't have a holiday party??

review_title: SMB Applications Sales Executive
pros: Name recognition. Learn about enterprise level software. Smart and energetic new hires that are eager to learn. Nice offices. L
cons: Management has a terrible go to market strategy for the SMB and Mid Market space. Pricing is way to high, out maneuvered by smaller competitors with less red tape, no free trials, poor support for acquired products leads to poor client perception of other products. Netsuite acquisition left everyone in Oracle SMB and Mid Market teams in the dark and fearful. Company still has no answer for how to reorganize divisions. More tenured reps are leaving, college hire program is a joke. Brand new grads only set appointments and aren't involved in closing deals (if there were any).

review_title: How not to walk the walk and talk the talk

International community.
Young & ambitious sales colleagues.
High level trainings and education.
Travelling for business.

Once Oracle is in your cv, you'll get more than often approached by other recruiters.

job_title: Senior Director, Product Marketing in San Jose, CA
pros: Great products with solid IP. Integration story across S/P/IaaS and will take the cloud market, overcoming Amazon and Google.
cons: Not a lot of internal promotions, unless there is growth within your specific team area. Translated, if you are tied to a market, like I am, then you will see the team, budgets and personal growth. If you are not, then you don't see a lot of growth. It's easier to leave the org and then get hired back in at a higher salary and title than it is to stay here and accomplish the same thing.

review_title: Senior Consultant
pros: Work & workstation is best in the world.
cons: No Downside. It is a good place to work.

review_title: Great place to work out of college
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Austin, TX
pros: It is a very young environment. There is a lot of colleagues in their 20s so there is a lot of people who can relate to your experience. The pay is great for the work you are doing. If you meet the KPI and your metrics, bonuses every quarter is pretty decent. There is also a lof of resources that the company offers and you can utilize to your advantage.
cons: Because it is such a big company, it can be very unorganized. The unofficial motto is "the only constant is change" but the changes at times are not implemented well. It can be really frustrating when there is absolutely no consistency for longer than 3 months. Depending on your manager, you might have to really go out of your way to learn something or find other opportunities for job progression.

review_title: Islands of brilliance in an ocean of mediocrity
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros: Can do innovative work in certain groups. Some amazing talent still works at Oracle. Some product groups are at the leading edge of technology.
cons: Fast degenerating into a bureaucracy. Politics rules, competence is much discounted. Resembles the worst of IBM and CA at times. Management for the most part is a blend of willful ignorance and blissful incompetence. The more one sucks up the higher they progress. Is more like a retirement community where the salary is your retiral benefit.

review_title: Oracle Financial Services Software
pros:
1>Good place to be groomed as a fresher.
2>Good brand value.
3>Good work culture
cons:
1>Compensation is among the worst.
2>Higher management does not take decision based on performance.
3> Stupid parameter to judge one's appraisal.

review_title: Better not.
pros:
Good salary, good colleagues.
People remained committed even when they were clearly stagnating in a deteriorating situation and working for management that distrusted their abilities.
cons:
No payrises ever - get a good salary when you start.
Training was available theoretically but due to work pressures no-one was ever allowed to do any.
No career path - no-one ever got promoted. They relied on imported "stars" instead of investing time and energy in local talented potential stars (not me, but others around me) to eventually replace them - they didn't seem to appreciate that even their stars were once learners.

review_title: Good pay and benefits; No room for career growth
job_title: Director of Marketing in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good pay and benefits, able to work remote. Rare to work overtime. 2-3 week vacations at a time are possible
cons: It is a machine set to the least common denominator. Everything is self service with huge roadblocks to over come for even the simplest thing. It gets to the point that you don't want to try anymore because there are constant roadblocks. Those coming in thinking they can change things quickly realize that it is a "rest and vest" job. No promotions, no pay increases. But, you can work remote and work bare minimum and get away with it if they is what you want. If you are wanting high career growth, excitement, and advancement, DON'T come here. If you want to end your career with a mini-retirement, then this is the place for you.

review_title: Great company to work for but it's not perfect.
job_title: Real Estate Analyst 2-Fac in Rocklin, CA
pros: Flexible work schedule. Great benefits and fair salary. Once you learn your job responsibilities, it becomes a little monotonous but relatively easy to accomplish your daily tasks.
cons: People who have been working for the company for many years (10+) are set in their ways of doing things, aren't innovative, and resist change. Lack of leadership from immediate supervisor/manager. When new hires start, they often do not know who to turn for training and sometimes it becomes a "blind leading the blind" situation.

review_title: Interesting projects, not very steady grow path.
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Zapopan
pros: It is one of the best companies to work at in México.  It has really interesting projects in the development area.  There are a lot of incentives like free fruit, working for home availability (depending on your project and manager).  It is one of the best companies to work at as a college graduate.
cons: The software development seems to be quite outdated, there are no recent methodologies being used (agile for example), any IDE or debugger must be setup by yourself, for example.  The development workflow is really slow and sometimes boring, each bug fix has to be throughly tested and reviewed, this leads to really slow development (and this produces low motivation). There is not a clear career path and the raises are scarce, it is common for new hires to earn more than you.

review_title: Marketing Specialist - Marketing Cloud
job_title: Marketing Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Where you Work at Oracle (what division and team) is critical to your experience AS WELL as your manager. Some divisions are better to work for than others but it is critical you interview with your would-be manager and get a good idea what he/she is about and their expectations. One of the best things is that the benefits are some of the best I have seen in 15 years.
cons:
>A lot of "resting and vesting" - You will hear about the "80/20" real at Oracle. 20% of the people are doing 80% of the work while the other 80% are on a near permanent vacation.
>Difficult to work between departments
>Old, outdated computers/networking make it hard to keep up with more nimble companies using Saas-based working platforms
>No bonuses
>Difficult to move up unless you know the right people

review_title: The End of Hope
job_title: Senior Manager, Brand in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Easy to stay under the radar, do mediocre work and still keep your job; lots of ancillary benefits, especially at HQ; predictable, plodding work life.
cons: Autocratic—you'll spend your career managing upward ... everyone is kissing someone's butt; a fear-based corporate environment that results in an active disincentive to produce or present creative or unexpected solutions; fiercely siloed departments that resent or actually obstruct cross-functional problem solving; persistently low pay, stingy or non-existant raises and promotions, and ... they're cheapskates ($37 billion in revenue ... potluck holiday party).

review_title: Brilliant Company to Work With
pros:
1) Flexible work culture. Work life balance.
2) Great technical people all around to guide you.
3) If you are amongst the hard working people then very good hikes and benefits
4) Stock options/RSU give to high performing individuals which is a hallmark of a good product based company.
5) For technical people lot of scope to learn.
cons:
1) You might get bored after a while as work becomes repetitive. But you can still change products/modules if you talk to managers.
2) No fair opportunities for people who want to move abroad like US/UK. 
3) HR is terrible, which i think is omnipresent across IT

review_title: A lot of disgruntled cry baby's have been sacked ....Good riddance! Onwards and upwards the rest of us go!

A lot of people have been fired this is a GREAT thing because they were all happy to sit around not building pipe but spending up on corporate credit card getting fully paid travel to Singapore and getting drunk. they were happy to spend uncle Larrys money!!! but then come back and party up and not build pipe, not make a single call and just hoping they make money. review_title: Terrible, soulless corporation
pros: Ability to work remotely.  Also, it is incredibly difficult to be get fired, so you will find a ton of subpar people in every department who have worked for Oracle for 15+ years who add virtually no value but don't quit because they know they have a sweet gig.
cons: Literally everything else.  Virtually no raises or promotions.  In fact, I personally know of several people who were told they were being promoted and getting a raise, started doing the work, and then Oracle would try to block the actual pay increase and title change for months (in some cases it just never actually went through at all).  This company does not care about its employees at all.  They want to cut costs, increase stock prices, and buy and takeover other companies.  I wish they had never acquired us.  I would not wish this company on my worst enemy.

review_title: Applications Sales Representative
job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Austin, TX
pros: Pay, customer saviness, free drinks onsite, initial training to IGNITE, having "worked" at Oracle.
cons:
Leadership - no morale building and no true sales experience and would take credit from field sales teams (applying for spiffs just because it fell within territory) for doing nothing. Complete lack of respect and professionalism for coworkers and no true knowledge of product or sales cycle. 6% close rate for previous fiscal year...

Would constantly need to keep track of your own deals because comp department would always get the numbers wrong and management would wait to escalate until it was large enough to matter in their paycheck.

Constant threats behind closed doors, witnessed multiple scheming plays against multiple employees when authority was challenged - leading to the need to document everything.

review_title: Good for starting career
pros: The program is super ok. I start quite late which is good for me because i woke up late. The company is quite central here and i use the subway to arrive very fast. We have all kind of coffee, tee, soda, tennis tables, fun at work programs and a lot of things to learn. If you are a student it's a great place to start your career. But don't stay too much. Lot's of training's.
cons:
The department where i work is very stressful, the workload is tremendous, everybody is very tense and upset. The manager is obsessed of micromanagement and it gets everybody angry with lot of nonsense instead of let them work.
People usually cannot resist more than one year, sometimes only 6th months.  A lot of tools and processes too many to understand and keep in mind.

review_title: Such a big brand with bad management
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros: Not really. The cons* are too significant.
cons: They will calculate your target from the first day of the current fiscal year even if you start working later that year. For example if you started in September they will put in your hands the target for June, July and August. Expect to receive your territory after at least one month meanwhile your target will count as well. You will also sign a commitment  containing the target for the entire fiscal year. This way they will make you vulnerable and can kick you out any time they wish. Moreover, only the friends of the team manager will have benefits and get good accounts making their lives easier. They will move the potent accounts from a member to another’s if the management doesn’t like your eyes colour being discriminatory.

review_title: OCI is a Dying Dinosaur with a Hostile Backstabbing Culture
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Nobody works very hard at OCI, especially not the engineers and designers. It's like a welfare program for people who couldn't get hired at AWS or Azure. The snacks are pretty good.
cons:
Management is the worst I've ever experienced in my 20+ year tech career. Mid-level to Senior management actively tries to screw over their staff, lies about them in performance reviews, and promotes anyone who surreptitiously complains about their teammates. It's a culture that rewards backstabbing, lying, cheating, and generally anti-social behavior.

OCI is 5-10 years behind every other cloud infrastructure provider in terms of their product offerings and customer value proposition. They're like a dinosaur flailing in a tar pit. Their constant re-orgs and layoffs only hasten the inevitable. Senior management's only plan is to cheat their employees, lie to their faces, and collect enough RSUs to bail out before the stock price tanks once Oracle runs out of cash for stock repurchases (look it up).

review_title: Your success is completely dependent on account assignments not your selling skills
pros: Everybody knows your name and they will at least meet you.  Benefits are very good.  There are lots of resources to help with sufficient skills.
cons: There are too many sales people and "co-primes" jousting for the same revenue and relationships.   Success is all about the accounts you are assigned versus your selling skills and work ethic.  You won't know the realities about your accounts until you are in the door.  The only good thing is you can get lucky when they realign accounts at the start of each fiscal year.

review_title: Great company, too many directions
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Menlo Park, CA
pros:
Great resources across business units
Helpful and engaged colleagues
Well qualified co-workers
commitment to doing things right
cons:
My biz unit has a tendency to rush to ship status, which results in cutting corners. The quality of the people doing the work lets them get away with it, but every now and then it catches up. 

There is a tendency to allow "pet projects" - projects with no demonstrable commercial viability but some VP protects it because he or she has convinced themselves it will be great. This results in wastage due to mis-focused resources. 

There is also wastage due too many different directions at once. I'm sure this will go away with the change to Oracle.

My specialty is especially under-resourced, spreading me wayyy too thin.

review_title: Oracle follows the other tech dinosaurs into the dust
pros: Not too many Pros; hours and workload vary widely; management is not really managing much; everyone is afraid of losing their jobs, no real innovation, constant cost cuts, no raises or bonuses in 4-5 years, but work-at-home is more then allowed, it is encouraged.   Insurance coverage is actually pretty good.
cons: Travel rules are impossible to deal with; Purchasing is designed so no one CAN purchase anything in reality.  Expense reporting is also made overly difficult (I assume so employees will eat some expenses, rather then bother trying to expense them).  No raises or bonuses in years.  IT has plans at top level, but no one below Directer cares, after ever increasign workload on most employees.

review_title: Keep your head down and be glad you have a job, don't make waves.
pros: There is a reasonable amount of flexibility for one to manage their own time; most important aspect is to get the job done. Benefits are fine for an entry level employee, though not altogether generous for seasoned staff. If you want a narrowly defined position and willing to stay in your box waiting for other silo'd teams to complete associated tasks, this is the place to be.
cons: Extremely top-down management style, micro-managed to obsessive levels. "This is just the Way Oracle Works" is the advice from mid level management when pressed to explain the rationale for the many mind-boggling decisions passed down. Clear evidence that power is not instilled beyond the executive tier.

review_title: The people at Oracle are very nice and I like the way employees interact.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Rocklin, CA
pros: Most of the people are great. In general the management style is laid back and positive. Depending on your role there are lots of opportunities to interact with different teams, see different processes and network. One of the nicest things is the ability to work from home some of the time (this varies between employee, departments, etc).
cons: Oracle does not provide very many opportunities for advancement as far as training. It is also difficult to receive significant raises without leaving Oracle and then coming back.

review_title: Oracle offers true opportunity for talented women to accelerate their careers, but they must be careful of politics.
job_title: Administrative Assistant I in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Really committed to success of women
Good pay
Excellent professional development opportunities in sales division
Healthy and delicious cafeteria designed for a diverse workforce
cons: Some groups are more difficult than others, and as in all companies, one must take care of political realities.  If you find yourself in a group where you are not thriving, the good news is that you can find another where your efforts will truly be appreciated.  Bide your time, grow your network, stay positive and you will have a chance at a company committed to rewarding talent.

review_title: Disappointing and not what I expected.
job_title: Associate Sales Consultant in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: The pay is good and the job is beyond easy.
cons:
Extremely political and corporate. No autonomy. Feels like there is no room for growth. Treated like a number. Everyone, especially the managers and higher-ups are obsessed with money. If the idea of buying a Ferrari makes you salivate, this is the place for you! You'll definitely get paid enough, and you'll fit in with all the other saps who hate their lives and try and compensate with material objects.

The culture is quite dull and not very fun. Most people are on the same page that this is a place that you just want to stamp on your resume and move on.

review_title: Human centipede
pros: Good place to sit around and collect a paycheck, if that is something you are looking for.  You will go far if you can talk a good game.  No need to do what you were hired to.  Exposure to plenty of technology if you want to actual learn them, but not required or common.
cons: See Pros section.  Raises are virtually nonexistent, it takes years.  I have not personally received one, but I hear they are pennies from the few that have.  Management prefers to hire out of "low cost" geographic regions to save money for their bonuses.  Even hard to transfer internally to progress since the job postings are usually for low cost centers.  As a result, very few peers are knowledgeable.

review_title: 2009 Rating
job_title: Sales Specialist in Menlo Park, CA
pros: Sun Microsystems was one of those companies that a person can look back upon and say, "those were the good ol' days."  The culture was very good, the work was interesting and the pay was on par with the industry.  No, it wasn't perfect.  What company is?  But Sun was novel in many areas such as company-wide work from home policies before it became trendy.  It was a sad day when they were acquired.  Many Sun-Alumni will agree that our network is still strong and supportive of one another.  When you come across someone who used to work at Sun, even if you never worked with her before, a knowing smile will come across your face as you remember your time there.
cons: Leadership sometimes didn't listen to new or novel ways to grow the market.

review_title: Big machine
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Management does not micro-manage. Flexible remote work policy and great benefits. Name recognition. Overtime for sales employees. Ability to travel. Breadth and depth of product offering. Great talent stream via constant acquisition. Market power, authority, and swagger.
cons: Slow moving. Very little individual accountability where needed in management and operations. Sales, client success, and support are hindered by complex processes that cost the business an unbelievable amount of money. Employee base so large and far flung that it's impossible to build cross-functional internal relationships. Internal systems are a mishmash of acquired company and homegrown technology. Acquired customers wary of such a big vendor.

review_title: Innovation Hub in the Cloud space
pros:
- Tremendous Autonomy
- Fantastic Pay and even better benefits (Make sure that you negotiate your first pay well)
- Really big on innovation. I myself have brought in 8 new wonderful technologies that have positively influenced the company over the past 3 years
cons:
- Product Development IT is so disconnected and unsupported by the upper management. Just by fixing the challenges on PDIT, Oracle will save billions every year. They are so misaligned with the needs of the Cloud teams

- Some parts of the organization (again IT teams and on-prems) give away titles too easily, so don't be surprised someone with 10 years less experience and less skilled than you would be a VP

review_title: Wouldn't Recommend
pros: It is a global organisation so is a great addition to a CV. They invest a lot in training and the benefits package is good.
cons: Unrealistic targets and although they invest a lot in training, there is not much development. You can go through a strenuous and extensive process to try to become an Account Manager, but if you want to development into another role outside of this, it is not feasible and not much help is given. The systems used are outdated, even though Oracle sells more advanced solutions. The org is too big - serious lack of communication between departments and countries, causing duplication of efforts. The general feel for the company is very serious, dull and outdated.

review_title: Challenging Company
pros: Very large company that aggressively pursues opportunities. Global company. Interesting opportunities. Very good benefits and 401k options.
cons:
Opportunities are not always accessible. Moving into different areas tend to be challenging. The hiring process is very long and when employees decide to leave, staff replacement are not granted. The workload is just spread amongst the current group members. 

Employees are not compensated accordingly.  Despite large senior level bonuses being given yearly, mid-level management and below are not given bonuses.  Salary increases have not been awarded in years and no stock options have been awarded in lieu of the lack of salary increases. 

Employees are forced to take vacation prior to year-end. 

Training opportunities are limited to online, due to travel being restricted.

review_title: Heavy on politics
pros: Depending on role and team, you can learn a lot, and have great flex options such as working from home. Some managers are great and treat you as a person.
cons: Top level executives need to realize they need to stop treating their employees like pawns. Too much politics and broken promises. Unlike other companies, Oracle provides no insight on their culture because there is no culture and people can be unmotivated. All offices around the world are pretty much isolated with their own direction rather than have one direction and one culture driven from headquarters.

review_title: NetSuite Consultant
pros: The Analyst Development Program hire new university graduates and train them on the software from the ground up for 3 months. Experienced consultants are friendly, knowledgeable and very willing to provide support/guidance. Regardless of which office you work out of, there are many resources in the Professional Services team that are willing to help you out. Hours are flexible and there are opportunities to work from home.
cons: Communication and direction from management is very poor and expectations are unclear. Most consultants are overworked, under appreciated and discouraged to take vacation. Consultants are given more projects than they can handle and are quickly burnt out. Management shows time after time that they do not care about employee development or growth and turnover is very high as a result.

review_title: BDR
pros:
Pretty good pay and resume builder 

Would recommend if it’s your actual first sales job and you’re learning to get on the phone, cause it’s mostly luck and really easy. You’re not closing deals.
cons:
The BDR org is completely separate from actual sales. They try and act like they’re training you, but really, you spend half the day cleaning up data and filtering leads in the system to see if they are legit or not. Basically, you are doing marketing’s dirty work. 

Political atmosphere - feels like a dictatorship, they don’t care about your concerns, only care that you suck up to higher ups. People play favorites

CRM is brutal - every time it loads it reminds me of when I was on internet explorer circa 2005

review_title: Good company if you're a starter.  Don't stay for long.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Denver, CO
pros: Big brand. Good growth opportunities if you're in California or India.
cons: Compensation sucks.  Too many acquisitions in recent years means the company doesn't have a culture anymore.  Moreover, in all the layoffs that happened at Denver office (4 layoffs), not even a single manager was let go, while hundreds of individual contributors was shown the door.  This is so unusual for a tech company, and reveals how the politics at Denver office works.  Most of the Denver managers have been there for a long time because they are incompetent and won't find work elsewhere.  This has created a culture of favoritism and mediocrity.

review_title: B+
pros:
Ability to move around and learn new things. There is plenty of opportunity
You do have good people around you
Allowed to work from home. This takes some time to get used to, but it is very nice once you do.
cons:
Communication is challenging when you don't work in an office...sometimes you miss the old days of learning what is new around the coffee pot
The mindset is that you should be happy to work for them and this is frustrating. I had a lot of perks at my previous company that motivated me and made me feel appreciated. We have none of that here.

review_title: If you're in a services group, the only thing that matters is being billable.
job_title: Senior Principal Consultant in Reston, VA
pros: You have the ability to take classes at Oracle University (assuming your project manager will actually let you leave the project for a week), and you get to work with very smart people
cons: The work/life balance is a struggle. You can easily end up traveling a great deal or working on a project with a terrible commute. Management seems to care very little about employee's career goals and doesn't keep promises. And for your efforts, you can expect very little in the way of raises.

review_title: Good Work environment, horrible compensation
pros:
Flexible timings
Lots of travel opportunities which allows you to have client side experience.
Seniors are easily approachable.
Great exposure to Banking Domain and on how Banks around the World work.
cons:
Poor HR and their Policies. Instead of pushing the problems "up" they push it down.
No more earning on travels. What you spend, keep the bills and get it reimbursed. Loose the bill you pay from your pocket.
Unstable Product.
In the guise of Product Company, works like Service Based Company.
Worst Compensation in the IT industry.
No effort to retain experience people as a result of which product quality has taken a nose dive.
Blindly implementing Oracle Policies which doesn't fit in Indian companies.
Not much to learn in terms of technologies. Either you work on Java/J2EE or PL/SQL.

review_title: low pay, terrible culture, complete lack of respect and professionalism
job_title: Deal Manager in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: The benefits are ok. Flexibility used to be a pro, but they took that away from us in the Contracts/Deal Management group.
cons: This company does not care about its employees and shows it by across the board no pay raises (that's right - no COLA - seriously I'm not kidding), disrespect, and a terrible top-down culture. Several people in my group have been at the same level for 5 years or more without any pay raise whatsoever. These are excellent, hardworking, licensed attorneys with impressive backgrounds in technology and the legal field. These employees have stuck around because of the flexibility the job provided. Now that the flexibility is gone, the employees will follow. If you're interested in making less money over time, work for Oracle.

review_title: Great people but slow progress
pros: I loved the work culture and talented people. I always had flexible timings and my leadership was performance oriented. They have acquired a lot of great assets over the years. Travel and general benefits are great in Oracle. As they say, 'Larry will pay (LWP)'. Few companies have such liberal policies. This is great because for a few bucks more, people offer much more productivity in return.
cons: There is too much old technology and old thinking in the company. This is holding them back from making great products. The tech process is so slow that you don't really see any impact of being there unless you stick around for a decade!

review_title: Culture better than expected but bureaucracy is crushing and company is way behind in the cloud transition
pros: A lot of good, smart, friendly people, supportive culture and decent pay.  Acceptable work/life balance.  Good flexibility in achieving your plan, i.e. willingness to make adjustments due to changing business conditions.  Acceptable autonomy in doing your job with help if you need it.
cons: Unreal bureaucracy, more time spent filling out spreadsheets, reports, and PowerPoints than in actually doing your job.  Feels unnecessarily hard to get anything done, also that too much energy is going into simply justifying your function's existence.  PTO plan is way behind the times, particularly for a tech company.  No merit increases.  Seems every year they take something away - 2014 it was car allowances, 2015 it was forced PTO at end of year, announced after 3/4 of the year had passed when many already took the year's PTO and now owe it back (or get it deducted next year - are you kidding?).  For a company with considerable resources, not enough attention and focus put on programs to transition to SaaS-based business model.  Senior management and HR seem way out of touch with the way people expect to be managed today and what's actually required to run a successful tech business in the cloud.

review_title: Great company to work for
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Oracle is the database company.  If you work in the database kernel group, you will learn the state of the art in the relational technology.

If you want to learn how to develop database applications, again this is the best place.
cons: Oracle is huge company.  There are pockets of inefficiencies and career stagnating positions.  Treat Oracle as a microcosm of the software industry and move if the learning stops. Don't become too comfortable in your position as it is easy to do.

review_title: Territory Sales Manager
pros: Oracle sales provides excellent opportunities for sales people to achieve excellent compensation. Salespeople also have a lot of latitude and autonomy in managing their territories and activities to meet sales objectives.
cons: Oracle emphasizes quarterly results and everything is geared toward making the quotas from the highest VP down to the field.  While this is not unexpected in any sales role, because of the quarterly focus, there is little in the way of professional development and career guidance.  While the self-service nature of Oracle is great for representatives who value independence, this also translates into taking control of your own career progression.

review_title: BEWARE OF FAKE REVIEWS!
pros: Gym in the building, insurance, free biscuits and instant coffee/tea.
cons:
Was not going to leave a review here, but am disgusted with what Oracle has done recently.
Notice how there was a lot of negative reviews for Oracle Digital Prime over the course of several months. Then, suddenly within a matter of days, all these positive reviews popped up! I assume this is because they still need to recruit more people and lots of people have been discouraged to join based on the negative reviews, WHICH ARE TRUE AND FAIRLY OBJECTIVE!

I am part of the Digital Prime Tech team and it has been a very disappointing experience. Just read the other (non-fake) reviews: management through fear, incompetency, demanding results without proper training and ramp up, etc. Unfortunately, from what I know ODP Applications is just as bad.

review_title: Fantastic opportunities, but hierarchy-obsessed
pros: Oracle is a huge and diverse company, and works at quite a pace for a  multinational employing more than 130,000 people. The job variety is excellent, and the "can-do" attitude that pervades the company allows you to actually achieve what you set out to do.
cons: Quite elitist in terms of the decision-making (and remuneration); sometimes job titles, status and levels are a matter of disproportionate focus. A lot of senior people have been in situ for years - in some case more than a decade - and are under no pressure to rotate onwards, which means progression can be slow.

review_title: It’s all about the big O, clients; customers come along way down, and employees don’t count.
pros:
Good work from home policy.
Gym on site.
Oracle has purchased some great products.
cons:
Slow, everything is slow – but your management and clients wants everything quickly!
For one deal or a client request you may need to deal with up to 3 different time zones, which are all behind us (Australia) in hours. This becomes very stressful. Not one person knows how to complete a single task if it goes of the core path, which is often. As a self-service operation, a LOT of time is wasted in self service applications. 
So much time wasted on duplication of reporting, to your management and other teams.
For a large company, it has no real perks for the stress and hours required to complete your job. No pay rises. No atmosphere. No Celebrations.

review_title: Sales Repsentative
pros:
-Talented and great colleagues
-Challenging and interesting
-Reasonable targets, if you have experience about complicated IT sales and have a decent accounts.
-Good products (R&D  is paying off)
-Office Location
-Alright pay
-Well known name for CV
cons:
-Internal politics between field and Oracle Direct sales
-Reputation of Oracle
-some of senior management, focusing more to create and toxic environment than actually to care about the customers
-More compulsory technical training for sales people, and pre-sales as well , start from the basics. 
-Some people think that they are better than other people, when working at Oracle.

review_title: Land of the living dead
pros: Great benefits, job security, good people. Huge company so you can find any type of job there and I do believe some people loved their jobs.
cons: No merit raises, metric crazy management that rated you every month on your  metrics that were many times out of your control. Ego-maniac leadership. People looked unhappy there and walked around like zombies. Company so huge that you would think you could move to other jobs and find the one you like, but there were many walls to moving. They wanted you to "pay your dues" in your current job before you could move.

review_title: The Average Corporate Beast
pros: Good Flexibility (with the right Manager), potential for progression in the right departments, benefits are decent, work is challenging and lots of resources to learn
cons: No roadmap for Corp Direction, big ideas but no execution.  communication is spotty at best, youre better off reading the WSJ about whats going on with the company.  Recognition is varied, it really depends on how much your manager cares for his directs.  you can easily be lost in the corporate landscape without proper management support.  Pay raises are extremely hard to come by.  Unless you get a promotion dont expect to see any salary increases.  If you do, its a joke (<2% on average).

review_title: Not a bad company to work for.
pros: Looks good on your resume. You can maintain good work life balance if you want. Hiring process is not very lengthy - maybe 3-5 interviews and background, reference checks. They are devoted to cutting costs and as a result reliance on technology is high. I like the bonus structure and the fact that they are paid out quarterly as opposed to yearly. It may take a few weeks to get used to everything but life gets easier after that.
cons: You can get lost in the crowd. Onboarding process is very hap hazard and it takes a while to get used to settle in. I don't think they are the best paymasters in town.

review_title: Oracle is good for stability and flexibility, poor for compensation
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Stability of Company - it's doing pretty well when others are being bought up
Flexible work hours, at least for some teams, it depends on your manager.
Knowledgeable people to work with, alot of smart people here
Training Opportunities are good to increase your skills with classes and some money for education
cons:
Pay and bonuses are low, and you usually don't get regular salary increases, and if you do, it isn't much.
Can be hard to move very far up and take on more challenges since it's such a huge company, so you have a lot of competition up the ranks.
The Executives are paid way more than their peers at other companies, while the workers are underpaid, so it can make you feel very unappreciated.

review_title: Great for resume, not the best internal communication
job_title: Principal Product Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: The best things about working for Oracle was gaining experience from a major software giant and having that experience listed on my resume.  Oracle on your resume is very impressive.  I also feel that the pay was competitive and the benefits were the best around.  Great medical insurance and if you work at HQ--a fantastic campus.
cons: For me, the main downside of working at Oracle was the lack of cohesiveness within the company.  I felt very disconnected from other parts of the company.  I was in Development, but felt detached from other product teams that supported our product.  I feel that management in general is good, but my department was very secretive.  Communication was not the best.

review_title: Big Company, many groups
job_title: Applications Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros:
They have great benefits and a good starting salary. 

Of all the different teams and products at Oracle, I am lucky to be in a very good group for a good product.  My group works in smaller teams, and our product is a smaller product so we have more control over our code, thus making a bigger difference to the product.

I did start at Oracle in a different group and it wasn't as enjoyable or rewarding.
cons:
It is a big company, and you might not initially know if the group you are joining is good for you or not.  But it is relatively easy to switch within the company.

Promotions and raises are also quite infrequent.  I know great engineers who have been working there for years but haven't moved any where.

review_title: Tremendous experience, great place to understand how to pull together complex solutions
pros: Oracle continues to add software assets to its portfolio making it very difficult for competitors. A customer in any industry that Oracle serves would be hard pressed to ignore Oracle as a provider of business solutions
cons: Oracle's sales strategy is to staff each solution area with an independent quota carrying sales team, this results in a large uncoordinated effort with multiple sales people calling on the same account and the same set of people.  Oracle is harder to do business with than most other software companies.  And it is difficult for sales people within Oracle to focus on the job of selling vs managing the internal strife in account ownership

review_title: Do not expect pay rises or career progression if you are not in Sales or development
pros:
when it's not end of quarter, the atmosphere is quite easygoing, the hours aren't too bad
if you like autonomy, everything is self directed here, you basically get no help from anyone for anything
cons: unless you are in Sales or development or something 'front-end,' you cannot hope for any kind of pay rise, career progression, etc. It's given to a few people and everyone else just helps the Oracle machine tick over. I would NEVER recommend this place to anyone unless they were senior and respected in their career, then Oracle has the bucks to win you over, because they're so good at saving.

review_title: Work and professional atmosphere
job_title: Service Delivery Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros:
For the most part, work life at Oracle is good. Colleagues can be broadly classified into only 2 ethnic groups at mid to low management levels. As you move up the chain, you find other ethnic groups occupying mid to higher management positions.

10 years ago, interview process seemed rather complex, but now, it seems to have gotten much easier to get through the process and become an employee.

Great gym facility. I know lots of folks that don't want to quit the job because of the excellent fitness center!
cons: Salary not so great, especially if you signed up for lower end of the spectrum. Raises are hard to come by, so negotiate initially for what you want to get for the next 10 years!
