review_title: Great Benefits & Pay, have to put up with Oracle
job_title: Consulting Sales Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: Oracle is very clear about what it's selling, and that is anything Oracle.  In sales, they are very clear about what it is they want you to do and pay fairly well for success.  They do have a tendency to add some sort of "gate" to commission plans that end up managing compensation.  Benefits are the best I've ever seen for very low cost.
cons: There is no spirit of collaboration at Oracle.  Everyone is incented to compete with each other and think of themselves first, the company second, and the customer third.  Moving between divisions can be difficult, unless you "know" someone.  Initial compensation better be good, because there is no such thing as raises.

review_title: A truly soul-less company
job_title: Senior Solution Consultant in Toronto, ON
pros:
Decent pay
Training in Oracle products is usually available
cons:
Upper management constantly shuffling things around - doesn't seem like they know what they're doing
No pay raises ever - that's policy
Everything is driven by the bottom line - no allowances made for happy emplyees
No real chance to move around in the company due to hiring freezes and various policies

review_title: Oracle is a smart company that attracts great talent
pros: You will be in some of the best conversations of your career--a very smart company with great colleagues when you find your tribe within the organization.  Great customers, and great opportunities to learn new things all the time.
cons: There are no merit pay increases.  Being a great performer is not rewarded at all.  I was talking to a colleague that just left the organization and he had not had a raise since 2009.  Another colleague had not had a raise in 15 years!  There are instances where they just take pay away because they are not going to offer that benefit anymore.  There also seems to be no effort to retain really good to great talent.

review_title: Review
pros: as a huge corporation Oracle has the resources to provide some pretty decent benefits. The extensive range of products and services can present 'safe' opportunities to branch into other areas or make career path changes - or try your hand at something new or different
cons: easy to get lost in, or become a 'victim' of the Corporate Political Machine, where chasing the $'s to satisfy the greed of unknown shareholders and maximizing their return of investments, becomes more important than common decency and social responsibility.

review_title: Bean Counters at the Helm
pros: oracle is the largest start up you will ever work for.  lots of opportunities to innovate and try out your ideas.  great flexibility for internal transfers.  benefits are terrific, with most people allowed to work from home.
cons: salaries in marketing are among the lowest in the industry and it is very hard to get raises.  good people tend to leave.  bonuses infrequent and small.  executive management is focused entirely on corporate earnings, and budgets are small and diminishing.  management is not interested in investing to position oracle competitively in the market

review_title: Retired
pros:
1) Excellent benefits
2) Competitive starting salaries
3) Individual experiences vary WIDELY from business unit to business unit
4) In my unit, one could take courses at Oracle University frequently - training was great!
cons:
1) Management styles make a huge difference in promotions and salary hikes
2) Raises were non-existent for most during the 2004-2014 timeframe for most
3) Individual experiences vary WIDELY from business unit to business unit
4) In consulting, it's rare to be able to have downtime to take courses; if you're on the beach long enough to take a course, you might find yourself on the unemployment line
5) Great investments have been made to offshore jobs; if a company can hire 12 people at a cost of one person, it's considered a positive if managed correctly

review_title: Oracle, an Average Company
pros: Self Service environment.  Mgmt is very open to new ideas and innovations.  A lot of opportunity to advance career.  The ability to add on your resume that you worked at Oracle.  If you are in sales Oracle is a great place to work.  Revenue generating positions are highly compensated.
cons: Oracle currently uses it's own Oracle EBS software which is far from the best technology on the market.  From a technology standpoint you are behind the times in HR and Payroll.  HR policies are very weak with little consistency across organizations.  For example, there is not a uniform policy on performance evaluations.  In payroll we used the tool built in the system.  In HR reviews were conducted over email.  Employee appreciation is poor.

review_title: Too many useless managers directors and VPs
pros: Good benefits, flexible, can move around to other orgs within the company but not so easily.
cons:
Some organizations are efficient but it doesn't last long.  Eventually you will see the corporate culture of "build vaporware fast then throw it away once another company is acquired that does it better".  Once that culture starts to creep in you find yourself looking for another freshly acquired org within Oracle that hasn't been tampered yet with the culture.

Most VPs are territorial, they are purely after higher headcount and titles and not after better product and inter-org collaboration.  You stay low you will do well.  You try to show competence you will feel very frustrated by lack of passion or the overall apathy.

review_title: Oracle: Bring your A game.
job_title: Business Development Manager in Redwood Est, CA
pros: Great product line and prestige. Also, the vast majority of Oracle employees are very intelligent and very talented. It was great to work with a group of smart people.
cons:
Incredible pressure to perform NO MATTER WHAT. They are very intolerant of outside circumstances and current market conditions. The numbers have to be met no matter what happens. No excuse is tolerated and that is because the expectations flow upwards. Each manager has heavy expectations on them and each one of their managers has even more on their shoulders.

Also, Oracle will reduce staff regularly and without any fanfare in the market place. They will whack chunks of the org chart with no notice. Only producing salespeople are safe.

review_title: Stable company with conservative design
job_title: User Experience Designer in Redwood City, CA
pros: Slow-moving pace means a great work-life balance. Also Oracle compensates very well, both with salary and other benefits.
cons: There is a lot of political inertia here, it's a conservative culture, and ultimately this is a developer-driven organization. Designs always get cut and scaled back. Truly creative designs are unlikely to get built and shipped here. You will end up spending at least as much time on organization and project logistics/management as you do on design.

review_title: Great pay but little loyalty
pros: The pay was excellent and the bonuses were great.  The benefits were very good as well.  If you like the challenge of constantly learning new products, features, functions and selling techniques it was a good environment in which to work.
cons: There was an every 'man' for himself mentality.  You sank or swam on your own.  If you were a self-starter, willing to put in tons of overtime to learn the products, politics and systems on your own you could succeed.  However, hard work was not always rewarded with any type of loyalty.  Decisions often came down to politics.

review_title: Not a bad place to work, but lower than average pay
job_title: Senior Technical Support Engineer in Burlington, MA
pros: Great opportunities if they're taken advantage of.  Many divisions offer flexible work schedules and they have a fairly relaxed dress code for non-sales or marketing.  Oracle's huge, and there may likely be travel opportunities, but the company does incorporate telepresence and in-house telecommunication applications.  The benefits are pretty on-par for the course.
cons: Raises and salaries are often a herculean struggle to fight for.  Upper-management will start/engage in many projects but skip-level meetings and top-down engagements to get the status of "the boots on the ground" are too rare.  There are no employee-only conferences for many divisions.

review_title: Some good, some bad, pretty much like everywhere...
pros: Most of my work is remote and remote workers are supported well.   I have good team members on my projects, almost 100% of them are motivated to do the right things.  I don't need the medical benefits (I use my spouse's) so I actually get a credit $$ amount in each paycheck.  Nice 401K match.  Lots of training available online.
cons: No salary increase companywide in 2013.   Bonus amounts - management does not ever share how they are calculated.  I never have any idea what I will get.   I know several people who have gotten promoted with no salary increase just so they wouldn't leave.

review_title: Great company for those planning to settle but not for beginners
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros: Both the pros and cons mentioned here are specifically of my team. It varies from team to team. The work-life balance is great. Initial compensation was pretty good. A very relaxed work environment. Very friendly colleagues. No inner politics. Learning opportunities are limited.
cons: Annual hikes are not so great. No bonuses. Visibility of the team in India was almost zero. Possibility of getting completely shadowed by the HQ counterpart(and that affects the increments). Not a place for those at the starting of their career. This place will make you lazy and you might struggle when you switch your job.

review_title: Army of Road Warriors
job_title: Senior Principal Consultant in Dallas, TX
pros: Oracle provides a good salary and great benefits to its employees.  The company is widely known and there are multiple offices across the country.
cons: Constant Travel and insufficient training.  Management does not look for the best resource to place on a project for a given product.  If you are available, you are placed on the project regardless if you have ever worked with the product before.  Oracle has a number of product offerings that do not integrate well together.  If issues are raised, the sales team is engaged to offer another product.  So it is often left to the army of consultants to figure out how to get everything to work together.

review_title: Worst place I've ever worked at.
job_title: Senior Director Marketing in Mountain Home, AR
pros: Great health care benefits and good ability to work from home.  That's it.
cons: Everything is self service- all apps that one has to use, but they aren't intuitive, help desk is an hour wait on the phone, and search tools for online help are ineffective.  They get most of their employees through acquisitions, promise bonus programs, and renege on them.  Pay is below par, it's such a huge organization that you can't see the value you add, and no raises.  I worked 12 hours a day as I dealt with marketing groups across the globe.  It was hell on earth.  I'm 55 years old, have worked at many companies of varying sizes, and have never felt so undervalued, ineffective, and used.  I couldn't get out of there fast enough- but it took me nearly two years.

review_title: Ocean of Learning, explore and grow
pros:
All pros and cons are my personal views based on my tenure in Oracle Noida

1) there is no limit of how much you can learn. Linda, Otube, Oracle Streams, OVMs, MOS are to name few.
2) facilities of a product-based company
3) oracle trainings/documentations are one of the best 
4) Profile value increase if you have it on your CV
5) Individual Contributor role
6) no micromanagement (totally depends on your manager) 
7) your peers, colleagues, seniors are technically very sound and you can learn a lot from them.
8) Work from Home. great work life balance
cons:
1) less or no hikes compared to other product-based companies
2) hard to negotiate for initial offer.
3) not enthusiastic about non-technical activities.
4) no onsite for some LOBs
5) cost cutting attitude of higher management.

review_title: Worst place I've ever worked at.
job_title: Senior Director Marketing in Mountain Home, AR

cons: Everything is self service- all apps that one has to use, but they aren't intuitive, help desk is an hour wait on the phone, and search tools for online help are ineffective. review_title: Good for long term employment and role changes
pros:
Great people with some of the best managers I've ever worked with
Very flexible with working from home
Decent benefits
I'll add the "Self Service" culture here as it's something I appreciate
The company is so big you can always try to switch to a different role and department after a while
cons:
You get stuck with the same salary for years on end, so do negotiate carefully
They are much in favour of "dry promotions" with no salary increases to match the new role
You always need an endless supply of patience to navigate through the byzantine internal policies and argue with other teams that don't always realize you should be working towards the same goal

review_title: Its a big company.
pros: Good benefits and Learning opportunities, fantastic place to stretch your knowledge and get involved in essentially whatever gets you the most excited to be at work every day!
cons:
Top -> down mentality when it comes to instituting new things into the environment, definitely feels like any advice passed upwards, no matter how well documented or presented, is ignored/shot down once it gets past "local" management. 
I have several co-workers who have not received raises, even as little as 2%, in the last 3 years, in spite of the "huge revenue growth" emails we receive periodically.

review_title: Powerful company and a stable employer at a global level, less on a regional level.
pros: Salary above average if working directly with Oracle, not as a contractor; huge and unlimited learning options. Many benefits ( health, service providers, discounts) and business learning from the many interconnected departments.
cons: The most sad thing that makes people leave the company is that the salary increase is almost mission impossible at Oracle. Unfortunately, if one already has 3 years within the company he/she gets amazed when finding out that new comers have the double of the salary for the same position.

review_title: No pay rises, no career path
pros: Flexibility, some work colleagues are great to work with.
cons: No recognition from Oracle overall, no career path. Raises and reviews do not exist.  Oracle pays lip service but it is not transparent - yearly review comes round and closes without any information being shared - no one is  told there will be nothing.  Year on year workload increases with no chance of additional help.

review_title: Great growth opportunities for self-starters
pros: Lots of resources available for development, training, etc.  Bright employees, and overall, management seems to 'get it' in terms of what the job actually is -- minimal 'pointy-haired bosses'.
cons:
not a lot of guidance or support - very much a 'self help company' - the resources are there, but you may not know about them, and no one will go out of their way to make sure you're getting what you need.

Good place if you have a plan, but there isn't much structured guidance on what you're supposed to do

review_title: Requires an acquired taste.
pros: Oracle helps you get a brand name on your CV. There are enough opportunities internally and across divisions to keep climbing regularly. Exceptionally well positioned for the recession.
cons: With all the M&A activity in the last 4 years the company has become a confusing place to work in. There is too much of change happening all the time. Change is a good thing - in moderation. Unfortunately - Oracle changes for the sake of  "change".  It is a machine - that will become obsolescent in about ten years - unless they are able to find a way to work with the market - other than muscling their customers.

review_title: We have no contact with Larry, there's a relatively big chain of managers.
pros:
(Note that I'm talking about Oracle Consulting here.)

- nice package (salary, car, ...) for a young graduate
- looks good on your resumé
- great trainings from Oracle University (though it depends on your manager how easily you can follow the trainings, as your cost center pays for them - they are not free)
cons:
(Note that I'm talking about Oracle Consulting here.)

- not a lot of knowledge sharing, both company-wide and from management
- I've heard the salary isn't very good for more senior-level positions
- unclear what your career possibilities are within the company

review_title: Stuck below a swirling mass of moderately qualified VP's
pros: It's good to be part of the mongol horde.  In our industry, it's a good name.  Larry rocks, as always. If you can't work for Steve, Larry is the next best.  The network you can build at Oracle wills spread throughout the industry over the years - everyone leaves Oracle and goes to a smaller place with a bigger title!
cons: Who outside our industry knows what we do?  With all the M&A our DNA is more mixed up than the average pound dog.  The company is so big it's hard to figure out how to do anything outside your silo.  And getting outside your sile into a new LOB is impossible.

review_title: Great place to work if you can create a niche valued by the company and customers alike but  inflation erodes your pay.
pros: Great products and a continually evolving product portfolio so you get the chance to be at the edge of technology developments and trends. You have the opportunity to make your mark but you need to be highly motivated and capable to get there and remain.
cons: Ever increasing inward focus on who is doing what and why. Self-service applies to everything so you need to sort out any issues yourself such as pc problems, career development etc.

review_title: Secure, medium challenge and growth, perfect work-life balance, learning opportunities and support for higher education.
pros:
The best part is the work culture which more or less gives you ample personal time for oneself and for one's family. Flexible timings, facility to work from home, freedom to participate in extra curricular and social activities, support for pursuing higher education including monetary and leave support. Working at Oracle means working with freedom and with a feel of security in job!

On the professional front, you have a say in doing things. Most managers, and peers are very accommodating. They listen and value your opinions and approaches. At any level, the management encourages and appreciates taking initiatives and coming up with ideas to solve the problems at hand.
cons: Slower growth prospects as compared to other at-par technology and research companies. In-kind gifts and awards are lesser.

review_title: External view of Oracle not the same as the actual working environment.
job_title: Business Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good salary but no or limited bonus or promotions.  There are free sodas.
cons: Internal teams do not work together, acquisition process is very poor and new teams are not worked into the Oracle base properly (or at all).  Product teams do not talk to internal teams to help design the products they sell.  What a great resource internals teams could be!  No training on Oracle products.

review_title: Review process
pros: Overall good company to work for. There is a mixture of great talents and unqualified souls in this company. Great opportunity to learn different technologies and processes.
cons:
There are no mid year reviews to provide feedback. The reviews are not in depth and they almost feel like they are done out of formality. Managers do not provide clear and realistic feedback regarding the employes performance.

Managers need to take management training to handle adverse situations more skilfully. Managers, Directors and senior management should do less sucking up to each other for job security and pay more attention to their responsibilities.

review_title: Can expect a reasonable growth, salary and responsibility in India
pros: Overall aggressive and forward thinking in the Enterprise product space. Company has grown fast through acquisition and assimilation of technology/product. Company culture differs from group to group. Opportunity to work in different technology, product and domain. Good work life balance. Company expects you to be proactive, independent and enterprising. You need to push yourself to move ahead. Remuneration is good if you are a key person in the team.
cons: Large organization, somewhat bureaucratic and slow in decision making. Minimal HR presence, they work as a support team with very less impact to individual. Over time quality of people have gone down. Yearly hike / bonus amount is less and thus not everyone will get it. Growth opportunities are limited in India.

review_title: Poor appraisal system good flexibility
pros: Good flexibility, can wfh any time, US managers don't hassle you like Indian managers,
cons: Appraisal is pathetic, it seems they do it per manager's own wish, there is a formal tool for appraisal but I was never given my appraisal feedback, stuck at the same position for 5 years and the only explanation I get from my manager why I am not being promoted is 'It takes long here to be promoted'. I can't complain to higher management because they all seem to be least concerned about the welfare of employees. I am just working here because my colleagues are good.

review_title: Decent
job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Redwood City, CA
pros: Pretty ok pay, everyone is young and fun. Great work/life balance, you can make your own hours and work from home if your manager is relaxed. No micromanaging, and pretty good food on campus.
cons: The commute is rough and there's no bus from the city (which is crazy considering how big of a company Oracle is...), very sexist company, hard for women to advance, the pay is definitely not enough to live on in San Francisco and they brainwash you into thinking that you're selling the best software out there. You're not.

review_title: Good Company if one is satisfied with anything
pros:
1. Work culture and good people
2. Timings are flexible and no dress code
3. The available knowledge base
4. Low politics
5. Really open door policy
cons:
1. Work is very much outdated in majority of cases. I mean with that experience if some one wants to shift to profile not related to oracle products then it is of no use
2. Very low salary hikes and humiliating bonus(es). Salaries after working for few years will be far less than industry standard.
3. Most of the year there will be no work and one has to be creative to be occupied, unless one is in right team

review_title: Sales Consultant
pros: All of the employees are very inclusive and want to help you succeed.  My manager is one of the best managers that I have ever worked for.
cons: The vacation policy is terrible.  They offer only 2 weeks when you start.  You gain another week after 3 years of service and that is most vacation you can get.  Oracle also makes their employees take the week off between Christmas and New Years using their vacation.  It is not a paid holiday.  In addition, the bonus structure just changed for all of the Sales Consultants so 40% of the bonus is given in the fourth quarter rather than evenly spread out 25% per quarter.  This affects everyone's paycheck and everyone is very upset by this change!!

review_title: Great company to work for
pros: Good place to settle down, offers job security; great work culture; flexibility; you get to work from home; high intelect coworkers/ opportunity to work in collaborative cross functional teams
cons:
In Oracle, you will never get a substantial raise, unless you leave then get rehired- and you have to wait 1-2 years after leaving the company, to come back and get a higher salary. 
They prefer to invest in new. more enthusiastic employees, rather than offering raises to seniors in the company, so you will soon find that you are dispensable.
Be sure to negotiate a good salary prior to starting, because it's pretty much locked in after that.

review_title: Application Sales Rep
pros:
Great products from a technical perspective.  
Onstage teams &  people are wonderful. 
Great Training plans .
cons:
Internal processes are incredibly painful as it takes weeks not days to be responsive. 
Not customer centric - most customers have to deal with 15-20 reps who are not aligned all fighting for revenue - it isn't customer friendly to say the least and very hard to navigate. 
The company is ALL self service however if something goes wrong - it can take months to resolve (health care enrolment, laptops procurement, commissions).

review_title: The tricks of the trade - good and bad
pros:
Sales training is being set up & rolled out internationally, highest level of trainers are available here

Still regarded as one of the top companies in ICT

Loads of room and budget for market enhancement, lead generation, partner enablement, ...

Working for the gorilla, very profitable company
cons:
Incredibly political environment, in which politically inspired people flourish - being succesful at Oracle seems to go hand in hand with siding with the 'powers that be'

Demand for creative input seems more like a front - hence the numerous of Oracle spin-offs which originally pitched to senior management, left Oracle and were succesful outside (e.g. Business Objects, SalesForce, BEA WebLogic, PeopleSoft, ...)  - some of which were later reacquired by Oracle

Focus on the cash-cow, which are the customers using the database - if you are not in the core DB teams, you may have little effect on the course of action.

review_title: Happy experience
job_title: Senior User Experience Designer in Montevideo
pros:
Work schedule is completely flexible. I work from home 2 to 3 days of the week, but only because I like it so much to go to the office. 
I work with a team with other 8 people, plus the management and indirect teams.
The Montevideo offices are very tidy and the workload is good and balanced.

The management is very approachable and people works in a very collaborative environment.

They offer free fruits, coffee, tea, yerba, and credits to vending machines that are around the building. There's also paid a priority health provider.

Salary is good to very good for Montevideo.
cons: Some teams managers are not as flexible as my manager. That can affect parity sometimes and creates a weird atmosphere sometimes.

review_title: Oracle HQ - Experience highly dependent on your team/manager
pros:
- Nice cafes with subsidized food
- Amazing gym: pool, classes, awesome equipment. Massages and personal training available for extra cost
- Lots of employees here seem to have flexible hours
- Good work-life balance
cons:
- Compensation: Minimal raises and slow development, even when you are recognized as a top performer
- Culture: I've met many employees who do not like change or being questioned. There are endless rules and restrictions, and you will spend a lot of time navigating bureaucracy... Especially true in non-tech roles
- Feedback: Nobody on my team has ever received an employee evaluation. If feedback and development is a priority, please ensure your hiring manager shares those values before joining the company

review_title: NetSuite is a very good company...until it was acquired by Oracle
job_title: Senior Software QA Engineer in Makati City
pros:
I've been with NetSuite for 6 years (even before Oracle acquired NetSuite)
- High HMO benefits
- High starting salary
- Good working environment
- Managers are approachable
- Flexible hours
- Work from home
cons:
- Employees started to lose good benefits  (such as bonuses/rewards, no budgets for team buildings for some teams, exciting and expensive raffle prizes on parties)and perks after being acquired by Oracle.
- There is no difference between annual increase and promotion increase
- Upper management has continuously changes in some department

review_title: Great company, great place to start if you are interested in tech
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Boston, MA
pros: Young culture in BDC organization and great training/pay starting out. People are there with open arms whenever you need help at all levels. Overall, the company has a major footprint in tech and you can grow a career if you commit yourself to the company. Keeping a network is important.
cons:
Burlington office is in a nice suburb, so it's hard to live near the city without a commute that's at least 30 min. Work gets annoying, but if you can stay motivated you'll be fine. The product and the territory assigned can determine how your year is going to be. Don't expect to get the full 25k bonus unless you get like 400% of your number. 

Changes come and managers don't even know what's happening.

review_title: Great company that is headed down due to a few type A executives with abnormal psychology
job_title: Product Management Director in Redwood City, CA
pros: It looks good on your resume. Its a great place to learn about enterprise software. One should join Oracle for 1 or 2 years, learn a lot, meet people and then move on fast. It does provide a good work life balance but you need to be careful and not get cocooned. Lots of opportunities to move within the company can help you transform your job.
cons: Oracle has a top down management style. All the ideation and strategy is driven by top management. It is very hard to get recognized at this big company. Some managers are nice while others are outright disrespectful and mean. Its a mix.

review_title: Decent place to work.
job_title: Product Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Large Company - diverse opportunities. Good benefits. Stable company. Growth opportunities exist but vary by division and group. Company growing by acquisition so lots of new areas coming on and there is constant change.
cons: Salaries are low (if you have been there a while). Not as good to employees as some other large companies. Lots of long time veterans so sometimes growth can be stifled. Lots  of politics and some groups have a lot of backstabbing etc, going on. Turf wars between VPs etc. are also quite common.  Also, promotions are quite slow in some divisions and it takes a long time to go up the chain (if you leave and come back, you can short-circuit some of that).

review_title: A good place to start in sales, not a good place to stay.
pros: oracle is a big name within the software industry and is highly regarded as a tough place to sell.  i am sure that my experiences here will translate well when it comes time to move on.  there are opportunities to move around within the company.
cons:
career progression opportunities are limited.  to move from inside sales to outside sales is quite a coup, and rarely happens.
management could be better, not a lot of support and timely communication about org. changes which happen very frequently.  salary raises are extremely hard to come  by

review_title: Steady Place to work. Growth depends on who you know.
pros:
- Pay not as poor as people say. Engineer/Analyst pay above standard DBA pay rates.
- Management have always been flexible and understanding with requests for time off, vacation, training.
- Pretty much go on as many training courses of various types as you want.
- Opportunities to work with acknowledged technical experts and work/transfer abroad
cons:
- Pay rises are non-existent.
- A promotion does NOT mean a payrise.
- Customers and Sr management expect engineers to know everything about ALL Oracle products
- Management do not value technical skills. Believe anyone can do this job and hence outsource to low-cost countries such as Romania and Egypt.

- Management do not value technical skills. Believe anyone can do this job and hence outsource to low-cost countries such as Romania and Egypt.

review_title: Great place to stamp your resume, but not a company where you can grow a long-term career.
pros:
Actively encourages working from home for most employees - they don't care where you live.  This gives you a ton of flexibility in your personal life.

You can entertain yourself with the occasional pet project that you find interesting, but you should treat it as more building your portfolio rather than expect it to take off inside the company (there's a lot of red tape and consensus building required  to push any creative or new thinking up the management chain so most creative or inventive projects often die on the vine)

Being able to say you work for Oracle

Mostly  intelligent and hard-working colleagues - everyone is generally a B+ (not bad for so huge a place)

You can learn about technologies and aspects of the IT footprint you have little knowledge of through osmosis

Lots of options for benefits, and pretty good employee discount programs (Audi, Apple, etc)

Good place to take shelter in during a recession provided you can prove you're adding value

Good place to re-charge your batteries if you're burned out from previous jobs and need time to re-group.

This is also likely a really good place for new Mom's or Dad's  to hang out that need to be at home while waiting for their kids to start school full time.  Your career trajectory will still look good (because of the Oracle brand) but you won't be so consumed by work that you can't do what you need to do at home (plus you'll be working from home if you prefer).  Then when you and the kids are ready, you can leave for something more challenging  to get back on your career path (it's true and, not being cynical! Many people at Oracle do exactly this!).
cons:
Title and Salary Don't Move: 
There's a reason why Oracle has some of the best profit margins in the Fortune 500 and that's because they keep the organizational structure VERY flat (there won't be many people between you and Ellison or Hurd, which is really funny to see) and there are very few people in the company that are empowered to promote people or give them a raise.  Chances are your manager has no authority to promote you or give you a raise - regardless of how much they value you.  This keeps things nice and flat for Oracle while maintaining payroll costs,but you can be pretty sure that the salary and title you come in with will be the salary and title you'll leave with.  Also, cost of living adjustments are almost non-existent so you effectively will experience earnings power degradation if you stay 4-5+ years.  Now, there is an exception to this.  If you come in and you end up on a sales comp plan, you can make a lot of money here, but if you're not on a sales plan, your should plan for a flat salary/title trajectory during your tenure.  

No Career Development Programs:  
What has always been shocking is that there is no "High Potential Employee" program at Oracle like most other Fortune 500 companies.  This should tell you quite a lot about Oracle's attitude towards career development.  Also, there is no program for helping you move around inside the company (only an internal job board). So if you think that once you get here you can move around into other business units you'll be disappointed.  If you're looking to switch jobs internally you need to know someone who wants you and has authority to move you (keep in mind: Networking outside your immediate team or business unit is very difficult here because chances are you'll be working remotely).  Otherwise, if you see a position elsewhere in the company that you'd like to try, you might as well be coming in as someone who currently doesn't work for Oracle.  The fact that the company doesn't have any formal employee development or job rotation program (pre-recorded webinars and an internal job board do not count) is really quite crazy since it's a lot cheaper than giving raises or dealing with attrition because it does help people feel like they're being recognized or being rewarded in some way for their efforts.

Duplicate effort, too much socialization required to get anything done, internal teams competing with each other, ill defined roles and responsibilities: 
 It's not like this is a secret since Oracle is well known for having multiple sales people calling on the same account with none of them knowing this about the other, but this problem is much more toxic inside the company.  It's not like every large company doesn't suffer from these dynamics, but because of the way the organization is structured, if you are someone that gets a lot of satisfaction from owning and delivering a project from start to finish, you're going to spend a fair amount of time being frustrated and held up by other employees that think they have a right/responsibility to weigh in.  Decision rights can be pretty unclear, but the WORST aspect of this is that you spend a A LOT of time selling things internally and making everyone feel heard versus actually executing on a project. A lot of times, you'll start out with a deliverable that in the ends up looking nothing like what you started off with, and it's not a better deliverable, it's a deliverable with a lot of compromises.  I guess it's almost like getting a Bill through Congress in that regard.  Also, because of this dynamic, many projects simply fizzle or disappear (this is pretty demoralizing after a few years).

Marketing at Oracle means "Marketing Communications" and not the "Marketing" that a Product Marketing professional practices
With everything else above to consider, if you have a product marketing background and are looking to practice this at Oracle, you're going to be pretty disappointed (although see the Pro's about working here since everything is a tradeoff)  The heads of Marketing at Oracle are great event planners, and know how to make a big splash with the brand, but that's really the only thing they are focused on.  The CMO is really not a CMO, but really the Chief Event Planning and Marketing Communications Officer (and she does a great job at it!).  This is in no way a sleight, but positioning, messaging, and market analysis are really orphans within Oracle.  I think this is because the most exectives running the business units and the Sr. Execs don'tt feel like they need to worry about these aspects of marketing given Oracle 's size and market dominance.  This is good for Oracle, but not good for your career!

review_title: No morals, scruples or appreciation
pros: the Oracle name carries a lot of weight in the SF Bay Area. There are many "Oracle Perks" and discounts employees can enjoy. The company pays well...and if you have a higher salary, your managment will constantly remind you of this when they ask you to do things you don't want.
cons: The culture is to beat you down steadily, while at the same time saying how lucky you are to be working at Oracle.  Usually, ONE person from a team is singled out for adulation and kudos; that person will possibly get a bonus, while the rest of the team will not.  You will rarely get the opportunity to leave your position for another in a different department; management will squash that idea, even if it means putting you on a "performance plan" or something in your file so you can only work in their department.

review_title: Behemoth. Solid upper management. They know what they are doing.
job_title: Senior Director in Redwood City, CA
pros: Solid upper management. Mostly good work life balance. Flexibility to work from home. When management decides on a course the whole big ship moves towards that in a relatively short time considering the size of the company. The company encourages internal transfers and since they own many different technology, hence there is a great opportunity to learn new things by transferring to right group that you like.
cons: It is a ocean. Some groups are more important than others and that reflects in perks and compensations. Salary is in the lower end of the scale unless you have some unique skill that the company badly needs. In that case sky is the limit. But that is  an exception.

review_title: Great work, poor salary
pros: The work is interesting, lots of projects to broaden your skillset & many very talented people to work with
cons:
No budgets for pay increases!  No matter if the company has one of the best years in the history or Oracle according to Hurd, many employees have not had a pay increase for years.  No budgets for salary increases.  This is the norm as opposed to out of the norm.  If you don't negotiate when you are hired, you're screwed.  Then again, you work 24x7 & there is no monetary award in recognition of that work.  Sweat shop.  If that's your thing, join Oracle.

Lastly, the path is very long for slow progression in the company.

review_title: You can make a Decent Living in Sales IF you exceed your sales numbers
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Redwood City, CA
pros: Making money, building your credibility internally.  Also, being a successful Oracle salespeople is regarded positively in the rest of the industry ie If you 'make your bones' at Oracle, you will likely find more doors opened to you with other tech companies.
cons: High pressure in sales: if you are a Hunter-Killer, you won't mind the relentless emphasis to exceed your quarterly numbers as much.  If you prefer to focusing mostly on your own success, you'll be rewarded.

review_title: Stability
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Broomfield, CO
pros: You can find your niche and if you do a good job you probably won't have to worry about layoffs. Depending on group the work can be interesting.  Since there is stability you won't encounter the politics and back stabbing that often arise at "hire and fire" companies.  If you are willing to stand out and do above average work and show commitment (working late when needed) you will get a raise. Very liberal with working from home. Above average insurance benefits.
cons:
401K match is kind of weak.
Paid time off is very below average.
While salary ranges look good, most are paid below the midrange for their grade.

review_title: Deadend Position
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: Plenty of time to contemplate where to go next.
cons: This could go on for pages. Simply put, Oracle couldn't care less about its vast majority of the employees. Larry recently earned 1 billion over night, however 90% of the engineering staffs that's being making him rich does not get any bonus whatsoever. Pay is significantly below market average, and technologies here are far behind industry leaders. You won't learn anything that is transferable in the next job, except maybe powerpoint slides making and meeting notes taking skills that are viewed as the most important skills here.

review_title: Senior Director, Product Development
job_title: Senior Director Product Development in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Working from home is commonplace; saves commute time 
Good benefit offerings
Some good colleagues 
Somewhat secure as long as you are in the right group
cons:
Top-down management to the extreme
Employees not valued; they are interchangeable commodities 
Salary increases/bonuses extremely rare, except for execs
Difficult to get the required tools to do your job
Cut-throat, political work environment
Frequent US layoffs; eliminated positions are replaced in India and Mexico
Quality not valued - "just get it done" attitude

review_title: Was Happy Not Anymore
job_title: Senior PS Project Manager in San Mateo, CA
pros: You're busy all day long so time goes by fast. Unlimited vacation. You can work from home whenever you want. Offshore employees work US hours.
cons: High stress job, no opportunity for growth, mediocre salaries and shrinking bonuses. Everyone is sitting in line waiting for a promotion and when they do have openings to promote within they either hire from the outside or they hire a friend from another team. Without declaring within the team that there is an opening so others can apply.

review_title: Evolving
pros: While Oracle is a large organization, my team is small, collaborative, supportive and close-knit. Our manager supports a family friendly environment. They invest in their employees, from a training perspective, rewards, and internal opportunities.  Working remotely is  one great perk that keeps me here, along with work/life balance when it comes to travel.  Good benefits.  We use the software we sell.  They are doing more to recognize employees.  We have great partners.
cons: Bonuses could be structured better.  Make sure the required training is relevant to employees if it is not regulatory or compliance related.

review_title: Oracle Digital (if you have more than 2 years of experience in IT sales it's not a good career choice)
pros: Good base salary compare to others company in Prague. nothing special to add here, good new office and life/work balance. Social package
cons: Since the job is so easy to get, you'll often find yourself surrounded by people that bring so little to the table that it makes you question your own career choices. Then there's poor and uninspiring micromanagement. There are so many layers and so many "managers" that add absolutely no value and don't truly care about the people... Huge focus on the operational side of work and a lot of first levels training and product learning sessions (it can be useful just in case if you've never worked in IT or it's your a first job). It's not a good place for an experienced person, there is a huge turnover of the staff 1-1,5 year here is counted as long-term

review_title: Oracle Fusion SaaS
job_title: Senior Director, Software Engineering in San Francisco, CA

- Lower than industry compensation

review_title: Good Company if you want to settle down and do same work through out your career

Great work life balance except for 2-3 months when the work is overloaded

Low salary and low hikes
No salary refitment even though all the employees does the same work.

review_title: Good, but not all it seems....
pros: Great products, great people, and good customers to work with
cons:
Don’t be fooled by the name. I have worked for Oracle for 5 years and received NO formal training on any products, nor been able to achieve any qualifications through the company. Oracle provide some online training, but you are expected to do this in your own time.
If you work in sales or other areas of the company where you bring in business you are treated well. As a consultant you are a chargeable entity - so when it’s quiet you cannot go on training because it affects the units profitability, and when it’s busy you don’t have time.
Staff morale is often low - for example right now we have no Christmas party / meal, when other areas of the business are all being taken out.

job_title: Director of Marketing in Redwood City, CA

review_title: It is great
pros: Company is a very cool company. They dont take you out even if you are on bench for an year like me. Unless you are working for the client-Statestreet bank, your life would be wonderful. We get a free pickup and drop on bus and cab if timings are odd. Shift allowance of 350 is more than many companies. HRs are good. Most managers are really good especially for clients Deutsche Bank and Standard bank. Pay is good for freshers and laterals but increase in hike is lesser. Less projects these days but the brand name of Oracle can always bail the company out. Flexcube is world no 1 software in banking services.
cons: Recession and lesser profits make you miss out on hikes and lesser no of good projects makes it tough to grow in career.

review_title: Stable, profitable company to work for
pros: A tightly-run and fiscally responsible machine. Oracle is great for career stability, though this might depend on what division one lands in. The option to be a virtual worker is a big bonus and keeps work-life balance issues at a minimum. The size/scope of the company also means there are many other opportunities to consider over time.
cons: Sometimes not sure if Oracle is profitable because of its business strategies or because it keeps a tight grip on costs. Salary bumps have been low, and moving into a higher pay band requires savvy and alliances. While the size of the company means additional opportunities, the know-how to find/connect with them is required. If you're not big on networking as a tool to get where you want to go it's not for you.

review_title: Great place for a broad learning across several IT Domains
pros: Huge Knowledge resources for employees and Partners. Very Diverse base of successful products across Database and Applications space and hence the opportunity available for people to gain experience on various technology ecosystems. Very solid Product development Senior Leadership team.
cons: Would help to give more chances for great technical talent from global Oracle teams across geographies to participate more meaningfully into ideation processes which form a part of future vision formulation activities. Greater involvement of global ideas in such a deeply connected global economy should definitely help.

review_title: Great brand & company to build Tech Industry experience, especially in Sales.  Salary increases don't align with tenure.
job_title: Sales Consulting Manager in Toronto, ON
pros: Great work life balance with Flex office implementation becoming more widespread & part of the culture.
cons: Salary increases are non-existent & title changes in Canada are made more challenging by pay equity laws.  Sales culture used to dominate however, that seems to be changing under Mark Hurd where it has become more operational.  Sales at Oracle not as 'sexy' as it once was.

review_title: Coming into the company as a new employee is challenging and often frustrating.
job_title: Business Development Manager in Tucson, AZ
pros: Many products and solutions enable a salesperson to have a fantastic variety of talking point capabilities with customers; a lot of commission dollars can be achieved; company is well known within every industry/vertical
cons: Management is not proactive in empowering their team; rather than supporting team collaboration, it is a very "every person for themselves" type of culture and you have a very short amount of time to prove yourself; you are basically on your own to learn what you need to know as it is defined as a "self service" organization which is very tough when you are new and unsure of who can best answer specific questions.

review_title: Oracle Consulting India Job
pros: Access to inside product info on latest in products, flexible timing
cons: Company does not invest in skill development.If you are fine with watching WBT and expect to become a Master then I can't comment.At the end of day, OCS consultants are like glorified Partner consultants (TCS,Infy,Wipro).No doubt, OCS India does not bag much orders in IN market.They want to bill their resources at US rate but at the same time don't want to invest in train them .I think Oracle is not interested in promoting OCS in India.Can't say about EMEA/US

review_title: Oracle
job_title: Principal Product Manager in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Global company.  You can work from anywhere, with people from anywhere else.  Hours usually flexible (depends on the job).  Pretty good diversity.  Generally good stability.
cons: Oracle tends to be on the low side of salaries.  You may need to be working at all hours to work with people scattered across the globe.  Oracle tends to assume that people are interchangeable, rather than valuing individuals for individual skillsets.

review_title: Big Tech Company
pros: Broad set of solutions, working hard to remain relevant in rapidly changing enterprise space.  Pretty likely to survive in medium to long term.  Experience will vary widely based on area you work in.  In most areas ability to pursue new ideas is relatively easy.
cons: Not a warm and fuzzy place.  People tend to do their jobs but not form relationships with coworkers.  Ongoing focus on cost - very difficult to get raises, options etc.  For older workers looking to finish careers may be an ok place but for younger workers either don't come or plan on staying a very short time.

review_title: A well run company, but lay offs are not uncommon.
pros: Really good communication across the company. Oracle uses its own technology, so using the internal systems is pretty easy and reliable.
cons: This is a huge company, and nearly all decisions come from the very top of the food chain. Everything is driven by the bottom line, so lay offs occur without warning and typically make little sense to individual contributors. Don't think that just because you're swamped in work, you're too valuable to the company to be laid off. You're not viewed that way. The people who pull the levers have no idea what you do day-to-day.

review_title: In Transition
pros: Oracle is a financial sound company with a clear vision of the future.  Everything in the Cloud.  They are well positioned for this future having the full stack of technologies from the "Chip to the App" as they say.  This is true and the key will be the execution.
cons: Oracle struggles with product verticals and the shift from on-premise to in the cloud.  The challenge is a cultural one and is driven by old behaviors and compensation models.  Financial motivation is the issue. People sell what they get paid for. Period.

review_title: Strong team with a great culture

cons: The pace and rate of change has been very fast.  Consequently, some people have not been able to keep up which has resulted in them moving on.  Sorry to see some good people leave, but overall necessary to move forward.

job_title: Senior Sales Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
Personal development, you can do as many as possible learning development, online or onsite courses are available.
When your BU is doing well, you'll be doing well.
True friendships will come out of your Oracle experience.
cons:
When your BU is not doing well, you'll not be doing well.
Employees get promoted as managers for the wrong reasons, therefore there are a lot of bad managers within Oracle.
The sales organisation is not a female friendly environment, you need to grow a thick skin to manage yourself within the organisation.

review_title: tech company for lifers; low paid; no career management
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros:
stable job; safe company; great for lifers

 It's great for the H1B worker sticking by to earn his green card  - Oracle is very good with sponsoring for immigration, in return, they own you for the 3-4 years it takes to get it done.
cons:
no career progression; stupid politics; people not motivated.

Oracle is the land of the walking dead employees.   Pay is low by Silicon Valley standards and the work is monotonous.  In general you require a heavy dose of politics to get anything done or promoted.  People are largely unmotivated except when it comes to positioning themselves to benefit from the annual restructuring - knives come out relatively quickly then.

review_title: Synergies between services/products needed, not just among products
job_title: Senior Principal Consultant in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Resume fodder – everyone in IT knows Oracle
Flexible work schedule and location
Good benefits if you take advantage of them
cons:
No yearly salary increase – make sure you are happy with negotiated salary
Difficult to advance in career beyond a certain point (“glass ceiling”)
Lots of internal politics – need to get the customer as your advocate to be “safe”

review_title: Starting salary decent. Pay increases hard to come by if ever. Flexible working hours, telecommuting available.
job_title: Contracts Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Ability to telecommute --Allowed to work from home with laptop almost completely. 
Flexible working hours
Good benefits package
Good people
cons:
Very tight on pay increases, even when combined with promotion.

CFO has every excuse in the book not to offer pay increases. They are given all at the same time to everyone (if you will be getting one at all), rather than individually. CFO has put it off for more than a year now. Its never certain when the time will come either. Very tight on salary money overall.

review_title: Oracle Consulting - Good place if you can and want to travel 100% of the time.
job_title: Consultant in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros:
Fair salary.
Some good products.
Access to internal material before it reaches GA.
cons:
You're expected to travel 100% of the time and management just assumes this is the life of a consultant and you can't complain.

Oracle Consulting seems to not know how to position itself, tries to compete with other consulting firms instead of focusing on being a 'product' consulting with product experts.

Bonus is a legend. They are hiring so many directors that it's impossible to get profitable.

If they think you are important to the area, you won't be allowed to move to other areas even if this is what you want to do.

review_title: Lucrative but intensely frustrating.
pros: Great benefits and work/life balance.
cons: Priorities shift every year and too many competing viewpoints at Product Management level.   Very slow product development process with unwieldly tools. Some groups very secretive and protective of turf;  "Prove to us that it is our bug, but you can't look at our code."  Since most products were acquired, not developed in house, there is no consistency in how products work internally or integrate.  Some acquired groups have inexperienced engineers.   Useless review process and no raises to speak of.    Highest management levels do not inspire confidence.  Product planning and scheduling are top down.  Schedules always have to slip, by a lot.  *Always*.

review_title: Acquired company now part of Oracle
pros: My company was acquired by Oracle. So a lot of the pros are still getting sorted out. But my company culture so far has remained what it was. It's a fun place to work, with some great people. Time off/work from home policies are great. Plenty of opportunities to help you grow your career and skills.
cons: The growing pains of being acquired are currently main drawbacks. Still sorting out how what we've been doing fits in with how they do things.

review_title: Very challenging and very frustrating.
pros: The best reasons to work for Oracle is the continuous learning curve and the opportunity.to be at the forefront of technology.  The salaries,benefits and bonuses are excellent.  In addition to customer travel there is a lot of business related travel internal to the company and.usually to great locations.
cons: Oracle is not an employee friendly company and regardless of your performance you may find yourself  unemployed for a myriad of ridiculous reasons.....senior managers change frequently and you may often find your career at the mercy of people who do.not know you or your contribution to the company. Many talented ex Oracle employees can be found at competitors...

review_title: Peaceful and no pressure environment
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros:
I worked at Oracle Server Technologies (Bangalore)
- Very chilled out work culture
- Pretty good office
- Nice and friendly people
- Pretty much the best company to work for if you don't wanna work crazy hours and if you wanna spend time with loved ones. They give you a decent pay and you don't work on cutting edge tech, you just do your simple job from 11-5 and head back home without a worry in mind. People are content.
cons:
- Very bad in terms of hikes and bonuses
- If you are looking for intellectually challenging and stimulating work, if you are hoping to ship 'cool stuff' this is not the place for you
- competitors pay a lot more than oracle does (Google, Amazon, Microsoft etc)

review_title: Regular company, not very good salaries
pros: Big company with enough capital, solid enough (and growing) so it won't go broke in the next years. You can have a reliable career plan. If you work very very hard you can be rewarded at the end.
cons: Almost none innovation is done inside oracle, the code is old and there is almost no documentation nor training, the initial ramp up takes one or two years. It is not very challenging since almost everything is already done. Productivity bonuses are almost none, so there is not much motivation on the economic side. Most people leaves because of this.

review_title: Sales and Business Development Rep
job_title: Sales and Business Development Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: No overtime ever. Put in your 40hrs a week at the office and never have to take home your work. A fun group of young people to work with. Great networking opportunity for anyone interested in tech as there is a high turnover of people moving to different tech companies and a welcome opportunity to return to Oracle at a later date.
cons: As expected with a giant of a company, internal processes and change is slow although things are steadily improving. The job is pretty robotic but if you develop a strategy and are self-disciplined, you can quickly make a name for yourself.

review_title: So far so good!
pros: A very flexible company that understands and respects work/life balance thus far.  A lot of resources are available to keep you moving.  My manager has been supportive and is the best at what she does.  It's been an excellent learning opportunity for me being in a new role.
cons: Very self-service oriented and you must work hard to get to know people.  I work hard to reach out and make connections, but it is possible.  There are so many remote workers it is hard to connect real-time with people on the team, but working from home is a plus too.

review_title: Management and PMO need updates
job_title: Principal Technical Consultant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Unlimited PTO, flexible work from home
cons: Crazy hours, management and PMO doesn't have control of development process or client expectations, so builds always run over time or budget or both, leaving teams and customers exhausted and frustrated. Management doesn't listen when ideas are presented for change, and teams/people are undervalued.  Performance reviews are only checkboxes.  Also no advancement opportunities...

review_title: Territory Analytics Sales Manager
pros: Oracle is a robust machine.  There is plenty along the lines of sales support, T&E op ex, and marketing events to help drive the relationships.  Plenty of domain expertise to draw from.
cons: Oracle has a very rigid sales process.  Very difficult to even get pricing out without being later in the sales cycle.  I would also add that there was a lot of churn from a management perspective and that made things very difficult to navigate.

review_title: Toxic Culture, Decent Start
job_title: BI Consultant in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Have to get your start somewhere, and that's where Oracle shines, giving ambitious new grads a chance to make a place for themselves in software sales, which is otherwise difficult to break into.
cons: Where do we start: the negligent managers?  The incompetent reps?  The "bro" culture?  Oracle is not a place for men and women of character, plain and simple.  It's for people who never grew up, never wised up, and never once thought about the consequences of their actions.  Match that with the low pay, shifting promotion standards, and the constant org changes and you have a recipe for disaster.

review_title: Account Manager
pros:
-Flexible Hours
-WFH days
-Fun environment 
-Great training
-Career progression
cons:
-Too much time spent on cold calling
-There are no REAL leads
-CRM is outdated 
-Too many sale reps mapped to an account. I believe there's over 50 reps mapped to each account and as you can imagine, your customer will be extremely annoyed since there's no visibility within Oracle. 
-All activities are tracked with an Excel sheet
-Very old school way of doing things
-Oracle's Cloud strategy isn't doing well. If you're a Cloud rep, good luck making money. 
-No raises

review_title: Deal management in France - WORST EXPERIENCE IN MY WHOLE CAREER
pros:
People are amazing!
Go there only for the line in the cv! Learn as much as you can! You will be able to sale you to concurrents or customers!
cons:
Huge salary gap between the team members (40K€ to 80K€). Do not expect any salary increases or bonus. You will have nothing.
Huge work expected under high pressure : more working hours than authorized by the French law. Sometimes you will leave the office at 2am and you will be required to be back at 9am. So you can forget your personal life you will be requested to work weekends too.
Total lack of empowerment.
Total absence of training and development.
Huge investment in the teams based in UK and in Romania. Nothing in other countries. I think it was the worst experience in my whole career in terms of people caring!

review_title: Obsessed with micro-managing, zero transparency, no corporate values
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Nice view onto the lagoon at HQ
cons:
Can only speak for my own department, things might be different elsewhere. I have never experienced a worse senior leader (SVP). Obsessed with micro-managing and lack of trust and confidence into people reporting into her. Basically everyone left because of this person, but there's a complete lack of self-awareness, and she's managing well upwards. Can't get out fast enough, even if it means leaving a pile of unvested RSUs on the table.

Beyond this, Oracle is surprisingly intransparent in terms of overall business performance, corporate values, etc. As employee, you're an anonymous worker bee expected to perform and deliver results. If you do, you *might* get an annual bonus, but that's not guaranteed, so don't count on it.

In terms of perks, average at best for Silicon Valley: No free lunch/fruit/etc.. At HQ, a total of 16 EV chargers, and they're pay-per-use.

review_title: This review for Hospitality Department only
pros: Big known brand, lots of recourses, Oracle University. If put right management with the right attitude to utilize recourses wisely could be a top service provider in the hospitality niche.
cons: Could pay better, shortage of training. Some managers have luck in product knowledge which leads to missunderstanding between managers and stuff. Overpromise underdeliver. Micromanagement must be gone.  Salary should be structure where new employees got higher pay and senior stuff must train them this is no go. This will lead to unhappy senior engineers and unhappy environment in the office.

review_title: Not recommended
pros:
Good location
Nice coworkers
Good compensation if you happen to make your quota
cons:
The whole OD (Oracle Digital) Amsterdam has become a call center. They only care about your calling and activity stats since very few territories provide opportunities for sale.

You might make your quota but only if you land a good territory. In majority of cases there's no chance of that happening and since territories don't change you're stuck. Have not seen a single case where a sale has happened due to a good salesperson.

Most of the people are given false information during the recruiting process and then realize they are stuck for 1,5 years due to the relocation package.

They have hired way too many sales people. Because of this they've had to divide the territories so that you'll get few accounts that make sense and rest is filled with nonsense accounts.

Most of the people hired have very little sales or technology experience so there's no one to learn anything from.

Very few career opportunities

review_title: Oracle's a very steady ship to be on in some very turbulent economic times.
job_title: Applications Sales Manager  in Denver, CO
pros: Financial stability and product leadership.  The results are that in tough times like we're experiencing now, there is more opportunities and safety.  For instance, the sales organization has built up a war chest that will prevent any RIF's for a substantial period of time.  The products for the most part are leaders in their respective spaces and where there are gaps, the overall strategy to build out an entire integrated application and technology suite can trump the "best of breed" advantage.
cons: It's a BIG company and there is a good amount of process (documented and undocumented) as well as a fair amount of politics to navigate.

review_title: Great colleagues, average salary, below par management
pros:
The work life balance is extremely good at i-flex. Even though you get to work at top notch financial clients, the projects are manageable. You do get very close interaction with senior IT executives at the client site. These contacts are very useful if you ever plan to switch to the client.
You will get very good opportunities to learn operations and processes followed in the financial industry. 
Good brand name in the IT services field. Ths is specially true for the Flexcube product. Of course, now that it has been acquired by Oracle, the future remains to be seen.
cons: Upper management is not employee focused enough. Average salary as compared to peers. Very Political.

review_title: Spanish management doesn't match well with international staff
pros: As Oracle is a big company, in theory it always gives you the opportunity to change to a different place internally. It gives you access to many products and internal services. The work environment and staff are international, projects in different countries.
cons: In this case (Malaga International Consulting Centre): The office was just opened recently so basically (in order to build up the centre) more people where hired, mostly in junior positions, than there is projects available. Lack of training, professional approach to work. There is no real communication with management, neither regarding project possibilities nor regarding the personal career options, experience in previous jobs and preferences are not taken into account

review_title: Great place to work for but a different culture from most other companies.
job_title: Senior Principal Consultant in Reston, VA
pros: Oracle offered a very comprehensive benefit package and a good salary and bonus. A great place to learn new technology to improve yourself.
cons: As a Oracle consultant, most projects are short terms (3-6 months max). You will be constantly changing projects which is very stressful sometimes. Company culture is different from most other companies. A very competitive place. In Oracle, you need to do more than your assigned projects. You were expected to help develop new business as well, which is a very important fact in your annual review and your promotion. Normally they like to give higher title to new hires to attract them. Once you join, it is very difficult to get promoted.
