review_title: You get to interact with some of best brains in the industry
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros:
Open work culture , abundance of learning opportunities, very good HR practices , you get to interact and work with some of best and brightes in the industry, 


Another best and very extremely progressive HR policy  is job rotation …you are entitled to seek opportunities within Oracle… other group after spending 12 months with businesss group which hired you…this policy practiced in both letter and spirit

Support processes are extremely employee friendly 

Its awesome experience especially if are associated with sales/market facing groups…you get to work with some of the extreamly motivated and the highly talented folks
cons: Sometime loyalty to manager /boss supersedes meritocracy

review_title: Oracle is for the most part paralysed by the faceless drones that prevent successful completion of work.
job_title: Senior Principal Consultant in Calgary, AB
pros:
Pay is decent.
Benefits package is comparable to most large corporations.
No real office to report to, high degree of mobility in the workplace, with regards to location.
Matched retirement contributions, without requirement for vestment.
cons: My biggest complaint with Oracle is the way in which competition is promoted within the organization, departments are forced to compete over the same table scraps.  If we could find a better way to foster inter-team cooperation, there is certainly enough business to go around.

review_title: Great leadership at the top, dissipates at mid-management level
pros:
Great vision
Execution
Solid technology
Excellent company resources
Larry Ellison
cons: Too many mid-level sales managers that offer little to no value/insight.  "Oracle bus" wanting to come on every sales call.  Internal systems aren't efficient to use as one would think for a leading technology company.  HR employee policy's are solid on legal compliance matters, but tend to be over run by the business in other matters.

review_title: Excellent company overall, underrated still by most people
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Great financial performance, products, customers, many fantastic employees.  Probably one of the best places for software developers early to mid career.  Successful and smart sales executives can really flourish and develop their careers at Oracle, if they are top notch.  Change is constantly happening in most areas, however.  Employees must be well-suited to adapt to change.
cons: Long hours expected, financial performance of company is priority over employees.  For employees, you need to know your employee number and almost everything is self service using the applications of Oracle.

review_title: Great Place for Senior Executives
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros: Work-Life balance is one of the best in Oracle . You will have time to focus on your Personal life . Culturally very friendly . You will always be in your best of progress in you interpersonal & professional life . For Senior Executives with families around to take care Oracle is the best place to serve . Flexible timings and good workload management .
cons: Except few, Trainings given by outside professional have to be paid for which requires your practice manager and HR approval . Owing to the large management portfolio and team, sometimes for certain issues it takes a long time to reach to the correct team . Sometimes there are tedious process for certain things which unless you know the organisation structure well makes it difficult for you .

review_title: Changing Culture... losing focus on the value of their employees
pros:
- Long 11+ yr career
- Compensated well until recent leadership change 3+ years ago
- Incredible products 
- Outstanding leadership in Development- world class
cons:
- Very little value placed on employees starting 3+ yrs ago with new president 
- Not compensating the Sales Consultants and Engineers who support well
- Increased turnover
- Not Stable or strong leadership at the top
- Losing strategic edge and hiring far too many sales people who are transaction focused vs. true sales professionals

review_title: Good working experience
pros: Support from management, per market they pay above, though my work is critical so quarter end is hectic and have to come on weekends too but get paid heavily if we work on weekends
cons:
Depends all upon the ultimate BOSS, so about my unit 
:- No work from Home, that's heavily needed, if u r working from home on weekends you don't get paid(pretty annoying and if u wana get paid come to office minimum for 6 hours, do not see any usage as works is done anyhow)
:- Be on time, god help them plz, comon yaar, Work is getting done by hook or crook, what else they need 
:- indian culture
These points are related to my business unit only

review_title: Great company, very good management
pros: Flexible work hours, work from home option available, motivating managers, lots of learning opportunities. No dress code! No minimum time requirement, login logout not monitored. Just finish your work and that's all. They pay good too. Even higher order managers are very technical, and managers are ready to support technically and otherwise, making it one of the best places to learn and earn.
cons: Nothing that I can think of. This is a great company to work for. But as in any company, a lot things depends on your manager. So, if you are lucky to have a manager like mine (you are very likely, as I see around), you will enjoy every second of your job.

review_title: Not Bad, but not so Good either
pros:
1.)Get to know the A-Z of Banking Domain
2.)Flexible working hours,however it depends on the individual team
3.)Good Work life Balance
4.)Mid-level seniors are very helpful and polite
5.)Good Brand to build a career on
cons:
1.)Highly unstructured training
2.)The senior most people of the team are just next to Useless,They themselves don't know the technical aspects and just keep poking their noses in your work, you are targeted both for yours and their Mistakes, they even make use of slang and abusive languages frequently
3.)Poor work ethics 
4.)Not at all employee friendly environment( at least in my team)
5.)Appraisal system is of least significance
6.)Salary hike and bonuses are negligible
7.)Highly unstructured work approach

review_title: Lots of Learning and training opportunities.Pay may not be motivating for higher experience people.
job_title: Principal Consultant in New Orleans, LA
pros: Lots of Learning and training opportunities. Benefits are very good. Large customer base worldwide.Company is very focused on launching and offering new and existing products in cloud space so growth is unlimited. Very customer focus. Solutions offered are industry standard. Overall great product lineup lots of big businesses run on it so you seek very good work experience.
cons: Hard to find work life balance. If you are young , unmarried and not much of family binding then you love this company.Be ready to work and travel any hours and time during weekends as well. Yearly Pay growth rate is not very motivating for higher experience people . Negotiate initial salary before joining itself make sure you ask for bonus % mentioned in offer letter.

review_title: Enterprise Tech
job_title: Enterprise Tech AE in Redwood City, CA
pros: The company name?  Oracle is well known for good/bad.. it is known.  They like to say that if you call someone they recognize the brand and will call you back...Definitely not, they know its oracle and it is one of their reps...
cons: Everything...from the management to the culture  to the coffee.. the worst I have ever experienced.  I have been in tech for several years and never thought an org could be this bad.  You always hear stories and thought it would be different, but it was a nightmare.  Avoid at all cost.  The managers are incompetent, arrogant and excellent micromanagers with no understanding how to manage.  They walk around being jerks, telling people they haven't earned their right to be one yet...and that is the goal.

review_title: Disappointing, unless you're in sales don't bother!
pros:
Flexible working arrangements. You have an opportunity to work from home. 
If you work in Sales no limits on how much you can spend on your 'client entertainment'.
cons:
No salary increase until you try to leave. Your colleagues in the same position can earn more than you because that's what they got hired on. 
No career progress, no opportunities to grow. 
Only selected employees get  bonuses with emails not to share that information with others (at least in my field)
No structure and if you need to contact payroll or HR you are doomed, no reply ever!

review_title: What you give is what you get
job_title: Business Relationship Consultant in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Its totally up to you. If you bring or develop the right skill set, know how to build and make use of a network it is a great place to work. International environment, fair compensation, lots of different career possibilities and most of all great people.
cons: Recent changes have lead to a bad mood within some teams on the floor. This is mainly due to some reps not having the mindset to suceed in sales. However, since more and more of the mood killers are leaving, this is already getting better..

review_title: GradeBeam- Severely lacking leadership
pros:
- Nice office in a great location downtown
- Excellent amenities w/ snacks and coffee
- Now a subsidiary of Oracle
cons:
GradeBeam has become a sinking ship under upper management. A major lack in leadership—GradeBeam is an absolute circus. Low company morale, massive turnover, plummets in sales, disgruntled employees, and constantly dealing with unsatisfied clients are par for the course. Not to mention, there have been some alarmingly questionable hires, including folks with known criminal backgrounds.

- Low compensation and the product isn't exactly flying off the shelves
- Management refuses to acknowledge issues with product, even will ignore client complaints
- Practically impossible to be promoted
- Will ignore egregious employee misconduct as long as deals are being closed

review_title: Enterprise Account Manager - Digital Experience - Middleware
pros: Decent benefits, realistic travel related expenses and competitive earning potential in a sales role
cons: Constant change is all aspects of everything (change is good - but not at the pace that it happens at Oracle). Moved in my assignment three time in 18 months, this creates a need to start over again every six months to a year, which is very expense to proven sales professionals in sales cycles that take 9-18 months. Very negative work environment and a culture of ONLY LOOKING OUT FOR YOU!! This type of culture hurts the customer!!!! They need to be more focused on working better internally as a team so we are all focused on the customer, but this does not seem likely to ever happen at Oracle.

review_title: Sales Development Representative
pros: Great way program to join to meet people when you move to one of the sales hubs. You get to go to San Fransisco and the base pay is higher than most other tech companies
cons: Your success depends on highly on what product you end up selling. If you're not selling Oracle database, then you're not going to have a great experience. Your biggest competitor in sales is not other tech companies, but other Oracle employees who work in the same territory as you. It makes it very difficult to sell to someone when 15 other Oracle employees selling different products on the Oracle product stack is saying that they're the main Oracle contact. Very negative sales environment. There is no teamwork in Oracle Sales.

review_title: Oracle SDR review
job_title: Sales Development Representative in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Because most SDR's are hired through the "Class Of" Program, you are surrounded by fun, young, and ambitious people. There are lots of little perks like 2 work from home days per month and access to a nice gym.
cons: The way Oracle is structured is extremely inefficient. You are expected to make huge sales, however field and more tenured sales reps take priority, so if they are talking to an account, you are not allowed to touch it. You can feel like a number sometimes at a big company like Oracle, so it is hard to want to show up for work when you feel like you are not valued/needed.

review_title: Challenging work in a challenging environment
job_title: Service Delivery Manager in Orlando, FL
pros: There are lots of opportunities to become a manager and many ways to get involved with challenging work. Good place to work for those that are very independent. If you can prove your value and have a good level of professionalism, there is a good chance that you will be able to move into a management position.
cons: There tend to be lots of processes which are not integrated with each other across organizations. Frequent reorganizations. Lots of overtime. There are very high demands for your time and the environment is very face-paced. This can cause a high degree of stress for those that are trying to keep more of a work-life balance.

review_title: Good place to work
pros:
* Big company means lots of career opportunities.
* Great benefits program for you and your family.
* Depending on the Team, work/life balance is possible.
* Lots of smart people to work with and to compete against.
cons:
* Big company means lots of process and/or repetitive process.
* Loyalty factor is blemished given Microsoft claims economy is impacting them and laid-off strong performing employees with companywide job eliminations. This in turn puts a permanent blemish on their loyalty factor for those working or thinking of working there in the future.

review_title: Great place for talented engineers
pros: Able to work with a group of very highly educated and highly skilled engineers.  Core database development provides the opportunity to work on challenging problems and develop new technologies.  Work schedule is very flexible.  Many managers are technically skilled and active in development.
cons: Time demands can be significant depending on where we are in the release cycle.  Pressure can get very high as a release approaches.  As with any big company they sometimes do things or have policies that seem really foolish.

review_title: Oracle Review
pros: Chance to work with top level talent across the board.  Expanded it's portfolio where it is a major player in nearly every vertical, offering full stack of solutions from Applications down to back end systems (Middleware and DB) and now able to offer Sun hardware to run it all!
cons: Salary increases are very hard to come by.  Very discouraging to see new hires come in with higher level titles and higher base salaries with little to no experience with Oracle technologies while experienced workers have not received based salary raises for more than a few years.

review_title: Decent company to work for; better than originally anticipated
pros: Solid company name recognition and industry reputation, good benefits w/plenty of options, pleasant working conditions in offices, excellent opportunities for training and personal development.
cons: Huge company; easy to get lost. Bureaucratic structure; a lot of red-tape obstacles to getting things done. Rah-rah corporate culture a bit too much. Pay scale is average, and company very stingy with holidays and vacation days for U.S. non-managerial employees. Middle management personnel shuffling constantly. Virtually all help desk personnel servicing U.S. facilities are outsourced in overseas locations. Too much emphasis on stock performance and the bottom line.

review_title: Large company with some of the old small company feel still left over --- its not all corporate yet :)
pros: Great benefits and part of a large organization with jobs available if your willing to go after them.
cons: Pay increases are not where they need to be for a company doing this well in the market place.  Seems that ever since ORCL became a dividend based stock that management has had very little to reward employees.  Pay increases may require that you come in from the outside to get what your really worth.

review_title: Good on the CV but not for the soul
pros:
Got to work with some great people, particularly in my team. 
Exposed to some interesting hardware and software, allowing me to learn things that normally would have to be learned outside of the working day.
Work from home policy, while not official, can be handy. More so for people like me who suffer migraines, allowing to avoid the hassle of commutes/travel but not use a sick day if the migraine is "bearable".
cons:
No real rewards for hard work done. Level increases happen but in name only.
With level increase you are expected to do more work at the new level but for the same pay as before.
After three and a half years working there, having met every target and goal set before me and even going above and beyond, never once got a pay raise.

review_title: Gotten worse over the years but still good overall
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Reading, England
pros:
- Excellent work-life balance
- Constantly at the bleeding edge of technology
- Excellent employee benefits (Flexible Benefits are cool)
- Resturant at tvp is excellent.
cons:
Non-Existent pay-rises, we have reviews, score "Out-Performing" and still get zero% payrise
Get promoted = more work, no payrise..
Career progression is very limited unless your in "sales"
Mgmt know the problems but are blinkered 
General Moral is low or indifferent..

review_title: Very good experience to learn and grow technically, but difficult to enter the management bulge at top
pros:
Quality projects, onsite exposure, new technologies, Oracle brand, good working environment
Best thing is working in a unified environment with other country oracle resources.
There is lot to learn and grown if you are ready to put in the efforts.
Will get good mentors and might get good managers if you are junior resource.
cons:
Favourism in senior positions, top management bulge, employees sticking for long time are taken for granted, change of managers in quick successions
I faced an issue that something was promised to me in the new location of Noida, but was not given even after 2 years.

review_title: Flexible work but not rewarded for hard work
pros: You can work remotely and the work provides challenges which keep it from getting stale. The health benefits are good and they provide the typical 401k and other comp benefits. Formerly had lots of budget for training.
cons: Low reward for hard work so don't expect competitive raises. They offshore too many colleagues which places a large burden on local staff to rework or take problems that need to be solved in a timely manner. The culture is too self help about HR, IT, professional development, etc.

review_title: Brilliant people under one big corporation.
job_title: Software Engineer III in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros: Flexible hours, you can work remotely any time you want, if management allows it. Tons of brilliant people to work with, Some of the most intelligent people are here and are very open, kind, and welcoming. Never a dull moment, something always interesting in the development pipeline.
cons: Flexible hours also means you could end up working overtime, heavy start-up mentality despite all of the financial securities, the benefits are not good enough in the long run. Heavy inequality, top coders get the same benefits as the worst ones, only incentive to work is self-advancement.

review_title: Depends on what you want
job_title: Account Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good people, best products in the business, best R&D, great benefits
cons: Central control, in sales there is no room for creativity. You carry a bag and sell what is in the bag. The sales avoidance department has much more strength than sales management. Love/ hate relationship with customer is expected, with the belief if the product is good enough you can treat the customer like crap.

review_title: Applications Developer - Oracle Financial Services Software
pros:
-Work environment and culture
-Peer group support
-Flexible timings and Work from home feasibility
-Good support for learning activities.
cons:
- ill-structured management policies
- Appraisal is conducted for namesake, actual hikes and bonus are left to management discretion only.
- Freshers get paid more than experienced (sic).
- Talented people leave the company regularly and company does not bother.
- No recreational activities.
- Less interaction between peer group and higher management.
- Management does not bother or respond to employee concerns.

review_title: Consulting Sales Manager
pros: I worked with very smart people and enjoyed my team. Oracle has so many product offerings that we always had something to sell to every customer. The benefits were also very good. I wouldn't have left Oracle when I did if it hadn't been for a re-org that put me in a position I wasn't interested in.
cons: Like in any large company, re-orgs happen and many times not to your benefit. The executive management wasn't consistent and on an annual basis, things were disrupted, sometimes just for the sake of having a disruption. That lack of commitment to a plan, filters downward at times.

review_title: Not a good place for young engineers
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Seattle, WA
pros:
- Expectation is low and if you are not looking for aggressive career or you are somewhat close to retirement and want to have slow pace environment, Oracle good be a good environment.
- Work life balance
- Flexibility of working from home
- Average benefits: no paternity leave, ok health insurance
cons:
-Slow innovation and doesn't appreciate high performers
-Lower pay raise than market and no annual bonus
-Super low vacation days. I have 13 days but company is forcing all employees to use 4  vacation days in Dec 24 and Jan 1. Therefore, you have less than 2 weeks vacations.
-Low budget for self improvement
-Average skilled software engineers
-Not a good place if you are young and eager to learn.

review_title: Oracle a great place to work?
job_title: Software Engineer IV in Broomfield, CO
pros:
Benefits are good, Salaries are competitive.
Management seems sound, I'd say its reasonably well run, but the money rules business decisions.  They are fairly cut-throat, if your group isn't making money, it will go. this is in the positive section, since, hey its a business, they are there to make money, what do you expect.
cons: Being money oriented, there is some feeling that they should be a bit more loyal, and think about drag on sales that products bring.  Also, on a "current" note, they have had 3 large layoffs in 2017, of a few thousand people mainly in the Solaris, Servers (Sun Acquisition), and Tape (Storagetek Acquisition), so I'd be wary of going into those areas, they "seem" to be going into maintenance mode at best.

review_title: Not a good place for career growth
pros:
1. Work Life balance
2. Work is less
3. Free pick and drop cab facility
4. You can opt for full-time WFH after 4-5 years of service in Oracle
5. You can manage 2 jobs at a time
6.  The scope of passing time is huge
(you will get 1 hour Breakfast + 1 hour break + 1 hour lunch for sure)
cons:
1. No hike
2. No bonus 
3. No career growth
4. No proper handover of work
5. Biased management
6. Seniors act as the authority
7. Office politics
8. No office decorum
9. No team bonding activities
10. Sodexo(meal card) can only be used in Oracle Cafeteria
11. Trust me food (both North Indian and South Indian) served in the cafeteria is worst

review_title: Good employer, but not a passionate place
job_title: Product Director in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Like many of the large tech companies, its a good place to work, as long as you have a good manager. Many opportunities for personal career development and acquiring and honing your skills.
cons: Sales has a lot of influence, and innovation and the products suffer as a result. Passioned product people and engineers move on to other opportunities. For instance, many of the best people Oracle got through the Sun acquisition moved through fairly quickly as they couldn't stand the stuffy culture. Regardless, still a good place to work if you find yourself in a good team, with good manager, working on projects that interest you. So it's all relative.

review_title: Good company, but too many agendas
pros: Good pay and excellent benefits. Overall it is a good company...
cons: The biggest issue is re-org without letting the folks that get involved in the re-org. One dat A is your peer and next he is your manager and then next B is your manager. I seen VP politics games, not fun... certainly if your VP lost and you are the mercy of the new VP and his agenda.  At one point it will get out of control. The other main thing is that in Oracle you use Oracle product period, even if it is garbage, opensource? if it get approved, 25 page form to fill and very little chance to get it approved...

review_title: Principal engineer
pros: HSGBU organization of Oracle is worst place to be in. They operate differently than overall Oracle culture. Few fogs in HSGBU are giving bad name to entire Oracle.
cons:
Micro management, Manger behaves like god here who never listen to employees.  Manager creates un neccasary pressure on employees. Manager will ping you every hour for status update.
No employee empowerment.
No hikes.
No WFH without manger approval. For approval you need to pray your god ( manager).
High stress environment, No work life balance.
No new technology and no learning at all.
I advise not to join HSGBU organization if want to grow and learn in your career.
No on-site opportunity.
All the team members left the organization with in 1-2 years for the team which I joined. I am also looking for change now with in 6 months.

review_title: survival of the fittest
job_title: Vice President in Redwood City, CA
pros: If you know what you want and have the energy to do it, it's all possible. If you're waiting for something to happen, you're probably working for the wrong company. Work with some of the most creative and technically astute people. Never a boring moment, seize the day. "Not possible" is not in this company's vocabulary.
cons: Don't even consider asking for a budget - anything budgetary is dealt with by a politburo. Work/life balance, what's that? Don't be surprised by internal competition, it can be as challenging as external competition. When you're interviewing for a job, make sure you ask the highest possible salary - once you're in, don't expect significant raises.

review_title: Oracle Retail couldn't sell ice to desert wanderer.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Oracle is trying to diversify.  It's database is one of the best in the world.  From a corporate view, Oracle sounds like a fantastic place to work.  It has server software, retail software, analytic software, etc.
cons: Corporate bloat.  Top level management takes a very long time to make decisions on things like salary, promotions, bonuses, etc.  Top level management is too reactive on a quarter-to-quarter basis that some things are canceled before they even have a chance to succeed.

review_title: Good place to work but reluctant to increase compensation
job_title: Marketing Manager in City of London, England
pros: At Oracle I work with smart people. The company gives me flexibility to work from wherever suits me and I have the ability to move horizontally.
cons: Oracle gives small salary increases in marketing (barely inflation) as well as small bonuses despite great financial results year after year. There is a lack of transparency in terms of compensation levels and salary increases don't go together with promotions or appraisals. An employee that may be rated 'outstanding' at appraisal time and may get the same salary increase (or none at all) as the employee that was rated lower.  The Manager has no responsibility to put together a professional development plan for the employee.

review_title: Challenging with a hint of Reward
pros:
- Flexibility in terms of work locations and hours
- Independence, can at times feel like a solo operator with the support of big company
- Total Pay can be rewarding when the consultants don't screw up your deals
cons:
- Consulting is a second class citizen when compared to license sales at Oracle
- Commission is 100% based on billable revenue, with no component for booking the deal
- All of the bureaucracy makes it very difficult to get deals out the door in a timely fashion
- The ability to take risks has been lost as more process is imposed

review_title: Flexible work environment
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros: I speak for my team and not Oracle India as a whole. The team I work for (in server technologies) is very flexible in terms of work timings and work from home policy. Every member in our team has been given a laptop.
cons: The hierarchy is very flat. It takes many years in order to grow in Oracle India. Patience is a must.

review_title: Decent place..Nothing exceptional
pros: Depends on the team that you are into.. Everything depends on ur manager.. Happened to be under an incompetent manager initially, didn't like it..Shifted to a team with a very competent manager, really liked it..  Very good functional learning.
cons: Lack of flexibility to move to different teams inside Oracle ( if they are under a different Line of Business - say consulting / presales / product management ) . That was the biggest problem that forced me to quit..Plus no standards maintained across the teams in salaries.

review_title: A very fulfilling and  challenging place to work with a high level of professionalism and competence.
pros: I enjoy the breadth of our product and services portfolio deployed at so many different companie. This allows for a variety of experiences both within Oracle as well as representing Oracle at our customers. I am lucky that I get to help customers with everything from databases to CRM to SaaS solutions. It gives me a unique look at many different customers and how they choose to deploy and work.
cons: With so many different information repositories, it is sometimes difficult to know where to look for an answer. With different acquisitions, come different processes. Sometimes it is a challenge to know the difference and get up to speed on a different process.

review_title: The cult of personality around Larry is unsettling, and the lack of principles of motive beyond "make money" is grim.
pros: My direct manager was great, that's about it. I wouldn't have taken the job or stayed there for 3 years otherwise.
cons: It's a sales-driven company. Engineering and innovation are not top priorities. The biggest business challenge they face is consolidation through virtualization, and not much is being done to address it other than shaking down customers through audits. The sales force is coin operated and wouldn't know a solution if it walked up and grabbed their nuts. The technical sales guys are spread so thin that it's very hard for them to be effective. The overall organizational structure has more to do with the egos of the senior execs than anything logical.

review_title: Great for individual work, not good team environment.
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros: Flexibility of work timings was the biggest pro of working at Oracle. The work was challenging too, but not always. Team members were of high caliber.
cons: There was no sharing of information by  the management. Especially since I worked out of Bangalore, most decisions were made at HQ and conveyed to us without involving employees in the decision making process. Deadlines and projects were changed often, thus causing disappointment among employees. Employees were not appreciated for their efforts and bonuses were kept secret, thus encouraging a negative culture of secrecy. Work was very unevenly distributed. Changes in projects were not easy, making work very repetitive and boring.

review_title: I have been with oracle for about 6 years now and here are my comments
pros: A lot of scope to explore new things, you will be with the best in the World. Your ideas are respected and you can balance work and personal life very nicely. An admiring place for any learner.
cons:
Compensation wise I am in the same place as I was 6 years ago.... No significant hike. New hires less than my designation get my salary multiplied by 2 or 2.5 

My advise is not to come to oracle in your too early stages of your career. Come here when you already have 10 year of experience in a good position and ofcourse compensation.

review_title: Great for individual work, not good team environment.
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore

cons: There was no sharing of information by  the management. Especially since I worked out of Bangalore, most decisions were made at HQ and conveyed to us without involving employees in the decision making process. My advise is not to come to oracle in your too early stages of your career. Come here when you already have 10 year of experience in a good position and ofcourse compensation.

review_title: A company with a good portfolio of platform products
pros: Recognised brand with a deep penetration into the high end of the market. A brand that businesses would want to graduate to, once they reach a steady state.
cons: Perceived to be an arrogant company to work with by some outsiders, while insiders face growth hurdles due to extremely OPEX focussed management.

review_title: Stable, experienced company with good opportunities for top performers
pros: Oracle knows its customers, and its business. The company focus is simple...build well integrated technology products that addresses the needs of enterprise customers...and then sell them. Oracle does both very well. At least from the product development side, if you're at the top of your game (top ranked in the team/group/org/etc., or nearly so), from a comp perspective the rewards can be stellar.
cons: If you're not at the top of your game, and one of the best performers in your team....there isn't a lot of recognition for even average performers...so depending on the team you're in, and how well you can compete, getting ahead can be difficult.

review_title: If you like working in the dark and changing targets mid quarter then this is the place for you!
pros: Training, work-life balance, people you work with
cons:
You don't get your accounts and targets until mid quarter. Fun fact: we still don't have our targets for this quarter (one month into this quarter).

Your targets might change completely mid-quarter with no warning, rendering all work you put down useless. 

Organization is unstructured and chaotic, and no one really knows what's going on. 

125% cap on targets, and if new PPI's goes through it could be impossible for some reps to reach 125%, it's all about having the right product and the right field reps.

review_title: Application Sales Manager
job_title: Applications Sales Manager in Burlington, MA
pros:
-Oracle invests a significant amount of time, resources and money in employee on boarding and training. 
-Quotas are typically attainable. 
-Understanding and selling various components of the Oracle stack enables holistic view of the software industry.
-Opportunities for upward mobility.
cons:
-If you're not a self starter you can fly under the radar but it will be very difficult to be successful.
-Internal approval processes are convoluted and frustrating.
-Current sales model and inside rep/outside rep relationship is counterproductive.

review_title: Big company, not a bad place to work.
pros:
The salary was above market.
Processes were well documented.
Big company.
Many opportunities to learn about new technologies.
cons:
Little opportunity for career development and growth inside the company.
Performance review process was not objective.
No raises or incentives.
Company not interested in talent retention.
Kept too many people from the old management at Sun Microsystems in the support organization after its acquisition, a company that was for sale because its management failed.

review_title: Sales Development Rep
pros: Great first job out of college, a lot of great training and exposure into corporate life. You will learn a lot about technology, and develop great relationships with peers. Very strong team oriented culture & clear career path. Overall, a great place to start your career and I'd reccommend it-but be aware of the downsides as well
cons: Can get repetitive and redundant at times. Lack of indepth training for the extremely technical conversations. Very large corporation so it's easy to feel like they don't care about your individual needs. Slow crawl to catch up in the cloud race, this definitely effects conversations and calls.

review_title: Field Technology Sales
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood City, CA
pros: They offer very good sales training and there are some of the smartest people you will meet working here.  Big company means if you are successful early, there are always opportunities for advancement
cons:
Poor company culture.  Fierce internal competition among sales teams with very little collaboration.  No emphasis on putting customer needs first.  Internal systems are very difficult to utilize and navigate and everyone depends on tribal knowledge to be passed down.  Soon as you learn a system it changes.  

I started as inside sales and was promoted to the field.  Terrible base salary that is well below market so was heavily dependent on commission to make money. Cyclical nature of the business means that you are left in feast or famine most of the time.

review_title: IF YOU'RE NOT IN SALES OR A VP- YOU DON'T MATTER
pros:
Good life-work balance 
Nice office space 
Decent perks (free online GP service, Bright Horizons back-up care, gym discounts, free Tastecard membership to name a few)
cons:
All those who joined before it grew and stayed are the ones that make the money, everyone else gets offer below market (and part-time equivalent salary) 

This means that top management are conservative, close minded and stuck in the 90s 

No Salary reviews 

No bonuses 

Micromanagement 

Outsourcing to Eastern European countries which sometimes effect the whole business

Underpayment

review_title: Great company
job_title: Senior Account Executive in Reading, England
pros: Awesome company that has a work hard, play hard attitude.. In a sales role you can earn unlimited amounts and the company has worked hard to transform itself to the "Cloud" and change is sales so it matches the need of a modern buyer. If you want to push yourself and work with some of the best, go to Oracle.
cons: The annual reorganisation - Spending three months changing and adapting and then realising that Q1 has gone, Q2 is under way and we all need to sell in 7-8 months to reach target.

review_title: unfair for talented  and good for  with no tech skills
job_title: Principal Systems Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros: work life balance especially for those who can not make things happen and flexible for work location
cons: the management pushes harder to those engineers who are capable to make good products but pay almost same to those who could not make the product work , also even by threatening to add pressure to talented staff, so many old products which do not even have enough customer to cover the costs and not able to move to cloud, and the high level management wrong decision let talented engineers to suffer

review_title: Associate Solution Engineer
pros:
You get to work with cloud technology that’s for the most part cutting edge, it’s caught up to the competition for the most part.

Coworkers are great, management can be hit or miss. The people are technical but personable.

Decent benefits and pay depending on location.
cons:
Management turnover and lack of change management. Too many people not having much to do and not knowing how to alter their workflow.

Lack of experienced SE’s in the hub may lead to struggles moving forward with some responsibilities. IE moving SE’s with 1-2 years of experience into much more involved projects and having them lead. Have heard gripes from other orgs that it’s not enough experience to do the ask.

Depending on your stack you may not be doing much actual development as opposed to being a software user.

review_title: Unrealized Potential
pros: As part of a major acquisition (This seems to be a hobby with Oracle leaders), my job stayed intact and provided me income and benefits for nine more years. Oh, and a big TV was installed in the break room. Sweet.
cons: Original management remained after the acquisition, and thus, little was changed for the better. They even tried cloning upper managers using subpar young, inexperienced favorites with aspirations of adequacy. Unfortunately, that method has succeeded to a great extent: More autocratic individuals moving on up, and using the backs of hardworking good employees as their stepping stones.

review_title: Great people but bad luck
pros: Excellent pay and ability to expand the breadth of your responsibilities.  The management was very privy to market conditions and knew exmployees should be well compensated to ensure we keep our core team stable.  This may have been pricey but in the long run allowed us to produce a high quality product given our resources.  All levels of people in the company always treated each other with a tremendous amount of respect even when the going got rough.
cons: Small company with little resources.  There was always too much to do and not enough people to do it.  Also we were very customer centric so we changed direction as a company whenever a customer suggested it.

review_title: A place to start with a good salary and leave. No recognition at all.
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Good benefits and nice friends to support you when you get frustrated with management.
Nothing else I can think of here... really hard.
cons:
Too big, you are just a number.
Management needs management because there are so many that they need to manage themselves and in the end just few to do the real work.
Compensation for people who are here for long time is not fair, it does not keep up with the market. New hires, fresh students get the salary of senior/principal members.

review_title: Oracle is a great place to work
pros:
1. Interesting work - part of a world class development / sales team

2. Great place to learn new stuff - vast resources available internally

3. HQ campus is really nice, lots of space, gym is great, six cafeterias to get lunch
cons:
1. Salaries not competitive / raises are seldom  - usually only for selected few in the team

2. Hiring people in US is almost always under 'freeze' - if someone leaves then the rest of the team just gets more work - replacement hires are seldomly approved

3. Direction of new products / aquisitions is sometimes confusing.

review_title: Here but if the economy were better....
pros:
Flexible work schedule
Work from home
On-site gym
Close to public transportation
cons:
Limited career advancement
Not team oriented
Projects not very interesting
Constant cost-cutting/not replacing lost headcount is exhausting.
Infrastructure is poor - always cost vs productivity and low cost always wins.
 Nearly every project I've been on for the last 2 years has been canceled.  When started they were all the highest priority - something Larry wanted - and within 2-3 months of hard work, all were canned for the next new thing Larry wanted.

review_title: Margin-Driven, Not Very Strategic
pros: Oracle is very focused on performance and thought leadership, and there are many competent, focused professionals in the organization. The company's acquisition strategy has served it well, and the applications business has grown tremendously.
cons: Oracle is still a company most focused on technology (database, middleware) and now, hardware. Business applications are still not the key focus of the business. There is a lack of strategic vision at the middle and upper management levels, and morale is suffering overall. Sales execution effectiveness has declined over the last 5 years - Smaller vendors are much more agile and tend to put Oracle on the defensive in sales deals.

review_title: Low Rewards, High Stress
job_title: Principal Member Technical Staff in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Good health care benefits, stable company.
cons: Hard work, loyalty, knowledge are not rewarded.  Raises and bonuses have been dismal for many years, and the latest round was an insult.  At the same time, aggressive schedules have ratcheted up stress and pressure. It's getting more and more political, and teamwork is affected.  Top management does not seem to realize, or doesn't care, that in a software company, most of the knowledge is in people's heads, and when they leave, it leaves with them.    The longer you stay, the further behind you fall in terms of compensation as compared to the market.  People are leaving, but I guess to top management, not enough.

review_title: Low Rewards, High Stress
job_title: Principal Member Technical Staff in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Good health care benefits, stable company.
cons: Hard work, loyalty, knowledge are not rewarded.  Raises and bonuses have been dismal for many years, and the latest round was an insult.  At the same time, aggressive schedules have ratcheted up stress and pressure. It's getting more and more political, and teamwork is affected.  Top management does not seem to realize, or doesn't care, that in a software company, most of the knowledge is in people's heads, and when they leave, it leaves with them.    The longer you stay, the further behind you fall in terms of compensation as compared to the market.  People are leaving, but I guess to top management, not enough.

review_title: Such a large organization, it really depends on which part you join...
pros: After coming aboard via an acquisition, it was clear that Oracle is a very large, stable company.  The work life balance is definitely there, there isn't any sort of "startup" mentality when it comes to deadlines for projects.
cons: Being such a large organization, things are very slow to change and move.  The salary offered after acquisition was not competitive, and equity was not offered to make up the difference.   Everything at Oracle is self-service, which is great for submitting vacation time or your updated W4, terminating yourself on a website is not a nice thing.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Big company with lots of name recognition. Everyone knows the company. Many many top notch folks.  Good opportunity to work with world class talent
cons: Oracle has always had a merit based culture.  Go hard or get crushed.  There is tremendous pressure to deliver nearly 24/7.  For many years this was rewarded with great pay and a feeling that senior management at least understood the sacrifice to family and sometimes health that was necessary to be successful.  Now it is taken for granted.

review_title: Overall Good Company
job_title: Hardware Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
1. brand recognition
2. good starting salary
3. great work life balance
4. lots to learn
5. nice campus
cons:
1. no salary increase or bonus for many years thus hurts employees' motivation. promotions difficult to come by, even come salary stays the same. 
2. can't see or feel the impact of one individual's work because org is very large
3. not a good environment for innovation, company seems to follow the model of expansion or innovation by acquisition. thus is not regarded cool to attract young talents like google, apple or startups.  
4. many managers are hired from outside which creates difficulty for them to understand engineers' work cuz they never gone through themselves in Oracle's work environment and infrastructure
5. group politics. bureaucracy.

review_title: Great Opportunity, but
job_title: Applications Sales Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: The technology and the people to work with are great.  They have a great story to tell their customers about their product offerings.  They also offer great benefits.
cons: Many times you are competing against another Oracle employee for the same business.  Because of continuous acquisitions, the company has offerings that directly compete which are sold by different reps.  They let the Sales Reps "duke it out".  In reality whoever has the best relationship with the customer will ultimately win.  Also, their internal process to get an order booked are PAINFUL and feel like order prevention.

review_title: Virtual and self-service
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Reston, VA
pros: The pay is decent and they offer commission if you are in a sales environment.  The company is huge so you can potentially stay and the company and progress.  It is a virtual company so lots of opportunities to telecommute and most teams are virtual.
cons: Oracle does not give raises.  You are left to sink or swim.  No live person help hardly...everything is self-service.  Easy to get lost.  Too much information...information overload...emails are not specific to your position or your pillar...so consequently you get every newsletter, etc...

review_title: Avoid the pillar Storage group..
pros:
I worked in the Oracle Pillar Data systems group as a test engineer and worked on Oracle FS1 product.

The Pros were it was  very slow paced & the people were nice.
cons:

review_title: Senior Assistant Financial Controller

review_title: Great Pay If You Put in the Work
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Fort Lauderdale, FL

review_title: Great experience and a good starstep to what God had planned for me.

review_title: Empty speeches from soulless management

review_title: Great place but be prepared

Be prepared for daily challenges as the information technology industry grows and Oracle wants to be the leader of the pack. review_title: Oracle Singapore

job_title: Contracts Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Depending on the campus: 
-gym 
-organized activities 
-relaxed atmosphere 
-diverse groups of people

review_title: An amazing learning experience
pros:
High diversity of taks and projects, a very interesting, complex and challenging job, exposure to very competent and experienced colleagues and management, a very good "school" from both a professional and personal perspective. 

Very good development and career opportunities, trainings, support and flexibility in changing roles within the organization.

Requires 100% dedication, long overtime hours and work during weekends and bank holidays. No work/life balance. 

Very good entrance salary, nevertheless it stays the same throughout the years. Do not expect your salary to increase - poor compensation and benefits in relation to the amount of work and effort required. 

Very rigid decision process, little empowerment. Decisions are made at high level, no possibility to impact them or participate in decision making.

review_title: Pathetic Political environment

3. Very few onsite opportunites.
4. Salary increments are few and far in between.
5. Same with promotions.
6. Adherence to appraisal process and cycle and their results on salary are adhoc at best non-existent at worst.

review_title: Great people, reactive environment, tiring hours
pros: The people at Oracle, whether in the US or India are bright, professional, reliable and hard-working. Salaries are good. Benefits are very good.
cons:
Work-life balance was inadequate when employees were required to put in 8 hr days and then get back on-line at night for meetings that often ran until after midnight and then required team members to stay on-line afterward in order to complete work assigned that night and due the next morning.  

Processes changed with each release which made it impossible to measure results for process improvement. The reactive environment was indicative of a lack of realistic resource planning or an inability to use that data to manage task requests from upper mgmt. 

Employees sometimes waited years for raises due to an aggressive acquisition strategy.

review_title: All about the Processes
pros: They know good, successful software companies and have the means to purchase them. I was with MICROS prior to becoming Oracle Hospitality.  The success of the original company led to it becoming a desirable target.
cons: The original companies are not allowed to continue with what made them successful. Virtually all processes, were forced into the Oracle way of doing things - whether or not they apply.  This causes extreme chaos for all concerned.  The processes are more important than sales, customers or employees.  Oracle recognizes they are difficult to deal with, but if you want to buy from them or work for them you accept it or go elsewhere.

review_title: Decent place to work
job_title: Senior Principal Software Engineer in Broomfield, CO

Great benefits and good job stability.  Most managers are flexible when it comes to schedules (including occasionally working from home).
cons: Typically no cash bonuses.  If there are, they're small.  Option grants are also generally small if you get them at all.  Software engineering is usually not cutting edge or terribly exciting, but if job security is your goal then that's likely not an issue.

review_title: Hardware engineer at Oracle

review_title: ODP - Tech

review_title: Senior Assistant Controller

Most of the Senior Controllers will dictate full control over all your tasks, email commentary and professional appearance. There are some good Controllers but most tend to be very particular allowing little professional growth.

review_title: Excellent place to learn and grow

Poor bonus. 
Cash flow is too much focused towards acquisitions while employees are not compensated well.

review_title: Database Systems Development at Oracle
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: There are incredibly smart and talented software developers from my perspective in the database division.  If you like developing and maintaining systems software, there are many (and sometimes too many!) challenging problems to tackle in the database.  If you like to learn and expand your horizons, there are many database components, database internals, algorithms, and optimizations for you to investigate.  Developers are generally willing to share their knowledge, unless they are too busy with short-term deadlines.  Management keeps politics to a minimum in the database division.
cons: The company and database division have grown in size significantly in the last decade and have had creeping bureaucracy.  Programming-in-the-large is never an easy task.

review_title: Kind of like selling cars minus the slicked back hair and gold chains.
job_title: Sales Representative in San Jose, CA
pros: Biggest software company in the Bay Area. If you can make it here, you can make it anywhere. Good opportunity to build a professional network, as turnover is extremely high. If you have not moved up after 2 years, move out.
cons: Process, process, process. Nothing gets done without permission. Morale is extremely low. The vast majority of people do not like their jobs. Like most large public companies, if you are promoted here your compensation can only go up by a small percentage, meaning brand new employees are always paid more than veterans.

review_title: Maybe a good place to work in 2020, but definitely not in 2010!
job_title: Project Manager in Frankfurt am Main
pros:
To gain experience of one of the leading core banking platforms
Exposure to Indian way of doing things / intercultural experience; offshore management experience when you are located somewhere other than India
cons: Company internal organization is very bad in almost all aspects; examples: HR processes (including time tracking, expense reimbursement, travel, career management (nonexistent)...), compensation management, branding, internal and external communication; process oriented way of doing things in practice (in theory, there are processes in the company but not followed really in detail)

review_title: Good company to work for with the expectation that you will not be there for long if you do not have a mentor.
job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Reston, VA
pros: Great company to work for in regards to product and service recognition.
cons:
Oracle constantly experienced growing pains because of buying other companies and their competition therefore the support mechanism was not  in place as with the original company.  When I worked for Oracle a good number of my accounts had JDEdwards which was apart of the Peoplesoft deal,  we did not have proper staffing or general know how in converting accounts over.
The general word on the street is that your employment at Oracle will be very short lived.

review_title: Work in challenging
pros: work is varied and challenging....normally leaving Oracle and coming back does help to gain promotion and salary increase...but because the staffing cost so much....support tends to be offshore to save costs...
cons: Little or no training for engineers....causes customer frustration, employee frustration and leads to unnecessary escalations. Oracle would hire more escalation managers, than fix the root cause of employee training.

review_title: The pay and location is good, but the experience is frustrating
pros: Working for Oracle was a huge privilege on my part after graduating from college because of the recession back then, the pay is good for a newly graduated job-hunter, and the benefits are very satisfying. There are extra-curricular activities every-now-and-then which helps unwind the stress.
cons: The only drawback to working for Oracle is the lack of any career advancement. There doesn't seem to be any way to get promoted and the only option to advance your career is to exit the company. I guess this prevents office politics, but it deteriorates the working experience into feeling somewhat frustrating because you can't progress anywhere. Plus sometimes the management can get pretty unfair.

review_title: Powerful company where wages have been stagnant for the last 12 years for technical persons in the lower 90%.
pros:
1. Powerful company with great access to the latest technology.
2. By IT standards the work environment is stable for technical persons
cons:
In an effort to have US based ORCL employees compete with ORCL employees in "low cost centers" wages have been frozen for the last 12 years for the lowest performing 90% of the technical employee population.

(CON) That's hard for us techies like myself (a top 20% technical performer) who suffer with a dozen years of slowly falling standard of living.

(PRO) This austerity program has at least kept us lower 90% technicals employed.

review_title: A company for seniors only...
pros:
1. If you are appointed as core product development stuff; there is a chance that you'll have an exposure to couple of cutting edge technologies. But it depends on the team you belong. If you are in the wrong team (with a manager who is just a rotten egg) then you'll end up with a frustrating career growth. So, be double sure during your interview round about the division you are being hired for. 
2. Office timing is very flexible; which is good.
3. Office location is good.
cons:
* Compensation will be pathetic if you are not good enough in office politics. 
* Some of the managers' attitude is so rude (without any reason). Some of them think of themselves as CEOs of the whole organization.

review_title: Consulting
pros: The training is outstanding, good bonuses, lots of opportunity for learning, decent benefits, strong internal support of peers and colleagues, endless opportunities for travel (if desired)
cons: Sometimes they put the consultants on engagements for which they are not prepared to delivered as much as expected.  This stems from the aggressive business development practices.  This is quite stressful as the consultants must perform under extreme pressure and deadlines.  There is also a constant hiring/firing cycle and layoffs seem very arbitrary.  Also, the org. chart was always in flux and it was difficult to figure out which group was responsible for which areas of business.

review_title: Compensation packages to do not grow with your career
pros: Stable and secure company with flexible work environments.  Lots of opportunity to expand knowledge and skills.  Training and education is available.  Good place to develop skills, education, and certifications.
cons:
Promotions do not include compensation increases.    Do not expect yearly cost of living increases or bonuses.  The strangle hold on budgets limit the control of localized management adjust salaries accordingly.  
Many Oracle employees come through acquisitions preventing initial salary negotiations.   Expect the same initial salary for years.

review_title: Good company for work life balance
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros:
1) Good work life balance.
2) Quality of work depends on the team you choose. So choose carefully and you may get good quality work where the learning can be quite good.
3) Talking to senior management is quite easy. In my team I do talk to senior management in case I have an issue and they are quite open for any kind of discussion.
cons:
1) Compensation is not that great compared to other companies and also there seems to be no great employee benefits
2) If you are not part of a good team, the work you are given may not be challenging and may hamper your technical knowledge if you stay for a long period.
3) Many teams work on technology which is either company centric or quite old.

review_title: Good Experience, Supportive on training, Low Pay
pros: There are some great people that work here and those involved in projects give their all.  You get great support in training for your role too.  Good benefits (medical, holidays, pension etc) and possibility for flexible working hours too.
cons:
Managers have a tendency to micro-manage
Hard-impossible to move or get promoted within departments / divisions
Poor Salary - pay well below industry standard and rarely do they give pay rises 
You can ask to be involved in initiatives but unless you are a favourite of the management, it's rare you get the opportunity.

review_title: There Once was a Great Company Named Oracle
job_title: Principal Sales Consultant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:

- Broad Product Offering
- Good work/life balance
- Easy to manage your schedule
cons:
- Taking away compensation elements from those who are making their company money
- Executive management focused on margins and their paycheck

review_title: Dinosaur facing extinction
pros: I have learned a lot about how to stifle innovation, inhibit sales productivity and lower employee morale to unbelievable depths during my time at Oracle. I can't get out fast enough and if I could advise my client base to do the same without risk I would.
cons: There are just to many to list. If you are fresh out of school and have the stamina to learn while being taken advantage of then this is the place for you. If you are a manager who can sleep at night while your team is taken advantage of then this is the place for you. If you are a customer focused team contributor and passionate about delivering results then stay away from the big red machine as it will jade you into believing that all corporations are inherently greedy and dysfunctional.

review_title: House of Cards' sense.
job_title: Project Leader in São Paulo, São Paulo

review_title: Competitive Intelligence Director
pros:

 -Flexible work locations
- Great learning experience because you expose to so many, global business units
- Very, very smart people at Oracle, so great learning from that perspective.

review_title: Working in Global Business Units is pretty good
