Work-life balance is great depending on your location or role.
cons: The culture suffers from a lot of old Oracle classic mindset conflicting with new cloud focused business leaders in the GBU or coming in via acquisition.  Sometimes new & better methods are encouraged and accepted but too often, the old BAU rule prevails

review_title: Oracle SSI
pros:
It's not Oracle, it is Oracle SSI for which I am writing my review. Oracle SSI is the EMEA consulting wing of Oracle which operates from Bangalore.
Pros:
------
- Work from Home
- Family work life balance
- Open Culture, but most of the cases on paper only
- You can survive in this company without doing any work for years
- A big hierarchy in reporting which is not required for a consulting firm 
- Most of the managers are powerless, so if you are in good terms with senior managers, you will rock in this company.
cons:
- Salary hike rarely happens. Last time after 2 years with a budget of less than 6%. 
- Growth is limited. Already 200 + manager's and 20+ director and company total strength is approx 800. 
- No onsite allowance. You will be told that your limit is 30-40 usd, but you need to provide the bills. No bill no payment, so no eating at roadside or restaurant who don't give your bill. Even you can't claim tips / liquor on expenses. This will go out from your own pocket as tips is mandatory in most of the country.
- Don't expect good accommodation when you travelling onsite for project. You might have to share an apartment with 2-3 other families / consultants.
- You need to pay your kids travel visa, tickets, etc from your own pocket. Air ticket and visa application fee for spouse needs approval and the you have to pay the pre-requisite tax on these.
- Once you at onsite or in project, you will be on mercy of your project manager. You will hardly get any positive response from your managers for any onsite related issues..

review_title: House of Cards' sense.
job_title: Project Leader in São Paulo, São Paulo

review_title: Competitive Intelligence Director
pros:
- Tough environment to survive in with competitive nature and position overlap, yet this sets you well for other companies in your career
 -Flexible work locations
- Great learning experience because you expose to so many, global business units
- Very, very smart people at Oracle, so great learning from that perspective.
cons:
- Job overlap is annoying
- Other business units will take your content, embed it in theirs and not provide credit to the original author
- Older, stuffy work environment
- Oracle is a global company, so they will let you work all 24 hours per day if you facilitate it

review_title: Working in Global Business Units is pretty good
pros: the Global Business Units (GBUs) is a fast growing organization with lots to keep people busy.  Large variety of technology, lot of customer challenges to solve and a good exec management team.  GBUs continue to be an area of growth and investment.  Work-life balance is great depending on your location or role.
cons: The culture suffers from a lot of old Oracle classic mindset conflicting with new cloud focused business leaders in the GBU or coming in via acquisition.  Sometimes new & better methods are encouraged and accepted but too often, the old BAU rule prevails

review_title: Oracle SSI
pros:
It's not Oracle, it is Oracle SSI for which I am writing my review. Oracle SSI is the EMEA consulting wing of Oracle which operates from Bangalore.
Pros:
------
- Work from Home
- Family work life balance
- Open Culture, but most of the cases on paper only
- You can survive in this company without doing any work for years
- A big hierarchy in reporting which is not required for a consulting firm 
- Most of the managers are powerless, so if you are in good terms with senior managers, you will rock in this company.
cons:
- Salary hike rarely happens. Last time after 2 years with a budget of less than 6%. 
- Growth is limited. Already 200 + manager's and 20+ director and company total strength is approx 800. 
- No onsite allowance. You will be told that your limit is 30-40 usd, but you need to provide the bills. No bill no payment, so no eating at roadside or restaurant who don't give your bill. Even you can't claim tips / liquor on expenses. This will go out from your own pocket as tips is mandatory in most of the country.
- Don't expect good accommodation when you travelling onsite for project. You might have to share an apartment with 2-3 other families / consultants.
- You need to pay your kids travel visa, tickets, etc from your own pocket. Air ticket and visa application fee for spouse needs approval and the you have to pay the pre-requisite tax on these.
- Once you at onsite or in project, you will be on mercy of your project manager. You will hardly get any positive response from your managers for any onsite related issues..

review_title: Great Company
pros:
Amazing technology provider with diversity of products.
High salaries at the time of joining.
Excellent Experience and multi culture organization.
cons:
High stressful Managment , internal conflicts, no annual increase , low employee morals, no employees loyalty.
Employees on same job category and grade are not getting same packages. 
HR is not protecting the employees but seams like the Managers assistant.
It is not a real equal opportunity company as manager can exclude any one from the recruiting process with no real reasons.

review_title: Support Sales Manager
job_title: Support Sales Manager in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros: Oracle is the company where you will go grow, will be faced with constant change, constantly going outside your comfort zone and you will be challenged, But in this way, you will truly feel you grow and that you take on new expertise and acquire new sets of skills
cons: Oracle does not offer salary increases, even when you promote to a new role. The salary you start with when you are first hired will most likely remain the salary you end up leaving the company with.

review_title: Not what it says on the tin...
pros: Free cereal & the occasional office lunch (yes this is really all I can think of)
cons:
Where do I start? Poor management, no real help when required. Office atmosphere is stale and a real sense of dissatisfaction. Recently been taken over by Oracle with the promise of change and benefits... Yet to see any of this. People leaving on a regular basis, I would predict about 15-20 people left since the start of the year. A real sinking ship feeling at the moment. Fellow employees feel demotivated and bored of the current situation. All this talk of regular pay reviews? Don't believe it. 

The lure of a 10% bonus is appealing, but they fail to tell you how much extra work you have to do to achieve this. Be prepared to lose a lot of your weekend!

review_title: Good company to start. Gets boring quickly
pros: Intensive use of technology. A great number of professionals and people willing to give the extra mile. Decent salary for the location. Great package: Dental, vision, health. Very flexible policies about working remote, personal days and sick days. That is about it.
cons: The Managerial team is not competent. I am talking about mid-management. Policies seem half cooked and never fully applied before changed again. Salaries could be better, vis-a-vis how much C-Level execs make. No career path or progression. No updates in your salary at all. If you want to progress in your career, you need to apply every time and get your boss to back you up. There is a lot of "who you know" and not "what you do".

review_title: Don't work for Oracle start up projects
pros: They pay you well and have good benefits.
cons:
They desperately recruited us all to the company for a start up project and promised us it was long-term, then fired our entire team months later. My apartment complex said they see more people move in and get fired from Oracle, due to projects being canceled, then any other tech company in the area. 

In general the company is so big it is painful to find any resources you need.  You could walk down the 9 flights of stairs to talk to security faster then you could figure out how to find their number through the poorly developed internal websites. When you email payroll or benefits, they take several days to answer and provide the bare minimum of information.  Worse off is after they fire you, they give you HR people to contact that only answer half your questions.

review_title: Not the place to work if you have any self worth
pros: Free beverages.  Good health benefits.  Everyone's moral is low but they hide it from management  to try to stay off the next layoff list until they find their next job.
cons: Difficult working for a company that wilfully tries to take advantage of employees when it comes to raises or bonuses.  They could not care less about the employees with the exception of some scripted lip service.  Everything in the GBU is reactionary.

review_title: Great people, challenging problems, good pay
pros:
Great teams and people. Work-life balance seems to vary by team. Mine is great, others not so much. So if you are considering working here, do ask your hiring manager about that.

Great pay and benefits.

Challenging problems (I work in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure) and great opportunity for growth. Performance feedback is given often on my team.
cons:
It's a giant company, it has giant company problems. Process. Heaps of process. If you're the type of person who flips out at small things, you will not like it here.

Internal tooling is slowly coming into the current century, but it's painful.

Takes forever to get an offer, be prepared and come with extra patience.

review_title: Good place to "retire"
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: Good work-family life balance. Nice gym with swimming pool. Good smart people for the most part. Great cafeterias. Easy to find somebody to carpool with no matter where you live. Has offices in India, so can work from there or from home when on a 4-5 week India vacation/business trip.
cons: Using many outdated technologies. Mindset still is to create in-house products even where much better open source solutions are available. Not much career growth. 5-10% annual salary growth max. Bug database is horrendous. Source control system is too overly complex and a big PITA.

review_title: Good place to train for your next job
pros: Oracle had a good training program for those not familiar with the database and application market. It was intermixed with working with existing sales people to get people up to speed quickly.  The building was nice as it had a nice cafeteria and large free onsite gym to workout in.
cons: There was no career path for sales people most people including top performers left after a while. Either you moved into management or you moved on. The sales team I worked with seemed to be a body shop with high turnover which could explain why the training was so good.

review_title: Give it a miss and go work somewhere else .. ANYWHERE else !
pros:
Office is close to the M4 Motorway
Coffee from the machines is drinkable
Canteen food is edible
Arrogance of management is hysterically funny
cons:
Difficult to know where to start. That the company autonomously run by a joker who swans around his japanese garden in robes is a big clue.
Anyone who dares to question Larry's omnipotence and omniescence becomes an immediate pariah.
Anyone remember Oracle's answer to the PC ?  The Network Computer aka NC ?
I was one of the guys who spent weeks trying to get the stupid things to work in the certain knowledge that it was a waste of time and a huge amount of money. Things kind of went downhill from there.

review_title: Generally a very good feedback from customers. But inside the company, you are just another ant.
pros:
#1 World Leader for Database Softwares.
High visibility in most countries with over 100 thousands employees.
Getting in touch with actual technical knowledge.
cons:
No recognition for employees but only for those who are lucky enough to be friendly with the top        
management. In other terms, most of the employees don't really know they're good because we don't tell them in order to avoid any salary raise at the end of the year...

review_title: Good stable company with strong senior management team.
pros: Good company if you are looking for stability, good benefits, and some opportunity for growth.  You will have to tolerate inflexible policies/procedures and complex management structures.  All in all, very comfortable place to work.
cons: No formal career growth plans.  Employees are cogs in the wheel.  Oracle has automated the organization to the extreme.  This decreased our operational costs significantly and is a good model to show customers what is possible, but the down side is a lack of flexibility.  There is very little wiggle room for creativity or trying new ideas.

review_title: A mixed bag
pros: It's a large, stable company with competitive salaries and benefits. Not a bad place to work if you're a line engineer.
cons:
It's slow-moving, bureaucratic and in some groups the political infighting can be quite bad. Top-down management style with constantly changing "strategic goals"

A terrible place to work if you're a middle manager, stuck between motivated engineers and the bloated bureaucracy.

review_title: Oracle is full of people with winning attitude. I love the challenges that come along and the trust that company keeps.
pros: I love the Challenges that come along with changing business scenario. Knowledge is valued and there is provision to keep oneself updated with latest technology via useful training sessions. Best thing about Oracle is allowing employee to keep the Work Life balance. Oracle trusts in its employee and there is no second thought to this.
cons: Career growth is a huge downside. It is important to have some transparency in the system to allow the employee to make the judgement about his own performance and evaluate his expectation. It is demotivating to keep working without reaching anywhere.

review_title: silent firing company
pros: well managed and good company and enviroment, kind of silos work style,
cons: even if the next cubicle is silently fired, you won't even get to know, such silent company it is ! if manager is a long-stayer(like 14 years) he would bring you under PIP before firing. follow boss or no life is the mantra. Most dumbest HR team as they have no role to play or stop or convince the manager once he has decided to fire. HR just follow dumb instructions from the manager. Again, it all depends on where you end up with. In general the most experienced manager is again, the difficult person to work with as he is well versed with politics..

review_title: Great company for a self-starter; little tolerance for coasters
pros: Despite it's size, the company is still very entrepreneurial - albeit with a strong/aggressive sales culture.  A truly global IT heavyweight with plenty of opportunity to do worthwhile and rewarding work and a lot of opportunity to work with talented people.
cons: Behaviours tend to be compensation-based which, whilst it increases business focus does inhibit x-team collaboration.  A lot of organisational complexity and, in some cases, overlap.  This is by design - competition drives greater performance but tends to result in a perpetual culture of political 'winners' and 'losers'.

review_title: I have enjoyed working here
job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Bala Cynwyd, PA
pros: I am trusted and empowered to make decisions.  The development group is always striving to improve.  Good and easy collaboration with members of UX team.  Management is very accessible.
cons: Vision and long-term strategy are not regularly and reliably communicated to development staff.  Large offshore development staff with insufficient mechanisms for communicating best practices and ensuring high quality and UX across the board.  No real training offered for development staff.

review_title: The only constant is change
job_title: Applications Sales Manager in Burlington, MA
pros: Incredible benefits, generous commission structure and accelerators if you exceed quota, lots of resources to help you with various stages of a sale. Lots of other opportunities in other positions or products once you are inside
cons: be prepared for constant change and lots of internal competition. Internal processes are some of the hardest part of getting deals done. If you need someone to hold you by the hand this isn't the place for you. Culture depends largely on your immediate manager and fellow teammates.

review_title: Not suitable for a life long career
job_title: Senior Support Engineer in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros: The people. Access to training but not as much as you would expect. Working from home.
cons:
The entry salary will stick with you no matter if the market salary changes. New employees may earn double than you.
The management is useless, Oracle would work the same with less then half the number of current managers. Working for Oracle you get the feeling that the management just doesn't care. It's a rigid company with high prices. It doesn't care for employees or customers, all they care is world domination.
Most important is that you get specialized in a very narrow niche and you lose the big picture. When you want to leave you may find that your skills are not marketable.

review_title: Application Sales Rep
pros: There were a lot of resources for salespeople, the technology is powerful, the people I worked with were very cool and knowledgeable as well.  The benefits were not as good as I've seen but they weren't bad either.
cons: Like many people say, it's such a big company that it's easy to get lost or buried in everything that's going on with customers and even internally.  There seemed to be a fairly high amount of turnover too which can obviously complicate things.

review_title: Great Company to Work For
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Santa Monica, CA
pros: Great culture and team oriented environment, with many dedicated and intelligent employees.  They have very competitive pay and do a lot to try and compete with younger start-ups.  Fantastic offices and have an incredible Sales Academy program.
cons: Incredibly long and complex hierarchies that can make processes and decision making difficult at times.  Management can be sluggish to respond to new stimuli and changing business dynamics.  While the culture is great, Oracle's massive size makes it difficult to progress your career long-term.

review_title: Oracle Romania - awesome place to work
job_title: Business Development Representative in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros:
Oracle is the most desired employer in Romania, and for good reason. The company has an aggressive hiring plan, employs young people without much experience and offers interesting compensation, benefits and a very nice working environment. 



I think Oracle is a very nice company to be a part of - high quality people and loads of opportunities for growth.
cons: There's a lot of birocracy, things tend to move slowly, and people tend to leave after a couple of years as salaries rarely increased from a year to another - sometimes even promotions come without a pay increase.

review_title: Sr. Sales Rep
pros: A glacier.  Isn't going anywhere soon.
cons:
Do not see field sales as a critical resource.  Moving toward a telesales model which will inevitably fail.

3 parts of the Sales Cycle at Oracle.

1) Sell the customer/prospect (easy)
2) Sell Oracle management on why this is a good deal for Oracle (difficult)
3) Collect commissions in a timely fashion (next to impossible without a lawyer)

Latest comp plan has a 'compensation factor' that turns commission from an objective computation to a totally subjective computation based on whatever management decides at the time.  So it's "go sell this deal for us and then once sold, we'll let you know if you will be paid, and if so, what % of your commission will be paid.  How

review_title: Sales Representative - HR Cloud Solutions Specialist
pros: Possibility to move and travel,  salaries are correct up to good, canteen provides local food, lots of activities inside Oracle.
cons:
Employees integration is egocentric, nobody knows more about the company than a 10 or a 20%.

My one month training with Oracle University has been quite  improvised and amateur...which is a shame being given the size of the company...

My manager had never have my job before, that she was suppose to help me manage.

Oracle's policy and strategy is unclear, Oracle's values and HR policy are a disaster (however my HRM was a very nice and kind person).

Each Sales rep is suppose to manage a territory - portfolio of potenntial clients. However the territory is constantly moving from employees to other!

review_title: Associate Consultant
pros:
1) Flexible job timings for Consultants
2) Job safety - you literally can't be fired no matter what you do.
3) Good exposure to the financial industry.
cons:
1) Laid back attitude of workforce.
2) Lack of innovative culture.
3) Employees aren't encouraged to work on new projects but are expected to stick to implementing existing projects.
4) Bureaucratic. Loads of documentation(more than what is necessary).
5) Extended hierarchy.
6) Middle management lacks vision.
7) Salary is high initially but they come up with trivial excuses to raise them over subsequent years(applies tp entire workforce).

review_title: Still has the potential...
pros: A company generally full of interesting and smart people. Senior management are competent but executive leaders are distant. Some great products and IP but not always the most customer focused. Pay is at market and benefits in some countries are excellent, OK in others. Career opportunities can be huge. Oracle is for many still a great company, and it has the potential to be a class leader but needs to fix two key things from the employees experience
cons: - to do a better job at communicating with and understanding employees - and to have executive leadership that encourages feedback, challenge and debate. Too much fear of getting fired has bred a corporate bureaucracy that may choke this great company to death..

review_title: Sales Rep - Account Executive
pros:
+good pay and benefits
+commission percentages and bonuses are pretty great
+very friendly people
+good culture (people from different verticals will help you a ton when you first get started, "win as a team")
+good software platform
+decent name recognition with Oracle
+Oracle allows NetSuite to work as their own Business Unit, and don't interfere with culture
+Super nice offices
+Best sales culture as a female I have been at
+No pressure to hit amount of cold calls a day (depending on manager)
cons:
-Corporate training is super cheesy and too long
-Prospects don't always like we work for "the man" being Oracle Corp.
-Unrealistic amount of pipeline (dependent on vertical)
-Hard to hit quota year one (takes 2 months just to train)

review_title: Bureaucracy at its best
pros:
Flexible work hours and option to work from home
Opportunity to learn technologies on the job and via internal/external trainings
cons:
Very poor pay revision/hikes. No perks or rewards.
Too much of bureaucracy - the org follows top down approach. Management dictates, employees follow. Career growth is extremely difficult, if you can't play political games. It is wrongly categorized as product company. Oracle is merely a "Mergers & Acquisitions" company.

review_title: Tech support role
pros:
- Able to buy holidays up to 10 days 
- Health insurance
- Friendly Co-workers
cons:
- Uses career advancement as a selling point but it is non existent, at least in this office
- No salary increases, you stay on the same salary until you get a promotion or have a new job offer outside the company (see  first point) 
 - New staff start on higher salary than current staff who will be training the new employee's from day 1.

review_title: Worst job I have ever had
pros:
None what so ever!!!
Even if I try I cant think of anything positive.
cons:
Toxic office atmosphere between new and old employees.
Zero training given and expected to be able to resolve cases assigned to you.

Our supervisor literally shrugged her shoulders and turned her back on me when I came to her with an issue. 

Poor work life balance with hours of 2pm - 11:30pm Thursday - Tuesday. 

No weekends off without applying for holidays.
Even though I was told that that I would have every second weekend off when I started.

All managers on sight went home between 3pm and 5pm Monday to Friday. Absolutely no supervisor on sight after five Monday to Friday and none at all at the weekend.

Wages are just above the living standard pay scale.

review_title: Great place to work.
job_title: User Experience Designer in Redwood City, CA
pros: Its a great place with some really sharp and smart people working in the company. I have met numerous people who have worked in Oracle for over 10 years, and still going strong. I guess, you can say that they are now super specialized, but still, the overall benefits are great. It is also provides a great relaxed atmosphere to work, and the culture is very laid back. Very flexible working hours, and a less stressful work environment.
cons: Oracle often gives great salaries when you join. But after that, its very much slow to give an increment. Unless you have a great manager who can root for you, to get a good bonus, its difficult to get your salary raised.

review_title: There are better companies to work for.
job_title: Senior Principal Consultant in Mississauga, ON
pros: You can learn and get experience on Oracle technology and the new an upcoming technologies.  You can get access to training and internal help with technical issues.
cons: Not a place to be if you are looking for job satisfaction and advancement in your career.   Employee morale is very low.  Most employees have been getting very limited salary increases and very few employees have been promoted in the last 5-7 years.  There are very limited employee benefits (e.g. the Christmas party, golf tournament, childrens Christmas party, stock purchase plan, bonuses etc. were cut or reduced during the tech meltdown in 2001/2002, and none of these benefits have returned.

review_title: Large, stable corporation not known for innovation
pros: Established company with a lot of stability, good employee benefits.  Oracle is a dominant player in its core areas despite threats from SAP and growing MySQL threat.
cons: Not  very innovative.  It can be hard to change the direction of projects and many middleware projects seem doomed to fail or has very little potential for impact.   Currently Oracle is hard to beat because it has many existing clients who are too lazy to switch to other products but eventually people will switch to superior products.  You cannot simply fight SAP with aggressive salespeople.  Too much acquisition can cause indigestion.  There are many clients frustrated by the lack of integration between Oracle's products.

review_title: Work here if taking it easy is your #1 priority, well above things like compensation, exciting work...
job_title: Software Engineer III in Redwood City, CA
pros:
If you have a family and kids, want to take it easy and settle down in life, work at Oracle.

Or, as an entry level job, Oracle is not a bad place to work for a year or two to add to your resume. Because it looks better on the resume than it actually is.

The fitness center is good.
cons:
Reward for level of contribution vary widely between groups. If you are unlucky to be in the wrong group, forget about career advancement.

If you are looking for some exciting work to motivate you, this is not the place to be.

review_title: Risk of getting a low self-esteem
pros:
Some consider its a good brand.
Flexible timings.
Learn new frameworks(if you are lucky enough to get into such a team)
Learn various applications which have good opportunities outside.
Good for people who are in the middle and higher management.
Free internet !!!
cons:
Money minded management.
Very unfriendly towards employees.
Salary and bonuses differ within the company between different teams. It all depends on which team you are into. Very frustrating when you get to know less experienced people earning more than other more experienced people.
Good for new recruits for the first couple of years(after which they cannot expect good hikes)

review_title: Oracle from a Sun Acquired Employee Perspective
job_title: Program Manager IV in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Much more cost controlled and metrics driven.  Decisions are not made based on emotion or gut feeling.  Oracle believes in testing the latest, greatest software internally and that makes a big difference when working on production control systems.
cons: Oracle believes in controlling decisions at a very detailed level.  All financial decisions above $25k required executive management approval which can slow approvals.  Integration into their IT systems is extremely slow and painful with little to no support.  If you are illiterate in technology in any way, you won't survive.

review_title: Wouldn't recommend anyone work here, unless in sales.
pros: location in the UK was ok, free bus service to the town at lunchtime; flexible benefits scheme to purchase extra holiday, dental plan etc. Cycle to work scheme, many canteens to choose from, free parking.
cons: poor management and direction from senior members, no real structure for reviews, salary increases or advancement.  poor salary/bonus in comparison to other companies. poor communication from other departments. unless you are in a sales role, you don't matter.

review_title: Oracle has changed
pros: I stay for the benefits, which are still great so far.  First line managers tend to be very good managers, very employee oriented, open to ideas, and supportive of their teams.
cons: Little management respect for the Customer Support organization, little or no training or time for self-learning in Customer Support.  Upper management culture is one of bullies, profanity, and ego.  Took away all of the bonus plan for non-management.  No incentive to go the extra mile for customers - very few rewards or acknowledgment for superior performance.

review_title: They crush the competition, customers, and -- employees
pros: They aren't going out of business, so there is some stability in that. Their ruthless pursuit of shareholder value means a minor dip in your division's business will send you into the streets with a pink slip.
cons: The company treats its employees very badly. They are the typical powerhouse, pushing others to the farthest extent possible before attrition is too damaging. Your manager and manager's manager and manager's manager's manager won't have the power to treat you right no matter how much they think it is fair unless the folks at the top decide to dispense some liberality. If you get hired in, you can know at that time the terms are fair to you. But year by year you'll slip farther behind.

review_title: A pocket of wonderful in a huge corporation
pros:
Strong, supportive management
Excellent teamwork in our division
Great communications - everyone on the same page in our division
Ability to maintain healthy work-life balance
Able to make a difference and feel appreciated
Personal and professional growth from a learning perspective
Bright, fun, motivated co-workers
cons:
"Greater Oracle" process inflexibility can inhibit productivity and frustrate customers. Rules are there for a reason, but there is a need to improve the balance (rules vs ideas) to allow progress and business process innovation.
Compensation is relatively low.

review_title: great company to work for. very stable.
pros: company is profitable, a market leader and has a good reputation.  Company continues to grow.
cons: salary increases are minimal or non-existent.  Company exercises a level of financial prudence that sometimes seems too conservative.  transferring jobs within the company (especially across borders) is more complicated than it should be.

review_title: Oracle Romania, Non Management position in Global Finance organisation
pros: On a non-management position the place is great for the flexibility. It allows homeworking and also provides all the necessary technology for the job. It is a company where is important to get things done, no matter when/how, the restriction level is low meaning that it allows creativity, self time management and self service.
cons: Salaries are not flexible, you need to be very happy with the salary when you sign the contract as you will not see relevant changes even in case of promotions. Bonuses are also low comparing to different other companies and they are not yearly, the annual employee appraisal with high score does not necessary come with any bonus.

review_title: Not a bad place to work
pros: There are a few reasons to enjoy working at Oracle, one of which is job security. Also there is job consistency. If you can do your job well the first couple of months that you are employed, you can do it well for the rest of your time there. This may sound like a con, but it's not. There is something to be said for finding the right job and doing it well.
cons: You're not going to get paid a lot of money. Also, the further you are away from company headquarters, the less likely you will move up the ladder. This is especially true if you are from a company that was acquired.

review_title: Consulting Software Engineer
job_title: Consulting Software Engineer in Bedford, MA
pros: Ability to work remotely, decent benefits,  flexible hours, good easy paycheck.  Not much more to say here but need 20 words minimum in this section.
cons: Crushing bureaucracy,  limited career growth for young motivated engineers, foolish use of sub-standard Oracle products when competition is much better.

review_title: Class of Program BDC
pros: Free trip to San Francisco, decent pay for first job out of college, no work outside of work hours
cons: Entire job revolves around making cold calls and following up with emails. That's it. There's no variety of work and no travel. Company strategy is set up to call into the same accounts, as a company, at least 10 times every day. Prospects are fed up and tell you when they answer the phone. Lots of pressure to stop harassing coming from customer end and lots of pressure to continue harassing coming from management. Very uncomfortable position to be in.

review_title: Good place to work if you're not interested in advancing..
job_title: Senior Functional Architect in Lexington, MA
pros: Remote work is very common, lots of flexibility and freedom. Plenty of smart talented people, fun working environment.
cons: Email overload & overwork due to inadequate processes does happen, you just have to create your own systems to deal with it. Political atmosphere due to thick and entrenched management layers and the light usually doesn't shine through. If you're happy to live in your little cubby hole, it's a decent place to work. If you want to grow, best join a competitor.

review_title: Good place to work if you're not interested in advancing..
job_title: Senior Functional Architect in Lexington, MA
pros: Remote work is very common, lots of flexibility and freedom. Plenty of smart talented people, fun working environment.
cons: Email overload & overwork due to inadequate processes does happen, you just have to create your own systems to deal with it. Political atmosphere due to thick and entrenched management layers and the light usually doesn't shine through. If you're happy to live in your little cubby hole, it's a decent place to work. If you want to grow, best join a competitor.

review_title: A great place to learn and that's it.
pros: If you're fresh out of college like me then Oracle is a great place to start your career. You will get to work with some bright consultants and great technologies. You will get plenty of opportunities to learn and grow technically.

job_title: Business Development Consultant in Redwood Shores, CA
pros:
-Great work-life balance- very flexible, people go to the gym during lunch breaks etc.
-Lots of young people, work-life balance
-2 days to work from home per month
-Nice brand on your resume to have

-Team can be hit or miss

review_title: good company, in a painful transformation
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Dublin, Dublin

cons: poor marketing, a lot of cold calling, territories are not properly distributed so that some are great and some are bed. its clear to see in day 1 of the FY who is going to hit his number and who is going to finish the year on a near 0%. diversity is great, but promoting woman just because they are woman is not the way

review_title: Sales Development Representative
job_title: Sales Development Representative in Austin, TX

-The "Class Of" BDC program builds strong relationships among 100+ college grads, which makes for a top notch social environment. Every day at the office is a day with friends. 
-Outstanding benefits, strong brand, in-house sales training program for employees.
-Excellent work/life balance.
cons:
-Cannibalistic sales organization. Roles meant to work together have conflicting goals, directly influencing deception and harmful rather than healthy competition. It's a dog-eat-dog experience.
-Managers do not seem invested in the individual.

review_title: What do you expect?

cons: At the whim of an organization who will tell you they care....and then cut you off.  I was part of an organization that was purchased by oracle.  Execs were promptly flown in to tell us that the organization had a history of purchasing people as assets and will integrate even if technologies didn't survive.  It took a couple of years but the former organization was decimated.  Fine, but why the need to be so deceptive?  Because image is the only thing that counts.

review_title: Really good first IT job

loads of support
loads of opportunities to travel and expand
in-dependency in your function
big company name does open the doors
loads of holidays and working from home options

trying to move the business into a new model and loads of teething problems
its a purely revenue based target with no incentive track down new business, so your sales skills and the overall business diminishes 
senior management isnt very inspiring or hands on

0 (zero) innovation

review_title: My perspective after 3 years
pros:
- Great work life balance; Oracle offers workout classes during lunch and most managers won't frown upon you for working out during lunch. This can be an 8-5 job but it is not very strict. Leaving a bit early or coming in a bit late is okay. 

- Though turnover may be high (it's sales), management has been trying to invest in activities for its reps, like covering lunch for the team once a month when the team goes out to eat/drink. 

- Not an "old school" sales culture (no heavy dials, though you will have to do it sporadically). I've worked in other sales organizations and Oracle's prospecting efforts in inside sales is very relaxed. This may be good or bad, but overall people like that they can find other ways to reach out to customers instead of pounding 50+ calls a day. 

- Generally, people here are very nice and you will make lots of friends; though some may say Oracle sales is "fratty" (it is), people are not mean and you can get along with pretty much anyone. 

- $50K base for a Tier 1 rep is decent and liveable in most places in Austin. You can request an increase after a full year of being at your quota (Tier 2 pay is $65K). 

- Great health benefits and investment plans (401K match and stock options, as well as financial advisory if you want). There is also education reimbursement and a bunch of other stuff. Vacation is 14 days for your first three years (accrued at 0.8 hrs per paycheck; more after three years). Management PTO is unlimited. 

- You can make a lot of money if you work hard, get lucky, have good accounts, a knowledgable manager, and a great field rep who knows what he's doing and is willing to include you in sales cycles. More into this in the cons. 

- Beautiful office in front of Lady Bird Lake that makes you proud of working here and makes it easier to come to work. The office building has a Starbucks, gym, is 30-seconds away from the lake trail, and has amazing views of downtown.
cons:
- Your success is mostly out of your control and almost entirely dependent on your accounts/sales territory/manager: Reps who are working on deals and closing them "found" their deals because customers reached out to them saying they were interested in buying. Or because their field rep handed over the deal to them so the field doesn't have to do all the paperwork and approvals. Or because one or several of their accounts are adding a subsidiary and need to buy more licenses to stay compliant. Or because their territory has a lot of renewals and opportunities to do uplift or add more products to customers who just wanna buy more. Or because your manager has strong relationships at the field level and can get you included in deals and helps you with internal negotiations. You're effectively "rolling the dice" in this role every fiscal year. 

- Competition with field reps: if your field rep finds an opportunity in an account you share, he/she may leave you out of working that account altogether. The only way for you to work the account is if the field agrees to let you own the entire forecast of the deal, which likely they won't if a lot of money is on the line. If your deal is "too big", field management may take it away even if you found it. Why? Because they have the power of going onsite and leveraging the relationships they already have in those accounts (field reps don't get rotated every year as inside sales reps do). Most of the inside sales reps who do work with the field are simply pushing the paperwork for them. If you want to learn to actually sell, this role may not be for you. 

- Internal cannibalization: you may sell products that other reps at Oracle can also sell, which can get confusing/annoying for the customer. You may also sell a product that another pillar at Oracle also sells in another marketed version, so you'll be competing internally to see who gets to sell it to the customer. You also have a lot of reps from different pillars calling your same customer about different products, which creates a big mess. Imagine having business development, inside sales, and field reps from multiple lines of business at Oracle calling the same IT department in a company. 

- No work from home flexibility and average PTO plan: we brought this upon ourselves for having a relaxed culture, but work from home is almost nonexistent. The work from homes that do exist are "awarded" to reps during sales contests and are seldom. I don't personally see this as a con because having reps on the floor can be very useful when you have a question, but if you are used to having this flexibility than this job is not for you. Moreover, PTO is 14 days, and it is frowned upon to take it all at once. You may have to book them well in advance and spread them. 

- Hard to break away from established procedures or bureaucracy: obvious one for a big company, but still need to discuss this. Oracle has a lot of rules and procedures in place for you to even get a discount approved, or anything you need to help you win a deal versus a competitor or just to get the deal across the line. A lot of internal negotiations will delay or derail your deal. You will spend most of your day writing approvals to get a discount or some other requirement approved instead of prospecting or talking to customers. Then there is a lot of waiting. In addition, the rules for getting promoted are clearly laid out, but they can be unrealistic if your success is entirely dependent on things out of your control (see Con #1).

review_title: Try joining Oracle NOT an acquired company
pros:
Employee benefits are great 
Quarterly bonuses
One of the biggest IT companies on earth
Looks good on your CV
cons:
- I joined a department in Oracle which was bought in by acquisition of another company. Unfortunately, the company didnt change its culture even after becoming part of Oracle. Racism, bullying, harassment, sexist jokes. It was a living nightmare.
- I will happily work for Oracle again but not in an aquired setup.
- Too much self service 
- No human touch in form of accessible HR( its their but mostly through emails).

review_title: Great place to start
pros: Great place to start for newer analysts.  Great team members and flexible work schedule.   Lots of volunteering opportunities throughout the year.  Work spaces are modern and relaxing.
cons: Little to no advancement.  No raises or bonus regardless of performance.  Going above and beyond or doing the bare minimum results in the same outcome for your career here. Will have to apply to different units/areas to move up.  Seems common place for analysts to be here for 4-5 years without a single raise.

review_title: Do not pass go, do not collect $200
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Competitive pay for the area.  Many of the employees in the Gen. 2 cloud in Seattle are ex-Microsoft and AWS so the culture is compelling but as friendly as it seems, traditional Oracle culture bleeds in and halts any significant innovation.
cons: Far behind competitors in many different aspects. Not at product parity in the Gen 2 cloud - worrisome future for Oracle despite the stock price. Cloud is maintaining steam by auditing for database licenses. Executive leadership is not transparent enough and it seems like a neverending witchhunt where every employee is out to protect themselves.

review_title: Customer Success Manager
pros: Good salary, good benefits, great team (EMEA CSM Team)
cons: Oracle is an extremely heavy and complex organization, not very focused on its customers. Being a CSM in this org, despite the fact that the CSM team was truly composed of great people, is a complex position to handle. Sales and CSMs  targets, state of mind, and organizations are "by design" meant to fight against each other. Oracle is all about new business, without consideration for Customer Success and contract renewal. This means for example "fake" deals where a customer is undersold additional softwares without any use case, and is left to Customer Success organization with responsibility to renew the contract. Sales Rep sells a fridge to an Eskimo, and expects the CSM to make sure the Eskimo needs it and keep it....

review_title: Its not for everyone
pros: Solid brand, job opportunities and some good products. If you are happy to work in a system and not try and challenge the status quo, you can do well here.
cons: There is no real soul here.  Its not the most friendly place.  As part of a Global Business Unit, I did not even really feel like part of Oracle. The company does not share much in terms of direction and futures and it does not really invest in its people. Like many others I was aquired into Oracle. We were not welcomed. They did not seem to care. I guess thats just another day at Oracle.

review_title: Great opportunities to learn
pros:
- A wide spectrum of technologies - off course it depends on the team
- Lot of options to learn - Free courses from LinkedIn learning, safari online, Oracle University.... etc
- Unlimited work from home - Again, depending on the team. It was virtually unlimited on my team.
- No micromanagement. Most pressure is absorbed by the manager itself.
cons:
- Low increment in salary. I joined two years back. Got salary incremented only once (for all members in the team), and that too in low single digits.
- Sometimes, feels bored at office. May be because too many people works from home
- No free meals. But coffee, biscuits, all cocacola products are free in pantry

review_title: Great gym, Not a employee friendly company
job_title: Development Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros:
1. You have earned lots of money before
2. You do not care about growth monetarily
3. Stable job compared to the job market
4. Work from home options available
5. Good health benefits
cons:
1. Cares about product delivery on time but not their appraisals/hikes/bonuses
2. Not a employee friendly company
3. Bonuses and hikes are pathetic. 
4. Performance reviews not done on time as well as no proper goal settings in most groups.
5. No direction about future releases to employees (kept secretive)
6. No spot recognitions.
7. Expected to work 24X7 because of scattered team members
8. Too big and your hardwork may not be appreciated by anything monetary.

review_title: Good for a big company
job_title: Consulting Software Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros: An stint at Oracle, on your resume, makes getting future jobs  easier. You work with some very bright people and that helps you greatly, especially if you are beginning a new career. It pays to work for an industry leader in the Enterprise Software space. Oracle has great benefits in addition to a competitive salary.
cons: As with most large corporations, there is a little bit of bureaucracy. In terms of headcount, there is very little organic growth and that diminishes advancement opportunities as you move up the ladder. Work life balance can get skewed at times. Working for groups, which deal with mature product/features, will lead to stunted professional growth.

review_title: Oracle is OK
pros: For me I have good hours (8-5) while still making a decent salary and commission structure for my level.  There are good benefits in terms of health, dental etc.
cons: Management has no concept of the differences between territories.  They will give the same quotas to everyone even if they have well known inferior territories as compared to a great territory.  Therefore it has nothing to do with your sales ability but about how lucky you are the day you come in and get your territory.

review_title: Competitive, pressured but rewarding - but not rewarding in a financial sense
pros: Technology driven and a great place if you thrive in an ever changing environment. Professionally run with good governance and compliance, and has clear goals which it drives to achieve. Good opportunities to move within the company, and gives ability to travel in certain roles. Skilled and experienced staff to learn from.
cons: There seems to be a gap between executives and the rest - huge salaries on-top, but nothing cascaded. Pay rises are not given, and this causes a problem for staff retention. There are no pay rises for added responsibilities and no pay rises for promotions.

review_title: Senior Consultant
pros: In my case, Oracle financial service software is a good place which I learn a lot. Management always give chance to employee who wants to improve themselves.
cons: Since company has a lot of people, it needs to treat its employee equally. Sometimes, you may feel unfair but if you stay long enough. It is a good place though. If you want some place to earn decent money in a short time, it is not kind of place.

review_title: A pretty good company to work for
job_title: Software Development Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Oracle is a big company, but it runs very efficiently. Oracle's benefit seems to be quite good - one of them is the long term care insurance; one can purchase it for his parents as well. Key people get pretty good rewards. The work/life balance at Oracle (at least the division I work for) is quite good. Many people work from home one-day every week. Oracle also provides various training for employees: one can learn quite a bit if he really wants to.
cons: One needs to think about his own career path; otherwise, it is easy to get buried by day-to-day tasks. Also, different divisions at Oracle can be quite different. Choose one that works for you.

review_title: Great work place, lots of learning but needs to improve on employee benefits
pros: Great team to work with, a lot of help from all over the sides. Best thing about oracle is it's self-service culture. You get in to things and always come-out knowing new things. The thing I love the most is that Weekends and holidays are mine and can have lots of family time.
cons: People are not happy with compensation benefits. Specially the Non-Sales LOB. Salary growth is sometimes absent and mostly very very low. Work pressure is very high at all times.

review_title: Can be great, but can also be stifling
pros: It's a pretty open atmosphere wherein you get your work done and no one is watching over your shoulder.  Also, its so enormous that there are resources available for nearly anything you need/want to accomplish
cons: Extremely silo-ed and self-service (meaning you have to work really hard to find and convince someone to help you when you need it).  Very tough to be visible to higher ups in a number of positions, not a great culture all-in-all

review_title: Mostly a Great Company to work for
pros:
Oracle always enjoys a great place to work in at India. Though is a heavy weight in terms of number of employees, people I meet still think of Oracle as a great Company.

Work and work culture is Excellent. Training programs available for employees are good. General HR practices are good. Work life balance is good.
cons: Though this has been a great technology company, in the last few years hasn't been making big impact in terms of revenue and hence the salary not to the mark. People who stayed back longer are left out in a lower salary with a bigger gap in the market.

review_title: Management Issues
pros: Great Medical Benefits and they give free soda
cons: Company hires less experienced people at a high salary and does nothing for the ones already experienced in the workforce. Company pays for overtime but certain management will only allow certain people to do overtime or work from home. No raises and no promotions unless you are management.

review_title: Laid back culture, decent work
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros:
Work from home options. Flexibility in working hours.
Decent enough work. Can learn a lot if you want to.
No pressing work with a few exceptions.
Internal transfers in different teams/BU possible (at least on paper, haven't seen in practice though)
Average Salary
cons:
Non-competitive salary.
Very slow growth in terms of salary hike, promotion etc.
Bonus happens once in a bluemoon.
People joining with lesser experience may get better salary and designation without the need to prove themselves.

review_title: Good company with awesome benefits
pros:
This review is based on my experience with Oracle Consulting. Other departments may vary:
- Wonderful, comprehensive benefits package.
- Opportunity to work remote if the client allows it.
- Diverse product offering means you'll never get bored doing the same thing.
- Being the top database and database application company means Oracle isn't going under anytime soon.
- Free Oracle University training (as long as your cost center pays for it).
- Decent work / life balance if you get onto a project with competent project management.
- Very progressive company with regards to corporate culture and values.
cons:
Again, cons are based on my experience at Oracle Consulting. Sales, marketing, product development, etc experiences will vary:
- Your resource manager will only see / talk to you once a year, and they are the ones responsible for your performance review. Not good.
- Pay is extremely low when compared to other Oracle development / consulting jobs in the industry.
- Layoffs almost every quarter. If you find yourself in between projects, expect a severance package in the mail.
- Performance reviews are actually not based on performance, but dictated by upper management. This creates an environment of favoritism.
- Senior management in consulting had been in disarray while I was there, resulting in low morale.
- Oracle Consulting is a revolving door and Oracle is turning into a training house for other companies.
- Promotions / raises take forever. Every year they have a new excuse as to why they can't promote you.

review_title: A Great Place to Retire...Early
pros: A very flexible work environment with a big company work pace and resources. Good pay, benefits, and stability. A very large and specialized organizational structure with many product lines provide ample career opportunities for employees looking to expand their skill set or change jobs.
cons: Monolithic bureaucracy driven by lowest common denominator policies with many layers of departments and management to contend with. Very little opportunity to effect change or see the measurable results to your efforts. Horrible HR practices, poor culture, and very low employee engagement leading to high attrition of talent. Many employees actively using the complexity of the organization and lack of accountability to "rest and vest" making it difficult for the remainder to get anything done.

review_title: Strong Company, Weak Management
pros:
Great technology.
Good talent below mid-management: smart, decent people.
Private Health Fund: nice benefits.
Work-life balance in some roles.
cons: Too many directors and senior directors are programmed to manage by email and spreadsheet and don't have basic people skills. Talent programs are run by previously-redundant telesales managers who had no talent development experience and treat people as numbers. Their graduate programme has recently become a telesales hire program, leading to grads losing jobs in the latest restructuring of the Asia Pac telesales function.

review_title: Software Engineering Intern Summer 2016
pros: Get to work on really cool technical projects with extremely knowledgable team members.  Workplace is relaxed, hours are flexible, intern packages are very generous.
cons: Some of the teams are very distributed, with members in several different offices across the country (or even internationally).  This could be a problem if you can't work independently or can't advocate for yourself when you need help.  The East Coast offices have very few interns/intern events, so you'll have to do some exploring yourself if you want to have a social life outside of work.

review_title: Great company to learn and advance your career
job_title: Cloud Engineer in Redwood Shores, CA
pros:
Learned so much and met great people!

Oracle is a large company with many different business units and opportunities to excel in.  If you need a change just apply for another job in oracle internally and snap you have a new team and new project to work on which is easier than searching for a new job outside the company.  

The company is involved in databases, Linux, Middleware, cloud, etc so there is a lot to learn and soak up while your there as well.
cons:
Oracle is ruthless in looking to outsource resources outside the U.S (cheaper labor)

I have seen globalizations ugly side at Oracle as more work goes overseas and leaves the U.S, its unfortunate but leaves us in the U.S to fight to stay competitive for our price.

The June "Hunger Games" are real!  Let me explain, around June time is the end of the fiscal year and then projects and team efforts are assessed.  If your team is not performing up to par or you personally you may want to update your resume just in case you go to the chopping block.  Just make sure your getting good performance reviews :)

Oracle is a large company and as expected your work becomes more partitioned into islands or "silos". So for example the networking team does the load balancing and network design, the ops team deploys the servers and manages them, then the dev team creates the automation, etc.  So if you like startups and how you can change hats from system admin to dev, to network guy, you will miss have that option open at oracle.

review_title: Sr Principal Consultant (OFSS) Netherlands
job_title: Senior Principal IT Consultant in Amsterdam
pros:
Lots of Travel
Opportunities to work with various clients
Flexibility to work from home
Good medical insurance plan
cons:
- Like many at Glassdoor have said and it is totally true that Oracle doesn't give salary hikes. I got 3 promotions at Oracle and i was never given a raise. 
- No clear vision shared from the group head. 
- Lack innovation and no platform available to share innovative ideas within the group
- No proper training offered on new products. Employees are expected to learn on the job, on the projects

review_title: Senior Application Engineer
pros:
1. If you can join as a fresher, you can meet the expectations as you can get knowledge from the team. 
2. Good hike for earlier years to compensate market standards.
3. Other than technical people, functional and hr laterals can enjoy.
cons:
1. Work life balance is worst for all teams in Chennai.
2. Laterals, don't even think of joining this company because even the best cannot meet the expectations due to lack of product knowledge and lateral who joined as fresher's will definitely do more than what you can.
3. Compensation during offer is good in the market but hikes are minimal.
4. Laterals joined with me, most of the people left the company.
5. Management may threaten employee to PIP or fire but they won't as the attrition rate is higher and no one willing to join the company.
6. No fun, Strict timelines 
7. No on-site.

review_title: Good Company. Maximum flexibility
pros: I work in RE&F, so I can't speak for the developers or sales, but I like the team I work on a lot. We all could make more money elsewhere, but Oracle provides us with flexibility and a nice culture. I genuinely enjoy going to work most days because of the people. One of my good friends is a Java Developer and he genuinely enjoys working here too.
cons: Sometimes my work is boring. Often times I wish I had more work to fill the day. I wish there was a greater emphasis on learning and growth. My team is scattered around the globe, and sometimes it's lonely when I have to work alone. That probably won't be the case for most people at Oracle.

review_title: It's OK
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Raleigh, NC
pros: Profitable and, as a result, has survived the last two relatively large economic downturns. Lots of different technologies and lines of business. Very nice benefits.
cons: I really don't count since I don't work at HQ. Although profitable, those profits are not shared with me (unless you count the 1.5% dividend on the stock I can buy through the ESPP at a 5% discount). My development machine and monitor is not be something to be proud of. The main motivation of many projects is to impress upper management, not impress our customers. In general, the people are not very social.

review_title: OK, not great
pros: Working for such a large established company looks good on a resume.  They also provide decent health benefits and 401k.
cons: If you're outside of their corporate headquarters (i.e., brought on as part of an acquisition) it's easy to feel like a faceless cog in a giant machine.  For a tech company, their IT practices are surprisingly unfriendly to developers.  You may see arbitrary layoffs dictated by someone 3 layers up the management change from your VP.

review_title: Inside Sales
pros: Great sales training is provided in the business development program at Oracle which allows their sales people to be successful when hired from within. There are a lot of opportunities to learn about the IT industry and the individual industries within one's territory.
cons: The competitive nature of Oracle is not a friendly one as it promotes internal competition rather than collaboration. When you have a company selling hundreds of products into one account - it really requires collaboration to have a thriving and happy sales team. The opposite is true and creates many unnecessary internal battles.

review_title: Inefficiency and complete lack of desire to retain employees
job_title: Field Marketing Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Large company that will have all of the basic benefits - espp, 401k, vacation, etc.
cons: Every process is super tedious and non-intuitive (HR, Expense Reporting, etc).  They are all in legacy Oracle applications, so it feels like 1992 with super clunky, old applications.  Makes it hard to be proud of the product, when every time you have to interact with it, it is so painful.  They also do not care about their employees - it very much feels like each employee is an (easily replaceable) line on a spreadsheet.

review_title: New World
job_title: Senior Sales Consultant in Houston, TX
pros: Deep financial stability of balance sheet.   Broad customer base.   Broad market coverage.  Wide geographic presence.  Constant change in organization, if that is something you like.
cons: Disconnected vision of products and industry.  Limited opportunity for advancement and growth.  Miserly attention to costs and access to resources for training their technical employees.  Strange view of employee value and relationships between product maturity and level of customer technical support to both sell and implement could technology.  Sales Management believes that the cloud product maturity supports a non-technical sales approach.  Business and Industry experience seems to have little value.

review_title: Oracle Direct Regional Manager (Real Sales)
job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Austin, TX
pros:
1. For those that can figure out how to "manipulate" the inflexible Oracle systems, you can make a lot of money if you have the right territory or territories.  
2. For those that want to be lazy and collect a paycheck, come on in! The water's great. Easy place just to sit and never be fired. Suckers like me will take pity on you and help you through whatever you need because that's the way I am. 
3. For those that love change, come aboard! The plan and strategy (lack thereof) changes every 3-6-9 months, leaving everyone trying to clean up and ride out what was approved only to have everything turned upside down. 
4. If you did want to stay at Oracle and not for #1, there are potential opportunities outside of sales however, you will need attainment and awesome networking. You are just a number here, so thinking that you can apply internally and get preference is a horrible lie.
cons:
I've never worked at a Sales oriented company where I've had to fight with so many departments to get a deal done, only to then have provisioning screw everything up. I spend more than half my work day helping my reps fix Oracle created internal problems so the customers can actually receive the service they want or are paying for. Its embarrassing to win a sales cycle only to have Oracle screw it up so badly (internally) that the customer questions why they're going to trust their mission critical enterprise application to a company who can't get a technical question or something else answered in a week?

Secondly, from an operations standpoint, SaaS/PaaS/IaaS need better resources. Asking a customer to wait 4-6 weeks after the customer buys to receive their environment, is unacceptable. Other Cloud Providers I've worked for do it in minutes if not hours. To add insult to injury, then provisioning screws up the order and when they're questioned, you get some snarky answer of: "These are complex deals". Clearly something is broken. If they're overworked, why should the customer suffer because Oracle can't hire people fast enough? Or, as its commonly known throughout the Sales Org, there are bugs in our provisioning software that do not get resolved in a timely manner. I'm not referring to a couple of weeks but rather months. This is months of this negatively impacting the customer.

review_title: A good school, a good place to settle, but not so much to evolve
pros: Innovative company with strong products on many market areas. They hire a lot of young employees and train them. Excellent work-life balance and very competitive salaries and benefits. Coming from Oracle makes you legitimate for the customers.
cons: It's a sales company, they're not so interested in the delivery, support or development. Processes are very long and communications between divisions is not so great. It's also a very pyramidal company with very little opportunities to change jobs. Many people have been at their job for more than 10 years.

review_title: Insight & Customer Strategy
pros: Per se the work it's quite interesting in that you are always exposed to new customers and industries and you get to work with senior stakeholders
cons:
-Very poor management. Bully, pretentious, lacking any trust and any form of respect for individuals, micromanagers, lacking any strategic partnership with Sales, anchored to old way of working
-Very poor culture based on competition rather than collaboration. There are 3-4 different teams with overlapping responsibilities so colleagues hide things each others to drive personal agendas. "What is in for me" culture with little interest on what is right for the customer
-Company with flat growth rates: every quarter there is tension as results are poor and they have to find someone to blame.

review_title: Billionaire Boys Club
job_title: Program Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great salary and benefits. LGBTQ+ friendly. Telecommute opportunities.
cons: Immensely political and management only wants to hear things are going great. Very few females (and non-binaries). There is an awareness of the reputation for being an old, tired company run by men with terrible UI's but very little is actually changing. Being honest and bold is generally frowned upon. All of the rhetoric about their product capabilities is smoke and mirrors for the mess going on behind the scenes. Hiring process is a joke.

review_title: Unappreciated
pros: The people were nice to work with. Very accepting. Job stability
cons: No growth. Unappreciated. Raises were few and far between against top producers. Last minute demand for OT. Often required to work one day of three day holiday weekends. Those hours wouldn’t qualify as OT due to week start so basically one would loose four hours of pay if classified as OT pay. All other departments would have three day weekend.

review_title: Flexible and Forward Looking
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: I joined Oracle nearly two years ago, for the opportunity to lead a growing team, expand my experience as a global marketer and work in remote role that would allow flexibility in my life as a working mother. I can confidently say that my goals were met - but also that I've come to be even more excited about Oracle's future ahead. I knew Oracle had a strong history as a tech leader, but had no idea how revolutionary their technology really is. This is an exciting opportunity for a marketing professional - to help bring this story to life!
cons: This is a complex organization to navigate, with a "self serve" culture. It can be especially overwhelming to new joiners who are remote.

review_title: Should give more thought before you join
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros: It is a huge company and have many resources. There are so many things, technologies and/or products that you can learn and try. It is all free because all owned by Oracle. The experience will enhance your technical skill and some of the products, to be frank, are fairly leading edge.
cons: The schedule is so tight, they will not invest on training. You have to take initiative at your own time. Also, do not expect raise at all nor stock option grant instead negotiate a higher salary starting. Even your manager do want to give u a raise, her hand is tied. It is all control by the most upper management.

review_title: Flexible and Forward Looking

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros: It is a huge company and have many resources. There are so many things, technologies and/or products that you can learn and try. It is all free because all owned by Oracle. The experience will enhance your technical skill and some of the products, to be frank, are fairly leading edge.
