review_title: Great place to work if you can find a leadership role
job_title: Group Product Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: A large, stable, successful company where you can move around and grow. There are 1000s of smart, capable people. The company has good benefits and salary. Its a good place to work when raising a family. Sales, engineering teams are great.
cons: Some executives are highly political creatures with strong anti-innovation mindset. Try to work for newly acquired executives (or startups Oracle has bought), if you want to learn and grow. Working with Oracle long-timers is usually a bad idea unless there is a specific smart person.

review_title: Quantity is preferred over quality
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros:
- Great opportunities for career growth if you are willing to bite the bullet and work insane hours.
- Its a very secure job with quite a lot of benefits
- Diverse environment. So there are lots of opportunities to develop your communication skills.
- Has tons of projects and groups to choose from. If you dont like something, you can move onto something else.
cons:
There seems to be a scarcity of quality people in Oracle.
Process verbose in a whole bunch of areas. Sometimes its difficult to get things done.
Technologically, there is no innovation. The focus seems to be on copying the competition and try to overtake them.

review_title: oracle is a good company to work for
job_title: Senior Principal Consultant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: it offers higher position compared to other competitor, such as big 4. I have just jointed, so I will have to make up for the rest. oracle is developing so fast compared to big 4, they are definitely getting a edge over others. the learning experience of oracle financial also sounds cool, for sap does not seem to be as promising as oracle financial in the long run. oracle seems to be more open minded and provides more room for professional growth.
cons: I asked for too little. seems they can pay more, but anyway, 10k is nothing compared to a good career.

review_title: Senior Product Manager at Oracle Corporation
job_title: Senior Product Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Employee benefits (e.g., insurance, etc.), work location in the Peninsula which always has beautiful weather, corporate perks (e.g., food/drink on the floor), ability to work from home, great technical resources, extremely talented and hungry employee base, a beautiful corporate campus, provides a great name and reference on a resume.
cons: Not a true meritocracy, the entire business relies on the database, politics plays a huge part within the organization, "what happens when Larry leaves?," many employees are great at their positions but that leaves some decisions and insights to be binary in nature (e.g., either you're brilliant or this is the most doomed idea on the planet).

review_title: No Bonuses, No Raises, We are not rewarded for the company's success
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: It's stable, and the work is interesting.  I do credit executive management for keeping the company stable through these turbulent times.
cons: It has gotten very stressful in the last 2 years, with management asking for more and more 'productivity' with fewer people.  This translates to poor morale, and ultimately bad products.  The people who have been with the company longest, know the most, are now the worst paid.  Does that make sense?  The raises really tanked after 2000, followed by the stock options, and then the bonuses disappeared.  How do we share in the company's success?

review_title: Depends on what you are looking for. Server Technologies better than other Development groups in India
pros:
1. Lot of product areas and thus scope of moving across groups
2. If you get good manager / product area career growth taken care
3. Server Technologies support employee initiative and extra curricular stuff like Work life balance, Learning and Innovation
cons:
1. Salary... Once you are in, tough to get money unless you show obvious displeasure regarding salary
2. Non transparent compensation, bonus and hike policies
3. No strict policy / process follow for goal setting and appraisals

review_title: Encouraged to over deliver, though any tangible return on discretionary effort applied is non existent.
pros: Fast changing company , highly acquisitive , lots of new virtual teams to work with , access to good products and supporting collateral, the Oracle brand opens doors.
cons: Pay grade changes are prohibited. Over delivering in a role is at the employees expense. HR processes are non resistant. "investing in people" is an alien concept. only Sales and Development are respected , the remainder is 'over head'. Attrition remains in low single digits , giving the corporation the upper hand in managing Human Capital.

review_title: The experience largely depends on the group
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros:
- Large company, lots of different groups
- Leading player in databases and storage servers
- Nice gym
- Free Friday lunches for new college hires and many free events/outings
- Flexible work hours
- Pretty campus
- If you are lucky to get into a good group, then your coworkers and your manager are probably smart and know what they are doing
cons:
- Overall the atmosphere is not as vibrant as lots of other silicon valley companies 
- Limited vacation days (13 total for employees working under 3 years) and public holidays (8 total)
- Some groups are not nearly as good as others

review_title: A long, rewarding experience with its up and downs
pros: Freedom is the one greatest offer from Oracle. Very loose every day control and reliance on people expertise. Oracle is also THE top B2B information technology company globally, possibilities are only a step away.
cons: Little integration between division can make a consultant life very frustrating. Very little chance of vertical career as everybody above likes his/her own chair and replacement at the top is basically non existing.

review_title: Big Company mentality, Decent Life Balance
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros: Overall, a pretty good life balance which is important if you have a family or plan on having one.
cons: Compensation for developers is not adequate.  I think that management believes that developers are expandable and can be replaced by college hires (cheaper labor).  If you stick around for long enough (10+years), then I think the picture changes

review_title: Not a great place to work long term...
job_title: Product Development in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Stable company. Decent benefits. Some new technologies through acquisition. Some training depending on your manager/department.
cons:
- Lack of raises
- Promotions do not come with a raise, in fact I lost OT with my promotion so it was really a pay cut after all was said and done (Boy was I surprised!)
- Long term Oracle employees (15-30yr) are mostly mediocre at best (Oracle red tape sucks the passion out of people)
- Internal tools are terrible
- There is a lot of politics

review_title: Oracle isn't that bad of a place
job_title: Director Product Management in Nashua, NH
pros:
There isn't a ton of pressure. 
Deadlines are clear and generally manageable
Very flexible workplace-depending on what group you're in
If you're good at your job, then the stock options and raises are pretty amazing. They pay for talent. People that complain about no raises, no bonus,  and no stock are likely doing enough, but not going over and above.
cons:
At best a middle of the road employee gets 2-3% raises a year.
constantly changing priorities hurt productivity and morale
Good management, but very shiny nickel driven.

review_title: Software Developer 2
pros:
You get to work with one of the best minds of the company
No strict hierarchy system as such, you can approach anyone directly
Flexible
cons:
Manager and his/her skills play a tremendous role in all respects. If you have a good manager, your work will be appreciated, hikes and bonuses are all up to the manager. Sadly, we dont have that many good managers.
HR is a pain. They dont even let you get references from your managers/peers. So if you are planning for higher studies or job switch that requires a recommendation letter, you may wanna do it without too many people finding out

review_title: Oracle Financial services,not so good not so bad
pros:
Can maintain a good work life balance
Flexible working hours,often u have to stay late when u have more work,but if you don't have much work , u can leave early too
Approachable people,All managers,team leads and team members are quite helpful and friendly
cons:
No exposure to new technology
Your domain knowledge increases, tehcnical knowledge doesn't increase at all
Employees are never given a feedback on their performance whether it is positive or negative.
No proper hike or appraisal. Hence not a good company for a fresher

review_title: Great Company to be Involved with.
pros:
Large Company with tons of resources. Easy access to many coworkers with a wealth of knowledge, all more than happy to help!

Strong leadership - my management has my back 100% and it just breathes a positive vibe and atmosphere into the job. 

Remote employee roughly 50 - 75% of the time.
cons: Have yet to see a raise, but my former company was acquired by Oracle and the integration process just kicked into gear rather recently. Hopefully this changes!

review_title: Strong Company lacking in Communication and Compensation
pros: Good benefits, flexible work schedules and location, lots of online training available. Good tools and templates to do the job.
cons: Groups are all silos, lots of acquisitions leading to integration challenges. if you are not part of the main business lines (EBusiness Suite, Database, etc) there is very little focus or excitement for senior leaders, raises and bonuses were few and far between (and it was never explained why), vision of group was often not communicated, reductions in staff happened every year and seemed to not be thought out.

review_title: Network Engineer - Oracle Austin Data Center
pros: Very laid back atmosphere. Lots of exposure to diff technologies (juniper, cisco, f5, windows/linux servers). great environment for self starters and independent workers. i met my direct manager once in 3 years. you are responsible for being professional and handling your work load.
cons: not too much training involved. you'll need to come in the door with a decent idea of these technologies. to be a major company, their documentation is almost non existent, however you are more than welcome to submit your own documentation regarding configs etc. pay is lower than most companies, so you better negotiate well at the door. raises? yea right. bonuses? yea right.

review_title: Opportunity and Work Life Balance
pros: There is a lot of opportunity within Oracle to transfer across pillars and business units if you want to diversify your background. A lot of growth and acquisitions that continue to provide opportunities for movement. Very flexible when it comes  to work life balance and very open to the ability to work remote part or full time.
cons: Though the opportunity is the there to move around the organization, you have to be very proactive about it. Not a lot of tools in place to help leaders in other groups to identify those that want to move. Also in regards to working remotely you have to put in the effort to network and get connected to people outside of your immediate team.

review_title: Senior Software Engineer, UI Tech Lead
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros: Mature environment, opportunity to work with highly professional software engineers with experience and deep knowledge of systems. Stability. Good healthcare benefits.
cons: A little too slow, easy to fall off the latest innovation in technology. A lot of processes, sometimes annoying but if you have a good manager that's not a problem, meaning that managers are trying to make the processes easy and give good amount of time for employees to go through them.

review_title: I liked the Software Program they used for time Mgt. as well as booking airline tickets, Hotels & renting cars.
pros: The time passed very fast because you're working fast & efficiently.  There's never a dull moment.  You must get an early start before the boss man gets in to see if there are any "fires" to put out or make him/her aware of them.
cons: Don't expect a pat on the back for all your efforts.  Just let this part roll off your back.  You work hard & you're under appreciated.  It's like being a great Mom... you're expected to break your back for your boss.

review_title: Program Manager
pros: The people that you work with are outstanding in their field.
cons: Management is challenging.   Bonuses and raises are not done yearly, only every several years, and mostly to management, not the rank and file.  Oracle is off shoring many of their positions and therefore layoffs happen almost weekly.  I was laid off after 21 years and it was due to my position going off shore.   Truly feel like we are just a commodity and can be replaced at any point in time.  Oracle does make money, but it is on the back of the workers.

review_title: Good Place to Work if you Work Hard
job_title: Partner Account Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: As an employee, I feel Oracle values people of all ages & ethnic backgrounds. Our technology is solid and in most cases better than our competitors. We have a complete array of solid PaaS Cloud offerings.
cons: Oracle is hard to do business with from a customer's perspective. More to the point, Oracle is respected in the marketplace but we are not loved by our customers. This is Oracle's biggest challenge in our efforts to grow our Cloud business.

review_title: It's ok to work at Oracle.
job_title: Principal Support Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Flexible work arrangements.  Equitable compensation package.  Recognition (by immediate management) for a job well done.
cons: I was part of the PeopleSoft takeover.  Oracle is certainly a bigger company and a great deal of the familial atmosphere that was inherent of PeopleSoft is definitely lost.  Albeit there is a reason Mr. Ellison makes the money he does and surely I represent just a small part of his employee population.  It appears though, that executive management at PeopleSoft had a better knack for understanding what we, who are on the front/first line of ''combat'' with the clients, go through.  Changes were instituted with both the client and us, in mind.

Heavy work load leads to burn out and poor morale that is not addressed.

review_title: Good for long time career

pros:

In times of good profits the employees are rewarded and long term commitment is also valued.
cons:
Young people who join the company are expected to stay 3-5 years to see any reasonable growth in both career and salary. 
Going to HQ and other offshore opportunities are limited.

review_title: Not that bad, not that good
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Beijing, Beijing
pros: From job security perspective, it's a good place to stay, it offers not bad welfare, such as outing activities, social club. You have flexible working time, you have paid annual leave; most boss I met are nice,

review_title: It all depends on how hard you work!
pros: If you really work hard and set direction, you have all the chances to become successful. Also if you feel that you would contribute more to other team, you can change and move on, well, this if you can get the job first.
cons:
You need a lot of patience, also you might need to wait many years till you get a promotion or a raise, it  depends on too many things, so it kind of subjective, but you can do it.
Sometimes you just get lost in the processes as it is such a huge company and you find out that instead of sales, for example, you do paperwork 70% of your time.

review_title: Good if you don't wanna work too much
pros: Flexibility. No one cares when you come and when you go. Its not a problem if you don't meet the target, or even if you do.
cons: Extremely difficult to actually start doing something challenging. Developers spend all the time fixing bugs. Development is also mostly understanding their proprietary API that are buggy and undocumented. Knowing people is more important than know technology. No hikes and no bonuses. review_title: I have stability and decent benefits but satisfaction is starting to wane after several years of minimal advancement

pros: Stability of the company and sense that my job is secure. Facilities are nice. There was flexibility in job location in the past but that seems to be changing.
cons: Starting to feel a lack of commitment to long time employees over bringing in new people where lower expectations can be set for them in relation to job conditions, salary and perks. Feel like a minion at times.

review_title: Principal Sales Consultant
pros:
A huge place with some of the smartest brains.
Plenty of technologies to learn. A place where you can develop both technical and business skills.
A huge plus is Oracle's work flexibility. As long as you get your job done no one will ask why you are not showing face in the office.
cons:
Aggressive selling to the effect that some customers start hating Oracle.
Plenty of politics being a large organisation with different LoBs with their own agendas.
If you are not part of a core team that deals with high-end solutions no one will care about you do.

review_title: Good and Bad (marketing and product management)
pros:
- working hours flexible
- benefits pretty good
- lots of internal opportunities
- have mostly worked with amazing people
cons:
- promotions and any kind of raise or bonus are hard to come by and their pay is either really good or not at all, but once you are hired you are stuck with it.
- layoffs are done in very small numbers so they do not have to give the 2 month WARN act pay (that is my personal opinion)
- They change course a lot, teams get re-orged and ramp up just in time to get re-orged again.
- too many exec layering, causes confusion to teams since they all have their own agenda.

review_title: Fabulous Place to work.
pros:
Oracle is an incredible place to work. There is opportunity everywhere. It does required a couple things though. 

1) You can be having the time of your life while the person sitting next to you is not.. This is the nature of a company as large and diverse as Oracle. Therefore you need to do you're due diligence and ensure the manager/role/KPI's etc. are going to give you a good work environment. Don't rely on 'Oracle' as it's too big - be sure you understand the team you are going into. The company is in a growth spurt particularly in the Sales function around cloud applications. This can mean ambitious hiring in advance of the demand so if you are going into a sales role be a self starter and study up on demand generation. 

2) Bring your personality, idea's innovation and positivity. Oracle is crying out for this and we were always on the hunt for people to make a positive example of. I've seen careers grow incredibly fast as people take their own initiatives. I've also seen people a couple weeks in the company leading global projects - just because they like the subject matter and pushed for something to happen. 

3) Branch out! Meet new people every day. The ones that isolate themselves to a small group often find themselves lonely in the long run... It's a place where you need to get your name out there and find something to be known for.
cons: Oracle Dublin is an amazing place to work overall. Currently there are parts of the business changing incredibly fast.While this always brings opportunity it can make for a tough start if you prefer something more stable.. Overall however if you are adverse to change - Oracle is not the place for you..

review_title: Joined Oracle through acquisition - worst experience in career
pros: Hard to think of many - er... Good canteen, quick expenses payment, good benefits - I enjoyed making the most out of my David Lloyd membership as well as other benefits whilst there but that was about it.
cons: Horrible culture, horrendously old school attitude to a lot of things and a lot of mediocre employees who are happy working 9 - 5 and picking up their pay checks. Also, renowned for buying the hottest tech companies, not investing in their products and killing those companies. If you want to work for one of the large firms don't choose Oracle - choose Adobe, Salesforce, Microsoft - all better to work for than arrogant Oracle.

review_title: Cloud Applications is a Disaster
job_title: Applications Sales Executive in Burlington, MA
pros: Zero - Management is awful. Culture sucks. No one is booking ANYTHING and the higher ups are completely tone deaf to what is going on.
cons:
Culture is awful, no one wants to be here and morale is at 0. 
Territories are so small that no one is booking anything.
Class of's are terribly trained and have no idea what they're doing, but are told they are the future. They literally can't sell anything and have no business being in this role, they are ruining customer relationships by being clueless.

review_title: Change is constant
pros: The beauty of working at Oracle was being at the forefront of technology and working for a company that is a giant in the industry.  But, if you work here, you need to be able to move on a dime to the constant change.
cons: There's plenty of career opportunities for movement, but when you make a lateral move, you will not be compensated the salary the position offers.  There are no raises or standard of living increases, so negotiate wisely whe you accept the offer. On the flip-side, benefits were incredible

review_title: Need to work on retaining employees
job_title: Software Developer III in Broomfield, CO
pros: Good benefits, flexible working schedule, fun coworkers
cons: There isn't a focus on retaining current employees. No specific directions or path for career growth. They need to work on growing people who have been committed to the company for a significant amount of time instead of hiring in new people to take higher paying roles. Even for employees who want to stay, the minimal raises and lack of bonuses/stock grants after hire make income go down over time. Good employees can't afford to stay here and watch new people come in and take higher salaries. Super demoralizing.

review_title: An actual house of cards
job_title: Associate Sales Consultant in Austin, TX
pros: Work-life balance is great, with hardly anyone working past 5pm. Management gives you free reign to handle your own business, so no micro-managing. The office culture is young and laid-back, most people dress semi-business casual, and everyone is generally positive and friendly. Oracle also looks good on a resume.
cons: Management has little to no formal management training and it is pretty obvious. The "self-service" nature of Oracle is really just an excuse to provide no training or guidance when you first start. On-boarding is a major company weakness. There is a quite a bit of downtime in the role, and most recommendations are to use this time to train yourself on product knowledge. A lot of your success will depend on which sales team you support and how well you get along with the sales manager. There is no accountability, so no one checks to see if you have learned something correctly. This causes misinformation to commonly be passed around the organization for extended periods of time. It often feels like no one really knows what's going on or what any of the products do, and commonly push back on your questions. Whenever there is an actual problem, it becomes very apparent who actually knows their stuff and who has just been faking it. Bonuses are tied to unreachable goals and we've recently only received 60%-70% of our annual bonuses. Also, in the first year, your bonus ramps up (only eligible for 25% in first quarter, 50% second quarter, etc...). No one will tell you this and it's not in writing. Compensation plans have been incorrect two years in a row, however, you're forced to sign the incorrect document so that you get paid while finance fixes the issues. Every year, it felt shady signing an incorrect, legally-binding document around my pay.

review_title: A Great Place to Work
pros:
As a company is really only as great as its people and Oracle has some of the best people to work with in the industry, I give it a high rating. I worked at Oracle for 4 years and made the mistake of leaving. They hired me back and I had a 2 year run then was let go. I took a territory that I shouldn't have taken so its mostly on me. 

I would happily go back to work for Oracle again. I'd hoped to retire there but a sales person needs to hit numbers and it was impossible given my patch. They'd not been successful there in 15 years and I new that going in. What prompted me to write this is  someone I worked with there reached out to me on a business focused social media platform to connect. They've been with Oracle for 20 years. I felt envy but very happy for them. There are many people with a very long tenure there.
cons: I don't know of any relevant cons to share about Oracle as a company to work for. Yes, of course there are some people that perhaps shouldn't be in management and yes managers can play favorites but people are people. My best advice would be to share what my first manager told me which is to be good at reinventing yourself and move into other organizations within the company. Looking back, I should have started to make a move to a different group long before I was let go but I loved my manager and my team and let that put a rose color tint on my glasses. They did let a VP from my group go in June who was great to work for. That person missed their number for Fiscal Year 17 but helped build a line of business from a near disaster to a success and hit the team numbers for 10 previous years. I found that to be a little bit of a shocker.

review_title: There is life after Oracle!
job_title: Database Administrator in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Training, experience, knowledge. Stating you are a former Oracle employee is huge! I had left Oracle twice, which make me ineligible for re-hire a third time.  However, I have raised my salary by over 100k since I left Oracle.  Oracle experience and training is worth a LOT of MONEY.  Go out to the real world and apply what you have learned at Oracle and make your life!
cons: Lots of work, no raises in last 7 years, very small bonuses!

If you want to settle down or spend 2-3 years of life peacefully then Oracle is the best bet. But don't expect anything in return . I mean it.... anything. You will be same as you were before 2-3 years  in terms of salary , knowledge, technology growth... everything.

At one point of time you can think of joining Oracle Bangalore, but never ever join Hyderabad. It is completely based on fusion applications which no one uses except Oracle

review_title: Mixed bag.  Some good, some bad.

review_title: Its sales what can i say
pros: Working at Oracle has many pros like great pay, great culture, great benefits and many more. Most of the pros are not the actual job you will do though. The job is sales related so you will have good days and bad
cons: Getting into seat they had no work for me for almost a month. Once I got my accounts I made quick work of them and was not given more so this is a huge con. I am expected  to reach similar quotas to people with many more accounts or better ones.

review_title: Stay as far away as possible
pros: Free drinks in the kitchen
cons:
Employee culture is terrible, the only priority is to keep management happy, and management is only concerned with keeping their managers happy.  Meanwhile our products are quickly becoming over engineered garbage.  
Compensation is a joke, if you apply as a non manager, be sure to get as much money up front as possible,  because your raises will be laughable.  I got a total of 7k in raises in 7 years there, despite consistently getting good performance reviews.  If you do come in as a manager, you will get better raises, but be prepared to sell your soul, you will mainly be a messenger for higher management.  Being a yes man is the only way to survive here, and life is too short for that nonsense.

review_title: Great, Large, Stable Company to work.
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros: Large, Stable company with great benefits. The pay is pretty good, and the stock has been on the rise for at least 6 years. Like any big company, you have a secure job.  You don't have to work extremely hard, and the campus is very nice.  I've worked as both a remote employee and a HQ based one.  Each were fulfilling jobs.
cons: Promotions tend to be hard to get.  Typical large company problems, where you feel like you can't make a huge difference. Sometimes the process can get in the way on innovation. Hence the amount of small acquisitions. Small companies tend to innovate better than large ones.

review_title: World-class database technology plus a growing applications business
job_title: Consulting Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: Great benefits except 3.5 weeks vacation seems average.  RDBMS is industry leading and has great technology. HQ has excellent cafeteria choices.  HQ campus is beautifully landscaped and very attractive.  Managers have engineering responsibilities so they can understand technical issues and relate to their direct reports.  After a certain number of years, you are practically guaranteed an office.
cons: Working from home is expected.  E-mail needing replies can come in at any time.  Customer escalations can be stressful.  It is such a nice environment (campus and cafeterias) that it is stressful to think about not meeting expectations and possibly being laid off.

review_title: Oracle is being stangled by its management structure that inhibits its ability to react quickly and dynamically
pros: Large company with many many areas of work, businesses, competencies etc

review_title: Good place for work life balance; Not for high growth
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros:

- Good pay package

-perks - internet, telephone, bonus above ctc etc.

review_title: Software company's hardware growing pains
pros: Large, successful company. Solid benefits package. Opportunity to grow your career.
cons: Oracle as a whole is very knowledgeable when it comes to software. However, since acquiring Sun Microsystems, they struggled to understand the demands/requirements of hardware customers. The two businesses operate quite differently, but Oracle insists on the same blanket approach be used  for all products, be it hardware or software (and Services for that matter). You can get "lost" in the sheer size of the company. Decision makers can be several steps away from the average worker, creating unnecessary delays in correcting issues or implementing new ideas. Internal assistance in non-existent, as all apps etc are "self-help".

review_title: Does not value innovation or individuality
job_title: Principal Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Oracle is "comfortable", and probably a reasonable place to work if you enjoy a more rigid and straightforward environment.
cons: Oracle has become so large that they are incapable of fostering innovation within the company. They have transitioned into the standard "acquire and assemble" mentality of large companies faced with this problem. The result is an environment where engineers are not valued for their ideas or ability to drive innovation, but rather viewed as replaceable cogs in a ruthless business machine. Management makes broad decisions based on business metrics without understanding the technical challenges, and prevents individual engineers from having a say in the direction of the product or company. Support organizations, from recruiting to HR to IT, intrinsically suppress individuality and culture to create a monotonous business-focused monoculture.

review_title: International company with a lot of opportunities in all software and hardware areas.
pros: In this company you'll find an open culture and a lot of good opportunities, especially in Sales. But you have to work for them. We say: "Oracle offers a lot of doors, but you have to open them yourself".
cons: Oracle offers a big variety of products, it is difficult even to know the solutions from your area. Last years the company struggled a little which led to cost savings, which makes the company less attractive. Oracle pays good, but it is difficult to raise your salary once you are in. People prefer to leave and come back to increase their salaries.

review_title: Okay Experience... Ready to Go!

- Close to the metro.
- Interesting vertical.

review_title: Mixed bag

Huge network of talented people are available across the globe always willing to support you in meeting customer demands.
cons: For those that want to be managed and guided it can be disappointing. It's everyone for themselves - you manage your own career and don't worry about the processes.Yes its a big company but compared to many it's more results driven than process driven..

review_title: Business Development Consultant
job_title: Business Development Representative in Burlington, MA
pros: Great name with plenty of resources and actually a very fun place to work.
cons: Fake it till you make it.Business development program is sort of a joke. For the most part its all luck if you have a good territory and senior reps who let you pipe opportunities. Many people will just go in an watch Netflix all day and get promoted while others will bust and not get a chance.

review_title: Run and don’t look back
pros: None that I can think of
cons:
They put managers in leadership roles that have no business being a manager and who have no idea how to coach or lead their respective teams. Deal reviews for big deals were a joke. They lead by intimidating you. They also have multiple reps tied to each account. This means you may have 10 or more reps calling the same account and fighting for the clients budget. The internal competition that leadership created is all too real. We had an old school manager that emphasized running multiple campaigns simultaneously that didn’t yield results instead of allowing his experienced reps to find compelling events in their territories and sell to them. 

There are far better software companies to work for that have integrity unlike Oracle’s leadership.

review_title: Bad leadership, little to no training, no growth, and spineless management
pros:
Work from home is nice.
Benefits are decent
Work life balance
cons:
No training when you start.
Management does not have your back. They rather you take the fall for issues.
My manager did not support anyone on the team. They only jumped in when anything is on the radar of senior management.
No growth at all. When employees ask for growth/promotions, management would make up endless list for the employee to achieve knowing that it was end up no where. If these tasks were met, they would give them the run around. I witness this first hand.
No pay raises at all. People have been here for years with no raises.

review_title: Oracle review
pros:
Good work-life balance.
Exposure to the latest Oracle technologies.
Working for one of the leading software companies gives good reputation to an employee.
good training ground.
a lot of pleasant people doing exciting work;
cons:
Large company prevents career growth.
Compensation is lacking.
Too much red tape on administrative process (e.g. employee hiring, promotion processing)
Difficult for new hires to adjust because of self-service environment.
Very Corporate environment.
Environment does not promote teamwork, more like everybody is out for himself.
Larry looks like a ripped off  tony stark.

review_title: Visionary technoloogy, but disjointed execution in consulting and development.
pros: Visionary technology, pay is good considering you have little life to spend it.
cons: Plug & Play of personnel.  Lack of communication or rational performance reviews, but to be expected when you have 5 managers in 3 years.  Consulting reorganizes minimum of yearly, sometimes twice a year and you have to interview for your new position (way of getting people out).  Also trying to outsource consulting to India and subcontractors, where often half or more of the project is with people that know the applications, but not the tools or methodologies.

review_title: great place to learn
pros: Working at home is not a problem.  We are effectively reviewed every minute of every day by the quality of work, as defined by our customers.  Lots to learn, if you take advantage.  Great benefits.  Salary + overtime.
cons: Raises/promotions just don't happen, ever.  Been there over 8 years, and 2 raises.  Have consistently scored quite high on reviews, and Oracle is making money hand over fist.  But they don't share the wealth with their employees.  You don't work at Oracle for the money.  And sometimes the job satisfaction lacks, as higher management treat you poorly.

review_title: Bad corporate culture - no raises
pros: Oracle has average pay and benefits. The company will allow some time off it you are really sick and need more than just a few days off.
cons: No pay raises at all, ever! No promotions unless you are in the senior managers inner circle. You can work your but off and not get recognized. I have specifically recommended that my friends not apply to work at Oracle unless they are unemployed.

review_title: Solid
pros:
- Huge company with a worldwide presence
- Great benefits
- A lot of smart people
- HQ campus exudes Silicon Valley energy
cons: My experiences working at several different groups within Oracle were night and day.  One group was composed of young and inexperienced managers, which led to an overall low group morale while the other group consisted of a seasoned group of managers that ran a tight ship.  Oracle is so big that it cannot be overridden by one culture.  Your experience will defined by your team, managers, and group culture.

review_title: Ok place to work, acquire brand name, then get out....
pros:
1. Brand Name
2. Big name clients
3. Excellent training programmes, and knowledge repositories.
4. Flexibility, work from home etc
5. Good work life balance.
cons:
1. Managers only concerned with revenue and billing
2. Minimal or no hikes, there is a sense of arrogance, that one is fortunate enuf to be working for Oracle, dont even ask for hikes.
3. No clear career development path outlined.  Promotions are random, if you are onsite, you can forget promotions for the year.
4. Due to heavy attrition, quality of employees have gone down.

review_title: Great way to enter high tech industry, long days, high expectations, but rewards if you're your own advocate
job_title: Senior Reference Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Work from home, great on resume, well known brand and reputation, great way to learn high tech enterprise software industry segment, generous sales salaries if you can meet your sales targets.
cons: Long days, very high expectations, not great about promotions and salary increases (make sure you negotiate your initial salary well because that might be it for a long time with minimal change), very good benefits

review_title: Not worth it!
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Redwood Shores, CA
pros:
Oracle is perfect
- for people who want to lead a laid back IT life
- for people interested in playing politics at work
- for old people looking forward to retirement and a steady paycheck
- when all you need in life is a high quality gym
cons:
- too much politics being played across the board
- too many old people who don't really have the drive for accomplishments anymore
- too many old people who don't know how to connect with the smarter and younger people coming in
  and feel intimidated by their presence
- a very dry and boring work environment

review_title: One of the best I ever worked
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Lots of resources, lots of opportunities to learn new technologies, endless amount of work, high chance of getting your work into product, not asked to work on narrow focus, good medical benefits
cons: hardly any raises, some of my colleagues were getting paid well below the industry average for their skill level, lots of take-overs and mergers leading to politics in upper levels of management and cause endless reorganizations. culture is very focused on business and bottom line.

review_title: Work less expect less be happy
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros:
If you dont want to work and just want to earn some constant salary (which too will not increase even if you work hard) then Oracle is the best place.
Flexible working hours.
cons:
First the bureaucracy in oracle is worse. Even some nations have better workflow and processes. 
Second, if you want to work hard and expect returns then this is not the place.
Third, If you working in oracle India, you will not get good quality work. All good work in US and bad work outsourced to Oracle India to employees with low salaries.
Less trust of management on employees.

review_title: Project Lead
pros: Great place to work - flexible work hours, good compensation, good knowledgeable colleagues who are secure enough to share knowledge, no "customer" expectations to manage if you are in product development overall a good place for technology focused  professionals.
cons: You can get boxed into your small area of focus. If you like getting really deep into a area then it is not a problem, but of you want a broader exposure then getting that can be sometimes difficult.

review_title: 10,000 pound gorilla
pros:
Good benefits - including 401k matching, health spending accounts.
Flexible work styles - part and full-time telecommuting supported (encouraged).
Involved in many types of businesses, so wide range of opportunities.
cons:
Very large company - hard to figure out how to do basic business activities like purchasing, expense reporting, hiring, getting technical support. It's never clear who can help (though you know that somebody must have that function!).
Prefers buying innovation to cultivating it in-house - and crushes the culture of the companies it buys.
Business directions subject to executive whims - some things take forever to do and others happen in a moment because somebody important notices.

review_title: Corporate Culture Lacks Professionalism
pros:
Autonomy, Benefits & Flexibility

This company enables employees to pursue their own destiny.  They spend money to develop their employees and expect results as does every Fortune 100 company.

Oracle as a brand adds value to any resume.
cons: The corporate culture here is very cut throat and distrusting.  Managers are overly protective of their responsibilities and given the frequency of regime changes, it is difficult to retain any for of consistency.  Expectations fluctuate wildly and there is much dissension inside of company ranks.

review_title: Product Strategy
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Denver, CO
pros: Networking and contacts are good. Remote work encouraged by most groups. Ability to set personal schedule due to global work force.
cons: No personal growth encouraged, no raises unless you're in sales or connected to key executives. Very poor management of integrating acquired companies - not like typical micro management of all Oracle processes, acquired companies don't get integrated and create huge cultural issues, sales don't get booked and products aren't managed by Oracle. Oracle leaves former mgmt in place - creating nightmare to get anything done.

review_title: Great learning experience, but not the right company culture for me.

pros: Great training program, the opportunity to work at a Fortune 500 company and meet an amazing network of peers and industry veterans.

review_title: A good company, but can do a lot better for the employees

pros: A relaxed working environment. Very congenial environment for people trying to settle down in a company for a long duration. There are also quite a few teams which work on cutting edge technologies.
cons: Things tend to go slow here sometimes, w.r.t both hikes and promotions. You need to fight for what you want. Not a place where you can go and do regular work and expect to get high bonuses.

review_title: Inside Sales Review
pros:
- Great people (very young atmosphere)
- Lots of tools to help enable you to sell
- Lots of product training to make sure you understand the products
cons:
- Zero collaboration between different product/pillars
- Hard to get raise
- Raises are only 3K a year if you meet the requirements
- High turnover from the top down

review_title: Mixed bag of feelings
pros:
The pros of Working at Oracle varies widely from one team to other. For the team I worked in, I would count the following as pros :
- Some really good / technical team mates ready to help whenever needed
- Good cafeteria
- Well equipped gym
cons:
The pros of Working at Oracle varies widely from one team to other. Some teams are always overloaded and some are always idle. 
- The team I worked in was always under pressure with less resources and more work. 
- QA activity is not carried out properly on time thus causing last minute glitches
- Negligible bonus , hikes not on time, poor hikes (many a years, hikes do not even happen)

review_title: Principal Technical Support Engineer
job_title: Principal Technical Support Engineer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great benefits and work life balance.
cons: It is time to share the wealth > 401k match needs to go up and raises need to happen yearly (at minimum).  Current trend of low cubicle walls > sucks.  Tall fences make for great neighbors (as the expression goes).  You won't get a raise moving (being promoted) within Oracle > policy needs to change.  You max out at 18 days of PTO a year in your 4th year.

review_title: Corporate

pros:

- slow growth in terms of salary and position.
- encourages independence in terms of searching for how to do something (eg. phone plan, check benefits, contact IT), but so many resources that it's hard to navigate. 
- detached culture, always on the road.

review_title: and so the ship has a leak
job_title: Senior Principal Support Engineer in Chicago, IL
pros: hum, well it is a job and i get paid but since it is all about $ and earnings i can't think of any pros.  The only value is $.  not the customers or employees.
cons: lots of old tech, only buys innovations now and not developing any.  US employees have to take mandatory 4 vacation days this year between Christmas and New Years and of course the company didn't increase the number of vacation days earned.

review_title: Big corporation - and it feels like it
job_title: Campaign Specialist I in Chicago, IL
pros: Stability and excellent benefits. Flexible WFH policy. Excellent co-workers and department management.
cons: Feeling like unimportant cogs in a colossal machine - not valued for your contribution, despite years of exceeding expectations and operating at a responsibility level above your position/pay. In the services department, feeling like the red-headed step-child of the company - not understood or valued.

review_title: Not all peaches and cream for cx applications
job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Burlington, MA

New comp plan for enterprise makes it hard to partner with your field rep.  Can't get paid on certain type of field deals anymore either. Not sure why we even need a field rep at this point.   Could lead to more turnover.

review_title: Regional Sales Manager
pros: Ability to move up quickly if you network and connect with the right people. Can make good money if you are lucky to have a good territory.
cons:
If you don't have a good territory, no amount of sales effort or digging is going to get you to your number. Salaries are completely inconsistent. Huge company that could care less about you, even if you are s performer. Process to
Actually sell something is ridiculous. Too many inexperienced college kids is negatively affecting the companies reputation of hiring experienced professionals.

review_title: Review
pros:
Solid signon package
Flexibility to Work from home for a number of functions, including senior mananegment
Constant change can be a plus for those that thrive in it
If you are not looking for salary increases and a long-term career then Oracle is a good fast moving company.

review_title: Own worst enemy
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Redwood City, CA
pros: Great technology and great path to the cloud. The new HR under the CEO's direction is offering free internal training and encourages career growth. Solid benefits package. Great place for over-bearing bullies.
cons: Insecure Management will not allow you to take advantage of the new HR offerings and free training. Duplication of efforts and turf wars. No Pay Hikes. Too much off-shore. Stagnation sets in. Tons of responsibility for rank and file employees and managers all with zero authority. Internal Intimidation at times. ESPP is blah. 401(k) is just ok on matching.

review_title: Oracle Digital Prime Sydney  - ODP
pros: Gym, Cafe, Parking, and Private Health Care.
cons:
Oracle Digital Prime = ODP = Get On Da Phones.

Oracle has set up a new digital prime team with 40-50 reps most of which are not from the industry. 

Oracle has hired a new senior management based in singapore who expects the team to perform like machines and not like humans. Expecting high number of calls each day without focussing on actually closing a deal.

Training is non existent for a such a big company. There are people here who have been here for many months and still don't know anything about product as there is CLOSE TO ZERO PRODUCT TRAINING.

The team is expected to generate and commit to pipeline each month and expected to hit target each month pretty much from the first month itself.

Team Leaders/Managers exerting a lot of pressure by saying that this is a start up.

FYI - Oracle is not a start up...this is a new dept in a big organisation and should ease up and understand that a new team takes time to build.

After having invested so much money in hiring people the least Oracle should do is look after their employees. 
There are already people who are looking out for jobs outside of Oracle and that seems to be pretty much the way things are going to go if things do not improve.

I wonder if the HR Recruiters and Human Resources people at Oracle actually read the reviews at Glassdoor and would actually do something to improve the situation?

At this stage I would NOT RECOMMEND joining this ODP team.

review_title: Sales Manager
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Oracle is a great place to work.  You are surrounded by smart people who like to win.  It's a competitive environment in a competitive industry.  Oracle spends millions annually on research and development which translates to being an industry leader.
cons: Layoffs and reorganization's are pretty standard here.  One growth engine is acquisition.  With that comes frequent layoffs.  Often times you will be working with a colleague and then find out they are no longer there.

review_title: stable but question interest in employee retention
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Full of smart, talented people who are passionate about what they do.  Medical benefits are good, as is the 401k matching.  In fact, 401k matching is the best I've heard of talking with friends at other companies in the industry.  Company is stable.
cons: Compensation is sub par.  Bonuses, raises and promotions seem to be rare relative to company size, across the company not just in one department, no matter how hard you work and deliver.  Company doesn't appear to promote loyalty.  I've been with the company over 20 years so I know how it was.  Appreciation of employees and an interest in retention doesn't seem to be a business priority anymore.

review_title: Good company with clear pros and cons
pros:
- Stable company with high reputation
- Collaborative culture
- Opportunity to grow internally (many people have a very long retention like 10 - 25 years at Oracle)
- Senior engineers and managers are very strong technically.
- A lot of learning opportunities, materials and training courses
cons:
- Bureaucracy and politics (Oracle has 100k+ people, so of course there are more politics than others)
- A lot of processes to go through to do anything; which slows down your innovation
- Personal responsibility is relatively small
- If you are looking for a lot of freedom and large scope of responsibilities, Oracle is not for you.

review_title: Sel service company
pros:
On a "self-service" way you can learn a lot about products, market and sales skills. really good o understand how big companies are working. 
You can consider having a "safe" position if you are not afraid to change job every 12 month. 
Good basic salary for Spain even if you have few possibility to make you target and get your full package. 
Malaga is a great place to live, you have plenty of time for your private life and money to enjoy Andalusia.
cons: All self-service, no real guideline. Everything is only process, at the end of the day you are losing the purpose of your job and get lost between processes and micro management.

review_title: B.A /LLB  4 .8 years of experience in Legal industry
pros: Besides having challenging and interesting job there are lot more to do in this company .Oracle you will be part of a driven and professional organisation striving to become the best. Everyone knows that innovation is invaluable in an IT company, so you are encouraged to think outside of the box and come up with ideas in or outside your line of business.Also gives you a flexibility to work from home
cons: With such a large company, it is challenging to connect with the right people when there is a question outside of my area of expertise.

review_title: Business Development Representative
job_title: Business Development Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
-Pay is decent 
-They hire well 
-Halfway decent product
cons:
-They fire consistently, the most cuthroat company i've worked for in my 10 years of sales. 
-They hire you saying there is an 80% of promotion to the Account Executive role. I did the math, its more like 80% of the 9 BDRS (out of 120 BDR applicants) ACCEPTED the job, not were offered. 
-Kissing up works here 
-Least organized management in America

review_title: Dead end for customer support roles.
job_title: Senior Technical Support Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
Good benifits and decent starting pay.
People are nice too. Senior technical support engineers are willing to help.
cons: No raises, no incentive to work hard. If you enter in customer service (even as a "technical support engineer") they want you to stay there. My boss did not care about my professional development and told me that is in my own hands. For me that means applying to outside jobs the standard way and the internal oracle jobsite that posts the same jobs as it does for outsiders. So basically growth opportunities are very scarce.

review_title: Deal Specialist
pros: Work environment is great and the people you work with are awesome. It is nice to know that the management cares about their employees as people, not just cogs.
cons:
Raises are hard to come by here. 
Also, this center is like the ugly stepchild compared to the brand new Austin campus. Some people have been here for over a year and 1/2 and still do not have a pass to park in the garage. The shuttle is about 2 miles away and takes a serious chunk into the commute to and from work. SA needs a new building!

review_title: Good work/life balance
pros:
If work/life balance is as important to you as it is to me, then I highly recommend working for this company. There is a clear understanding that people have lives outside of work and you aren't chastised for it. 

The people who I work with are fantastic!
cons:
It's difficult to get a salary increase. This is something I wish I had known during my interviewing process, and something that I recommend keeping in mind when negotiating salary. 

Not a lot of room for growth. I moved to Oracle from a smaller company thinking that I would have move potential for growth at a larger company. Unfortunately, after being here for some time I am finding out that is not the case.

review_title: Environment does not promote teamwork, more like everybody is out for himself.
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros: Nice gym with free aerobics classes. Flexible work hours, though you usu end up putting in a lot more than 40 hours because of ambitious deadlines. Can telecommute (Oracle picks up the tab for ISP).
cons: Not easy to find out who is responsible for what. Documents are not easy to locate and search. Not easy to get hardware upgrade. (My desktop at work is more than 5 years old, with only 80 Gb disk space, DVD-Rom - not RW - drive, clunky CRT monitor). No free lunch.

review_title: A Great place to start a career
pros: flexibility, people, benefits, knowledge, working in a large organization affords one the opportunity to develop multi-tasking abilities as well as understanding and working withing internal processes
cons: poor communication between groups, lots of internal struggles, massive and extremely involved processes, multiple levels of bureaucy

review_title: The database division is a good place for developers.

Oracle is huge. While this can be challenging at times, it's important to think outside of the box. 
This is a great place to learn about software and business. 
Stable.
Management is playing with a full deck.
Great name.
cons:
Political-It's like going back to college, or high-school in some cases-You better make friends fast !

review_title: not a bad early job
pros: it has good cafes and the work is relatively challenging.   the groups are somewhat self-autonomous so you can do a bunch of things as long as you have the resources to go after there.  but nothing can be that big or else it will hit the purview of senior management and then the whole process will slow down or come to a complete standstill.

review_title: Its' alright... I guess

cons:
- very little pay increases, and a complete disregard for raises even after good performance years
- a very minimal bonus plan
- management from my personal experience has been incompetent with regards to my area and usually takes 2 or 3 tries to get something through or completed.

review_title: Oracle place to work if you want to lead a stable life
pros: Oracle is place where you can work for life time. They usually don't force employees to work after office hours. So we have high flexibility and very good personal life.
cons: As it's a global company growth is very very slow. Now a days they are paying very less at least in india. After few years you will realize that your bank account is not doing good. So it's up to individual that they want money or good personal life.

review_title: A good solid company
pros: Oracle is a solid company with very good finances and a strong business in the enterprise software arena. It provides a secure environment to work, without too much turmoil.
cons: It is a big company and as such you can expect the usual downsides to working on a large company. It is not as agile as a startup and there are many process that have been put in place over the years to make sure bad things do not happen.

review_title: Valuable but inadequately compensated
pros: The company offers decent work/life balance and flexibility, there are a plethora of resources available within the company network, business processes are mature and it employs some very bright people.
cons: One size fits all mentality by management on occasion, too much control over budget at higher levels of management, lack of recognition that management is a discipline, science and full time job and not to be viewed as something *extra* that someone who is basically a techie should do...

review_title: Good company, but come in with expectations set
pros: Solid company, successful business, great products, top talent in most teams, global culture, good infrastructure, great access to training, good individualistic culture (you can thrive being yourself).
cons:
Salary and career growth are almost stagnant compared to the business growth.
Politics get in the way of very good projects that would make positive impact.
Hiring is so hard to do that you hold on to low performing people instead of changing them for top talent.

review_title: Poor Management, Low Pay, no HR support.
pros: Flexible work environement, free coffee, free fitness centers if you have time to use them. Free smelly air from Indians that don't wash.
cons: While senior staff line their pockets, employees that are expexted to work 12+ hours a day are rewarded with either no pay increases or if you are lucky 2%.. Management pockets millions in bonuses, while Directors and below are left begging. Staff is hired and/or promoted based on friendships, not qualifications. Thousands of jobs have been moved to other countries, and H1B staff moved in to replace US workers. Company discriminates against White Americans unless they need them to sell product, then they revolve in and out faster they the weather. If you file an ethics complaint, it is casually swept under the carpet.

review_title: Draining Place To Work
job_title: Sales Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Decent salary + commission. Good health benefits. Lots of sharp people. Time off and work like balance is good. Oracle name carries a lot of weight and can open doors when leaving Oracle.
cons: No training or onboarding process for new reps. Leadership is poor and essentially absent. Company culture is demoralizing. Zero ethics in the sales orgs. Technology tools are humorously outdated and inefficient. Maybe compensation issues in the sales org, constantly finding ways to not pay reps and managers.

review_title: A Machine Optimized at the lowest common denominator
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great benefits! Some of the best benefits I have had from a company (health, insurance) and decent pay for mid-level professionals.
cons: Varies by BU and department, but generally the culture is such that 25% of your time is spent on non-productive issues (getting a PO takes 3-6 weeks, HR req for new headcount, etc.) I look around and most people are gone by 3pm everyday and noon on Fridays. 80% of the work is accomplished by 20% of the people...the other 80% are the ones that leave at 3pm everyday. In short, if you want a job, this is a good opportunity. However, if you want a stimulating career, you should look elsewhere.

review_title: Oracle Social: Slowly Evolving Worksplace
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Work/life balance is excellent, and I truly have the freedoms I haven never had within alternate companies. Pay & benefits are excellent.
cons: My former company was acquired by Oracle in their development of cloud services. It took about a year for Oracle to really deliver any direction; In most cases, employees were left in the dark. In addition, sales nearly halted in transition, which caused a lot of valued employees to quit. The office dynamic changed drastically, and the start-up spirit had basically been killed.

review_title: A very good company to start with. I have been working here for more than 3 years. Projects are nice and up to the mark
pros:
1- Good work life balance.
2- Some teams got good project and some not.
3- No hidden cut in salary. Most of it are in hand.
4- Flexibility in work.
5- less politics.
cons:
1- Management strategy is not good. They say, they don't know about any decision taken by the company.
2- Hiring policy is very bad, No transparency at all. A mechanical guy who doesn't know about java is doing development and a computer science topper is in support.
3- Retention policy is not good.
4- salary is a concern.

review_title: Be careful which org you join, but can be great if you join the right ones
pros: If you are part of the right department, you can have a good experience at Oracle. Many departments allow people to work remotely. Good benefits, namely leaves of absence.
cons: I was unlucky and got acquired into a department that had a lot of micromanaging and lots of politics. Upper management is also constantly watching over your shoulder. Very political and hierarchical. They do not want us to work remotely at all, even if you have a doctor's appointment. If you are sick, management is asking for doctor's notes.

review_title: I am working for Oracle On demand, new name is Oracle Managed cloud services. Same people - Mean managment
pros:
I am sure other departments are good as all benefits look great, but our department managment makes it sound like they don't have any budget and will pay you peanuts for work of gold. 
You can work from home. good trainings from Oracle. access to self study trainings.
cons: On demand (OMCS) is worst. I am sure Oracle itself will be good. Worst salary of my career..i finally agreed with the stingy manager as if he would pay from pocket, because of green card processing in EB2 category which didn't happened.  You would support 1000's environments in hosting services without any reward or recognition....
